description:
If I had a nickel for every time I've visited Golden Gate Park.... I'd have a dime. Which is rather a shame. And I don't mean because coins are virtually useless, only good for chucking at pantomimes, but because this park is awesome!! My infrequent trips to San Francisco have been brief vacations, because even with how fast I drive, San Francisco is not a convenient weekend getaway! It's a good 5 hour drive, minimum. Sure, when I was young, no kid, no wife.... Hell, I used to make it from LA to Seattle in 18 hours. But, once again: young, no kid, no wife. But wives need to eat. Kids need to poop. Both get all grumpy otherwise. Wives and kids don't understand about "making good time!" It's all moot now anyway.... I'm old. No way I drive 1,200 miles in 18 hours again! Maybe I should get back to the review.....

You could easily spend an entire day at Golden Gate Park. Possibly two! There's just that much to do. To me, it's reminiscent of San Diego's Balboa Park, in that it's a huge, sprawling oasis of activities and attractions. LA has much the same features, but they're all spread out individually over a wide expanse, and getting from one to the next takes an hour in traffic. So, it's nice to have everything condensed, like GGP or Balboa Park.

There's a variety of gardens and picturesque spots to wander around. There's a variety of museums to explore. There's a variety of sporting activities you can partake in. And if you're into people watching (which is rather voyeuristic, and therefore you should be imprisoned, you pervert!) there's a variety of people to watch. There's a little something for everyone in a more relaxed atmosphere, away from the hustle and bustle and assorted commotion of the City by the Bay, whoa-oa-oa.
author: Michael H.

description:
This low review is more for the surrounding area and the crappy police. The park itself is beautiful and this time we went to the Japanese Tea Garden which we loved, it's not too big so we went about an hour.

BEWARE: Do NOT park on Martin Luther King Jr. Dr.. We had our car broken into; the back window was smashed open and my backpack was stolen. Nothing was visible from the exterior of the car but I think they knew they could reach through to the trunk from the back window. We saw several other cars with back and side windows smashed in. We called the police and they wouldn't send anyone out; instead we had to do the police report over the phone and it sounds like they out source that. I spoke to a local walking with his baby, he says its been happening for the last few years now due to the increase in homeless and just overall crime. If you go to the park please park somewhere else that has more traffic although Martin Luther King Jr. Dr. seemed to be a high traffic street to us. I'm just going to avoid the park all together until they do something about the crime but I think overall the crime has increased in San Francisco. A local we saw at a gas station said his car was broken into near his work too.

I just hope this review helps someone avoid the terrible time we went through.
author: H. K.

description:
So I knew nothing about this place coming here and not doing the prior research it my fault.  However, in Google Maps when you click on "Golden Gate Park" it gives you pictures of Stow Lake Boathouse which is one place in the park.  So if you're not a resident of SF you think it looks like this mostly everywhere, kinda like Central Park in New York.  It's not, not even close.

We took an Uber to Golden Gate Park, almost perfectly in the center of the park and well, it's a forest.

It was pleasant and peaceful, but not like the photos, of Stow Lake Boathouse.  It's just a park.
author: Jim P.

description:
A huge park that's only good for locals hanging out like exercise, picnic, laying on the grass, painting and such in my opinion. For tourists it's just too big to walk between places on weekdays, they do offer shuttle rides on weekends and major holidays though. 

We came here on a Monday so there was no shuttles at all, and the De Young museum was closed too. We weren't interested in the science museum so we just walked around a bit. The rose garden was so small with no blooming roses, and we were just too tired to walk more. Some fountains were dry so they weren't too pretty to look at. So basically coming here was a complete waste of time for me, I should've just gone back to hotel to take a nap! At least sister enjoyed it and took many photos. 

I don't recommend this park for tourists, it's huge and it will take too many hours to tour the good places like Japanese tea garden, windmills, tulip, rose gardens, the lake and some more. It's not worth it to spend that much time here in my opinion!

But if you have enough time, by all means come here to spend half day or even a whole day to enjoy this beautiful park!
author: Mimi L.

description:
Easily one of my favorite spots to visit in San Francisco! The park itself is not the smallest park, so a heads up on that note. As for parking, expect the typical SF madness, but the museums offer underground parking at a decent hourly rate (My recommendation). 

As mentioned before, expect a full day here if you have the time as this park is easily walkable, but has many attractions to explore. My favorites are easily the de young museum and the main flora (and various fauna) that is well maintained throughout the park. Other attractions include the famous California Science Academy, Japanese tea garden, aquarium, botanica, etc. You can totally picnic here, so I'd suggest a nice and sunny day so you can really take in the people watching or nature views. With that said, there are also other food options nearby outside the park that are pretty phenomenal, so it really depends on what you want to do. 

With all of that said, easily a must stop if you are looking at this from a tourist perspective.
author: Ryan A.

description: This is a large beautiful park.  We were welcomed by three adorable raccoons running out in front of our rental car.  Thankfully the Mr. has good reflexes.  A welcoming retreat from the loud city life.  Walking thru, you are transported to a calm, inner zen like feeling.  You will find, as in most parks, joggers, runners, dog walkers, cyclists, and everything in between.  Everyone is happy, and calm and seemingly at perfect ease.  On the day we went we got to see the heavy morning San Francisco fog, and on our return walk the clearing of the fog that had previously enveloped the park.  It was quit magical.
author: Victoria C.

description:
I guess being a tourist most people would flock here thinking it's the best place to enjoy the Golden Gate Bridge! But that is quite the opposite, while this place is nice, there are other spots you can enjoy the bridge with just as equally if not better views. 

They have decent parking here, which is nice.
author: Krystine S.

description:
Just walking here is a zen experience. There are several museums including the fab de Young with increíble collections. The grounds include the gardens, horse trains, bike paths, monuments, rec areas and tons of history.
The city is pretty barren of trees so they really celebrate their parks and this is a gem
author: Daniella S.

description:
ESCAPE INTO THIS PARK AND EXPLORE ITS MANY POCKETS
[Warning: Young adults from Central Florida in for vacation] As someone who prefers the calm of nature, this was a great escape from the bustle of the city. There were many places to hide away from crowds even though there's many attractions scattered throughout this park to attract them. We actually rented a bike and traveled as much as we could from east to west. There were many sidewalks to share with walkers, but most of the time we cycled on the road and felt relatively safe due to the slow speed limits.

SOME THINGS WE SAW
Half the areas inside the park require an admission price such as the Science Museum and Japanese Tea Garden while others were easy to just enter and view such as the bison enclosure, the Dutch windmill, many playing fields and playgrounds. 

RESOURCES FOR A VISITOR
There's a few areas to grab a snack or drink, but not open as late as some attractions. With many trails and relatively calm roads, you'll run into many joggers and cyclists. We were also content at the pretty good bathrooms, plus it seems the homeless, mentally ill squatters of the city haven't really affected the park.
author: Pyra-Danny S.

description: Great place to work out! Beautiful, fresh, close to shops and restaurants, I fully recommend a morning run with a friend!
author: Jess B.

description:
This beautiful and breath taking park is more than 3 miles in length and will most likely take 5-6 hrs to pace through just the majority of it, especially if you find yourself caught up inside museums.

Parking was fairly easy for us on a Monday morning. We parked along Nancy Pelosi Dr.  (Free Street Parking) 

We decided to explore the Japanese Tea Garden. I'm not sure where folks are getting their $3-8 dollar entrance from, let alone free entry on Mondays, but when we went on a Monday (3/26/18), it was $9 per person at 10:30 am. Just thought I'd note that.

It was very pretty, filled with Japanese influenced architecture, artifacts, and plants indigenous to (or at the very least associated with) Japan. Cherry blossoms, bonsai-looking trees, koi fish etc.

We also ventured over to the Rose garden (Free) next door and found nothing to be in bloom unfortunately. 

We then took a stroll to Stow Lake where we saw some herons, ducks, and turtles in the lake.

We revisited the park later on in the day around 6 pm to watch the sunset by Ocean beach, by the Dutch Windmill and Tulip garden (also free) and was blessed with ample parking and a gorgeous view.

We also did a quick drive to Bison Paddock but they were hiding in the back. :( Overall a great experience and I'd come back to do the remaining half of the park!
author: Christine H.

description:
Perhaps it was the glorious day -- not a cloud in the sky and just short of 70 degrees.  Or maybe the company of my son -- the newly "local"
boy -- showing us tourists around.  Or possibly the eclectic crowds making for plenty to see and sop up.

Or maybe -- this is just a truly grand park -- in a famously picturesque port city -- every bit as intriguing and satisfying a walkabout as Central Park is in NYC. 

Whatever the answer -- it is a huge undertaking to get even a smidge of GGP under your belt in one gulp.  We took some small doses and I'm hooked. 

Never bothered to visit here in all my prior visits during years past and I can't understand why.  It is one of those organic SF places around which the City grew during its boom time in the mid-19th century -- and grows still.

I will miss the park and that day.
author: Yuri Y.

description:
Consider this a weekend review of Golden Gate Park. I came here with a buddy to go for a run this past Saturday. We parked close to the entrance by Lincoln and 19th Ave so that we would be close to all the delicious food post run.

It was an unusually warm day for the time of year which meant the various areas were bustling with people. We spent over an hour and a half covering the many areas including Stow Lake, the waterfall, the archery area (so cool, must try), the Botanical Garden and the cute buffalo (tatonka!) 

After our run we walked across Lincoln and refueled with Vietnamese food.

Pros: So many things to do at the park, people are friendly and the buffalo!

Cons: None.

Bottom line: Yet another reason we are luck living in the Yay Area :)
author: James M.

description:
The park is so big it requires more than one review. My first will be of the southwestern area of the park. I'll start by saying that I'm not sure if parking is allowed along the main roads anymore. Upon entering from Sunset Avenue, I saw a sight that read "No Parking 10:00 am to 6:00 pm everyday". I don't know how old that sign is, but I believe it is not that old. I got there before 10:00 am, but didn't wanted to get cited and parked Lincoln Avenue.

Having grown up in S.F, I took for granted how lucky I was to have such a huge park in the city. It was only recently that I've been looking at it with a (amateur) photographer's eye. It is truly magnificent and on sunny mornings I am reminded why it is so special. Writing about it simply does not do it justice, so I took a few pics.

There is something so wonderful about being there in the morning. The only folks around are joggers and people walking their dogs. With sun peeking between the trees and a few birds singing, it feels like you're a thousand miles away from the city. At that time of the morning it is pretty quiet and very, very peaceful. The light is fantastic and creates dramatic shadows. If you're lucky, there might be some fog that has started to dissipated in sun.

This past Sunday I was there with my commuter mug of coffee and my camera and I simply wanted to stop time. I've driven along Martin Luther King Jr. Drive and noted how beautiful the light is at that time and promised myself I would stop one day and shoot what I see. The area in particular is Mallard Lake and Elk Grove Lake. This is a must-see for Bay Area natives or out-of-towners alike. Anytime is great, but early mornings are exceptional.
author: Rich H.

description: The park is vast and beautiful.  Get a map as it's easy to get lost if you're not familiar with the park.  Park loses a star for their shuttle service.  The vans are empty for a good reason- the drivers do not have a clue of where they are going, drive less than five miles/hour, and stop to chat with friends.  Laughable service!
author: Susie B.

description:
I wish someone could build a park like this and place it in Arizona. We could use a spacious and magical park like this. Perfect spot to run wild and free everyday.  Wear the right pair of running shoes. Make the beach your reward run.  You'll run a path and pass the Conservatory of Flowers, flower garden, the botanical gardens, Japanese tea garden, a couple great museums, a couple lakes, the waterfall, the bisons!, the Dutch windmill, and finally the Ocean beach. 

Check it off of your to-do list and you can really complete it all in one weekend!  Seems like a lot of events make history at this park! 

Make it a picnic kind of day or cat nap it on the grass. Practice or photograph like a pro with this pretty canvas. Plenty of room to skip, hop, and cart wheel it up! And frisbee golf! 

Golden for sure!
author: Regina W.

description:
Super cool on a nice sunny day. Pack a light lunch and enjoy the surroundings.

This is the place to hang out and enjoy the day. Many trails that will peek your interest. Lots of people watching as you walk for miles. 

Everyone is out and about and living like you should. Prepare for all the fun and excitement.
author: Jimmie M.

description:
One of the best parks in the world! Nothing to add here except that no matter what time of year, weather will be pretty much overcast and 60s. Also usually it'll be pretty busy! But that doesn't take away from how huge and awesome this place is.

Great for runs!
author: Sunny K.

description:
Golden Gate Park is huge and you likely won't see it all in one day.
It is a beautiful departure from the City. The grass is green and trees are everywhere. You can take a lunch or visit one of the museums that is located there.
The Japanese Garden is so beautiful, I would go there first, especially if your time is limited. It is so peaceful. Just take a seat and breath. It is amazing.
There are all types of people there, from tourists, locals, homeless, runners etc. All our friendly and the park is very safe.
If you have a minute stop at the park. It really is very special.
author: Elizabeth L.

description: This place is so beautiful, so many things to do and see , the children's park is fabulous great for family outings and picnics or a jog/walk
author: Oralia R.

description:
Best park in the world? Better than Central Park?

Going to Golden Gate Park is a day on its own. There's so much to see and do. From running, biking or walking, there's tennis courts, a golf course, tracks, (dirty) pools and many ponds and forests. There's also random buskers and dance areas. Not to mention the Botanical Garden, California Academy of Sciences, de Young art gallery and Japanese Tea Garden.

The grass is so green and everything is well maintained. The east/central part is where all the tourists are, but there aren't many people on the west part. It's a huge park to cover, with a windmill and Ocean Beach at the end to cap off the long walk and amazing views.
author: Vincent H.

description: Beautiful and easy hiking trail. Very friendly wildlife (pls. don't feed them tho, no matter how cute they are). Also an easy walk right to the beach.
author: Seth S.

description:
I've have been going to this park since i was young, but have never wrote a review for this park. Big park so there are many things you can do here. Great place for a run, walk, picnic, or bbq. They also have disc golf course that are about 18 sections. There're also places like japanese tea garden,  botanical garden, academy of science museum,  de young museum, and few other places  thats close by that you can also check out if you're an explorers. Depends on what you like to do, theres always something for you can do. 

Parking can be tough especially on a nice sunny day and weekends.

Definitely a place you should check out
author: Julie N.

description:
Golden Gate Park is a world class park in a world class city. Very much needed green space for a hyper congested city that is 7 miles wide & 7 miles long. 

It is capacious, inviting, verdant with the over century old, venerable Hagiwara Japanese Garden; museums such  the de Young, California Academy of Sciences; Music Concourse, an outdoor stage; Conservatory of Flowers; Botanical Garden; golf course; stadium; polo field; Equestrian Center; Boat House to rent boats on Stow Lake; Bunny Meadow; Bison Paddock, Rhododendron Garden which is in full bloom in April, etc. 

There are lakes & ponds, trails throughout this spacious park. For tourists & city dweller alike, this is a great place to unwind to get away from the sensory overload of being in the city.

PS  The MUNI bus system is a great way to get here so leave the car behind to avoid the hassle of finding the rare San Francisco parking space. Now an endangered species.
author: Gary I.

description:
Trying to get from Richmond to the 16th Avenue Tiled Steps?  Why take an Uber when you have the opportunity to wander through the lovely Golden Gate Park?

Between the flowers and architectural gems we couldn't have asked for a better morning stroll.  At over 1000 acres we saw a small fraction of sites within the park but its definitely somewhere I'd visit again and again.
author: Alyssa R.

description:
In town or live here and need something to do.  WELL COME HERE!

This park is GI-NORMOUS!  We were meeting up with a friend here and took Uber so we could make it on time.  Walking the streets/hills of SF is GREAT but it can certainly put you behind if you not used to some of those steep hills, which was what happened to us.  So we called for an Uber.

We did carpool and according to my app we were not too far away like 1.4 miles.  When we arrive I was going to hop out but the Uber driver said wait we are not there yet and told us how LARGE the park was.  There is a little something for everyone here.

Like concerts in the park this is your place.  Apparently they have various artist at times.  I'm guessing there is some sort of calendar for this but not sure.  There are also fields for sports, a Japanese garden, a Botanical garden I believe you have to pay to get in all the gardens.  Probably for the upkeep.  There is also an outdoor theater, SEVERAL walking and running paths, areas for picnics, and some buildings I believe have events in them.  HUGE LAKE where you can rent boat, golf course, dog areas, California Academy of Sciences, a marina, etc.  It has just about EVERYTHING!  There is over 1000 acres and every inch has something going on.  

You could honestly spend an entire week here just exploring the different thing.  This is probably ZZ-BEST GREEN space in SF.  At least to me.  And it makes for an AWESOME meet up location.  But if you're going to meet up then be sure to give the co-meeters the exact address of where you will be.  Like an actual building or area such as Japanese garden.  They all have their own address.   

There is also underground parking and parking along the interior roads that is FREE but it goes quick.  Other areas for Uber to pull over or for drop off.  

If you have a chance just go peruse the walking paths that are FREE.  It really AWESOME!
author: Ryan P.

description:
There's nothing I can really say that hasn't been already said. This place rocks. There's no end to the amount of things you can do, and it's always filled with people exercising, having fun, and living life.

My personal favorite place is Lily Pond, which is literally right off of JFK Drive where everybody runs. Even though it's so close to where everyone is, it's kind of like its own escape into nature. It's just so lush and peaceful there, and the pond always reflects the light so well. If you go there when it's foggy out (which is my favorite time to go), I'd kind of liken it to being in like the rainforest exhibit in a zoo. 

My only gripe about the park is it's more crowded than you would expect, especially if you're around the Conservatory of Flowers on the weekend. For such a big park, you'd think people would spread out, but there are just too many people. And people love walking without purpose, so it's sometimes hard to just cut through the park if you're actually trying to get somewhere quickly. But I realize that I hate slow walkers more than most people, and this is a pervasive problem throughout the city, not just here.

Just a warning to people not from here: this place is not immune from the classic SF charm. That is, people still break into cars here and curse you out should you not stop for them at an intersection. And no one will bat an eye because that is just how things work here. Welcome to San Francisco.
author: Eric Y.

description:
Lots to do here.  Japanese tea garden, aquarium, planetarium, penguin habitat.  There was a small cafe inside to grab a bite.   I was very happy to see the healthy offerings, fresh avocados, salads etc.   

Huge success for a rain-out day that we had planned biking across Golden Gate Bridge.  Great rainy-day alternative
author: Sabrina M.

description:
Golden Gate Park is as iconic to San Francisco as Coit Tower, Chinatown, Ghirardelli Chocolates, Sourdough Bread, & the Golden Gate Bridge. In fact, if you're visiting San Francisco for the first time you might even be in the great park without even knowing. It's that fabulous!  

Golden Gate Park is overseen by the San Francisco Recreation & Parks Department, which has seen the development since 1871. The park is shaped like a rectangle, it is similar in shape but 20 percent larger than Central Park in New York, to which it is often compared. It is over three miles long east to west, and about half a mile north to south. 13 million people visit this great park annually. Tho in the Summer of '69 their was perhaps half our hippy nation here spreading peace & love with the Grateful Dead & psychedelic poet Timothy Leary. 

Today, it's a park for all to enjoy. Popular attractions include: The Conservatory of Flowers (est. 1879), the "twin" Dutch windmills (est. 1903), The Ornate Carousel (est. 1914), Stow Lake & Falls (1890's), Bison Paddock (est. 1891), California Academy of Sciences (est. 1853), De Young Museum (est. 1893), Japanese Tea Garden & Tea House (est. 1894), Garden of Shakespeare's Flowers (est. 1928), and the Children's Playground (est. 1888) where the Carousel can be found too. 

"If you're going to San Francisco
Be sure to wear some flowers in your hair
If you're going to San Francisco
You're gonna meet some gentle people there...
If you come to San Francisco
Summertime will be a love-in there..."

Well almost. Just avoid the few aggressive homeless peeps and buffalo turd and you'll do 'a'right! 

I have strolled, jogged, jiggled, and scootered through Golden Gate Park a zillion times. Picnicked, rowed a boat, slept on a park bench, talked to a RL hippy all at this fantastic park in one of the busiest cities in the world! I highly recommend visiting this park... Wait. I mean if visiting San Francisco... it's mandatory you do so! Oh, and did I mention about the resident ghost? She lives near Stow Lake (read my review there too)...
author: Eric R.

description:
This park is huge! 
The park has lost of open room and things to see throught out. Be warned the parking garage is a total ripoff!! I ended up spending $33 for parking.

In the morning hours independent artists setup their work and try to sell it publicly. Some were out there making new art on the spot. People were doing yoga in the main park. I'm not sure if there is live music everyday but when I was in the main area an orchestra was playing. 

In this park are multiple buildings and activities. The California Academy of Science is here, a Japanese tea garden, San Francisco botanical garden, art gallery, wind Mills and much more.

Many lakes to see as you walk the park. It might be best to get a bike or segway tour if you want to see the entire park in a short time.
author: Mike D.

description:
Really beautiful large urban park that takes you all the way to the SF coast, just south of Land's end. Many beautiful places to visit and a lot of open roads for cycling. 

Re: car break-ins. I saw a slew of reviews blocked by Yelp commenting on car break ins. I personally didn't have a problem since I always bike or walk to the park and never leave my car here. 

However, I did, not infrequently, spot people checking inside all the parked cars through the windows. I also saw broken glasses along the road/bike trail which is next to the parked vehicles on the streets. Since there are not enough police to patrol the entire park at the same time, bring your vehicles (especially rental, out of state) at your own risk and hide/bring your belongings.
author: Tony F.

description: Wow! What a park. Soccer, polo and baseball fields. Also, a nice soccer stadium, picnic fields and beautiful green pastures. Lots to do in the family-friendly clean park.
author: Juan M.

description: Golden Gate Park is a great park to take a walk and hang out anytime of the year. Don't leave San Francisco without taking a walk in Golden Gate Park at least once.
author: Leo T.

description:
In San Francisco this is a nice nature spot to visit where you can get away from the hustle and bustle of the city. The park itself has several smaller parks such as the Japanese Tea Garden, Botanical gardens and others where you can walk the grounds for a small fee. You can walk the Concourse area for free. There you will find several fountains, sculptures, gardens and other art and historical landmarks all within walking distance. A parking garage is available at $5 per hour as well as street parking (but it goes fast). Tours are also available (for a fee). 

We walked the Concourse area and visited the Japanese Tea Garden. I would've liked to have  visited the other areas if we had more time. This is a great spot to explore by yourself, with a friend or even with the whole family.
author: Lael M.

description: Awesome Park located in the heart of San Francisco close to the Golden Gate Bridge. I love going here my wife and I walked around and visited this place and they had great big trees everywhere clean smelling air lot of Runners going to the Parkville save felt nice very pretty flowers everywhere they even had a little obstacle course that shows you how to stretch and things it was awesome definitely highly recommend this
author: Jeremy J.

description: Beautiful park.  You can spend the whole day. And great history.   Would love to just run around this park all day.
author: Celeste G.

description: This place was beautiful, and huge. I spent a while here and I feel like I didn't even scratch the surface. I mostly spent my time in Robin Williams Feild reading, but I also strolled around for a while to take on the beautiful landscape. I definitely have to come back to see what else this wonderful place had to offer
author: John M.

description:
It happens at the end of every year--I tend to look back on my favorite memories from the year. This year was a doozy of a year, with some incredible moments. Probably some of my best. And although the year isn't over yet, I know for sure that my favorite moment from 2017 was a picnic.

Picnics are incredible experiences. You take the best of the indoors (food, duh) and bring it to the outdoors. Everything tastes better. Everything is more beautiful, more vibrant, and even the simple ingredients are elevated. Cheese. Bread. Mustard. Salami. Grapes. These are the staples of a good picnic.

I did not picnic at Golden Gate park, but while driving through recently I was reminded of how badly I still want to. It's been months and months since I had a picnic--since that favorite time of the year--and I really wish I was still picnicking across the country. Is that a job? Is that a life? Can we just do that? Picnic across the country and make every day a favorite memory?

Golden Gate Park is the perfect picnic spot. It's got huge bits of lawn, walking trails, massive trees, but it's also extremely accessible from all sides, so you can grab a sammich at a local spot and get there quick. Blue skies, foggy skies, I don't even care (though you'll have more crowds on a bright beautiful sunny day) I just want to have that picnic life.

I've spent some time in the park before, but usually it was with friends who wanted to go disc golfing. It's my favorite DG course in the world, and you should definitely put it on your wish list. 

If you're not lucky enough to have a picnic partner who's into the life, or disco golf buddies, you can use the park for plenty of other things: walks, runs, people watching, botanical gardens, a tea garden, the windmill, the De Young Museum, flower conservatory, playgrounds, arboretum, a carousel, an aquarium, and really, so much more. I want to picnic here and explore it all, please.
author: Jeffrey S.

description:
Beautiful!!!!  Take the time to truly explore this park to discover amazing trees, waterfalls and other little gems that you would miss by just hitting the highlights. 

Be careful as t is easy to get turned around in this park as it is rather large. Had the pleasure of running a half marathon through the park and it made seven miles fly by with ease due to the beauty of it all. Oh and there are bison...come on a park with bison!!!!!  How is this not a must explore?
author: Brigid D.

description: My son had a blast here. Not only is it a beautiful place to walk around with all the beautiful trees, flowers, etc but there is a huge children's park and a carousel that is only $1 for the little ones. There was so much more that we could've done (botanical gardens, museum, aquarium) but it was a nice day to just be outside.
author: Barbara N.

description: Stunning, gorgeous, splendid! The grassy verdant meadows beckon one to run across them. The towering trees provide shady seclusion. The sparkling blue lakes are havens for quacking ducks and hissing geese - particularly endering are the charmingly ugly moscove ducks.
author: Bill M.

description: Huge park in the middle of San Francisco that goes on for ever.  I know we won't be able to see it all but what we have seen is great.  We went up in the deyoung museum tower and around the academy of art.  Hung out with a guy making huge bubbles, went to play on the sweet playground.  You could spend days exploring this park.
author: Zen D.

description: I loved it here! There's so much to do so make sure set apart a few hours to spend here. We rented bikes for an hour ($14/person) and were able to get through half the park because it's huge! To be fair, we were newbies and did not know where we were going. It was also a bit scary as some areas are very uphill and don't have a bike lane so watch out for the cars! Regardless, it was an awesome experience. Definitely pay the Japanese tea garden (there's a small admission fee for this) and the lovely rose garden (free) a visit. It was pretty crowded, but still very serene and relaxing. I wish I lived in the area because I'd jog/bike here everyday---everything about it was really enjoyable.
author: Maysa M.

description:
Can't believe I haven't written a review for Golden Gate Park.  I've been here at least a dozen times, and every single time I find a new area to explore.  This is a huge park for something that's in the heart of a major metropolis.  We hiked the entire park one day and it honestly took a chunk of our day away. 

This place is beautiful and offers so much. From museums, to a flower house, to nature trying its best to stay alive within a city.  It's a great place to relax and just take everything in.  SF may have its problems, but this park really helps it keep a bit of its personality. 

Come and spend a day here.  You honestly won't regret it, and I hope to be able to come here for years to come.
author: Benny H.

description: If you have a few days in SF, save one day just for this park. It is huge and beautiful with so much to do. On other trips I have been to the Academy of Sciences and the Japanese garden, and those were both enjoyable. Today we were on our way out of town and just wanted to walk or dog. We walked through the AIDS Memorial Grove, which is beautiful and peaceful, then psst the tennis courts to a large open area where the San Francisco Opera was giving a free performance. So much beauty in about an hour. I wish we had more time.
author: Melanie I.

description: Views were out-of-this-world and a perfect place to go on a bike ride. Even some good people watching, very dog friendly and if you're a dog lover, maybe you'll get lucky enough to see the dog-walking squad. Only problem is if you're taking an Uber there, pick a specific place to go otherwise you may get dropped off in the middle of nowhere, much like I did. So make sure you pick a spot to go and don't just say take me to Golden Gate Park! Super peaceful out there and I think it's safe to say there is something there for everyone.
author: Cara H.

description:
I hope San Francisco residents recognize how lucky they are to have such a huge span of beautiful park land right in the middle of the city. It's a lovey place to walk around, boats several museums and attractions and if you're not planning on staying all day has a decent amount of free parking. 

We walked along the whole length of the park just taking in the scenery. You'll see some parts of the park are much more populated then others. There is garage parking under the science and art museum if you're planning on spending the day at the park but get there early as it fills up. 

The one major downside of the park is that it can free like an amusement park with ever attraction costing $10-40 per person to participate. The park is free but the cool attractions are most definitely not.
author: Marie B.

description:
Runners POV: This is one of my favorite places to run in the city. I constantly have to look out for cars, traffic lights, and congested traffic along most of my routes, but when I end up in Golden Gate Park, it's like a paradise.

I run in the evenings, and the park is well-lit to accommodate runners throughout the main stretches. There's a few blind spots, but there's always light from cars to lighten the path. 

Recommend everyone take a run, or even a light walk, through the park (night or day).
author: Nicholas G.

description:
This place is absolutely wonderful, amazing and beautiful.
It is such a nice getaway from concrete and asphalt.
You can literally walk through here for hours and just enjoy the "outdoors".  Great place to just spend time with family, have a picnic, people watch and enjoy life.  The only downsides can be parking on a nice day.... OMG... good luck, the place can be busier than Disneyland!  Allowing a few more food truck vendors to sell food (there were only 2) would be nice as you do get hungry.  We didn't venture into any of the museums or the science center as they can be costly.
author: Joe T.

description:
Huge park with a very long path to jog/run, lots of beautiful views and streams, some cool attractions and museums with in, defintely one of the best parks in the world!

Even the fellow joggers were nice, which as a New Yorker it was hard getting used to!
author: TheOnionedElk _.

description:
After arriving in San Fran, we were slightly overwhelmed by the crowds and size of the city! So the next day we decided to stroll around the park and am so glad we did! This is the equivalent to New York's Central Park. 

We had the best morning walking our dog through the well manicured landscaping, flower conservatory, dahlia garden, museum grounds, and hiking trails. Definitely recommend if you are looking to escape and get into nature for a little while. Plus it's very close to Baker Beach, which is also great for beautiful views of San Fran and the Golden Gate Bridge. Free parking all over the park.
author: Kat M.

description:
I visited this park after overlooking it on my last visit.  This park is HUGE!  I learned during my visit that it is larger than Central Park in NYC.  This park is located a few miles and minutes from the Golden Gate Bridge.  This park has many different areas to hang out and see and I don't think I saw it all.  

I thought I was having a moment of de ja vu because the park reminded me of San Diego's Balboa Park.  I noticed the bike paths, there were skateboarder, roller bladders and joggers there during my visit.  The beauty of the cherry blossoms were on full display and you couldn't help but feel relaxed and happy in the space.  

There is a Japanese House/Garden, California's Academy of Science, an Aquarium, De Young Museum and there was a Keith Harding installation on display in front of the museum.  There is so much to see, I would want to return and spend the day to take all the beauty of this park.  

If you have the time, check out the Cali Vibe & Join In...Don't Be Stuffy..Have Fun!!
author: Shane J.

description: I had an opportunity to go into the park a couple days ago. I used to live directly across from the deyoung and Academy of Sciences.  They have really turned the park around in the right direction . It was stunning ! No garbage, very well manicured. Not one light was out on building nor on the newly lit walking trails .  Amazing that I didn't see one homeless person asking for change or doing drugs . None of that .  Anyone thinking of paying a visit to our gem in our backyard, I encourage you to go .  A standing ovation to the parks and Recreation for making the park a place to be proud of in a City that seems to have forgotten simple values.  Thank you Parks and Rec!
author: Patrick S.

description: Park is gorgeous, but parking is horrendous. Got a great view of the Murphy Windmill but due to the lack of parking, we couldn't walk too far due to not knowing the area and it was getting too cold for our daughter. Would love to go back before leaving!
author: Erin B.

description:
Parking was not hard to find, either street parking or finding a spot in the garage. The sister and I explored the area and I love that there is so much to do! It's not all outdoors, there are museums all around. What I love most is all the photo opportunities! Everything is so beautiful!

I love the outdoor space and all the different architectural buildings landmarks. It can be quite a walk if you're trying to explore it all, but you barely notice how much you're really walking just because everywhere you turn there is something to explore or do.

I wasn't able to see everything so I know once I'm back I'll be sure to come here again.
author: Anh L.

description:
Relax in this Beautiful, Big Park
This is a great place to go if you simply want to get away from the commotion of the city and relax for a bit. 

Traveler Tip: This park is BIG so remember landmarks so you don't get lost while exploring. 

Traveler Tip: If you enjoy tea gardens this is a Japanese style garden within the park that is nice to see if you enjoy this type of landscape.

Traveler Tip: Order some food to go and bring the food and a blanket to the park if it is a nice day. Set up a picnic for your significant other, family, or by yourself to just relax and enjoy the beauty of SF.

I'm a fellow traveler so I appreciate when other people have given me tips/recommendations while in a new city. If this information is helpful, please let me know by hitting the like button. Even if this review helps only one traveler then it's worth it to know I'm contributing towards making someone's experience better, giving to the global community, and paying it forward. Safe Travels!
author: Neo N.

description:
California Trip Part 2 #7

"From a vast, windswept expanse of sand dunes, park engineer William Hammond Hall and master gardener John McLaren carved out an oasis-a verdant, horticulturally diverse, and picturesque public space where city dwellers can relax and reconnect with the natural world. The rest, as they say, is history." 

(http://sfrecpark.org/parks-open-spaces/golden-gate-park-guide/).

100 reviews and one year later, here I sit writing my 300th Yelp review. My 200th was for Point Lobos in Carmel; I wanted to pick another special place for this review. Golden Gate Park (GGP) is the king of all parks. With 1,017-acres and numerous things to do and see, GGP is phenomenal. I spent several hours on my last day in California and only got to see a small portion of this enormous iconic park.

There is just too much to mention in one review and I also didn't see everything. So, I am simply going to recommend my favorite part from my visit. Stow Lake Waterfalls & Park is a wonderful place to relax and take photos if you're into photography like me. I saw squirrels, birds and I swear I even spotted a fox! Of course, there's also the gorgeous waterfalls and Chinese pagoda. Strawberry Hill is included at Stow and it allows you to see a view of the Golden Gate Bridge. 

*Tip--I saw plenty of parking around the lake and this was on a Saturday.

I didn't know until today when I was researching for this review that there is a free shuttle at GGP. It would definitely be helpful when trying to cover such a vast area. Here is the link: https://goo.gl/Dtyqw2

I'm not sure that I will visit on my next trip simply because there are too many places for me to explore and too little time, but if I ever move to the Bay Area, my feet would eventually cover every last inch of GGP. I love you, California!
author: Carissa K.

description:
TL;DR Beautiful and fun park, gardens + museums 

PLUSES:
+ cal Academy of Sciences 
+ de young museum (art)
+ Japanese tea garden
+ stow lake (paddle boating)
author: Sophia L.

description:
By far one of my favorite parks EVER!!! 

We went about having a picnic here near The Academy of Science and had a most peaceful and lovely old time. The park is just splendid in every which way. We were able to really enjoy ourselves in San Fransisco and not be bothered by anyone. Laid in the grass under some eucalyptus trees and had some music playing while we drew on some canvases; it was really something out of a movie. The park is so big, it's hard for anyone to bother you somewhere (unless they really want to bother you) lol

There are several it the gems hidden in the park, from statues to ponds, to benches and little vistas. It is like our own "New York Central Park". Everytime I walk or drive through it, I always find something new. 

Overall; if I want to disconnect locally, this is a nice little safe haven. Pack a lunch! Throw down a sheet and soak up some sun!
author: Bruce's A.

description:
A gorgeous park! Trees, trees and more trees. Lots to do, lots of space with museums, flowers, trials and of course the beach on one side (Lands End) The Windmills are a cute touch too. I think one could explore this park forever, every day, and still find something new to discover. A Jumanji right in the city. lol- Oh yeah and Bison. 

I turned to my friend with a shocked look on my face. I asked in a squeelly, girly voice, "Are those freaking Buffalo?" He replies, "Oh yeah. I forgot to to tell you. We have Bison too." How did you forget to tell me that? Bison in downtownish San Fran area? Who knew?
author: Mary S.

description: Golden Gate Park is a versatile park in an unexpected area. It's huge for being in a city like San Francisco. The park itself is beautiful and has many things to offer. If you'd just like a place to walk around that's not the city I recommend going here specifically checking out Strawberry Hill. If you're looking more so for "something to do" check out the Japanese Tea Gardens. There is an entrance fee into the tea garden but it's inexpensive and worth it!
author: Alice G.

description:
Impressive, historic park with urban offerings like museums, a flower conservatory, and the country's oldest tea garden, but surrounded by lush, natural landscaping with lakes and forest and WTF is that a buffalo?? 

And, you can bring booze.  The only problem is that my cousin warned me of break-ins, and pointed out at least half a dozen piles of shattered car window glass along the roads as proof.  
That's why you need the booze.

It's bigger than Central Park, much more lush and shady than Griffith Park, and is less annoying as Linkin Park.  Seriously, rap or rock, pick one.
author: Glen N.

description: This park is beautiful and breathtaking. I'm still IN AWE from all the pictures I've taken. I'm in loveeeeee.
author: Michelle K.

description:
Perfect escape from the busy city! Parking can be difficult, but just try to get there early and stay the whole day. There are so many trails and hidden gems within the park that it will be worth the time. 
Also... buffalo in a city? What the heck? So cool! Go check it out!
author: Colby M.

description:
A big beautiful park.  Tea Garden is very nice (though you have to pay admission).  There are some nice trails, long walking/biking paths, some open areas designated for segways and great scenery.

If you don't have a bike, don't worry, you can rent one  You can rent a segway and also one weird combo bike/cart thing (though I don't recommend these ones as I saw some people getting stuck because of the hills).  

This is also a great place to relax and chill.  It's an open park that is basically a public space, so you can have picnics, bring booze and no one is going to stop you or give you a fine.

Verdict: I'd call this the Central Park of the west coast and a must visit while you are in San Fran.
author: Bernie C.

description: Large beautiful grounds with lots of attractions such as the science museum, the Japanese gardens, the rose garden and much more, including picnic areas and food trucks. It is peaceful. Families and couples cover the grounds in bicycles. Some choose to walk. There is street parking and covered parking available. The main reason for the four stars, instead of five, is the difficulty of finding the parking structure to return and retrieve one's vehicle once it becomes dark, especially from the de Young museum entrance/exit.
author: Kimberly H.

description:
Golden Gate Park - 5 Stars: a vast park (over 1,000 acres) in San Francisco that has numerous jewels hidden away in different areas. We visited the de Young Museum and the Japanese Tea Garden that are both located in Golden Gate Park. They also have the Golden Gate Park Aquarium, the California Academy of Sciences, Strybing Arboretum, and the Conservatory of Flowers. Whether you visit the numerous museums or not, a trip to Golden Gate Park is worth the visit. 

There is an upcharge for the museums, but simple entrance to the beautiful grounds of Golden Gate Park is always free. They also have Segway tours for those that want to see it all, botanical gardens, and tulip gardens not to mention ten lakes...on some of which you can rent pedal boats. They also have on-site underground parking to make your visit easy...try it.
author: Rick B.

description: I've been through the Golden Gate Park so many times. Usually driving and going to specific places. This trip my boyfriend wanted to walk around. Golden Gate Park is definitely beautiful with lots of hidden areas to explore.
author: Jenn D.

description: What a wonderful park. I enjoyed the buffalo and laying in a field of small daisies. Parking can be a challenge but that's how most parks are.
author: Melanie F.

description: Golden gate park is one of the most wonderful places in San Francisco. I can't imagine a busy and crowded city like San Francisco would have such a huge park here. You will see everything natural here in Golden gate park, trees, rivers, gooses, you name it. I love coming here over the weekend by myself, just to relax my mind. I ses a lot of people biking around also, I guess that's what I would like to try in the future as well.
author: Mary J.

description: This is a huge park and a couple hours is not enough to explore all it has to offer you'll get lost in it we were able to visit the Japanese garden it was beautiful admission was like 8$ per adult we also stopped by the lily ponds but not a lot was going on there and we walked around for quite a bit then left to catch a flight wish we had more time, Wear some good shoes and go check this park out there's so much peace here!
author: Lana S.

description:
Golden Gate Park is gorgeous - I wish I'd had more than just a few stolen hours on my way out of town to explore.  The Japanese Tea Garden, the Conservatory of Flowers, Stow Lake, the museums, the walking trails, the Dahlia garden!  Omg - what is not to love?!  

I didn't get to see anything close to everything I wanted.  

This is a treasure in the middle of San Francisco and it a huge portion of the small town itself.  I love that so much of the city space is dedicated to a park.  Reminded me of London and their dedication to trees and greenery in a small, urban area.  Thumbs way up!

I easily found parking and was able to wander around and explore what I had come to see.  I loved the beautiful Japanese Tea Garden and spent a few hours there walking slowly around and feeling serene.  

I was a little less impressed with the conservatory of flowers - it was pretty and interesting from the outside but the inside seemed like three rooms of much the same thing - with a neat butterfly exhibit and a pretty lily pond area.  It was pretty for $8 but I would never come again so it wouldn't be a habitual place to visit if I were nearby or ever visiting the city again. 

I had to drive around a bit for parking when I visited both of the above because I was pressed for time so is saw tons of other things I'd love to see - as well as the Dahlia garden which wasn't in season but I was told is amazing when it is (my favorite flower).  

I will absolutely be back.
author: Alison M.

description: Golden Gate Park is an amazing park within the city of San Francisco. If I lived in SF, I can imagine it being a great spot to think, meditate and getaway with getting away. I was told it is bigger than Central Park in NYC. The Conservatory of Flowers, the many man made lakes, multiple museums, and endless paths make this one of the great urban parks in the world!
author: Sam T.

description:
The park was so large! Rent a bike (the price was comparable at $8/hr) and ride through the park to the beach. I think you can rent segways too--saw a whole family ride with them. Part of the park had a bike lane, for the others, we braved our souls and peddled our hearts out going up hill on the way back. It was a workout even with a tandem bike the bf and I shared. My poor friend was by himself, and he walked alongside his bike most of the way back up.  

There is the Botanical Garden and Japanese Tea Garden if you're more about moseying around and taking pictures. I'm unsure if you have to pay admission fees for these two areas. 

One part of the park had the bison area. Though you cannot touch them, they are in viewing sight from the sidewalk sidelines. There were also two large windmills if you want to stop by for quick pictures. The beach is super close to these so go there too! :) 

The park had nice scenery and was clean. There were lots of folks enjoying the fresh air walking, biking, golfing, having picnics, etc.
author: Andrea M.

description: This park is HUGE and there are so many museums and lakes in it. It's a great, peaceful place to walk around, and apparently it's slightly bigger than NYC's Central Park. It has cars running through it though so there's noise sometimes. It's pretty flat so it's a pretty easy walk, and there's tons to see throughout the park. Definitely recommend coming here!
author: Andrea W.

description:
For a person who lives across the street from Golden Gate Park, I rarely walk inside the park. In the 9 years I've lived off of Fulton, I think I've walked into the park a total of three times from my place. On Sunday, August 14th, one of my friends was having a bbq at GGP, so I ventured into the park around 1:45pm.

He was actually having his birthday barbecue at Strawberry Hill by the waterfall. What a great spot! (I'm pretty sure he reserved it ahead of time, but I don't know the specifics.) We had a great view of Stow Lake and a couple of picnic tables. We brought a grill, food, beers, etc. We even hiked up the hill to get a better view of the city.

Being over three miles long and half a mile wide, GGP is home to a lot of great places and events. I've enjoyed concerts at Outside Lands, the nightlife at the Academy of Sciences, a few exhibits at the de Young Museum, the beauty of the Conservatory of Flowers, had many meals at both the Beach Chalet and Park Chalet, etc. There really are so many things to do and see inside the park.

Glad I recently ventured into the park again. Reminded me of how much I actually enjoy being in GGP. After the bbq, I ended up walking the majority of the length of the park. It's was wonderful getting lost in the beauty of GGP.
author: Elena N.

description: A true gem! How often do you find a beautifully landscaped park in the middle of a crowded, urban city. Not to mention, this park is huge! Lots of cute little areas to explore within it like Shakespeare garden of flowers, stow lake, Japanese tea garden, DeYoung Museum, and so on.  After a stressful day, taking a stroll is so relaxing. Highly recommend checking it out.
author: Lauren H.

description:
So apparently, Golden Gate Park is much bigger than Central Park, New York City's version of this fine city attraction.

There's so much to say and visit about Golden Gate Park, that I feel I won't do it justice from just sharing my experiences. If you look on a map or gaze down from any of the view spots in the city such as Grand View Park, you can truly appreciate how magnificent this park is. It pretty much takes up a huge chunk of San Francisco, and from an elevation, all you will see is dense forest engulfing the city. 

There are a number of entrances into the park, and subsequently, you can park yourself in any of the many parking spots scattered around Golden Gate Park. Even on the weekend when all the kids come out to play, it IS possible to find parking if you are patient. Just remember where you parked and that the limit to stay is about 3 hours!

There's a number of maps scattered around the park which will help you navigate to where you need to go. Honestly, I'd suggest you just get yourself lost and come across new destinations! Or, if you are intent on exploring much see places, check out De Young Museum, Cal Academy of Sciences, the Japanese Tea Garden, and the many lakes!

My favorite part of the park was probably the short hike up to Strawberry Hill. It's not too strenuous, and you get a great glimpse of the city. I wish there were waterfalls and a cleaner lake, but it's still a great experience!

tl'dr Golden Gate Park will cater to most people's interests. That's how awesome it is.
author: Bryan W.

description:
A large urban oasis that's not only a free, ready-made gym for runners and bikers, but also houses a number of picnic grounds that can be reserved by SF residents, as well as many public institutions and memorials, like the de Young Museum, the Academy of Sciences, the Japanese tea garden, and the AIDS Memorial Grove.

Simply a gorgeous respite from the rest of the city, and it's all easily accessible, whether by car (there's parking everywhere in the park) or by public transit (there are buses going to the museums, as well as on the major thoroughfares that surround and cut through the park).
author: Vincent L.

description:
Bottom Line:  A natural beauty and fun cultural center.

The Golden Gate Park can easily be confused with The Presidio.  The Presidio is the park that adjoins the Golden Gate Bridge and Golden Gate Park is located about four miles from the bridge.  Confusion aside, for someone wanting some exercise, there is a bike path/bike lanes that connect both of this lovely San Francisco parks.

Regarding the Golden Gate Park, there is a lot to see and do in this park.  It reminds me of San Diego's Balboa Park or Washington DC's National Mall given the monuments, museums and gardens sprinkled throughout.  There are a lot of paved paths and sidewalks here that are perfect for walkers and joggers. Cyclists, whether causal in jeans or serious in spandex, should use the bike lanes.  Although you could quickly cruise through the park in a car I recommend stopping to smell the roses and buffalo, or maybe just the roses. There are various statuary and monuments that are worth a look too. Other big destinations in the park include California's Academy of Sciences (a science center, aquarium and natural history museum all housed under one roof) and the de Young Museum featuring a variety of art.
author: Courtney K.

description: If you're going to GGP, plan it out and map it out ahead of time. It's not your average park in terms of size, price, or activities. It's comprised of parks, museums, gardens, and everything else. There's very much to see and do. You don't want to waste any time getting lost and found.
author: Chris G.

description:
I took my family to the Golden Gate Park. Here is our experience.

We started from the Northwest corner at Fulton & Great Highway. There are two main streets: John F. Kennedy Dr and Martin Luther King Jr Dr. We took John F. Kennedy Dr all the way to Stow Lake. It was too far for us to go all the way across. There was so much to see on John F. Kennedy Dr. There was the windmill, the bison, several beautiful lakes, two waterfalls, a river/stream, and finally Stow Lake. There are several restroom points all along this street.

We looped around Stow Lake and took Martin Luther King Jr Dr. back. There was really nothing on this street to see. There were minimal restrooms along this street.

TIPS:
-The streets run with the paths for the most part. People on the paths and cars on the road.
-On the path there are several spots where a map of the park is posted knowing where you are.
-John F. Kennedy Dr is far better for sights and picture taking.
-Parking is free throughout the park if you can find a spot.
-Uber/Lyft drivers hang out in the park for a quick ride out.


Personally, this place is great for everyone.  The natural beauty is breathtaking and amazing. I think the next time we come, we would drive through the park rather than walk.
author: Sam N.

description:
When people say "American," they tend to mean someone from the United States, whereas North American would include anyone from the United States, Canada, and Mexico.  That said, my favorite urban parks are not American, but Canadian.  First on my list is Parc du Mont-Royal and second is Stanley Park in Vancouver.  In my mind, these are 5 star events ... the first for crowning the mountain in the middle of Canada's most interesting metropolis and the second for hugging the promontory at the peninsular end of Vancouver's downtown core.

However, Golden Gate Park is still an incredible city park and a destination in and of itself.  It seems to stretch about half the western half of San Francisco, though it's not particularly wide, and touches the Great Highway at the Pacific Ocean.  It is almost fully rectilinear, much like New York's Central Park.  With that in mind, it does not cover any of the hilliness that is part and parcel of San Francisco, though it is near it.

The variety of landscapes in the park is nevertheless something to behold, with lakes, ponds, monuments, recreational amenities, forests, the funky windmills, and other points of interest.  I would have to say that my favorite things in Golden Gate Park are some of the lakes and the Conservatory of Flowers, for its being a beautiful landmark and for the incredible color show put on by the flowers and plantings.  

Please be aware that, even though the park is heavily used, relaxing, and just a great place to be, do not leave valuables or personal objects visible in your car.  There are sometimes waves of "smash and grab" incidents and that would be a sad way to have your visit here sullied. (Incidentally, finding parking is doable ... most of the time.)  No visit to San Francisco is complete without visiting the many venues and seeing the many vistas available within Golden Gate Park.
author: Robert G.

description:
Drove straight to the Tulip Garden this past Monday afternoon just after 2pm...hardly anyone here. We parked DIRECTLY in front of the entryway to the garden..that's how not busy this area was at the time.

Within 10 minutes of taking pics, we were approached by an elder woman and her grandson who said if that vehicle they were pointing to (ours) belonged to us as they heard a car window smashed and only caught a glimpse of the fleeing dark colored vehicle.

She went around to the left side of our rental minivan to show us the left rear sliding passenger window smashed and we discovered that they stole my nephew's back pack!

We were so upset that this happened on our last full day of our vacation.

Other than that..we took a few pics of the beautiful garden and windmill. We would definitely return and hope karma will come to those thieves.

The undercover cops who just so happened to drive by about 15 minutes after the incident calmed us down somewhat. They told us there were a rash of break-ins in the park at this time.They sincerely apologized for this happening to us and told us not to think of San Francisco in a bad light.

All i can say is that rental vehicles are "marked cars" with their visible window tags and are the target for these thieves!

Too bad there aren't security cameras or bait cars placed here in the park..think they'd catch them.
author: Dennis Y.

description:
Definitely one of my favorite places in San Francisco! The park itself is huge, and is filled with so many things to see. Aside from the big attractions (DeYoung Museum, California Academy of Sciences, Japanese Tea Garden), there are hidden gems as well (mini waterfalls, a rose garden, a nice lake, walking trails, and much more). It's such a relaxing place to be at! 

The air feels so fresh, and it's especially beautiful in the park at sunset. The perfect place for a walk, jog, or bike ride! It would even be great to drive through and sight-see the different aspects of the park as well. Free parking on the main streets, so you can definitely stop to enjoy whatever you might find interesting. I've seen people having BBQs or picnics in the park as well. Such a fun place to explore and there is bound to be an activity that you enjoy there!
author: Kathy C.

description:
Born and raised in San Francisco I love Golden Gate Park and I love that on the weekends they closed it so you could just walk around you won't get your ass run over you just have to watch out for the bicycle people. Me and my cousin what here for a birthday party had me walking I was like damn dude you're killing me there's this really cool waterfall, but you have to go through the 19th and under the bridge kind of hard to get to I think the exit is to the left on Martin Luther way not sure.
 just Google it and figure it out it took us 30 minutes cuz we end up driving around the whole Dam Park. lmao
author: Lizzie G.

description: My wife wanted to visit the Japanese Tea Garden so  we took a Lyft to the park. Word of caution, it's a huge park so you want to get dropped or park as close as possible to your destination. We walked about a mile it seemed before we saw a shuttle which saved me as I wasn't feeling well and didn't feel like walking the distance. The park has a lot to offer for bikers, runners, walkers, people who want to play musical instruments, etc. There are activities within like the tea and botanical gardens but beware they cost. $9 for adult out of state to the Japanese Tea Garden alone...No military discounts.  Great for outdoor activities.
author: Gary G.

description: This review is just for the Pokémon go play in San Francisco's Golden Gate Park. Holy Moly there are so many poke stops and Pokémon to catch. If you are a Pokémon go player this park is a destination for you. There are great walking paths and they are lined with poke stops. There are several gyms too.
author: Jerry M.

description:
This review is #1000 for one of the most beautiful and useful parks that I have ever visited! 

It's functional - people drive, jog, bike, and walk through it.

It's picturesque - tourists and residents alike take countless photos here. 

It's full of historical landmarks such as Francis Scott Key's Memorial and the Dutch and Murphy Windmills! 

It's useful because it contains the Japanese Tea Garden, the de Young Museum, the Conservatory of Flowers, an archery field, California Academy of Science, and the amphitheater. 

It's awesome because there are Bison, a tulip garden, a carousel, a rose garden, squirrels, a golf course, and ducks there. 

People gather together and do Tai chi exercises, have picnics and festivals here. Children learn and get exercise on its grounds.

Golden Gate Park has so much variety and so many activities!  There's something for everyone!
author: Nadine C.

description:
How beautiful is this place?

You can bike, you can walk, you can picnic, you can run, you can chat with friends. There is every tree imaginable, the same goes for flowers, plus ponds and little critters running around. I was amazed by the variety found here, and even more amazed to know it's man-made.

What a spectacular gift to the city of San Francisco. I would spend all my time here if I lived closer to it.
author: Nic Z.

description:
A walk through Golden Gate Park truly completes any San Fransisco trip. You can literally get lost in this huge maze of parks, museums and gardens (and on a recent ACRONYM trip, luckily our trusty leader Jessica T. navigated the way for us!) Make sure to take some time to visit the individual gardens or one of the in-park museums, but note that although the park itself is free, the museums and gardens are paid admission. However, I highly recommend the Japanese Tea Garden, and they offer free admission when entering the gardens before 10:00am on Mon, Wed, Fri. In addition to this, you can find a tulip garden, Shakespearean garden and botanical garden within walking distance. 

For museum visits, you'll find the California Academy of Science and the De Young Museum. But if you want to stay outside to enjoy the sites, check out the buffalo, carousal or tennis courts or one of the many green spaces. Plus, you'll find a lovely children's playground on site to help get some wiggles out of your young ones. This is a perfect spot for tourists and locals alike, and with the acreage of the park, it's large enough to get your out of the "big city" mindset and allow you to relax in the beauty of nature.
author: Rose L.

description: Look like a nice place to go for a walk run or hike. I went through the park hoping to find a spot to take a picture of the Golden Gate bridge, but it did not seem like it was that type of place and part of the park was closed off for a special event. Go to Crissy Field if you want to get a great view of the city as well as the Golden Gate bridge.
author: rosemarie d.

description: There are so many things you can do at this park, and the best way to see everything the park has to offer is to run or bike through the park; however, if you are running be mindful that the park is a little over 10 miles around and there are a lot of hills! But the best part is that you can stop and take a break everywhere you go, because there is always something you will want to photograph.  You must pay to stroll through the botanical and Japanese gardens! This run has been on my bucket list for some time and I'm glad I was able to finally accomplish it!
author: Keisha K.

description:
Such a beautiful Oasis in San Francisco! It is a LARGE park, and very well maintained (and clean)! 
I would walk here all day if I could and explore. The Japanese Garden is inside the park, there is a museum, and lots of statues.
There is also tons of foliage and flowers, which is great for nature photography! 
Next time, I will try biking in the park to see more of it!
author: Amelia J.

description:
To me the Golden Gate Park is the Central Park of the west with over 1,000 acres of fun.  If you're not a local, one can easily get lost or end up wandering about.  There isn't one main entrance into the park, but  many ways for you to enter.  What gives this park its character are the many museums, lakes, Dutch windmill, carousel, par 3 golf course, playgrounds, archery fields, and many more.

I enjoy the museums the best and recommend visiting the following:

1) California Academy of Science
2) de Young Museum
3) Conservatory of Flowers
4) Japanese Tea Garden

These museums do offer free days so refer to their website for additional info.

Golden Gate Park is also a great place to go for a run or a bicycle ride.  On Sundays and all holidays, JFK drive is closed to vehicles.  This is great as you can run or bike worry free of vehicles.

Pro tip: There is a free shuttle service that operates from 9am to 6pm on Saturdays, Sundays, and holidays.  Feel free to use this service to help you get around.
author: Peter C.

description:
Very cool, very large. Golden Gate Park is a trip by itself. Between the de Young Museum, Academy of Sciences, Japanese Tea Garden, Botanical Garden, Strawberry Hill, the Shakespeare and Rose Gardens, and the Music Concourse, you could probably spend two days and never leave the vicinity of the park.

Neatly arranged and loaded with greenery, paths, signage and ball fields, this is the Central Park of the West Coast. It's simply amazing.

I lucked out, not having any sort of idea what I was encountering. Instead, I stumbled upon the de Yong, the Bandshell and the Botanical Garden. A more organized organized Yelper probably would have had a better plan of attack. I'll have to do that next time.

Well worth a read of the history of this park and how it was converted from dead sand dunes and trash dumps to a lush garden that's a quarter bigger than New York's Central Park.
author: Bruce K.

description: Here again as we make our way to the de Young. The park is a real jewel and well worth a visit. To avoid the parking problem just take a city bus. It is a great way to see the city, inexpensive and efficient. Like Central Park, it is almost possible to forget you are in a large city. In fact, I think the park is nicer than Central Park - and I am from New Jersey and like Central Park.
author: Dave W.

description: For as many times as I have visited SF, this was my first time going to the Golden Gate Park. We visited during the second week of March - after they got hit with a lot of rain - and it was beautiful there! Everything was so green! The park is very large and makes for a great mild hike. There are trails you can take to capture amazing views of the Golden Gate Bridge along with the beautiful architecture surrounding the area. It is family friendly and highly recommend taking time to stop by.
author: Julie N.

description:
Golden Gate park was probably one of the best ways I've ever spent a day in San Francisco. The park is huge and there is about a hundred different things to see and do here. The Middle of the park consists of lots of dog friendly trails that wrap around a lake, and you can even rent row and paddle boats if you're in the mood. Too lazy for physical activity? Well you can sit and relax and feed the ducks then, since there are park benches about every couple hundred yards apart facing the lake.

There was even a water fall that you could choose from taking a stone path across the base of to a gazebo, or the stairs that climb beside the sides of the water fall to another trail at the top.

You can also find the De Young fine arts museum here which is extremely affordable for the classy type ($10 for general admission and $6 for students) or if you're a free loader like myself, you can just go to the top of the museum which gives off a 360 degree view of the city and park all around, and the best part is it's free to everyone.

Just a couple of steps across from the De Young is also the Academy of Science museum. Admission with student ID can still be a little pricey ($30) but it's definitely worth it! 

Most of the museum is pretty much a giant aquarium, ranging from a large quantity of sea and fresh water fish and marine life, with a few science exhibits at the base of the first floor, and a giant indoor terrarium rainforest that you can go inside and observe free flying birds, butterflies, African leaf cutter ants, and plants. In the center of it all is a pond filled with alligator gar the size of a full grown man just swimming around like "yeah no big deal!" But keep in the mind the indoor terrarium is extremely hot and humid!!

At the very roof of the entire academy is an outside deck with a view of the entire park and rooftop ferns. 

Parking is little bit of pain, but the golden gate park is something that was 100% worth it! I would definitely come back and bring friends with me here, if you haven't been yet, do yourself a big favor and find a day you are free and go.
author: Alex A.

description:
This park has so much to offer and such a beautiful place-! When you think you saw it all you find more hidden places you haven't seen-!

What a beautiful park-! Love it-!
author: Jang R.

description:
There's something for everyone at Golden Gate Park, whether you're 7 or 77 years old. I didn't appreciate how awesome this park is until I moved away from the bay. This park is very large in size and every so often, local radio stations will host free concerts here. 

For the kiddies, there is a children's playground with lots of slides, swings, sandboxes, and even a merry-go-around. Snack stands near by for the hungry kids. 

The Japanese Tea Garden is one of my favorite components of the park. There's an $8 entrance fee, but it'll be money well spent, not to mention this is a great afternoon date place. Lots of photo opportunities available!

Most recently, I discovered that you can paddle-boat here as well at an hourly rate. Life jackets and paddle-boat included in the rental fee. No lifeguard on duty. Paddle at your own risk. 

The Golden Gate Orchestra was playing for free on a Sunday afternoon. They sounded great and there's really no bad seat. 

Various museums for your enjoyment, but check the hours of operation. Look for coupons in the free tourist books around town or online.
author: Jean L.

description:
As a native, born and raised, PROUD resident of the great city of New York, I must proclaim that I in fact do enjoy and give the edge to Golden Gate Park. YES, YES I favor this park over Central Park. I know it's blasphemous being that I am a New Yorker to express this but Golden Gate Park won my heart. I still have mad love and will always love Central Park but I just love this park more. 

The fact that you can chill on a legit beach, with beautiful scenic views, then go right into the park which has a Bison Barrack, an Island, an amazing science center, so many variants of plants, amazing sculptures, a Japanese tea garden and so much more, its just a big win. Again, a BEACH and an amazing city park? I'm a huge beach person so WIN, WIN, WIN. 

If you're looking for peace and quiet, you can easily find refuge to a tranquil oasis almost anywhere within the park. If you want to partake in whatever activity, this park more than likely has it. I also love that it never seems to get ridiculously packed and its also a HUGE park. Its also so lush and green, its quite amazing.


I really can't find the words to try and be as articulate and eloquent like other reviewers but if you're into city parks, especially the ones in major cities, you owe it to yourself to visit this amazing park. Its so unique in a lot of ways and has so much to offer. AMAZING.  

The one con I will say is that while the Tea Garden is amazing paying 9 dollars is just STOOPID to me. Since you're not going to get the tranquility you would want with all the stupid tourist and their stupid family just being a ton of goobers. I think there should be a screening for the tea garden. Like you have to actually buy tea and sit down and talk about deep shit. Instead of having stupid, ugly, tourist families just ruin the place just to say they have done it.

Other than that, its an amazing park to visit and must see, visit and do.
author: Near M.

description: As a young man in 1988 I would go to golden gate park and play pick up soccer games with whoever was there. One weekend it could be Europeans and the next week I playing with south Americans in jeans. This is a very relaxed park. Fond memories.
author: Tim L.

description:
If I can sum this park up in 3 words ---- Huge, beautiful, scenic. There's definitely a lot to see in the park and, for those who are first timers there are maps located throughout the park. For the people who decide to drive her, there are plenty of parking spaces on the road. 

Unfortunately, we didn't get to explore the entire park, but we did visit the Rose Garden and Kezar Stadium. The Rose Garden was pretty small, but it was free! There were lots of beautiful roses in the garden scattered within a 100 yard area. We were going to visit the Japanese Tea Garden, but realized there was a fee, so decided to skip that. As we drove out, we came upon Kezar Stadium, which was apparently the old home of the San Francisco 49ers and Oakland Raiders. We stopped by and walked around inside, which was pretty neat. There were some people doing crossfit and running. The stadium looked rather small as they destroyed most of the original stadium and left the field there with some bench seating.

We only devoted 1 hour to the park, but if anyone plans on visiting, absolutely try to devote  1/2 of a day to the park as there is a lot to see in the park that we missed!
author: Chris E.

description: When you go to San Francisco, THIS is where you need to go.  I'll be doing reviews of other parts of the park, but taken altogether, this park is heavenly.  Wish we had more time to enjoy it.
