This park is the Central Park of San Francisco. It is a great place to go for a run as there are a lot of different trails within the park and the outer roads are approximately 6 miles. There are plenty of things going on in the park with a Dutch Windmill (where there was a wedding occurring when I walked past it), lakes, ball fields, plenty of trees, and much more. The San Francisco Botanical Gardens and Japanese Tea Garden are also popular spots within the park. However, there are too many other things to do and great views in the city that are free of charge. As a result, I did not feel the need to wait in line and pay for either of those two attractions. If you want to see a beautiful display of flowers in the park, you can pass by the Conservatory of Flowers on John F. Kennedy Drive in the northeast corner of the park for free. I had a great time taking a loop inside the park. I highly recommend it on a beautiful day.

If you are visiting San Francisco and looking for recommendations, feel free to message me through Yelp and I can share my itinerary, which includes my Yelp reviews. The information for an electronic copy can also be found via my Yelp profile.
author: Patrick W.

description: Great park! Has a lot of walking options, lawns to play different sports. Recently some sections such as the Big Lawn area are paid. Weather in this part of SF can be chilly, dress up especially at late afternoons and evenings.
author: Ivan S.

description: Such variety, so many surprises, you'll need multiple visits to appreciate it's offerings! Must do in SF!
author: Pj M.

description:
How Many Days Do You Have?

This park is huge, and filled with so many fun things to do.  We did a quick tour of the Botanical Gardens, the Japanese Tea Garden, Stow Lake, and Strawberry Hill in a morning, and that is barely scratching the surface.  To be truly appreciated, those four attractions should be spread out over at least a full day.  That still leaves all of these to do:  Conservatory of Flowers, de Young Museum, California Academy of Sciences, Sharon Art Studio, and many, many more!  So, by all means, go to Golden Gate Park!  But, even if you have a week to spend there, don't expect to do it all!
author: Ted Q.

description:
What can you say about this park that hasn't already been said? Views of the iconic Golden Gate Bridge, beautiful lakes, amazing well kept, and enough foliage, flowers, and hidden gems to keep you busy for the day. 

If you're relying on public transportation, find the closest city bus. It'll cost you about $6 roundtrip.
author: Heather F.

description: This park is huge!  You can do so much... it'll take you hours to walk around, so be prepared.  This is one thing I'm jealous of San Francisco... their parks and playgrounds are simply top notch amazing.  (Something L.A. is lacking...)  anyway, this park has a carousel, awesome playgrounds, beautiful trees and flowers, bison, and so much more... There's so much space!  I absolutely love it!  You need to check it out!
author: Betty H.

description: So many fun things to look at here. It's a great place to go with your family . We love the Japanese tea garden and the California Academy of Sciences. There are many other attractions that you can enjoy, it's just a great place to spend the day.
author: Susan R.

description:
Beautiful and Huge Treed Park in the Middle of San Francisco - Perfect for a Relaxing Walk!

My mother and I visited Golden Gate Park during the afternoon of July 30th. We walked from the Mosaic Steps to the park. The park is also easily accessible by MUNI bus. 

Golden Gate Park was beautiful and huge! It was very natural and had a lot of huge trees and lush vegetation. It felt like I was in the middle of a forest instead of in the middle of a city, which was great! 

We walked through the park to Stow Lake, which was a pretty lake with a hilly island situated in the middle and connected to the mainland in one area. We wandered through some of the paths on the treed island and discovered Huntington Falls, which was a beautiful waterfall. 

The park was very peaceful and relaxing. After exploring the Stow Lake area, we continued walking throughout the park. 

There were a variety of attractions and things to do/see within the park as well, which we did not have time to do during this trip. They included the Botanical Gardens, Japanese Tea Gardens, museums, etc. 

I thoroughly enjoyed wandering around the park and throughout the trails at Stow Lake. This park is perfect for those seeking a relaxing walk in a natural setting. I recommend combining a visit to the park with exploring the nearby Haight-Ashbury neighbourhood.
author: Brittany T.

description:
Recently, I had the wonderful opportunity to spend a touristy weekend in San Francisco.

During my stay, my brother and I thought a walk (well more like a hike) through Golden Gate Park would be a  camera-clicking good time.

First off, Golden Gate Park is humongous, it's kilometers and kilometers of natural area mixed with peaceful gardens, conservatories, art, buildings and pathway that starts near the middle of the city and ends at the Golden Gate bridge in the bay. I would recommended a solid full day to get around the area. 

My first impression of the park was excellent since we stumbled upon Bay to Breakers which is an am run proceeded by a huge costume party/sun worship in the park that lasts nearly all day. In full San Fran style we saw every costume; and lack thereof; imaginable.The park is a great place to host an event like this  with wide open lawns, secret garden pathways and large trees to chill/sober-up under.

We saw only about 1/3 of the park since we were walking and decided to stop in the flower conservatory and the Japanese botanical gardens rather than hoof through straight to the bridge. 

The flower conservatory is a nice, historic building with five flower rooms recreating various tropical zones. Pretty orchids and nice ponds make for a pleasant tour.

The Japanese botanical gardens is obviously a tourist hot spot but luckily we got there after lunch so it was relatively empty. The Japanese garden grounds are beautiful, well-maicured and full of sculptural treasures both plant and bronze. The little tea house serves a nice selection of snacks and traditional Japanese treats. With a view of the pond, it's a nice place to sit and sip.

The wild areas of the park are lovely, big California-style forest make for a peaceful stroll in the afternoon.

Highly recommended, the Golden Gate Park is a great spot for a sunny afternoon break from other tourist spots.

T.
author: Tara M.

description: Golden Gate park is so huge and there are some many parts for you to explore. Definitely spent a good few hours walking around here. Lots of museums for you to check out as well as a Japanese Tea Garden! Worth a visit if you're in SF!
author: Jennifer W.

description: GO. Multiple times. You'll experience a new park every time. If you are visiting the bay, it is worth it to go our of your way, if you have to, to experience this gem.
author: Jon J.

description: Beautiful here at anytime of the year! The park is huge and you could be here walking around seeing many sites all day.. and still not see it all! Art museums, special events, people watching, ponds, buffalo.!
author: Kirk M.

description: There is definitely plenty to do in Golden Gate Park, whether you're into checking out the de Young Museum or the California Academy of Sciences, or just into walking around and having a picnic on the grass. Note that all of the attractions have a fee (but this is San Francisco, and as my friend said to a bum asking for money, "Nothing in this world is free"). As other reviewers have said, there are a lot of homeless people and druggies wondering about in the park. They don't bother you but I could see how a family with young kids that want to run around might not find this place that appealing. Many of the smaller trails are not marked, so keep that in mind when walking or biking. Overall it's a nice park to check out if you're visiting San Francisco.
author: Matt P.

description: What more can I ask for? This park is nice and clean. I haven't had a chance to explore everything but it was a nice place to walk Einstein. They have off leash areas which sounds really cool. People were running, taking pictures, walking their dogs, and picnicking. There also seemed to be plenty of parking but like everywhere else, you get to practice parallel parking skills!
author: Irene C.

description:
Golden Gate Park is a huge, lush public park in San Francisco.

Some of the popular attractions in the Golden Gate Park include the Japanese Tea Garden, Golden Gate Park Aquarium, de Young Museum, the California Academy of Sciences, the Golden Gate Carousel, Strawberry Hill, and the North (Dutch) Windmill and South (Murphy) Windmill.  There are several noteable flower gardens including the Queen Wilhelmina Tulip Garden, the San Francisco Botanical Garden (formerly known as Strybing Arboretum), Garden of Shakespeare's Flowers, and the Rose Garden on Kennedy Drive.

Many festivals and events are held at the Golden Gate Park every year.  If you are looking to listen to music, run a race, enjoy food, purchase art or plants, or meditate the Golden Gate Park has events to please everyone. 

Pack a picnic lunch or rent a bike and enjoy the Golden Gate Park.
author: Michelle M.

description: This is a cool park and kind of reminds me of being like the Central Park of San Francisco. On a Saturday afternoon there were a bunch of people out, some families and lots of younger people just laying out or playing games, just enjoying the day. It's a pretty area and you can easily walk to stuff in the Haight Ashbury area, which is where we stopped to grab a drink before entering the park. There were some bums, but it wasn't the dirtiest public park I've been to either.
author: Nicole D.

description: Great place to go for a run. If you do it east to west you can end at the beach and there are plenty of sites and places to rest along the way.
author: C C.

description: A hidden gem! We found the park by accident and were intrigued by the "forest-like" vibe it gave off so we stopped and explored just before sundown. This park reminds me of Central Park in that it has different areas to check out. There was a beautiful garden of roses and also some pretty impressive redwood trees.  If you're in the area visiting its worth checking out.
author: Alicia S.

description:
The park is huge and had a lovely windmill near the visitor center. Couldn't catch the Japanese Garden because we started a tad late.

We were walking back to our car which was parked parallel to the beach opposite the golden gate park when we bumped into Chris. He had his huge telescope which had been setup to view Saturn!! It was truly nice of him to let us have a sneak peek.

Thank you Chris!
author: Anand S.

description: This park is plenty large and in the middle of the city.  There are walking trails and bike paths. People can lounge or play games. Theres a botanical garden and a Japanese tea garden and more. There is something for everyone. There's so much to do here that you should make a game plan prior to visiting.
author: Andy S.

description:
One of the most beautiful, diverse, and a San Fran's jewel locations. Inside of the park, you have other destinations you can visit. One of them is the Japanese Tea Garden, Science & Art Museum, Conservatory, Botanical Garden, Chinese Pagoda, Stow Lake, Waterfall and more. 
Nothing beats the GG Park.

Love it!
author: Cindie N.

description: Didn't really get to experience the full park, but went to a Postcard show here in one of the buildings. I liked that the room temperature was nice and when we walked around the park outside it was beautiful, wish we would have gotten to see more. They had nice accessible restrooms which is always a plus for me. Just wish the parking would have been easier.
author: Diana W.

description:
Golden Gate Park one of my favorite places in San Francisco.
It's probably the main reason why I can go months without realizing I haven't gotten out of the city.

It has many things I like:
 - It has lots of trees. I'm from the Pacific Northwest, and I get cranky when I'm not near enough trees.
 - It's a big park, and all those trees help block out the city and makes it seem like you're getting away from it all
 - At the same time, you're never too far from food or public transportation.
 - It has many open meadows for picnics and paths in the forest for exploring.
 - There are plenty of moderately clean public restrooms throughout the entire park.
 - It has a ton of bike paths. On Sundays, one of the main roads is closed to cars.
 - It's mostly flat, so you can get pretty far on bike or running without tiring out.

If it's your first time there, the best way to see the park is on a bike. Preferably go on a Sunday, when they close the road. Even if you go when cars are allowed, the bike lanes are pretty nice.
Starting from the entrance near the Panhandle, you get the colorful Conservatory of Flowers, the "Skatin' Place" (happens on Sundays afternoons; you'll know it when you pass it), and that area with all those museums and the guy playing saxophone under the bridge. Once you pass under the highway, cars are allowed on the road and you're stuck in a bike lane, but it's a much quieter part of the park. There's a lake with huge miniature boats, a bison paddock, one of the windmills, and the Pacific Coast. If it's a clear day and you've made it this far, I recommend walking north to the landing outside of the Cliff House and look down the coast. Amazing!
The first section of JFK can get crowded on nice days, but it's wonderful seeing so many folks enjoying the park: children on tricycles, rollerbladers, runners, a guy pushing a grocery cart, bicyclists in fancy pants, a family on scooters.

There are also some nice places along MLK in the south, but it's not quite as wonderfully bike-friendly as JFK. The bike lanes are nonexistent at points and Highway 1 barges through and ruins the illusion of being away from the city.

Once you've done that, just check out the hundreds of little paths all over the park.
author: Jessica S.

description:
Golden Gate Park has been a continual part of my life as a San Francisco Bay Area Resident since 1984. Each time is a new adventure over it's 1000+ rectangular (and panhandle) space. I have walked, run (Bay-to-Breakers), biked, roller-bladed, and driven through various parts. My highlights have included:

- Kezar Stadium
- Conservatory of Flowers
- Music Concourse Area
- De Young Museum
- Academy of Sciences
- Japanese Tea Garden
- Botanical Garden at Strybing Arboretum
- Stow Lake
- Spreckels Lake
- Golden Gate Park Stadium
- Bison Paddock
- Windmills
- Beach Chalet
- Some of the surrounding Neighbourhoods

And of course the Homeless Camps...

Only in San Francisco!
author: Eric B.

description:
Golden Gate Park has so much to see and do, it's worth taking the time to plan your visit if your time is limited.  On this visit, we entered from the Great Highway, parked on the street and meandered thru on foot to view the windmills, Bison, Spreckles Lake and the soccer/polo fields.  There is ample street parking at 10:30 am on a Tuesday- just remember where you parked.  Its easy to lose your bearings here.
Our next stop was Strawberry Hill and Stow Lake.  Time was limited so we drove there and easily found street parking.  Wandering around here will take you to a man made waterfall, lush vegetation and Chinese Gazebo. The waterfall is not powerful enough to spray you, but there were water sprinklers going during our visit making the ground wet and muddy in spots.  Stow lake offers recreational watercraft rentals.  
Our last stop was the De Young store and cafe for lunch. You could probably walk from your parking spot at Stow lake to the De Young and Cal Academy.  By the afternoon, street parking close to the museum was limited.  Museum cafes are a favorite of mine- although the menu is limited and pricey, they usually offer something different.  This time we dined on a salad with salmon and purslane (an edible weed), roasted poussin ( the tiny French cousin of a Costco roasted chicken), Bratwurst and a deli sandwich for about $60.  Order from the menu or pick up a sandwich/salad from the refrigerated case.  
Food trucks were also parked nearby the Academy. 
A nice way to spend 4 hours...

Good to know:
Its very chilly here in the mornings- bring a jacket.
Park entrance is free, street parking is free.
There was no fee for all the places we visited, but most others charge admission.  Bring a student ID- some places offer discounted admission.
De Young is closed on Mondays. 
Download the basic park map : https://goldengatepark.com/map.html
author: Karen P.

description:
What a beautiful place. We spent a whole morning there riding our bikes. We are from out of town and was so glad we rented bikes to see this place. The journey to the park was anything but an easy ride, but the park was so beautiful that I did not care. I wish we had time that morning to visit the Japanese garden. Maybe next time. Be prepared for some physical activity riding uphill as some points. 

You see a lot of family here. Everyone was having a great time jogging, biking, or just relaxing.
author: Michelle G.

description:
My only regret when we went to the Golden Gate Park is that we didn't make the most of our visit there, which was a real shame. After copping a 16 hour flight from Melbourne, we checked into our hotel; freshened ourselves up and made our way to Golden Gate Park. We thought we'd walk on Haight St and check out the shops first (it's along the way so it'll be alright!) - bad move soldier! We'd taken the train (in our defence, we were told to do this by hotel reception so... not entirely our fault!) which got us to 16th Mission I think so we walked for ages before even getting to Haight-Ashbury! 

By the time we got there; we were exhausted and it was about 5 in the arvo as well so of course, we wouldn't have been able to see all of it - not a chance!

Anyways... Golden Gate Park is awesome. I can totally see myself going for runs there if I lived in San Fran and it would be so cool to go for a walk on a warm, sunny, beautiful Sunday morning as well! 

The park is massive and there's plenty going on in there... You've got the California Academy of Sciences, Conservatory of Flowers, the San Fran Botanical Garden, the Japanese Tea Garden and playgrounds for those who've got kids. 

The park is free obviously however attractions such as the California Academy of Sciences involve an admission fee. 

The park is truly beautiful and a must-see if you're in San Francisco so walk or rent a bike and explore it, it's a great experience!
author: Kevin S.

description: This is one of my favorite places on the planet. It's like being in a completely different place than the City of San Francisco. There are so many different experiences to have here, either going to art or science museums to getting lost on the many beautiful paths. You can see bison, flowers, art and beauty, for sure. I am blessed to be able to walk into it on any given day.
author: Kathy J.

description:
Golden Gate Park was an amazing stop on my trip to San Francisco. The weather was perfect today for a picnic and a nice stroll. 
In addition to the great weather, the park was nice and clean. I didn't see any trash or dog droppings on the ground. 
After my morning stroll, I went to the Japanese Tea Gardens. What a peaceful, tranquil, and beautiful place. The best part is Friday mornings are free admission to the public! What a bonus!
If you feel like getting your groove on, several people were doing tai chi in the park. It was fascinating to watch these people with long sticks and slow moves.
Later, I went to the California Academy of Sciences to see the aquarium and penguins. Some many fascinating creatures to see and learn about.
These are just a few stops in Golden Gate Park. There are a variety of fun things to do while visiting this amazing place.
author: Stella K.

description:
LOVE EVERYTHING ABOUT THIS PARK! 

Saw lots of ducks, geese, seagulls actually swimming and not harassing people (MINE MINE MINE), turtles, squirrels, OH and the squirrels are SO cute and not people-shy! I got some adorable shots of one who was playing peek-a-boo with me behind some tree branches. 

Tons of gorgeous flowers, cherry blossom trees galore, lush green grass perfect for picnic-ing, paths and trails to do some light hiking or power walking. You can rent single bicycles, tandems, bike-carts, paddle boats, rowboats. There is so much to do here. San Franciscans you are spoiled! If I was an SF resident, my doggies and I would be here ALL the time!
author: Pearl V.

description:
Lots to do for everyone, and a must see place in the city. Japanese tea garden was cool (a little over hyped, but still enjoyable). Also, you can go to the top of the art museum to get a good view for free. 
I hope to visit the science museum and go back to a lake we came across and get one of those pedal boats.
author: Matin F.

description: We have taken to stopping here and feeding the ducks during our last 2 visits.  The park is huge and one can easily spend an entire day there without seeing all of it.
author: Shawn T.

description:
Contrary to popular belief, not near the Golden Gate bridge.  However, this wonderful spot of natural greenery has its own claim to fame as one of the main places to visit in SF.  

In terms of the general layout, the actual park consists of an amphitheater at one end, a stretch of trees and fountains in the middle culminating in a statue at the other, encircled by a road for bikes and pedestrians.  On a good day you'll see plenty of tourists, skateboarders, seagulls, and tandem bicyclers.  Facing each other across the park is the Academy of Sciences musem and de Young Art museum, each of which I would recommend highly and could take up a day or more.  Behind the amphitheater is the bike rental place, and the four person bike I rented with my friends was largely serviceable but had a few glitches.  Lots of fun exploring the nearby trails.

Multiple flower gardens exist nearby, from the Japanese Tea garden (which costs money to enter and is to some degree worth it) to the Native Plants area to the Conservatory.  

The Golden Gate park also borders the Sunset district where a great selection of restaurants can be found, including Ebisu which is one of my favorites.

Parking is wherever you can find a spot on the street which can be kind of a hassle so practice your parallel parking skills.  If you choose to take an SF tour bus this is also one of the stops along the way.
author: Emily Y.

description: Golden Gate Park is 1.6 square miles of urban oasis. It includes a fancy art museum, a sketchy hippie hangout, an incredible atrium, the original 49ers stadium, a 9-hole golf course, an archery area, a frisbee golf course, a Japanese tea garden, over 80 geocaches, a phenomenal music festival every August and stellar views of the mighty Pacific Ocean. It's a very nice place to visit many times.
author: Nick K.

description:
Beautiful park. Make sure you take a few hours out of the day, as there is much to see. What we did was catch the free shuttle, which runs about every 15-20 minutes and has stops at most attractions. 

Make sure you take time to check out Stow Lake, you can rent a paddle boat here or you can hike the trails. Lots of wildlife and beautiful. 

There is food to be purchased throughout the park and plenty of restrooms. 

There was also a Segway tour, which we didn't do, it's more fun to explore yourself.
author: Nick G.

description:
This is so me.

http://whilstinsf.tumblr.com/post/35066265563/whenever-i-walk-through-golden-gate-park
author: Amy C.

description:
The 2011 AIDS WALK in SF just happened earlier today and I volunteered for it! It was tons of fun! I got to help unpack over thousands of granola bars, carry water around, recycle trash, and cheer people on! We had a great team today! we finished at 1pm which probably broke the record. 

The park is very green. It's such a clean place with different birds singing. The nature here is great! It's huge so there is a long trail for joggers. This park is also excellent for picnics and get togethers, etc. 

I would def return here for another event/picnic/free time.
author: Allister D.

description:
This is a gorgeous and ginormous park! You can easily get lost in this amazing park, so much to see and it's so serene and peaceful.. Like I said, easily get lost. :) 

I wouldn't know where to park though or how to get here.. I got here because I ran the SF Marathon, the 2nd half of it, and we run through the park for 6 miles. 

if I lived in the area, I'd always be here, to run, to relax, and to just be one with myself and nature.
author: Jimmy N.

description: Beautiful gardens, peaceful break from the city. The parks offer so many beautiful gardens to explore. Don't miss the Conservatory of Flowers!!!! Just amazing! Be aware that some of the gardens require an admittance fee.
author: Idaho Travelers S.

description:
You would think that after going somewhere more times than any other place during my childhood, I would be bored with it. But I can't get enough of this place. After ALL these years, Golden Gate Park still has that magic it had for me as a child. There was a period of time where my mom and dad took me here almost every day for the first 3-4 years of my life. 

At Stow Lake, I had my duck, seagull, pigeon, and cootie friends (eww, who has cooties? lol). I got to be fearless captain of a boat and lead a rampage across the high seas (of a lake). I had my very own special treehouse that I climbed. Years later I observed that the treehouse was not more than a 2 foot incline. I must have been REALLY small when I claimed the treehouse as my fort! In the last couple years, a bad storm took down my solid fortress and left us with just a dash of trunk. I was sad.

The magic continued at the *original* California Academy of Science. I can't even remember its previous name. My dad took me to visit every Tuesday! I loved going with him to look at all the various aquarium tanks which were much more spread out, the endless taxonomy (stuffed animal) exhibits that were designed as snapshots from the real world of nature and history, the dinosaur land which was a dream come true because we could climb on the rocks with the moving dinosaur models and it felt so real. And finally there was the planetarium, which didn't require call times and waiting in line. The pendulum blew my mind, how it would change "orbit" just so slightly and continue to adjust until it made a complete circle. Even though I went on at least 10 school field trips here, I never tired of it.

Then there were the Golden Gate Park Stables. These are no longer there, but I feel I must pay a tribute. I spent hours at this topnotch English riding academy every weekend and at summer camps. I helped out at camps for younger kids so I could get more riding lessons. There were amazing horseback rides that forged through the park to Ocean Beach. Beach rides are still relaxing and invigorating. My sense of smell adapted so that after awhile I couldn't tell that horses stank. Years later, I find myself becoming surprised when I can actually detect the smell of horses.

And I can't leave out the Japanese Tea Garden, Botannical Garden, and Conservatory of Flowers. All contributing to the stunning beauty of Golden Gate Park. It's impressive that a park that was 100% manmade is so gorgeous and can bring so many people peace and inspiration.

Thank you for all the memories, Golden Gate Park! You can count on me to keep coming back for more.
author: Denise L.

description:
The best park of San Francisco 
We live close to the park and is synonym of peace nature and walking. 
This huge park is clean, big and there are some great museum inside! 
It's really quiet and safe. 

My favorite activity is to walk around the lake it's romantic.
author: Laura B.

description:
Most of my cherished childhood memories come from Golden Gate Park. Especially the weekends, when my pops would take his bike out, and I would take mine out... and we just rode through the park, as father and daughter. So many people would come out in their bikes, roller skates, and doggies, to just move with joy. To be joyful and feel like nothing can ever go wrong. I felt so at ease, and had lots of fun biking with my pops.

Golden Gate Park has so many things to do. So many. There's the Japanese Tea Garden, the museum, the great huge playground, massive grassy areas for BBQ's and picnics, etc...

I don't think Oakland has a park that matches in size and wealth, in things to do, and beautiful scenic views, compared to Golden Gate Park. I find myself thinking a lot about my childhood in San Francisco, and so Golden Gate Park pops to mind. To be young and healthy... and carefree. To not have to worry so much, and be able to let go. That's what life's about... to be ABLE to FEEL FREEEEEEEEE! :P

Yea... I do miss my bike rides with my appah. Deep down, he has a good heart. Even when he does irk me, I can't stand the fact of other people disrespecting him... because he hurts too, and just wishes to be appreciated. Don't we all? Yea... Golden Gate Park and my father. I should learn to respect him more too, and not be so hard on him. After all, he would give up his life for his family.
author: Hannah Y.

description: Beautiful! The park is so big-it's hard to see all of it in one go. The landscaping is perfect manicured & easy parking!!
author: Katya N.

description: Spent a beautiful day with the husband this past weekend. What a lovely spot in the city. There's large spaces people use for picnics, bbq, playing with their dog, and weekend yoga I guess. There's a bunch of lakes you can wander off to as well. We went to Stowe Lake and it was just gorgeous. So many ducks and turtles to just stop and relax. There are so many paths to go off and wander. Will definitely bring the dog next time.
author: Jennifer T.

description:
Nature-iffic!  This massive park is the perfect place to spend a few hours on a gorgeous SF day.  To soak it all in, rent some bikes for a measly $8 an hour and maybe even break a sweat while you're at it.  There's a Japanese Tea Garden, lakes with quacking ducks and other cool things to see/ smell/ touch.

Great for:
+ Make-out sessions
+ Picnics
+ Running/ Biking/ Paddle boating
+ Kids
+ Old People
+ Dogs
+ Tree-huggers
author: Lorraine P.

description:
It's pretty much a given that the most iconic San Franciscan experiences have "Golden Gate" in their names. Every local I've encountered either suggests walking under the bridge and taking a stroll in the park. 

Golden Gate Park is not your typical lawn with a sprinkling of deciduous trees to which urban children have become accustomed. There are museums, bison, waterfalls, windmills, lakes, trails, gardens, statues, it borders the ocean, and it's completely accessible to anyone. 

Foggy walks in the Golden Gate Park, with all its greenery, are (along with foggy walks along the bay) my favorite things about San Francisco. I just absolutely love having views like this: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/KIVq5BlJKTipwtB3NATX0g?select=Y1XiK338MXZM_uNCzslOAw#LUC5J2IzrzFOrODNGSyShw
author: Christine A.

description: Golden Gate park is so awesome.  There's so much to see and do, that you need more than a day to check out all the cool stuff it had to offer.  If I lived nearby I would be here every weekend.  I wished we had time to check out the Japanese gardens, but it was that it miss out on the playground and the LO comes first.  Oh well, next time.
author: Rochelle R.

description: Awesome park.  Take the J-Judah here.  Lots of hiking from the Haigh Street to the Ocean.
author: Jeff J.

description: My favorite spot in San Francisco (on the 4 day trip to the city). Golden Gate Park is huge, beautiful, fun, full of things to do. If you visit San Francisco I highly recommend it. We rented bikes (I also recommend this move) and rode through the park (to the beach).
author: Rob K.

description: This is a beautiful park. We only got the chance to drive through, but it is beautiful. Lots of trees and lots of grass. It is huge! So many walking paths and so many other things! Give it a visit if you get the chance!
author: Tina S.

description:
Further proof that I DID NOT come to San Francisco ONLY to EAT! OK, ok...mostly, maybe.

Once again my son and daughter were enjoying life....."But honey, sweetie..."  http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/KIVq5BlJKTipwtB3NATX0g?select=au5BhKIIKqZO2o1eWzZ_5w "...you've been on the swings for like forty minutes.....and there's plenty of swings in LA....."

....but seriously, we're leaving now...daddy needs some bacon.
author: Cesar R.

description:
I came here a few weeks ago with my husband and 2 of our dogs. There is definitely a lot of places you can take your dogs to, and also places you are not allowed to take your dogs to (including the observatory and the walk ways near the observatory. These areas are marked). 

We spent about half a day here and really enjoyed our time, and we still didn't go through half of the park! This park is huge and also free (well there are admission fees for the museums that are here)! The backdrop with all of the lushness of mother nature is truly beautiful. This place kind of reminds me Balboa Park in San Diego, as it has a very similar set up. There really is plenty to see here at Golden Gate Park (also @ Balboa Park if you have never gone) and do.

Things that we did while we were at this park:

Watch lawn bowling- there is a lawn bowling club that meets here to play bowl and it is pretty interesting to watch the people play. 

Hike- Plenty of hiking trails throughout the park, with many easy trails to do. 

Take Photos- beautiful flowers, healthy green grass and large trees serve as the majority of the backdrop to our photos.

Play at the dog park- yes there is a dog park here where our 2 dogs had the opportunity to meet other 4 legged animals.

Have a small picnic- A ton of picnic tables throughout, but sitting on a rock or some grass would also do for a nice spot to get a snack or a quick bite to eat.

Overall, the park is pretty clean (free of dog poop & litter) and is an excellent place to spend an afternoon (or entire day). Really excellent in offering something for everyone.

By the way, there is also plenty of parking (FREE) all throughout the entire park.
author: Vic C.

description:
For my 1000th review, I have been waiting to review a place that is truly worthy of being such an important review.  Golden Gate Park is far beyond worthy.  It is the best park I have ever been to!

This park is incredible.  Stunning even.  Huge, beautiful, and full of so many activities!  You can either spend money by visiting places like the deYoung Museum, the Japanese Tea Garden (which is AMAZING), the Academy of Sciences, and more!  Or you can pay NOTHING and spend time walking through the gorgeous, expansive areas, fly kites (which we did!), have a picnic, or do some people watching (we happened upon a group of locals who were rollerskating and dancing to all kinds of disco, dance, and hip hop - too cool!).  There is a baseball field, an outdoor stage, an AIDS memorial, bike paths, etc!!  So much to do here whether you want to relax, be active, or take in the sights.  

This is easily a place you could spend an entire day - or weekend!  We unfortunately only had a few hours, but I had an amazing time here and I wish that we had had the chance to really dive deep into this park.   I am also bummed out that I missed the bison range!  Bison?  In the park?  Seriously will need to check this out on my next visit.  I love bison.

If I lived near here, I would come to this park every single day.  Unfortunately, Seattle is a little too far away..... :(
author: Sonya L.

description:
As a native San Franciscan, Golden Gate Park is an oasis of beauty. Sundays, when it is closed to traffic, feels like your own private garden. Walking, running, biking, skating; reading on a bench, observing. 

The one place that shields the crowded, constructed, busy-ness that has become the city. 

I'll never leave
author: JEANNE J.

description:
Most of my travels to San Fran are for work; therefore, I don't normally get to take off in the middle of the day and frolic in the park. However, when it's unusually sunny and warn in the city, it's nice to know that work people DO let you go outside to enjoy it.

After several trips to this fine city, I've discovered that there are certain neighborhoods that are consistently warm and sunny, while others are generally shady and cool. Golden Gate Park is probably somewhere in the middle. It was very sunny the other day, but also significantly colder than it was in the Mission. Considering the size of San Francisco, this is a little bit odd, but nothing that would keep me away from the park. Also, it was very cool to watch the fog roll into the park at around 5 pm... we don't see stuff like that in the Midwest!

Would love to come back and have a picnic or play Frisbee with friends, as this is a local gem for sure! Golden Gate Park - I'll be back!
author: Abby S.

description:
One of my favorite parks ever.  If I lived in San Francisco, I'd be here all the time.  It is huge!  People compare it to Central Park...I've been to both (I've run the entire circumference and through Central Park) and I like this one better (sorry NYC).  There are lots of gardens to visit (The Japanese Tea Garden should not be missed), along with attractions like the Academy of Sciences and the conservatory.

Go, explore.
author: Myia B.

description:
Beautiful and humongous park that offers a wealth of attractions: Japanese Tea Garden, paddle-boating, boating, Stow Lake, some museum, a botanical garden.  Those were the attractions I squeezed into one day, but I think there are even more available at Golden Gate Park.  Everything was pristine and immaculately clean - no admissions required to get into the park itself, but the individual attractions do sometimes charge.  Parking was very easy to find (I arrived around 10:30am on a weekday).

They're a 15-minute drive away from San Francisco so you're close to even more attractions if your day ends early, but you can easily spend an entire day inside Golden Gate Park.
author: Crystine W.

description: what's not to love about this park. From the people watching to the cool events held here, golden gate park always keeps it interesting and a tad weird. Love this place!
author: Amanda C.

description: A nice place!  Pretty and with a lot of variety of things to do.  Everything was unexpectedly closed when we visited though, and paths were not clearly labeled/defined.
author: Jenny C.

description: Beautiful big park with multiple things to do especially during the weekend when there are many people in it. I would recommend going before 10 am before everything comes there. There is parking near and around.
author: Rita S.

description:
This place is HUGE.  Check out the buffalo. They could care less about you, but when was the last time you saw buffalo? Exactly.

Many people don't walk this whole park, but my friends and I decided to give it a shot. It took a while, but we enjoyed a number of little things. There were all types of flowers in bloom and little trails you could take. The park also has mini trails, the museums like the California Academy of Sciences, equestrian center, a soccer field (kind of), gardens like the Japanese Tea Garden, and all sorts of things to check out. I had a ball out here and didn't even check out all the little things there are to do. It makes for a great walk, but remember to bring a jacket.
author: Mohib Q.

description: If I had to name my favorite part of Golden Gate Park it would be a hard choice. Perhaps it would just be that the park does exist. I can imagine my 19th century ancestors enjoying the park. I can picture my mother sitting in the Tea Gardens that she loved.  And I can always see myself enjoying the same places they did.
author: Terry T.

description:
Okay...reading other reviews and looking through the pictures for this MAGNIFICENT Golden Gate Park made me realize there was SO MUCH MORE to see. 

It is a beautiful place to just chill at whether you're biking, jogging, walking your dog, or just laying around. 

And for those of you into photography, I highly recommend this setting. The view is absolutely picture perfect. 

My friends and I have only touched on a little part of the whole area this past weekend. It is a beautiful place to be at with tons of walkways leading you to numerous different paths. It's like a wonderland for me. Everything seems very well taken care of, and it was not at all trashy and polluted to my surprise. 

We got to roll down the beautiful grassy hills together and raced across the field to the multicolored flower bush. It just felt so nice to be a kid again, even if it's just for a while. 

Did I mention it doesn't cost a thing?! Yeah. I know right. I've always believed in Eric Cartman's saying when he claimed that "everything fun cost at least $8." Well...I guess that's really not true now is it. lol

This place really helped me to appreciate nature and the great outdoors more.
author: Thanh B.

description: Another picturesque San Francisco setting, the massive park is home to miles and miles of walking trails, the Japanese Tea Garden, and Botanical Gardens. It would be quite easy to spend an entire day outside just walking though the bridges and pathways and enjoying the animals, plants and people watching.
author: Darren F.

description: We walked through here while visiting the De Young Museum.  It's a nice park, well kept with lots of trails and sidewalks. There are several things to do here as well,  from the museum, to the California Academy of Sciences, and even a Japanese Tea Garden. There is an on-site parking garage.  They also have an amphitheater, which looked like a great place to have events (such as weddings, plays, or concerts).
author: Robbie G.

description:
Off of only two experiences, this place seems like it really doesn't need too much of an introduction. 

I had only ventured inside once before this weekend to go to Outside Lands last fall (which was super epic btw). But now that I live directly across the street and it's too easily at my disposal I have no choice but to go and check it out on sunny weekend days. 

I gathered some friends up and we popped over to toss the football around, play some frisbee, and practice our handstand skills haha. It was great. 

Def a great place to go with a group of friends, crack open a few beers...or a bunch, and really just spend a few hours outside. 

There's so much to really tap into win the museums and various lawns and apparently wild bison?! All I have to say is wow. Ill def be frequenting GGP often.
author: Justyn W.

description:
Golden Gate Park is amazing. Just by looking at it on the map, you can see just how vast this collection of green spaces truly is. On our last morning in town, we started our day in Outer Sunset and sauntered into Golden Gate Park for a bit of a walkabout. 

The trees are magnificent. The different species and collections are really cool. You'd never expect to see such a great canopy collected in one area of SF, but its really awesome to walk under. I really loved all of the paths we found through the far end of the park we were in. It was absolutely gorgeous. Also, the crazy windmills were just fantastic to happen upon. 

Next up, I can't wait to visit the park zoo. I hear there are American bison. That's enough for me.
author: Benjamin G.

description: For the past three years I've been involved in the San Francisco Aids Walk at Golden Gate Park. There is no park that would be more perfect for this event. There are a lot of big grassy hills, a waterfall plus a bounty of different trees of all types that look like they were pulled from a painting. You can walk the park for hours and just be simply amazed at the beauty of nature. Bring a camera, because you won't want to stop taking pictures. They have food vendors on the path for the perfect bite on the go. Along with all the nature to look at you can also visit a variety of attractions that happen to be in the park. To name a few : The conservatory of flowers, The California academy of sciences, and of course the AIDS memorial grove, plus many other places that would make for an amazing day. It is a beautiful park in a beautiful city.
author: Jonathan R.

description: Not from SF but I had 3 hours on foot to spare and my only regret is not renting a bike and being able to see more. Started at the Japanese tea garden and holy cow this place. Had coffee at the darling little shop in there. Could've spent half a day there. There's nothing in this park not worth seeing. Easy enough to see it all on a bike in a day if you wanted to. Tea garden was amazing if I didn't say that. So great.
author: Tanna D.

description:
Biking around GGP was one of the highlights of my trip, it is massively massive, has beautiful paths for walking, wide fields for playing, a road network for driving/biking/busing, a conservatory, Windmills, a Japanese Tea Garden a freaking Bison grazing field and the list goes on and on! And to top it all off, your park trip can end at the Pacific coast where you can enjoy a great time at the beach! 

I highly recommend biking even if you are not a seasoned biker (it was my first time on a bike in 10 years) and I found it lots of fun, but do make sure you plan out your route first though because it can be easy to get your bearings right .

It's very convenient to get in and out of the park via public transit, it's close to great SF neighborhoods and has an Indian food truck if you get some cravings. 

I have to echo what many say and state that no trip to the city is complete without a trip to the park. You might want to stay away in the evenings since there is a larger than usual percentage of homeless people milling around.
author: Dishan W.

description:
So many secrets.

During the summer of love: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YzcKZOp_0iA

During the Indian summer: http://sf.curbed.com/archives/2014/07/16/from_bison_to_archery_mapping_25_secrets_of_golden_gate_park.php

We made it to almost all of them. Lakes, model yachts, bison, flowers, monuments and windmills were just a few things we saw. 

There are still so many San Francisco secrets to discover.
author: Jason B.

description: Love this park! Concerts and festivals and bbqs and picnics all years round! Walk around the academy of science of Deyoung art museum. Check out the Botanical gardens or the Japanese Tea garden or the Conservatory of Flowers or just go for a walk, a bike ride, a jog. I love this place. makes me feel good. I miss commuting to work through the park on my bike.
author: Aaron S.

description: Meh. Whatever. It's bigger than Central Park and it has more than a million hand planted trees, so why doesn't it show that crap off. Seems like a lazy park.
author: Loren G.

description:
The best park I have ever been too. It is so big in a bustling city that you can lost in here and totally forget your are surrounded by a major city. 

I was in the park while Outside Lands was going on and Kings of Leon was playing in the background. Such an amazing experience. I love almost everything about San Fran but this Park is probably top honors on my list.
author: Simon Leo N.

description:
Beautiful park in San Francisco.  I've driven through this park dozens of times, but I've only stopped here a couple of times.

The park is a large wonderful oasis located in the heart of San Francisco.  Kind of reminds me of Central Park in New York City.  There are some spots here that may get crowded and loud (especially on weekends).  There are other spots that are very quiet and serene.  There is something for everyone.  Playgrounds for the kids.  Picnic tables for enjoying family meals.  Trails for hiking.  Gardens to admire.  Just so much to see and do.

Lovely place to hang out and spend time with the family while in San Francisco.
author: PatrickJ T.

description:
I've had many memories here, being born and raised in San Francisco. Golden Gate Park is among San Francisco's beauty and treasure, with lush and diverse selections of plants. We even found some bamboos at some point of the park! 

The park is suited for many occasions: biking, outdoor sports, picnics, bbq, dates, photography, site seeing, ghost hunting, exploring, and much more! Yes and I have done all of the above. hehe

Urban Legend(s): There are two urban legends I know of for this park. One would be the lady who haunts Stowe Lake. She drowned her own baby and committed suicide there and now she haunts the park looking for her child. There's a statue with a lady holding two kids, some say if you gaze into the lady's eyes, she will move! There are different versions to the story but this is the one I heard. 

The other urban legend would be the phantom police car. Many cars have been followed by a police car but once they are about to leave the park, the car disappears. 

If you do decide to come here at night to explore, ghost hunt, or whatever, just be very careful. There are some creeps at night, my friends and I have experienced first hand one time. Luckily everyone was safe due to our strength in numbers. 

If you explore Golden Gate Park, you will also find some unique sites, such as the museums, man made water falls, statues, interesting architecture, and more. I found a Asian pavilion around Stowe Lake and it was cool. 

Overall, this beautiful park has all the recipe for fun but also mysteries and it's dark side.
author: Victor Q.

description:
This is a big ass park. Substantially bigger than both Prospect Park in Brooklyn, and Central Park in Manhattan. But size isn't everything. 

Or so my girlfriend tells me.
author: Peter D.

description:
GG Park is a lovely little (I mean big) oasis in the midst of the craziness and bum-piss-scented concrete jungle of SF.  I think my absolute favorite part of it is the Japanese Garden.  Unfortunately that thing is so full of tourists, especially on the weekends, it's difficult to get your zen on....but it's worth a look because it's beautiful anyway.

There are tons of trails for running and walking, and there's also the Academy of Sciences and the De Young museum (don't even think of doing a photoshoot there....those security guards will swoop down on you and chase you out).  Parking is a bitch but that's the reality of anyplace within SF limits.

Each May, the annual Bay to Breakers race meanders through the park on its way to the finish line at Ocean Beach.  Around Mile 5 when I'm starting to get bored (the novelty of naked weirdos and chicks in slutty Rainbow Brite costumes wears off real fast), I reinvigorate myself with the thought that at least in a little bit, I'll get to see some of the park grounds.  A little something to look forward to.
author: Heather K.

description: Wow. Just wow. The Golden State Park was truly an amazing and well worth it trip. The gardens were very nice, I love how as soon as you walk in, the entire world basically changes around you to accommodate the certain garden you are in. There are just so many different parks inside this one park you can spend an entire day here easily, maybe even a few days! If you go to the De Young museum you can go to the top of the tower and get absolutely beautiful views of the surrounding landscapes and city views. It was a wonderful area to walk around and explore. Between the De Young museum and California Academy of Science is the Music Concourse, it is stunning architecture. The day I went there, they had food trucks behind the concourse, I don't know if they do this regularly or just the day, but it was pretty cool. Also, they had a Twirl and Dip truck nearby, the ice cream was pretty good, check out my review of the truck if you want to know more. If you are visiting San Francisco, I would recommend coming here and strolling through the park. I'm from New York and I honestly can tell you this park is on the same level, if not, more beautiful than Central Park. Very clean!
author: Steven P.

description:
Another great day running through here. Hiking, walking, jogging through the park. It can be tiring going from one side to another but it feels good to be out and about. This is a great place for people who like being outside. So much to see and do .After all these years I never seem to get tired of this place.

Grab a bag of peanuts and some bread and enjoy some down time feeding the squirrels and ducks.
author: T C.

description: Park on any of the streets here at your own risk -- well-organized thieves abound! We parked less than 100 yards from the California Academy of Sciences yesterday and had any items of value out of sight and covered. When we returned to our vehicle 45 minutes later, the passenger door window had been broken out and items had been stolen. Even worse, we were 1 of 3 vehicles that had been broken into in a very short period of time! Closer inspection of Nancy Pelosi Drive revealed many piles of broken safety glass on the ground next to the road. A museum employee/volunteer walked by, shook his head and said, "I'm sorry; it happens all the time!" If this is such a well-known problem, why are there not more frequent patrols of the area? Why are no signs posted warning visitors of the danger? When we called the police to report the crime, we were told that a car wouldn't be dispatched and there would be no investigation because there was no homicide! What? We even visited the local police precinct office where we were told that even if we could trace any of our stolen items (ourselves, of course!), all the police could do would be to go to the address and ask if anyone there had our items (whatever happened to reasonable cause?) While we were there, another policeman came in whose garage had been burglarized. He told us that even if the perpetrator is caught, getting a DA to pursue the case is next to impossible. Moral of the story -- don't park on the streets of Golden Gate Park unless you are willing for items (especially electronics and jewelry) to be stolen and receive no help in their recovery
author: James F.

description: There is nothing better in San Francisco as GGP. There's just no more to say. Feast your eyes on green and beautiful.
author: Nicoletta K.

description:
Tons of homeless at the entrance! 

We waited across the street from the park at McDonald's until there was a good amount of people entering the park at once. You know, power in numbers... even though the numbers were made up of elderly and kids. While we were power walking/nearly sprinting past the homeless, they started acting up and screaming. It was like we were running through a gauntlet! It was so scary! Fortunately, they didn't haze... I mean approach us, and once we were in, it was smooth sailing from there. Lol.

Other than the rough entrance, I loved Golden Gate Park! I suggest planning a whole day because not only is the park HUGE, there is just so much things to see/do! In addition to the usual park activities (run, picnic, BBQ, play sports, rent a bike, lounge in the sun) there's a carousel, a windmill, archery, flower conservatory, random events (i.e. concerts), two museums, Japanese Tea Garden, man-made waterfall/lake where you can rent out a paddle boat... and bison range. WTF bison? Yes, I know. Did these majestic creatures once freely roam the park before us barbaric beings interrupted their beloved territory? Who knows, but they are there... just chilling, minding their own business, without a care in the world. Yup. Wish I could have touched the bison, but I'm pretty sure they aren't meant for petting. Lol.
author: A E.

description: Great place to come during the day for a walk, play with your kids at the playground or hang out or feed the birds. There's plenty to see! There are two museums on the property. Several playgrounds and running/walking paths.
author: Dorothy B.

description: Very fun park to walk around!  The park has a lot of beautiful areas and sub-parts, including the Japanese Garden, the Chinese garden, etc.  I visited the Japanese and Chinese gardens years ago with my family and loved the experience.  I visited Golden Gate Park again recently with a group of friends and we walked around (somewhat aimlessly).  We did get to check out a small lake with a ton of motorized sailboats, which was cool.  We also walked by the Bison reserve.  I was sad for the bison (being caged as they were, even though they have some room to roam around), but it was interesting to see them.  I had never seen bison so close up.  We also walked around some fields and past picnic areas before we realized it was time to head out, since our friends had to get to the airport.  I don't think we went to the most scenic areas of the park during my second time at Golden Gate Park, but it was still a very pleasant afternoon stroll.  I'd definitely recommend it, especially if you're trying to find some great tourist areas in SF!
author: Pegah Y.

description: Truly a fantastic place! A must visit especially on a Sunday when it's a car free day (no cars in the park).  Plenty to discover in such a HUGE pristine place.  You'll spend a whole day easy walking so put on some comfy kicks.  Just get here and you'll be amazed to find a jewel in the middle of the City!
author: Joel M.

description:
Stop #13 was our long trek to Golden Gate Park.  We had another beautiful day to enjoy being outdoors in San Francisco and we couldn't think of a better way to spend it than at a really nice park.  I live in Portland and we have some nice parks here, but nothing like this.  I'm really jealous.

This place is large so bring your walking shoes.  We walked about half of it and then waved down the free shuttle bus to take us to the end.  We saw signs for this service when we first entered the park, but didn't know if there were stops.  We saw one fly by us, but when we waved he stopped to pick us up.  That was a great thing.

If you get a chance to see the whole park, do take the bus to the end.  There are some cool windmills as well as the beach all the way at the far end of the park.  Well worth the extra effort on a nice day.
author: Dan H.

description: Golden Gate Park is beautiful, but my previous sentiments still remain. Although no park has impressed me more than Central Park, I will say GGP is probably the most impressive park on the west coast. On my most recent visit, we entered from Lincoln and 9th Ave, after lunching at Park Chow. We walked through Shakespeare Garden and the Music Concourse between the de Young museum and Academy of Sciences, trekking our way across to see Stow Lake. The park is filled with wildlife, from (my favorite) squirrels, gigantic bumblebees, to a ton of various types of birds.
author: Ivy W.

description: Huge, gorgeous park with plenty to see and do. I've visited the grounds three times in recent memory, walked through a rose garden, went to a museum, sat under a tree with friends to people watch and have a picnic. I don't quite remember what the parking situation was like, but it's possible to get there by public transit or taxi without too many problems. I look forward to exploring more when I'm in San Francisco again!
author: Christel L.

description:
Golden Gate Park - best park in the city. 

Living in Nopa, GG park is only a few minutes away and it's a great luxury to have. On a sunny day in the city, there's just no better place to be to hang out with friends and enjoy the weather. 

Beyond that, there's just so much to do here that it never gets old: 

Great for biking, as you can take the bike path from the beginning of the park (Stanyan and Fell St) all the way to the beach. 

Great for running, especially on Sundays, when all of the entrances of the park are blocked off to thru-traffic so you can run wild in the streets without fear. 

Outdoor attractions like the Japanese Tea Garden, Botanical Gardens, Stowe Lake, and The Bison Paddock (well kinda...)

Cultural attractions like The de Young Museum and The Academy of Sciences.

Nearby Restaurants: Beach Chalet, Jenny's Burgers, Pacific Catch, Kezar Pub.

Only thing to be careful of: Don't wander around here too late, there are certain parts of the park that get a little creepy at night that I wouldn't suggest wandering around at night.

Overall there's just so much to do, it's never gets old. One of my favorites parts of the city hands down.
author: Brian S.

description: One with nature. One with yourself. This place is so huge that it will take days to really see the entire park and embrace nature for what it's worth. I love how the park is divided into different areas depending on the mood you were in. We loved it so much that we drove there twice, walked around once, and took pictures with the bison! Yes, there is a Bison Park! Had to break suddenly because I didn't believe it for myself!
author: Angelie D.

description:
Loved this place! We cudnt see much in the limited time we were here. But whatever we cud cover was great! 

The Japanese tea garden is a lovely place. They have a small Japanese style cafe there. The tea sandwiches and miso soup was good. Cudnt try anything else.

The stow lake is very picturesque. Walking distance from the tea garden. We spotted a lobster and an OWL!! 

There are tall trees everywhere. We were supposed to cover the California academy of science but we got there late and would not have been able to cover it all. So that's next on our list when we come back here.

We could see people riding on their bikes. There are rentals available too and in adorable 4 seaters too!

The parking is one major problem but we cud find a spot on the road next to stow lake.

Please don't forget to carry tissue papers as the restrooms run out of them by the end of the day.

Will come back here soon.
author: Gangotri P.

description:
This is an ENORMOUS park, perfect for a day hike/walk, team sports, frisbee, a picnic, a day beerfest, whatever floats your boat.

Sure, there's Dolores, but here, you can escape the mounds of hipsters you have to crawl over to get a space to lie down in the sun. 

You enter the park and immediately smell the fresh GREEN of all the trees and plants. It's probably one of my favorite spots in SF, just because it's so massive and spacious. I've only explored a small part of it, so I can't say much about the rest of it, but I'm sure there are a million things to do here.

I basically just beach whaled out in the sun here:)
author: Ellie W.

description:
Most of my reviews are hundreds of words long, so I'll make this one simple. 

This park is big, beautiful and there is tons to see and do. 

If you have kids, they'll love it
If you have dogs, they'll love it
If you like to exercise, you'll love it
If you like lakes, you'll love it
If you like big statues, you'll love it
If you like wildlife, you'll love it
If you like flowers, you'll love it

In short, you'll love it
author: Craig R.

description: Wish we had some more time to explore this park with our son... Had a brief visit with the buffalo, and the little lake where they had the remote controlled boats.  Probably a lot of cool little corners to explore over many many days!
author: Steve L.

description:
It's a must!!

There are some bike rentals so I really recommend riding your bike through this place for better experience. It's a huge park - usually takes more than 30 minutes for me to ride it through casually. But it's so beautiful!

Remember to get there late morning or early afternoon because it does get foggy and cold around 3pm.
author: Yuki A.

description:
There are so many great museums, park space, gardens, etc. here that it's hard to imagine anyone NOT loving Golden Gate Park. Seriously, there is something for everyone. From the science museum, art museum, Japanese tea garden to all the beautiful, lush open space for jogging, walking your dog, or just having a picnic, this is truly an amazing place. There are also various food carts as well. 


Their botanical garden is one of the biggest that I've ever seen. The space is so spread out that we observed people laying out, playing badminton and having picnics within the actual garden. It's just a small fee to go in, (you also get a discount if you're a student)  and it's totally worth it! The garden is separated into sections according to the geographic origins of the plants. It's an extremely beautiful and peaceful place to chill.
author: Evonne L.

description:
The only thing cooler than the Golden Gate Bridge in SF is Golden Gate Park.

In Kansas City we have a mega-park (Swope) that houses a Zoo, an outdoor amphitheater, etc.  So too in another city of my love, Saint Louis (Forest).

Golden Gate Park is a crown holding a bunch of SF's jewels. 

Museums, gardens, fountains, open spaces, festivals.  Yeah, awesome.
author: Stephen H.

description:
Golden Gate Park is great! Lots to see, and a perfect way to get away from the hustle and bustle of urban San Francisco. It's a vast park with something for everyone! There are lots of grassy fields - perfect for a picnic on a sunny day or for that lively ultimate Frisbee match!

The California Academy of Science is also here, with a few other museums, a Japanese tea garden, and a large auditorium in a large plaza. The down side: it's pretty pricey to enter all of these areas. Up side: there are free days where you can visit for free! I was really eager to look around the Tea Garden, but I was turned off by the plethora of people in the garden. There's basically no room to move, and the ambiance is completely ruined! I'd love to go on an off day, just to admire the garden without the masses of tourists crowding the place! Oh well...

I love Golden Gate Park just to get away from the city. To enjoy the quite moments in life alongside nature! Good stuff!
author: Kevin J.

description:
BEST. PARK. EVER.

There is too much to do here! I can't possibly see everything and yet I still make an attempt to do so =) Whether you are a local or a tourist, this park is not to be missed!
author: Sam F.

description: Over impressed with the activities offered here. I had added it to our itinerary on a whim, and it became one of the most impressive parts of the trip. The sound silos provided the group great entertainment as each herd each other sing. The tower was awesome to climb up. The forests and the gardens were impressive, and the botanical gardens were worth every penny. I appreciated so much here and would highly suggest it for anyone who appreciates nature even a little bit.
author: Shawn L.

description: This has to be one of the best parks that I have visited in the entire world, not only is it historic and a bay area staple, but it's one of the few places in California that is known worldwide (Hippie Hill/Janis Joplin Tree). This is one of the only parks that I know of that has something going on every day of the year, whether it's a fair, festival, or museum tour. You could come here everyday of the week for 2 weeks and you still wouldn't be able to discover every hidden nook and crannie in this park. Most of my visits here are a simple outing with my kids, we hike, we eat, we play, and it always consumes our full day, they love it. When I come without them, it's usually for a festival, I always visit 420 fest and Hardly Strictly Bluegrass, both free and lots of fun. If you come here, visit every museum at least once, and snap plenty of photos, no two visits will ever be the same.
author: Joseph A.

description: In many ways as another Reviewer noted, Golden Gate Park will remind you of Central Park in New York.   Beautiful, fun with lots to see and do.   Biking, jogging, picnicking or just walking.  There's gardens, and the special California Academy of Sciences.    BUT at the same time always be aware of yourself, your belongings and your surroundings.   Have fun visiting all the special places the park has to offer, just use common sense.   The park really is lovely and worth a visit.
author: Sandra Q.

description: Wow!  Can't believe I lived on the Bay for so long, but never made it to Golden Gate Parl until now.  So huge, so green, so peaceful.  The Academy of Science, Japanese Tea Garden, the trees, the air, the paths to ride your bike on or stroll.  The perfect place to go on a sunny day.  Bring a cost as the breeze from the ocean can make it feel cold fast.
author: Amanda M.

description:
Golden Gate Park is, for a lack of a better word, awesome!

I know that when you think of San Francisco's gloomy weather, it's a bit difficult to picture yourself in a gorgeous park with sunny weather. Well, Golden Gate Park offers you just that.... except maybe not in the sunny bit.

But what Golden Gate Park fails to give you in sunshine-y days, it offers back 10x as much in the "charm" department. 

~ Visit the gorgeous lakes and even take a rowboat or pedalboat out!
~ Bicycle rentals including tandem bikes for the family.
~ Beautiful oriental temple.
~ Gorgeous miniature waterfalls.

And best of all, most of the time it's not even ultra-crowded so you can definitely find peace and quiet here. This used to be one of my favourite spots to meditate and it still would be if I hadn't moved to the beautiful Australian city of Melbourne. 

What a terrific place! If you haven't visited Golden Gate Park yet, what are you doing?! Take a stroll, walk your dog, etc etc!
author: Clarissa Y.

description:
For my 100th review, I wanted to make sure it was extra special to mark the exciting event (for myself). I thought about it for a looong time with multiple reviews in my draft folder and finally decided this park deserved the honor. 
Yes- excuse the fog overcasting its love for the sunset on most days but on those rare and beautiful sunny days- GGP is absolutely gorgeous. Fresh, CLEAN air with nature all around. I love starting my mornings with a chill run through this park- fog or sun. If you're not a runner, all good too because you can visit museums, people-watch, walk a dog, frolick through the fields, or even paddle-boat at stow lake. This park has it all.
author: Patricia K.

description:
Now this is what I call a great park. From young to old, hippies to runners and athletes, you will find everyone doing something they like in this park without being bothers.
There are couple of different cool museums inside the park that attracts more people, there's 2 lakes I believe In here and lots and lots of trees which is my favorite. Big old trees and fresh green grass all around which brings in the fresh tropical air :) oh me oh my!! Haha
Lezzzz go back yall
author: Zeenna K.

description:
I can't believe I've lived in the Bay practically my whole life and have never been to Golden Gate Park! My friend suggested we go exploring one Saturday and I was totally down since I've never been (my first time at Twin Peaks as well... what's wrong with me?!?). Anyways, this park is gorgeous and there is so many different areas to walk around. Is so cool to see so much green in the middle of the city! Golden Gate park is HUGE! We went to the Shakespeare Garden (they only grow flowers mentioned in his books - how cool is that??), Stowe Lake to paddle boat and exploring Strawberry Hills. 

It's such a nice and relaxing place to go to. I heard there's some hiking paths as well. And it's a great place to just hang out and read a book or have a picnic.

I can't wait to come back next time to explore the rest of it!
author: Sophia Y.

description: Such an incredible place, in the middle of an incredible city. This is a must visit for tourists and a great place for SF/Bay Area natives to spend some time. You could easily spend days here, exploring the various trails, visiting the California Academy of Sciences, deYoung Museum, Botanical Gardens, Japanese Tea Garden, etc., hanging out with the bison, grabbing drinks and lunch at Park (or Beach) Chalet... Seriously, the options are extensive. The public restroom near the stadium was surprisingly nice. I also did a 5K Fun Run here (Awesome 80s) and am doing another next month (Hot Chocolate). Needless to say, I welcome the opportunity to spend more time at Golden Gate Park!
author: Emily J.

description:
Beautiful and clean. Definitely not a place you can take in all in one day. Maybe a weekend. Or maybe if you rented a bike to cruise around or take that Segway tour. 

I've been to the science center a few years ago and remember how enormous the place was. This trip was just a casual stroll around one of the lakes and around the stage area and fountains. 

Will come back and soak in more of the sun and traverse the landscape some more!! I think a picnic would be PERFECT here!!
author: Sarah M.

description:
Golden Gate Park was nearly in my backyard where I grew up in the Inner Sunset District near Lincoln Way. I did not miss a game at Kezar Stadium (1965 -1970) in the park when the San Francisco 49ers played there. Does anyone remember getting a free ticket by clipping off a coupon from a Christopher Milk carton? I also learned how to play golf at the Golden Gate Park Golf Course. It was also cool to see the Jefferson Starship and the Grateful Dead perform together for free at Lindley Meadows in 1975. Worked at the Boathouse at Stow Lake and learned how to cast for fishing in the park. The California Academy of Sciences admission was free up to the early 70's and remember the alligators not moving for hours with coins on top of them. A good way to protect money. 

On Saturdays, immigrant men from Greece (including both of my grandfathers or papou in Greek) used to play Pinochle (and gamble!) in the park to escape from their wives for a few hours near Hippie Hill. The hippies chased most of them out in the late 60's. The hippies moved on to be "The Establishment" today.  Kezar Stadium was demolished and replaced with less seats for football and track meets.

I still enjoy buying popcorn at the Boathouse at Stow Lake and feeding the ducks. The island on the lake is called Strawberry Hill and offers great views of "The City" at the top.

Big Rec, near Seventh Ave. and Lincoln Way, has two full sized baseball fields and had indoor/outdoor racquetball courts. I used to play handball there which is similar, but gloves were used instead of racquets.

I had a secret way to get into the park at 15th Ave. and Lincoln Way where a gate was installed but not locked. The Botanical Garden is located inside the fence and offered fast access to the Japanese Tea Garden, de Young Museum, and the rest of park. 

I recently suffered a medical condition and was told by the doctor to walk at least a mile a day. I started my rehab by walking around Stow Lake which brought back memories. Thomas Wolfe, an American short story writer and novelist, once said "You can't go back home to your childhood." Wolfe apparently had never visited Golden Gate Park in his youth.
author: John S.

description:
What kind of loser writes a Yelp review for a park? This loser!

It's my 300th review and while I could share my razor sharp insights regarding my local drugstore or mall, it's nice to occasionally branch out and review something different and more...wholesome.

My first experience was around 6 years ago when I ditched a course in DC for the weekend to go visit my little sister in San Francisco. A picnic in Golden Gate Park was kind of one of the highlights! We weren't dining on caviar (gross) and champagne, but I felt like I kind of belonged in the city. We chatted and lounged on the grass near some water, just watching the world go by. It was joyful.

Fast forward a few years and I'm back to SF but this time for the little (grown up!) sister's wedding. We were staying in an apartment in the Richmond by the park and she was getting married there.

You'd think that it was kind of risky to go back. Things are never as wonderful as you painted them in your memory. Except GGP. It's an oasis in the city. I ran there every morning and it was just blissful. I really felt like I was miles away from everyone else. You get to hear the birds, run on trails, explore new areas, run around lakes, smell the flowers. I ran further than usual just because I was actually enjoying what I was seeing!

It's ridiculous how much there is to do too in a way. The carousel, the de Young, Science Museum, Japanese  Tea Garden, Botanical Gardens...days of activities. Or just do nothing. Sit on the grass and make daisy chains. Stare at a lake or fountain. Watch people do an exercise class while you luxuriate. 

The little one got married in Fuchsia Dell. It's not the manicured wedding venue some would go for and was therefore perfect. It was pretty, natural, a little bit private and extremely special. GGP will forever hold a special place in my heart because of that day, and also because of the peace I felt each time I entered through the gates.

Tips:
It's easy to get lost if you don't head straight across using the cross roads. I did a lot of running in the wrong direction!
As we discovered on the day of the wedding, it can be very very difficult to get parking inside the park on a Saturday. The carousel is great for photos...but you might have to sort out a drop-off plan
author: Grainne M.

description:
This is seriously an incredible park, perhaps the best one I have ever been to. I live in San Diego and am exposed to Balboa Park and if you've ever been there, you know it supersedes Central Park in New York.

However, I will have to say this park is better than balboa park on the arguments that there are more people participating in this park. Here there is more energy, more life, more community, and more imagination instilled into this park.

The park is so vast, one day is not enough to enjoy it. 

The people are welcoming, engaging, and excited to be involved in their community.

Next time, I'm bringing toys to share at the park :)
author: Matthew M.

description:
Holy guacamole, this is a big park.  I knew it was long, and I think my map was not quite to scale because we came in at the Sunset Blvd entrance and walked to the Equestrian area in what seemed like no time, but then we tried to walk from the bison paddock to the 19th Ave access and we just about died.  I think the hills surprised me.  I don't know what I was expecting.  The park is much "wilder" than I imagined it, I guess?  Way more big cypress trees and woods than I had pictured.  I think, based on what I could tell was there from Google maps, that I thought the park would be all short grass, well-manicured and easily walked.  

I should have listened to those who said "rent a bike!"  Though with the hills, and being out of shape, the bike might not have been much easier.

We only saw a tiny smidgen of what this park has to offer, and I'd love to go back and see all the cool stuff at the east end that we missed!
author: Johanna K.

description:
Pros:
- huge forrest-y nature in a bustling city
- a TON of activities here: picnic, free concerts, paddle boating, Outside Lands, museums, etc.
- large enough that you can't explore the entire park in just one day
- good for locals and tourists!
- gorgeous on a sunny day
- larger than Central Park, NY
- dog friendly

Cons:
- freezing cold. The moment you step foot in the park, the weather seems to change drastically
