- a bit too large, at times. It takes forever the traverse the entire park
- difficult to find parking when there are large events at the park

Bottom line: I don't go out of my way to visit, but when I am here, I have a good time enjoying the nature. But, make sure you bring a light jacket!
author: Jiann M.

description: Beautiful park with so many things to see & do. This park is huge so I only saw part of it while in San Francisco but they had the museum and other art outside as well as a beautiful little waterfall and lake such a nice place for picnics hikes or just to relax.
author: Elizabeth G.

description:
This park is pretty big so be ready to spend a day here! I was only able to walk by the huge Green House, the small rose garden , the beautiful Japanese tea garden, and somewhere in the middle with lots of fountains (made a wish) and a Greek stage where performers were putting on a show. 
I know there is a carousel somewhere but didnt see it. Very beautiful for picnics, photos and to enjoy a walk.
author: Harlow H.

description: Even in the pooring rain I loved this place.  It's HUGE and there is lots to do here.  I didn't see any of the outdoor attractions like the Japanese Tea Garden but there are lots of indoor things to do like the California Academy of Science and the deYoung Museum.  On a sunny day you could easily spend a day here just wandering around and enjoying all the park has to offer.
author: Julia D.

description: San Francisco is awesome to have this amazing park that stretches for miles in a city that is known for its craziness. We love this park, especially when have 2 young boys under 5 years old. We like being around the museum area and exploring the many walking paths. There are public bathrooms...if you know where to find them :-). This place is so nice on a sunny day. We like going there on a weekday to avoid the large crowd. There are food trucks and a food stand if you go their early enough...I believe before 4pm. It's a must for anyone who just wants to relax or to explore the walking paths.
author: Phi N.

description: So impressed by this park. I am blown away by the feelings that I feel while driving through/and also walking through this place. It is heavenly and gorgeous. They have done a fabulous job with the upkeep. My husband and I live about 6-8 hours away. I wish I lived closer so I can visit this place more often. I'd also love to run or bike through here one day as well.
author: Summer S.

description: I'm so grateful to have the beautiful golden gate park in the city.... So many things to do.
author: Dulmaa Bor R.

description: Who in the Jesus wouldn't give this place five stars? It's the best park in the world! IN THE WORLD!!! It's huge: bigger than Central Park by more than 100 acres. It's diverse: two museums, a carousel, a golf course, a disc-golf course, a horseshoe court, an archery range, a boathouse, meadows, playgrounds, lakes and botanical gardens with plants from 6 of the 7 continents, and that's just scratching the surface. It's safe and accessible: plenty of parking for people coming by car, wide, safe lanes for bicyclists, a hundred miles of footpaths for walkers, free shuttle buses. I could go on and on. Just know that if you live in San Francisco and don't make regular use the park, you are doing yourself a severe diservice
author: Eli H.

description: The most striking city park I've ever seen. Loads of potential, if it were done slightly differently.  Heat lamps and semi-permanent tents would make for great outdoor theater in the sunken garden. Not enough cozy (and safe) nooks for taking a breather or reading a book. The Japanese tea garden should be expanded and the visitors sparced out.  Also, the teas should be more fun and better quality.
author: Van X.

description:
I wish I could give this place 100,000 stars

From the windmill to the panhandle and every nook and cranny in between, Golden Gate Park is an urban oasis. Some of the trails are so secluded that you might think you're in the middle of a forest, but you never have to worry about getting lost because you're never too far from civilization.

There are ducks, blue birds, coyotes, and bunnies.  Oh, and who could forget our precious bison! 

The Polo Field is pretty neat, it has a 70s par course/work out stations all around. I used to go on all of them, until I developed a fear of insects. 

Sometimes after a long hectic day in the city, there's nothing better than walking off the beaten path and listening to the birds chirp and admiring the beauty and sent of countless trees and flowers.
author: Wanda M.

description:
I really like this park. However it always seems to be a nightmare to get parking or we have only a brief amount of time in which to try and see what we can.

I need to get back here for a whole day and really take the time to explore it. We had planned to once before when we took a tour of the city but there had been issues getting there due to the bay to breakers race!
author: Sarah K.

description:
There are so many things to say about this place! I live right across the street from the park so needless to say, I'm here a lot. Great spot for nature photos, taking a walk to cool off from an argument with your boyfriend (is this just me?), walking your dog, afternoon picnic, eavesdropping on a concert, and GEOCASHING!

Anything you want you can find inside this gigantic park. Concerts, soccer fields, Frisbee golf, cement slides, pottery studio, archery, etc. the possibilities are endless.

Just some advice, it's usually pretty cold, so don't forget to wear layers. There's really something to do for everyone.
author: Mindy T.

description: I lived in New York for the past ten years and have always been a fan of Central Park, but, after a recent visit to Golden Gate Park, I'm in love with Golden Gate Park now, too. Beautiful park with a lot of open space. What I love the most about the park is that you really feel like you are escaping from the city - Central Park, although, beautiful, is, unfortunately, surrounded by towering skyscrapers, so you never really get to feel like you're out of the city. Great place to take a stroll - my fiance and I took our dog to Golden Gate Park this past weekend and we had a wonderful time! WIsh that we could have spent more time in the park, but, street parking was expensive! Will definitely be back to check out the rest of the park!
author: Irene L.

description:
Parking around here was tough but be patient.  It's a really nice park to walk around and the De Young Museum has a tower which gives a nice view of the city for $10.  The outside design of the museum is interesting to learn about and how they modeled it after nature.  

One can easily kill a few hours at the various Museums and such the park offers.  I only went to one section of it but I am definitely going back.
author: Kenneth H.

description:
There is so much to see and do at Golden Gate Park. You could easily get lost in this sanctuary for hours. First there's the places you must pay admission to visit, The deYoung Museum, Japanese Tea Gardens, California Academy of Sciences and Conservatory of Flowers, among others. Some of them worth the price of admission, (Japanese Tea Gardens) to others that aren't exactly worth the full admission price. Especially when they often offer deals for certain days.

The real beauty of Golden Gate Park is when you drive into it's serene wooded entrance (or walk if that's your thing), it feels like you're instantly transported from the hussle 'n bussle of The City. It's an oasis within my favorite city in the country. If I were an SF resident, I could easily find a way to waste many a day here.

Golden Gate Park is especially memorable for me since it's the place I spent my first date with my great love. Exactly one year ago today, on 05/31/12 she changed my life with this one singular day in the park. We went from being friends to something much more meaningful, and everlasting. Just laying there on a blanket talking and holding each other is a moment I will never forget. I wish we had brought a picnic because we spent nearly the entire day there. Although this wasn't the original plan, it just worked out to be that way, losing track of time in each others arms. It shows you how easily you can spend an entire day here, yet not even notice the time flying by.

If you ever have the chance, do visit during the pre-daylight hours. The place is eerily quiet with a Silent Hill type fog rolling through. Now I see why the majority of the bums in SF like to call this place "home". After spending yet another day in the park with the woman of my dreams, I returned extremely early the next morning. I thought she had lost her watch here while we were horsing around. I couldn't sleep while thinking about it and the fact it might be my fault. I woke up early, hopped in the car, and drove back here to look for it. When I arrived around 5am it was quiet and beautiful. There were very few people out except for a cyclist and a runner or two. I didn't find what I came here for but I found a new appreciation that I would drive 45 mins away to look for something for someone only because I knew how much it meant to them. It was a small price to pay for the chance to put a smile on her beautiful face. Even with the scant chance I might find it in the dark while wandering around with a flashlight. In the end, I found the watch a few months later behind the bed when I was cleaning. I still laugh when I visualize it hiding there the whole time. I'm still, happy I drove here as I was able to see the park, as well as myself & my babygirl in a whole new light.

We'll be back here soon as the park holds several great memories for us. It also contains many things left unexplored, and I'm looking forward to many future visits to discover all the wonder it contains.
author: John B.

description: Love coming here and walking the different trails! Also recommend sitting by the lake and waterfalls is definitely relaxing especially under the shade!  Came here recently for a wedding and it was beautiful :-)
author: Elle C.

description: Golden Gate Park is huge and it's such a great park! There is always something to do and it's a nice place to relax. I love coming here and I don't come here enough!
author: Vanessa S.

description: Lovely. I loved the trees, the birds and all the photos I was able to take. Absolutely beautiful. A plus is that you can rent a paddle boat nearby.
author: Heather S.

description:
It's a lovely park with allot of things to see either going to the De young museum,  California academy of science,  gardens either in the Japanese tea garden, Shakespeare garden,  and finally walking to the beach

There's a big area for kids for all ages too
author: Alex W.

description: San Francisco's saving grace.  So much of the city is treeless and ugly, I don't know how its residents could survive without this beautiful place.
author: Lisa V.

description: This is one of the reasons why San Francisco is my favorite city. There are so many things to see here - but the out of the way place to see if the Bison Paddock. http://sfrecpark.org/destination/golden-gate-park/the-bison-paddock/. Located west of Spreckels Lake along John F. Kennedy Drive - Zoo staff take care of the animals and Park & Rec staff maintain the enclosure.
author: CJ L.

description:
We went to Golden Gate Park on a Sunday because we had read that on Sundays the park is closed off for bicycles.  Unfortunately, we didn't read the fine print.  It's closed off only in one tiny section of the park.   And the rest of the park contains highways.  Yes, locals use it to cut through to other streets.  

Bikes are not welcome on the sidewalks.  Bike lanes are not provided.  Cars are parked on either side of some streets, allowing for narrow to no shoulders.  Cars are driving by at 55 mph.  How exactly is this park bike-friendly?   

The park itself does have some interesting places to visit -- museums, a flower conservatory, etc. which we didn't get to.  I loved the tranquility of the AIDS Memorial Park.  The park also provides access to the Pacific Ocean where you can (once you cross the busy street), ride your bike along a path next to the beach area.  

I guess I was picturing something totally different from what I read about in the guidebooks, though, and that was a put-off.  I pictured something along the line of Central Park in NYC that's totally blocked off to traffic where bikers can ride safely throughout the entire park.  I didn't enjoy dodging cars and white-knuckling it.  I probably wouldn't rent bikes here again, but I would check out the other areas of the park that I missed.
author: Eric K.

description: What an amazing place to explore while in SF. We did so by bicycle. The fresh air, the trees, the flowers in bloom. So much to see and so much to do that you would need a few days to experience all that GGP has to offer. So plan ahead because certain venues are open on certain days and bring walking shoes, some snacks, and water to give you the energy you will need to see the sights.
author: Loren M.

description:
This park, along with Central Park in NY, makes me wish that my hometown of Seattle had something similar. There's tons to do here and it's all contiguous so you can stroll for miles and miles and keep experiencing something new.

There's a lake, the ocean, ball fields, lawn bowling, bike and walking trails, tennis courts, botanical gardens, performing halls, etc.  Pretty awesome, esp. being right there in the city.

My only complaint, SF, is the lack of garbage cans. Seriously, do you just want me to throw my trash on the ground?
author: Joshua B.

description:
You can't be in San Fran without visiting the Golden Gate Park.  There is PLENTY to see and do.   The park is ginormous!  It's great to bike, run, walk, or cruise in. 

Great for the day or night.  Great to hang out with friends, for a date night, or to fly solo.
author: Linda Y.

description:
Beautiful park! There are so many things to do here. Go for a nice walk/jog, get lost on the trails, take a nice boat ride around the lake. Played the 'Which way should we go?' game with my friend when we visited and got lost along the trails near the lake for about an hour. It was great! Hah.

Parking was easy along the streets/driveways in the park.

I spent a very nice and relaxing afternoon in the park and loved every part of it. What a great way to say HELLO SAN FRANCISCO!
author: Kevin C.

description: Full of history, we passed through this park on the way to the Golden Gate Bridge. It is beautiful and huge. It feels like your in the mountains (somewhat) even though your near the ocean. Next time I'll spend more time here and take a few pictures!
author: Joshua W.

description: Love the flower scape on strawberry hill. Wild flowers abound as do the butterflies that seek their nectar. Try around 4pm.
author: Kelly K.

description: So now i see why everyone loves San Francisco the place is just magical the bridge the surroundings are incredible.  Like I always say if we are so blessed to live in CA its paradise.
author: Armen G.

description:
Yelp 100 Challenge * 91/100

Monday afternoon, I had my binoculars dangling from my neck, a map of the city in my hands and a handy dandy compass, all ready to venture out to San Fran. Stepped into BART, got off at Glen Park and took the bus up the Park. 

This adventure happened on what any Las Vegan would expect to be a typical 100 degree July day but first-timers, beware, San Francisco summer is equivalent to wintertime in Vegas so bundle up. I went up there with a jacket on and two thinner layers beneath it. Fog blanketed our uphill journey by bus and visibility was low. Rain began to drizzle and temperatures plummeted down even further. I asked around for directions and this one lady on the bus pointed where the bike rentals were on my map.

By the time I got there, it was already 5pm and the rental place told me that they stopped their service at 5:30pm. So instead of going back, I explored the park on foot. The California Academy of Science and the de Young Museum were already closed and the fog was so low, I could hardly see the street signs. Therefore, I had to make use of whatever was in my hands to navigate my way through the park. The Botanical Gardens were also closed but one attraction remained open, and I'm glad it did - The Japanese Tea Garden.

Peaceful zen and all too familiar beautiful Asian scenery kept me in the Gardens for nearly an hour. Bonsai trees were delicately shaped, koi fish swam alongside the well-trimmed trees, pagodas stood tall and rock bridges connected pavements through the ponds. For $7, I would go back again. Sure I didn't see any birds that day nor did I get to check out the museums but simple things like feeding squirrels and making wishes with pennies made this trip worth it.
author: Kirstie M.

description:
I wish I had more time to explore seeing how big the park is. There seem to be quite a few interesting attractions like the museum, the Buffalo Paddock, and the Japanese Garden (which we couldn't find) and people (like the lady on something fun, chasing after her mug that she's holding in front of her, crazily up the street and the man in the Dick Tracy outfit hiding behind a bush, then swiftly sneaking his way behind another bush). 

I really appreciate the history of the park and how it has held up through many of San Francisco's generations. It's nice to see people jogging early in the morning and families picnicing and playing games.  Dogs are out on walks, prancing about happily. It feels so ideal, how a park should feel on a cool summer morning. I look forward to coming back in the future to explore the vastness of Golden Gate Park.
author: Alison M.

description:
Believe it or not, this place is bigger than New York's Central Park. 

REALLY! 

This place almost have everything to look for in a park. Man-made lakes like Stow Lake, which some say is haunted but at the same time a romantic place for lovers. Hike up the hill and you can see the most amazing view of the city. It will also give you a pretty good workout or if you're a child, you can let your imagination run wild. 

This place even have Buffaloes. Buffaloes, I tell you. They're roaming around, and eating grass without a care in the world. Head out to Ocean Beach and you'll see those giant windmills facing the Pacific Ocean. They have been weathered through time and their glory days are behind them, but don't let that full you. Underneath that one windmill is the Tulip Garden. When in full bloom, it is a sight to behold. 

There's plenty of places to play a catch of football, baseball, frisbee or let your dog play a game of fetch. Hey, I even played flag football with a bunch of Yelpers a couple of months ago. (I played with the East Bay team; go figure?) If archery is your thing, they have that too. This is also home to the famous Conservatory of Flowers. If you're a tourist, you've probably picked up postcards of that place. 

I haven't even gotten to the best places yet. Yes, somewhere in the middle are my three favorites things with this place. The new De Young Museum and Academy of Sciences both long time residents have returned to their rightful place. And my favorite is the Japanese Tea Garden. I get my Zen on whenever I visit this place. I mean it will transform you somewhere in Kyoto once inside its magnificent grounds. 

Take that, Central Park.
author: John G.

description:
The park is huge! From exhibits to a lake for rowboats, to hike trails to bike paths, golden gate park has it all. Great for family and friends. Parking is okay, depending on the day. You probably would have to do street parking.

Don't really have too much to say about the park, but figured I'd write one because of my visit to Lake Stow within the park.

Cool and chill place to go rowboating or paddle boating and such. Google it for the 411 that I cannot remember :p
author: Ben T.

description: If your not prepared, this place is MASSIVE. Wanted to see the GG Bridge from the park, but were the bus drooped us off, would have been over a seven mile round trip walk to see the bridge. Did walk a couple of miles through the park, and it is really beautiful... next time may plan to spend the day there and check out more to the exhibits (some free, some at a cost).
author: Mark K.

description: Love this amazing place. So much to do. Have been for walking tours, Hardly Strictly Bluegrass and just to walk around. Last week we went to tour the Japanese Tea Garden. Wasn't sure I would like it but it was so interesting, beautiful and peaceful. Don't overlook this gem.
author: Joe M.

description: Golden Gate Park makes an epic backdrop to the annual San Francisco Aids Walk.  Participants get to explore the beautiful scenery as you trek 6 miles and forget you're deep in the heart of the city.  On regular days, the wonderful DeYoung art museum and California Academy of Sciences (3 museums in one!) are a very short walk from each other and are easily a full day's worth of entertainment.  This park is an SF gem!
author: Terri N.

description: This park is so huge, it's ridiculous! Went bike riding here in the park and for a 2 hour bike rental, only made it about halfway through the park and back. It's a beautiful place in the city to relax, hang out with friends, or go for an event. There's so many activities to do here. Yes, there are some homeless people in certain areas of the park, but I think this is normal, considering the city itself. You can enter the park through so many different entrances and exits. It's just a great place to go and relax for a few hours or more. I hope to someday make it back to the end of the other side where the water begins.
author: Lalida S.

description:
This place is huge and absolutely amazing. There are parks and then there are PARKS. This is the latter. Stunning creeks, Cala lillies that grow naturally, a Japaneese garden, trails and trails and again trails you can walk all day. There are views of the city and the ocean. There are lakes and waterfalls. 

This is one of those places that I am amazed with because it is in the middle of a montropolis.
author: David m.

description: Beautiful place to visit! We stopped in the De young museum and it was a really coo, place to check out. The art museum and stow lake was on our list and everything was amazing. Never knew the park was that big.
author: Allen O.

description:
This park is simply massive. Initially I assume this would be a good thing, but after a walk around I found it pretty underwhelming. We entered from the Haight-Ashbury end and were aiming to get to the Japanese Tea Garden. 

Things I didn't like: 

- Roads. Through a park. This was weird to me, and our return walk felt a lot more like walking along a road than it did through a park. 
- Layout. The paths for pedestrians are somewhat directionless and to head to a specific bit in the park was a bit of a pain in the ass. I had to keep checking the map to make sure we were going in the right direction. 
- People. I don't know how to say this in a polite way, but there was definitely some groups of people that you'd rather avoid while walking through the park. 

Good things: 

- It seemed to get nicer towards the middle where the de Young museum & the tea garden are. 
- Looks of wide green space and it seemed like there were a lot of staff around to keep it nice. 
- Baseball pitches - these are definitely worth walking by if you aren't seeing baseball while in SF as it was a nice spot to chill out for a while.
author: Briony C.

description:
This park is seriously huge. I walked through it all on a trip to SF and by the end I was wishing I had a car.

This place is great for a picnic, a stroll, a run, a flag football game, some pick up soccer, maybe even some softball.

There are museums and the lake where you can rent a paddle boat is perfect for a date. There are lots of activities to partake in here, which will keep you coming back.
author: Luis D.

description: If you're coming to SF, I recommend a walk in the park. Often, you can find special events taking place there. If you have a car, you can find parking at the garage under the science museum near the de young museum. Parking is around $6/hour.
author: Pale C.

description: This park so big. It has a lot of areas consisted in 1. I love going here to take pictures and enjoy the autumn with family.
author: Becky N.

description:
Removing elf door?
All for the "health" of a tree?
Lifeless decision.
author: Josh G.

description: I love the architectural work on all the play grounds in San Francisco! Golden gate park and and Delores park off of church at are my kidos top 10! They never get bored playing in the spider web tower and sliding down the concrete slide with cardboards!
author: michelle r.

description: This place all you could ask for from nature and it is right in the city. The flower gardens are gorgeous and the hikes are wonderful. There are plenty of places to go for romantic walks, and if you are a vampire like me, then places like Redwood trail will contain just the right amount of Sun coverage with the large trees. Driving around from Kennedy to MLK drive in the park circle gives you a view of most of the things to do there. In addition, the west side of the park ends on a great walking beach along the Pacific Ocean. We go here each time we visit San Francisco and plan on continuing to do so.
author: Preston S.

description: Beautiful park. Grew up having family reunions and picnics here. Lot of great memories. A must do when in the area.
author: Jas L.

description:
Beautiful park. Make sure you take a few hours out of the day, as there is much to see. What we did was park at the beach, stop at the tourist center for a map and figure out what to see, then catch the free shuttle, which runs about every 15 minutes and has stops at most attractions. 

We stopped at the Japanese Tea Garden, which is $7 for non San Francisco residents. It was beautiful.

Make sure you take time to check out Stow Lake, lots of wildlife and beautiful. 

There is food to be purchased throughout the park and plenty of restrooms. 

There was also a Sedgwick tour, which we didn't do, it's more fun to explore yourself
author: Dory W.

description:
Beautiful grounds and a well kept park. Like others say, you can wander around for hours and not see the same thing. Rent a bike and have even more fun.

Don't be surprised if you smell something funny coming from the bushes. Gotta love Cali!
author: Erin L.

description:
Best park ever! It is well-maintained and very beautiful. Extremely huge! You cannot see everything in one day. The layout can get kind of confusing so look at a map beforehand.

There are various activities for everyone from museums to outdoor activities. I enjoyed looking at the pretty gardens too. Check this place out for a nice breath of fresh air.
author: Noel K.

description: Absolutely beautiful park, we aren't from San Francisco but after spending a day in the city walking around the park makes you forget that you're in a big city. Lots to see, pictures galore and you can definitely spend a whole day exploring here.
author: Gage B.

description:
One of the greatest sights I had the pleasure of visiting in San Francisco was the Golden Gate Park. This huge and gorgeous green space is clearly the place for picnics and frolics, weather permitting, and is utterly vast comparatively to the size of the parks in the UK. It's a clear and obvious choice for a romantic stroll, healthy jog, little amble with a dog and as I perambulated to the work picnic I was attending whilst out here I was instantly jealous that for all the Yorkshire greenery we don't have one of these. (Of course, one brief trip to Otley Chevin once home and I was satiated!)

I think the thing I was most jealous of was the eerie mist. Akin to the vibe of a Hitchcock thriller, the most glorious mist flowed in from what seemed to be inland, and in less than sixty seconds the tendrils curled over the tree tops creating a new and almost tangible sky. I'm not sure there's a word for this yet, and I'm a word-geek so I have looked, but it was one of those situations where somehow real life reminded you of a film, or a painting. It's sort of "life imitates art", only trees and skies and other such things to my knowledge don't act but simply are.

Strange how real life and real experience can bring about a de ja vu for something stuck in time, like media. Anyway. Enough musing - go and see for yourself if you're fortunate to visit the city!
author: Rowena H.

description:
I love a big park in a big city.  We enjoyed several hours in Golden Gate Park a few years ago.  We wandered around, looking at the plants and flowers and taking lots of pictures.  There was a wide range of people enjoying the park, from families with kids, to hippies and their drum circles, to street punks drinking 40s.  I never felt unsafe, but I'd be cautious at night.  

Mildly amusing story: at one point we found an old house or structure.  As we approached we saw three people.  As we got closer we realized it was a guy photographing two naked ladies!  They quickly scurried off, and it gave us quite a laugh.

Visitors take note: you will not find the Golden Gate Bridge in this park.

I would definitely like to visit Golden Gate Park again if I ever make it back to San Francisco.  I especially want to see the Japanese Tea Garden, more flora and fauna, and alleged herd of buffalo.
author: Shekinah S.

description:
This park is full of awesomeness! 
I have never been to such a huge park in my life. This is the central park of SF that includes the CA academy of science museum, japanese tea garden, shakesphere park, and the list goes on! It's a great place to bike ride, walk, run, explore, boat, you name it, they got it! I came here a few times and the last time i came here had a dance party. Quite interesting with people dancing and performing. I want to come here one day to bike ride around the whole park. I recommend this park to anyone, it's just full of fun, family activities.
author: Mimi V.

description:
Golden Gate Park is absolutely wonderful. What a treat it must be for local San Franciscans to have access to this park whenever they want. With a handful of museums, beautiful grounds to walk around, and several other attractions, I could easily see coming to the park on the weekends just to wander around. 

The admission prices may seem a little steep for some of the attractions, but outside of the amazing free museums in D.C, I have no reservations about the admission prices. The Japanese tea garden is $7 for non-residents, the Academy of Science is $30, and the De Young museum is $25.
author: Mark W.

description:
***********Happy 140th Birthday Golden Gate Park****************

One of my most favorite place in the city. Measuring at more than 1000 acres it stood as a symbol of natural beauty for years.

I can not get enough of the Japanese Garden. The serenity it provides is much missed now that I'm far from visiting it.

But today I remember it's birthday and wish it many more enjoyable years with San Franciscans to enjoy and of course the visitors that take their time to drop by.
author: Janet D.

description:
A fantastic park to have in the middle of a massive urban area.  There are tons of things for just about everyone and some great museums as well.

I am definitely a fan of GGP, it's cool that there is the panhandle kind of hanging in there too just to bring the park area a little closer to the masses.  There is a waterfall in the park which is just too cool for an urban park.

One problem is that there are some pretty busy roads running through here, and that excludes 19th Avenue which gets its freeway on once it hits the park.  There are some other roads that people smash the pedal on and make it kind of scary.

The park was built to emulate Central Park in NYC, but it is missing one huge key element of Central Park, which is dense urban settlement along its borders.  Sure there are tons of houses along the park, but in many areas the park isn't very easy to access directly from the street.  They should have a clear entrance every block or two at minimum.  There are also quite a few homeless encampments and seeing a guy doing what bears do in the woods is not uncommon.

Still the park is fantastic, and if you live near it you are lucky.  There is definitely room to spiff it up a bit though.
author: Brian L.

description:
Hel-lo, gawjus! It's almost unforgivable that I have been to SF so many times and never spent time at Golden Gate Park. If you are like my former self, fix this. Wait. I mean, come here. It was overwhelmed by the massive beauty that is GGP.

Trails, flowers, trees, creeks, conservatories, hippies, hipsters, unruly children, green space, hills, dales, nature at it's most manicured and beautiful. For all of my rants about dive bars, questionably clean beer glasses, b!tchy servers, restaurants with no a/c, etc.... they were all quieted by a journey into GGP. It's located in the belly of the beast that is San Francisco but you would never know it. You would never know that at any side you are beset by urban excellence and decadence in its most American and left-leaning ways. You would never know that you were so close to pro sports, threats of earthquakes, amazing humanity, heart-breaking homelessness, mind-blowing food, fat cat excess, children who want, earthy dinginess, and penthouse pristine palacialness. 

You would never know because you would be surrounded by sheer, deafening lushness that's free, open to all and closed off to none. Close your eyes and get lost in the silent solitude of vegetational beauty and for a moment -- perhaps, only a moment -- nothing else matters. And, in a world in which the noise never stops, in which the plug is never out of the socket... why, that is a modern day miracle. For this, we give thanks.

Replenish that which you may have lost. Gain that which you may not know you needed. American beauty.
author: Johnny T.

description: Golden Gate Park is huge. Like Central Park it has a lot of attractions within it to check out. While we didn't get to see it all, you would be able to spend hours walking around and taking it all in. The park is a great FREE spot to check out and get the California experience. Start at Hippie Hill and get "supplies" to enjoy a sunny day. Great people watching here as well as beautiful scenery.
author: Joshua C.

description:
Probably one of my favorite places to go on a nice day in the city! There's just so much to do. People are so active around here - there are always activities going on, people running, walking their dogs, taking their family out, barbeques... I love it. Such a positive atmosphere. Parking kind of sucks sometimes, but it's not too bad! Lots of street parking just outside of the park [The boy&I usually park on one of the streets off of Fulton and walk in. We go during weekends, so no worries about time limits for parking!], but I believe there is also at least one parking structure.

I love that so many diverse people frequent this park - kind of speaks volumes about the population of San Francisco/The Bay, yeah? From the older Asians doing taichi in front of the California Academy of Sciences/De Young Museum to the huge family reunion on one of the many lawns. So come out on a gorgeous day, and enjoy the sun! [It's pretty with fog too... just in a different way!]

Oh, and yes there are bison. They're in a pen, but it's pretty cool! :P
author: Amy L.

description: why do ya always gotta pay for the japanese gardens that everyone offers!? isnt anything free anymore. ugh anyways other than that there was some nice scenery around here. walked around the lake.  seen some waterfalls.  windmill , some random animals. nice stop in our venture around the area
author: Greg Z.

description: Golden Gate Park is one of my favorite places in San Francisco.
author: Gavin M.

description: Just a great park. I have been here a few times and I don't think I have seen everything here. The Japanese Tea Gardens are nice. Strawberry hill is an easy little hike. You will get a great view of the surrounding neighborhood and the Golden Gate bridge. Shakespeare Garden is a nice place to get out of the sun and relax.  I would just recommend taking some water and exploring.
author: Danny M.

description:
Love taking a walk around the California Academy Sciences and De Young. Beautiful day in SF today. Great place to jog! 

Only hard part is finding parking! They close of the roads in the park on Sundays for bikers to ride!
author: Adam J.

description:
HUGE!

My boyfriend and I didn't even cover half of this place.  We came here on our last day in SF and visited the Japanese tea garden.  We hoped to see more but we enjoyed every part of the area that it was hard to see all of it.  Next time we go back to SF we are spending one whole day here!
author: DJ P.

description:
The first time I visited San Francisco, my father suggested going to the park. The idea was absurd. Why would I want to go to the park when there is so much food and shopping to be had?

Now I'm older and wiser (ha) so this time around I figured I'd check it out.

This park is gorgeous. And I'm not just talking about the fit joggers all over the place. You can really get lost here and entirely forget that you're in the city. There is plenty to see and do, even without paying for the botanical or tea garden.

Get yourself an ice lolly from the Twirl and Dip truck, put on your sunscreen and walking shoes, and enjoy the outdoors!
author: Samantha B.

description:
What do you say about this man made gem?  Start at the Windmills and work your way inland.  Walk around Stow Lake, watch the people practice their fly fishing, get 9 holes of golf in, see the DeYoung, the Japanese Tea Garden, the Conservatory of flowers, the buffalo, etc., etc., etc.

So much to do and so much to see.  It's not a tourist attraction but a place to be, relax, and romance.

Hard to believe that this was mostly sand dunes and scrub 100 years ago.

My advise if you have never spent much time there is to go online, get a map or two and figure out what you would like to do there.  Try http://www.sfgov.org/site/recpark_page.asp?id=17796

Otherwise you will spend all day running from one thing to the next.  That's not they way to enjoy this beauty.
author: Jeff H.

description: I had an opportunity to bike around this place, and boy was it wonderful. Next time I'm in the city, I'll be sure to stop by again.
author: Susan A.

description: One of my favorite parks to go to. You can do anything from walking, running, sight seeing, museum roaming, flower watching, anything!
author: Moses D.

description:
Stunning!

I wish I had more time to explore but I was there for a work picnic and it was a perfect setting.  A HUGE field with a DJ, Food, Bars and picnic tables.  It was such a beautiful day too, we could not ask for a better setting.

As we were driving through the HUGE park, the trees were huge and mesmerizing lining the entire layout in flush greenery. The water fall with all the ducks was gorgeous, not sure what part that was at. If I lived there I would have taken a book out there and just chilled.  A ton of people were hanging out by the greenhouse with their dogs, blankets and books, it looked like the set of a movie.

I was in awe of the rose garden and I just drove by it, I can't imagine how I would have felt walking through it.

Can't wait to go back! Do NOT miss this if you visit!
author: Colleen B.

description:
I never really explored Golden Gate Park until I moved out to Sunset, but now I know what I had been missing out on all these years! I absolutely LOVE this place! Sure, it can be kind of unsafe if you're out solo after the sun has gone down, but other than that, it's a beautiful place to go running, a lovely area for a picnic, or just a nice place for a stroll!

It's an added bonus that there's lots of free events that are held at the park! Additionally, it's the home of the Botanical Pavilion, the Japanese Tea Gardens, the Academy of Science, and the De Young Museum!

My absolute favorite is running counter clockwise around the park (which is approximately 8 miles if you follow the outer trails), and running out towards Ocean Beach with the windmill on your right. It's an absolutely stunning sight!

Each time I go, I feel like I discover something new! And even if I don't venture off into another new trail, I love to people watch on the weekends during my runs!
author: Leana L.

description:
I'm a fan of anything outdoors and even though this park is nothing like Central Park in NY, it has it's own charm and vitality.  You will never find this park empty.  Both locals and visitors enjoy this wonderful 1,000+ acre patch of land in the middle of an urban city.

Check out the Japanese Tea Garden Wed. or Friday at 10am and it's free. then you can spend your money on your walk past one of the few museums on the property.
author: Kevin J.

description:
Absolutely gorgeous. I find it quite incredible how SF intentionally made space for a piece of heaven like this. Well done SF.

Taking a walk towards the ocean through the park as the sun is setting is absolutely surreal. Do it for a date. The sun beaming through the trees is breathe taking.

I felt like I was in Game of Thrones.

Well done SF.
author: Richard W.

description: This had to be a stop for my family and I. I'm glad we didn't miss it. We came to the Japanese tea garden but we realized that this was a huge and magnificent park. It has parking all around the park, plenty of parking for the disabled. ( I hope I'm being politically correct) this park makes me want to live in San Francisco.
author: Terry M.

description:
How can you not like this place? It has the Conservatory, Tea Garden, Academy of Sciences, de Young Museum, Stow Lake and paddle boats, Windmills, Park Chalet and even street swing dancing. Not to mention the summer music festivals. Despite all of these tourist spots, it does actually feel like a park, a jungle, an escape from the city itself!

Beats Central Park by many, many, miles!!!
author: Kevin N.

description:
As a child, I was happy to enjoy the many trips to the botanical gardens that my city which used to be the garden city of India offered.

As I grew older I appreciated my trips to the museums, the Indian institute of science, the tata institute and HAL. By then my city had become the IT capital of India.

I went to college, and people would make fun, you throw a stone and you will find an engineer.By then, we became world famous, I was no longer satisfied with a degree in Engineering and got my MBA and read 'The world is flat' where Thomas Friedman coined the term 'Bangalored' in honor of my garden city.

Today I am married, I volunteer @ the blue grass festival, I have walking races, love watching remote controlled boat races and sometimes a wedding! I take many pictures, sometimes in front of the water falls that sing to me, sometimes of the people who play music for people like me. 

 I lay down on the green grass, and I say, mom, I am here in a bigger garden, more museums share their wisdom, I have tea gardens that heal me, and I learn as I look around at the possibilities of many more memories to be written, the sameness and the uniqueness of it all!

GG thanks for the memories ^ _~
author: Harsha G.

description: Golden Gate Park is place to be during the weekend in the summer.  There is always stuff to do for your whole family.  However I do not recommend going there after dark because certain area can be sketchy or dangerous after dark.  In the morning you can always find joggers running through the park.  It also has Academy of Sciences which is a very popular place.  If you are out of town people visiting the parking definitely give yourself a day or two for the whole park.  Because it is impossible to see the whole park in one day.
author: Jen J.

description:
I Love this place!!

Museums, Japanese Tea Garden, Botanical Gardens, Bike Trails, Lake...what more could you ask for in a park!! 

Wish I lived up here to do spring/summer picnics! 

Beautiful day with family!
author: Nahid D.

description: It's a beautiful park. We were in a rush so just drove through. We were able to see Bison from a far. And we stopped to take photos of the wind mill. Across the street from the park is a pretty beach and a visitor center where I was able to use the restroom.
author: C L.

description:
Biggest park I've ever been to. Its no joke, this park is enormous. I don't think I will ever get sick of this place because of the vast flora this place has. It is well maintained and clean.

Just one of the beauties that CA has to offer.
author: Juan F.

description: Great Sights, a must see if you are in the area!
author: Mike B.

description:
This is a very beautiful place.  You're bound to embark on many quests and run into many people of all walks of life.
Some places I've been to and what I did:
--Nightlife at the California Academy of Science
--Went on adventures in the Arboretum
--I rented the four person bike with friends near Stowe Lake
--I played some football, had BBQs, and played many drinking games at Speedway Meadows 
--Witnessed the free spirits celebrating 4/20 at Hippy Hill
--Played ultimate frisbee near the baseball fields
--Hung out at the roller rink on a Sunday
--Hiked up Strawberry Hill
--Went on the Merry-Go-Round
--Played disc golf at the course!

GGP is amazing.  You must go here whether or not you live in SF.  This place was so close to my apartment at the time, I would often call Golden Gate Park my backyard.
author: Sam K.

description: My husband and I ran here twice while we visited San Francisco.  The scenery is breathtaking and the trails are great.
author: Nikki A.

description:
My husband and I had a wonderful day at this park. We rented bikes and biked the park, to the ocean and back. It was a beautiful day and very affordable! I would highly recommend going to this park while in San Fran! 
We enjoyed the conservatory and the many lakes.
author: Stefanie R.

description:
BESIDES THE ALLERGIES...
(5 stars)

I dedicate my 500th Yelp Review to Golden Gate Park. There is never a park in this world like Golden Gate Park!!! To be honest, I'm never appreciatitive of this park UNTIL I am in it. I've been to GG park so many times and still, you can litereally get lost in here. Because my friends and I did just this past weekend in the scortching sun and kind of intoxicated. 

There's just so much to do, especially all those countless times of watching free concerts for years and years and years. You just bring your beach mats and lay out and have a picnic with your friends. There's SO much to do in here that you don't see when driving outside of the park. So while lost in the park, we've seen that there is Academy of Science, Japanese Tea Garden, Botanical Garden, Tennis courts, Conservatory of flowers, de Young Museum, old people playing lawn bowling, wedding reception, etc. etc. the list can seriously go on AND ON.

Will I be back? The upcoming nice weekend I do plan to jog and lay out on the grass and enjoy nature (drugged up on allergy meds).

JABA APPROVED... until the next review.
author: Jane A.

description: This is truly one of those cases where a picture is worth a MILLION words. I stopped here forall of 20 minutes as part of my bus tour Sunday. Timed just perfectly to catch the Pacific sunset, the combination of nature and machine makes words worthless. I think this is the place  where the City by the Bay casts its spell on you!
author: Sergio F.

description:
The only reason I am not giving the park 5 stars is because of the crowed parts (not the whole thing) draws.  And the personal feeling that I could not walk through it alone at night.

Other then that..I mean there are are endless things to do here.  It's not just a park.  Staring with the museums and tea gardens with and moving on to more active things like the tennis courts and bike trails and polo playing fields.  I am sure there is a bunch that I don't even know about!
author: Red R.

description:
This park is ridiculously overwhelming. It's HUGE. There are maps posted everywhere and we'd walk for what I thought was 15 minutes and we barely moved by the time we got to the next map.

I was really impressed though that a park so big was so well maintained. We only made it a quarter of the way through and that was only in a straight line - we missed a ton of stuff on the way.

We walked through (one of the many) entrances and were surrounded by bums everywhere. I kind of regretted that we were going to spend our last day in San Fran hanging out with bums who somehow had a ton of weed. (The amounts could have rivaled a frat party.) But as we walked further and the weather got nicer, the bums seemed to dissipate. 

I wanted to go to the Japanese garden which was our first stop. It's free on certain days of the week but of course not on the day that we went. $7 per person. Cash. Exact change requested. It was a cool little garden - fairly small but fun. Go on a free day though. 

We then walked around one of the lakes which was a beautiful walk. We saw sketchy people hiding behind bushes...probably wouldn't be super safe to go alone here at dark...but who would do that anyway?

After the lake, we also hit up the California Academy of Sciences - check out my review! 

Cool park - a must see while in San Fran. 

Oh, and there's a shuttle that's $2 per person...you can cruise around to a dozen of stops around the park. If you're not a big fan of walking, I'd recommend this when you go.
author: Sarah M.

description:
My wife and I were in San Francisco on vacation and we took the light rail all the way to the end and began our walk through Golden Gate park. It was a beautiful day and I did not realize that Golden Gate park is so huge.

We walked the path and saw so many things. There are frickin' Bison in the park. they have a polo ground area, a few beautiful lakes where you can get peddle boats and the scenery is just majestic.

There are multiple couples walking hand in hand like love is in the air. The romanticism is oozing in this place. It recalled the courtship process with my wonderful wife walking around the gorgeous lakes in Minneapolis.

There were BBQ's going and tons of family reunions going on. There was happiness abound. Frisbees were being thrown and leather baseballs were flying everywhere.

What a beautiful place!
author: Jason K.

description:
This place is big and nice.  It reminds me of Central Park as far as the whole park-splitting-up-the-city thing.  

I came here when I was visiting my friend.  He as in class so I wandered around here myself.  There's some pretty flora and fauna here including the rose garden and a tree that reminds me of the lion king.

There are spots here such as the museum and Japanese tea garden that charge but there's plenty of pretty things to look at for free too!

It was a nice relaxing afternoon during my vacation.
author: Ninette C.

description:
I went to San Francisco last Saturday, Golden Gate Park is a very very big park in the downtown of city. It looks like Beijing Olympic Forest Park.
I like the lawn, a lot of children play on the lawn.
Just sit on the lawn, feel relaxed.
author: Devin Z.

description:
Fantastic locedated in the heart of a beautiful city.   Lots to do at this park. Running, cycling, picnic, yoga, sightsee, you name it  
Weather can be a bit cooler so dress accordingly.  Near the beach which is nice!   Packa lunch and enjoy!
author: Rich H.

description:
Golden Gate Park is like San Diego's Balboa Park.  I like!

Museums, parks, gardens...biking, hiking, picnic spots - you can come back over and over and have a different experience.

Go explore!
author: Jennifer A.

description:
Surprisingly, I've never been to the Golden Gate Park; even though I've been to San Francisco about 2-3x a year for the last 10 years. Maybe I just assumed that it wouldn't be worth it or there were rumors of all the bums, etc that were there. Didn't sound appealing. 

I was taken back by how peaceful and beautiful our walk through the park. Loved that we were able to drop in at de Young! Nice surprise for me. :D Not sure how much ground we actually covered, def not all of it. I may need to add this in to my to do's when I am in town, if I am unable to trek to any other local hikes.
author: Sara P.

description:
I have now wasted what could have been a perfectly good three years on Yelp, and this is my 500th review (except for the one Yelp deleted because I was a bad, bad girl, and a few others I thought were better to retract). 

Golden Gate Park is really rather wonderful. I used to poo-poo it and cross the bridge to Marin for outdoor recreation at every available opportunity. But right here in River City, right in my own backyard, there is plenty of recreating to be had.

Old timers say that GGP used to be manicured within an inch of it's life, every bit of it. Poking around under the overgrowth, you'll find a lot of "water features" that have ceased to be. The stables are crumbling and the horses moved out except for a few police horses, who live across from the bison. 

Much of it is pretty scruffy, with a bare bones gardening staff trying to keep up. Old timers also have their own names for places in the park, so if a native is directing you, feggitaboutit. There seems to be some sparkling new signage for roads and places so navigation may get a bit easier. 

A lot of people live in the park. Some of them are very nice, and have done things for me like return a lost cell phone. Some of them are not so nice and have a menacing air about them and leave a lot of garbage behind. There are feral cats and the odd coyote, hence the lack of bunnies and other smaller critters. 

Thanks to my part-time pooch Roxy the Wonder Dog I am often in the park at daybreak and dusk, and I can't think of a better place to be. Out here in the fields, you can see the stars at night too, unlike center city. People who live in other neighborhoods are convinced that it is always foggy and cold here. We hope those thoughts keep you warm and in bed and out of our way.

Every year Michael Franti has a day long Power to the Peaceful concert in Speedway Meadow, and Warren Hellman hosts a multi-day extravaganza called Hardly Strictly Bluegrass and god  I love that man for this incredible free gift. These are just two of the many musical events I can roll out of bed and into the park for.

So what's not to love?
author: Gwynnie P.

description: Walked across the park once...then came back and tried looking for the dog training area...failed again. however we were able to walk through little niches and explore the park a little more. Very fun walk after you take your pup to play at Ocean Beach....and then walk to the park to dry off. Worth it. Will come back.
author: Susan L.

description: Pain in the butt to get here, whether by public transportation or car (parking is awful!), but once you arrive, it's a beautiful place. Spacious, scenic, ideal for walking or biking, common spot for picnics, and often a venue for large events (i.e. concerts, festivals). Great for all ages. Definitely one of the places you must visit if you want to explore San Francisco.
author: Christina L.

description:
This is absolutely one of the gems in SF. We live in SOMA and coming here feels like going to a different city since it's all the way across town but we just love it.

Cal Academy of Science-awesome, we are members and the aquarium never gets old.

deYoung-a great museum and place to hang out on a rainy day

Conservatory of Flowers-small little greenhouse but SF residents get $2 off and admission is only $5. The train exhibit was really cute

Japanese Tea Garden-it's a lot bigger than it looks from the outside and it's adorable on the inside....totally worth the price of admission.

We love this park, whether you want to jog, bike, walk, people watch, have a picnic, rent a paddle boat, it's all of the above and so much more.

Parking can be tricky, especially on the weekends but it's totally worth it.
author: Betty C.

description:
Golden Gate park is such a magical place in the middle of a hustling and bustling City.  Once you're in the park limits you'll feel like you're miles away.  From the various playgrounds, fields, picnic areas, ball parks, lakes, meadows, tennis courts, and other recreational venues, GGP is a place for San Franciscans to enjoy the outdoors and recreate.  

Parking at times can be a big pain but overall a great place to come hang out.
author: Henry S.

description:
I loved this park but had an experience that marred its charm. While returning to our vehicles we passed broken auto glass in the ground, we had passed on way to gardens. Them we came across 4 visitors from Germany beside another vehicle which was broken into. 

My family and I helped them make calls because of the communication issues they experienced on the phone as people passed by with barely am acknowledgement. 

Here is what I learned after calling 911 and approaching a park employee. This is a common issue during tourist season. The police will not come out and after 3 numbers you should call 311 to file a report or so it online. I was very disappointed and I hate it marred my opinion of such a beautiful place but  if anything occurs of its not " severe" expect no assistance.
author: Jason H.

description: I loved walking through the park! It was nicely shaded and so much to do! It was very nice to sit by stow lake and absorb some sun, then explore all over. Be prepared to walk though. It seems like with a car it can be a hassle. Wish I lived closer, I would be there ALL the time.
author: Sarah T.

description:
My first 5 star review and it goes to Golden Gate Park! If I lived in SF, this would be my go to park! 

I love this park! It's absolutely beautiful and spacious! You can't help but be happy here! The freshly cut green grass and fresh air easily puts anyone in a good mood! It's surrounded by mother nature, fountains, ponds, and happy people!

I've only explored a small part of it, but there's something for everyone to do! There are just so many attractions, so no one ever really gets bored! I personally come here to ride surreys or bikes with my friends. I usually come here on a sunny weekend, rent the surrey or bike from one of the vendors, and ride away!
I like coming here on the weekends because they close certain streets so you can go all 'fast and furious', bike edition. 

Btw, I come all the way from across the bridge just for this park, so that's already telling you how awesome it is!
author: Wendy K.

description:
Golden Gate Park is wonderful. And I live two blocks from it, so I spend a lot of time there. Where else in America (no the world) can you see bison, lawn bowling, a museum with a rainforest bubble, hippie drum circles, a statue of Beethoven, a dutch windmill, the Pacific Ocean, a really poignant Aids Memorial, and so much more complete delightful randomness set amidst eucalyptus, grass, flowers, redwoods, etc.? Answer: Nowhere.

So why can't I give it five stars? Roads. So many roads. I mean I read some note that says you can't be more than 1000 feet from a road in the park. Moving here from the East Coast, I really am baffled that the California love of the automobile extends to the point that the everywhere in a park has to be car accessible. From my New England sensibilities, that makes absolutely no sense. The purpose of a park is to escape cars: go a park, park your car outside of it, and then spend the time enjoying nature in the park, not driving through it. Oh well. Cultural differences I guess.
author: Tom Z.

description:
Wow, what a park!  A group of us rented bikes and spent a few hours riding around this gorgeous park.  We weren't  biking for more then a few hours but it was enough time to see some buffaloes, waterfalls, turtles, gophers, strangely odd tourists, horses and etc.  This list can go on and on, which is pretty amazing for a park.

We're use to visiting parks that resemble somewhat like a golf course populated by occasional pigeons.  The Golden Gate Park will catch you off guard because its natural ambiance makes you forget that you are located right in the middle of San Fransisco.  It's a really relaxing place.  

Amazingly, we only saw a small fraction of what this great park has to offer!  It's huge.  We can't imagine how many trips it would take to discover all it's hidden secrets :)
author: Trang H.

description:
Wow, this park is expansive...you can feel like you're outside of the city without actually leaving the city! I came here with some friends last weekend; we took the train from South Bay and took the lightrail (N Judah) from the station to the park. It's only 2 blocks away from the last stop. You can even walk to the beach if you want to.

I saw something about the free shuttle online...when we got the park we weren't sure where to go. We were by the Murphy Windmill, so we decided to walk along Lincoln to get to the visitors center/the Beach Chalet Restaurant. The guy at the front told us the shuttle would go to the parking lot by the beach (other side of the street). The shuttle runs every 15-20 minutes, but we got lucky and flagged down the shuttle just as it was going through the parking lot. We asked the driver to stop at the Rose Garden for us to get off...it doesn't seem like the shuttle has any pre-determined stops. This is kind of odd because it would be nice if people could count on the shuttle to stop for them to get back on after walking around a certain area...the park is huge so you don't want to walk the whole thing. The shuttle is a good idea though, I hope they keep it around.

We walked through the Rose Garden, which was beautiful. Then we walked over to the Japanese Tea Garden...alas, you have to pay to go in. We skipped it. There was a bride and groom taking pictures outside...it's a nice and serene area. We walked around the area surrounding the CA Academy of Sciences...you're surrounded by nature and statues of philosophers. We stumbled upon the Twirl and Dip soft serve ice cream truck too! It was a really nice day out, so there were quite a few people in line.

Next time, I would drive to the park to spend the whole day there. It doesn't look too difficult to find parking in the park itself. This way you can get out, have a picnic, walk around, and go to the other end of the park easily. We ran out of time to see everything we wanted to see (Bison Paddock, the lakes), so we walked back out to Judah Street to catch the lightrail.

Definitely a top free thing to see/do in SF!
author: Katherine S.

description:
The largest park in San Francisco is also the most diverse and interesting. Whats best is the natural scenery, the California Academy of Sciences which is great for the whole family and the de Young museum, a fine arts museum across from CAS. 

The downside is that its filled with junkies and the homeless, and you will most likely be asked to make a purchase during your stay at the park. Ignore these folks and enjoy the great beauty and sights.
author: I G.

description: GG Park is a must. I love walking endlessly through it, checking out the island, the plaza where the museums are always has something fun going on, the giant windmills and tulip gardens near the coast, the kids smoking grass in the grass at the entrance near Haight Ashbury, the bros playing some rendition of kickball with kegs next to that, the botanical garden and tea garden which I can't afford, the drum circles the 70's rollerskater scene, the weird assortment of statues. Even hidden gems like a 40 foot stone cross in a hidden outcropping commemorating the first recitation of the Lord's prayer in city boundaries. Random!This place has it alllllllllllllllllllllll. Best day I ever had here was during Bay to Breakers with thousands of naked drunk people and lil' ol' me.
author: Ryan S.

description: This is the largest park I've ever seen. Okay, I've never been to Central Park - is that just as big or bigger? In any case, it's gorgeous. There is so much to look at with little spectacles here and there. We only had time to come here to sit on Hippie Hill for lunch after a walk in Haight-Ashbury but I was impressed. I could see great views of San Francisco. There isn't much nature but lots of people watching on any day.
author: Julie L.

description:
Much like its inspiration - Grand Central Park in NY- this park does a marvelous job of blocking out its surroundings. There are moments when it almost completely silent. Come on a Sunday morning like we did and you will find free swing dancing classes, street closures and the beginning of a roller disco. So much variety and beauty make this a gem in the city!

Visited August 2013
author: Jennifer A.

description: Golden Gate Park is huge (bigger than Central Park in New York City) and there's so much to do there that I would need days and days to be able to take advantage of everything that the park offers.  I enjoyed seeing the bison, walking around Stow Lake looking at the waterfalls, going to the California Academy of Science, going to the Japanese Tea Garden, and going to the Windmill and tulip garden.  There's a lot of wildlife in Golden Gate Park.  When I was there I encountered raccoons, squirrels, fish, ducks, and various other species of birds. Because Golden Gate Park is so vast, it would take you a long time to get to for instance the de Young Museum to the Buffalo Paddock, so on the weekends they offer free transportation. Golden Gate Park is great, and there truly is something there for everyone.
author: Michael G.

description: A wonderland.
author: Morris R.

description: Bring plenty of snacks as you can spend all day here
author: Joe B.

description: This park never falls to fascinate me. I've been going to this park ever since I was a little kid and til now this place never gets boring. There is so much to do in this park that it takes at least two days to get through the whole park. Today was my first time going on the sightseeing tour bus and I love it. Its worth every penny because they take you around San Francisco and you can hop on and hop off whenever you want to. They have certain stop points and the next bus would come back every 20 minutes to pick you up to the next destination. The tour usually takes about 2 hours if you don't get off at any stop. Quick tip that I learned today is that if you want the bus to take you through the Golden Gate Bridge you would have to go before 3pm because after 3pm it hits traffic so instead it'll drive by it. If you're looking to just roaming around SF and nothing else in specific, riding the tour bus is definitely something you should do!
author: Maii H.

description:
I can get lost here.  So big, so pretty, so much to do!

Their observation deck is free.  Parking can be a hassle.  Food trucks.  Japanese Tea Garden is the best!
author: Lauren T.

description: Where to start with this park? There are so many hidden gems that you never get bored exploring this park. It's surprisingly fairly clean for a public park. Beautiful views, perfect place to bring a friend and get lost exploring. The park is so big that it would be impossible to experience for just a view hours. Can't wait to come back and explore again!
author: Roshni P.

description: This is a great place to be! I enjoy all the items in the park, De Young, Tea garden and so on. There a some great Geocaches in the park also. This is a great place to walk around and have fun with friends and family!
author: Sean G.

description:
Great park, lots of scenery to check out.  Great for hiking.  I see a lot of runners, but I'm more a walker.

Favorite places to go to there include:
Stow Lake
Japanese Tea Gardens
Botanical Gardens

Lots of great places to hang out on the grass, get some sunshine, people watch.

You can rent bicycles but I've never biked around the park.  If you do choose to bike, be sure and inspect the bikes really well.  I've heard some places don't maintain their bikes all that well.

I used to also go there annually to participate in the ACS Walk Against Breast Cancer 5-mi walk they hold there every year.
author: Wyman L.

description: Beautiful urban park. I really enjoyed navigating this place. Definitely worth checking out. There are a couple of museums in the park, and there are a lot of joggers with their pups. Good place to walk around if you have kids.
author: Lewis B.

description: We love it at GG Park. So much to do, so beautiful and it's hard to believe you're in the middle of San Francisco when you're in this park. We often spend a day here, it's our favorite place in the city. Grab a couple beers and find a nice spot, have a picnic, enjoy the scenery, check out the sites and bring a camera.
author: Becky M.

description:
As a  New Yorker I maybe committing heresy here but  I like this park better than Central Park.
It's cleaner, the grounds seem better maintained and it's not as crowded as Central Park gets. 
The Flower Conservancy is beautiful.I didn't think of myself as a flower guy until I came here.
Another must see is the Japanese Tea Garden. I really enjoyed it. It was however one of few places that
felt cramped on a Sunday afternoon due to narrow
paths and baby strollers. Still not unbearable.

I also stopped by De Young Museum and saw Chiluly(sp) exhibit.  
I do  wish I had planned better and given myself more time to see the park.
Adjectives that aren't part of my normal vocabulary in nyc like tranquil, and serene kept popping into my head as wandered the park. While SF natives may find it crowded, I didn't. 
I didn't feel like I was on someones heels or dodging joggers and bikers as I do in NYC.
author: James F.

description: One of the all time great urban parks! So much diversity it could only be in San Francisco. Botanical garden? Museums? Windmill? Fly fishing? Horse riding? Lakes? Meadows? Japanese garden? Award winning roses? The Pacific Ocean ? We have it covered.
author: Umair K.

description:
Well maintained for a public park and safe. It is gorgeous and huge! Trails and amenities galore (museums, etc).

Free parking (inside of the park) is available if you park further west.

I first visited as a child many decades ago and this place never gets old!
author: James W.

description:
Whether you desire to visit a museum, check out man-made waterfalls, rent a boat to ride on Stow Lake, or maybe play with your remote-control electric boat, Golden Gate Park probably has a spot to fulfill your desire.  This is not including the many options of places to jog or do walking exercise.

This place definitely fits the "engineering marvel" description I once read or heard used about this section of San Francisco that over 100 years ago was nothing but sand dunes.  In fact, one might even find remnants of this historic sand, like in the area at Stow Lake on the island by the waterfall.
author: H K.

description: So much to do and see here. You can have tea at the Japanese garden, paddle around in a boat, rent a bike and ride around in the park, play tennis or frisbee, walk the many gardens, look for the waterfall, catch a polo match. Really a neat must stop if you are in san fran
author: L M.

description:
What's not to love.

On my first day ever in San Francisco my boyfriend took me biking through this park.  It smells like eucalyptus, a smell that has come to signify SF for me.  It connects many neighborhoods (shout out inner sunset!) to ocean beach. The first time I glimpsed the beach, dusk light illuminating the sand, it literally brought me to tears.  Make sure you have this experience once while you are here. 

Since the early days I've taken to running to the beach through GGP.  There is an un-paved path off to the far left of Martin Luther King Jr. Dr.  It's easier on your knees!  It's such a reward to see a beach at the end of a run (ride the N back!) there are also public bathrooms on Judah right before you hit the beach (key after a long run)

There are a bunch of gems like the conservatory of flowers, the Zen temple, the plaza between the de Young and the Music Hall.  

I've heard there are live buffalo.  Can this possibly be true?
author: Meg M.

description:
Gotta love the park, especially on car-free-Sundays! 

Bunny Meadow is a good spot for picnics, Japanese Tea Garden is fun for a touristy day and the waterfalls are beautiful for a little hike.

I just don't like the big road (JFK) and the amount of cars, but I guess that's what you get with a park in a city
author: Helen D.

description:
I live right across the park, so I take runs around here all the time. Lloyd Lake, Spreckles lake, and North Lake are my favorites. There are footpaths in the hilly area between the Bison Paddock and North Lake which are great for running if you want to get away from people. I also love to run around the casting pools. There are almost no tourists in that part GGP. Did you know there's a dog park behind the Bison Paddock? I love visiting the dogs during my runs.
 Beautiful plants and animals are here; the coolest ones are the turkey like birds (I don't know what they're called) around Lloyd Lake and the occasional loner crane you see strolling around JFK.
author: Ana I.

description:
Well that moment came!
I went to New York City and Central Park makes this park look weak. 
I still like it but trying to get to the park is like trying to find a needle in a haystack.
author: Nadav M.

description: Love this park! there is so much to see and so many beautiful spots.  Come for a walk, bike ride, picnic...Lots of photography opportunities. The rose garden is amazing, Love the windmill, THERE ARE BISON!!! What???  The Japanese tea Garden is my favorite...so beautiful and serene!
author: Kori M.

description:
I went here recently for a "Doing it in the Park" event.  Yeah, I know how it sounds, but it wasn't that kind of party.  My traveling experience to the park was not  fun, but granted it is a beautiful place to be.  The high trees and fogs and there are a LOT of different meadows.  It is SO big and such a vast place.  I got lost looking for Marx meadow, but that's only because I got off on 3rd instead of 30th street...My bad.  

Its a nice place to go if you want to take a walk with scenery.  But be prepared as it is very cold since it is near the water and there is usually fog.  When I left the east bay it was burning up hot and by the time I got to the park it was freezing cold.   Overall, its a nice place for anyone that feels up to it.  Parking is not the greatest from what I was able to see, so I would suggest taking BART and bus up there, although there is a lot of walking involved.  To give you an example, it extends past 30 blocks! But beautiful nonetheless.
author: Lydia B.

description:
The park is so beautiful but not quite as beautiful as central park (bias new yorker speaking) 
But definitely a fun place for the family to hang out for the day and picnic or w/e 
Nice and quiet too which for me is a huge plus
author: Jeremy R.

description:
Came here for Outside Lands... I'd visited before, back in 2007 when the Beach Chalet was having $1 beer night. 

One thing I didn't realize until I walked to the festival from the Civic Center... it was a much longer walk than I expected (but I don't regret it!), and this park is HUGE. I got to the far end and still had 30 minutes to walk to get to Polo Field.

There are tons of places to explore around the park and get lost, and I believe I saw a botanical garden. I'm pretty sure I only saw a tiny fraction of the park, but it was a nice experience none the less. If you want to get away from the city without looking far, this is the place to do it.
author: Erin B.

description: My favorite park in the state of California. the museums, the Frisbee golf course, the festivals and events held here on a regular basis make this a must visit park. Situated near the middle of San Francisco it acts as a divider for several different neighborhoods, but it also hosts those who inhabit the city it lives in. Great place to be.
author: Steve L.

description:
Seriously no way to see this whole place in one day...but then again who would want to? I just LOVE Golden Gate Park! Lush, Beautiful green as far as the eye can see, smack dab in one of the most beautiful cities in the world. Who wouldn't love it? 

From the Museums, to all of the different diverse gardens, Lakes and attractions...so much to see and do, and there is something for everyone. 

We will enjoy going to this park for years to come, and hopefully it'll become a tradition for my daughter and her family when she gets MUCH older. :)
author: Nicole C.

description: The GG Park has something to offer for everyone. Its almost always cloudy or foggy there, which I love. A peaceful oasis in the middle of San Francisco. Really huge which means you can potentially get lost in there. It gets creepy and shady after dark though, but what else can you expect from a park of this size. Full of annoying foreign and out of state tourists.
author: Kev N.

description:
Paradise.

This is the place to go for a jog, picnic, meditation, watch a polo match, cycle or just walk some of the trails.  

This place is massive!  It's easy to get to and worth planning a picnic or at least a drive through.  No kidding.

I didn't get a change to hit the museums or Japanese tea garden but you can bet your ass that I will next time.

What a breath taking place.

Don't half step.  Grab some sandwiches and a blanket or sheet from your hotel and have a nice little time.
author: Brendon D.

description:
SO far my favorite place to take my kid and pet to. So big, green, full of friendly people, tourists and so much more. You can easily get lost here due to the size of the park. Parking could be an issue sometimes but usually you can find a spot and may need to take a little walk. LOVE the botanical garden- have the best memories of taking my parents there and just hanging out. 
Just check it out for yourself!!!!
author: Rup B.

description:
I think this big, beautiful and clean park is the best one in San Francisco. I love the Japanese Tea Garden, Strawberry Hill and the California Academy of Science. It's huge and it's possible to spend a lot of time there. 
It's really good for running, walking or just having a nice time in nature with friends and family, enjoying the nice weather (hopefully!)
author: Emilie L.

description:
Head down to Golden Gate park and check out the gorgeous trees, trails, and the beautiful Queen Wilhelmina Garden. Named in 1962 for the late Queen of the Netherlands, the garden is home to a beautiful Dutch windmill, restored from its original form built in 1902. In addition to the gardens, the park is also home to several museums. Ocean Beach is also walking distance from the park.

The Verdict: A beautiful place for walking around and taking pictures. If you can catch it while the tulips are in bloom, all the more fantastic for you!
author: Cara S.

description:
5 stars.
The park can be so many things to so many people. There is something for everyone here.
Personally I love the park.
Just so nice to laze the day away.
Come and see for yourself.
author: Nick L.

description: Beautiful city park, the eucalyptus trees smell amazing.  The park gets a pretty fair amount of tourist traffic but it is peaceful and serene in some parts.  Definitely worth checking out if you are visiting San Francisco.
