author: Bill J.

description:
Have you ever seen small herds of Bison UP CLOSE?  Well look no further and come to the greatest park located in Northern California.....GOLDEN GATE PARK! =)

Besides the museums, the Japanese Tea Garden, the Botanical Garden, they offer random things like:

-Free swing dance lessons between 12 to 1 on Sundays.  
-Free skating lessons if you aspire to be a member of BreakSk8
-They have a polo field??
-They have random lakes with ducks, turtles, and koi fishes.
-And don't forget the Buffalo!  Who has that at a park in a big city??

When the sun is out, it's a great place to kick back and fly a kite or play with your yo-yo! Whatever floats your boat.  There's just a bunch of random people, jogging, walking, skating, biking, and hanging....

Come join in on the fun! It's a green place at minimal cost.
author: Diana M.

description:
GG Park is so big I have not seen half of what it has to offer but from what I have seen it is great, whether you are just here to escape the hustle and bustle of downtown or for one of the many events held in the park it is great day out!

It has everything, free & paid festivals, drunks, hippies, comedy, sports, bison, pretty gardens, great museums, windmills, waterfalls, fountains and much more I am sure I am yet to discover. 

Start at the Haight and head to the beach in time to watch an amazing sunset! 

Always take a jacket! This is SF it can rain or drop 20 degrees at any moment!
author: Chris M.

description:
Oh Golden Gate. How is it that, despite being relatively inconvenient via public transportation, I keep coming back to you? It doesn't matter if I'm living in San Jose, Berkeley, or the far-flung not-near-Bart or Caltrain Vacaville. I just keep crawling back to you.

I'm not sure if it's the gigantic, beautiful forest you have nestled in a major city with amazing views. It could be the wacky and entertaining homeless guys, who greet me in that laid-back, eyes glazed way and offer me pot. Or maybe it's your amazing hippie festivals (I might've cried when I had to miss Strictly Hardly Bluegrass this year). Perhaps your slightly chilly temperatures have managed to shatter my cold, frigid heart.

Golden Gate, I will brave your rain, cold temperatures, and long rides on Muni to come see you again. I love you just that much!
author: Denise B.

description:
More times than not, I find myself lost in this here park. If not lost, aimless looking for street signs that don't seem to exist. While there are plenty of maps scattered throughout the park, I can't seem to find street signs - whether I am traversing the three mile green span on foot, bike or gas-powered hunk of metal. Frustrating. Really. Maybe it's on purpose. Get stuck in the park.

Aside from getting lost in the gardens, general rule of thumb: go toward the setting sun for wind and sand. En route, scope out the roaming bison. New discovery for me. Burger anyone? Go the opposite direction for rose gardens. In the middle, check out the architecture of the De Young, then head into the Cal Academy of Science.

Every time I'm in the park, I find something I didn't know existed there which makes it always worth going back... even if requires getting lost on my way there. It's all part of the adventure, so make a day out of it. And when the day is running out, head for the wind and sand. Nothing beats the sunset over the ocean.
author: Alissa A.

description: Golden Gate Park, the Central Park of the west coast.  It has everything a park needs and some more.  They have world class museums, world class gardens, world class architecture, and world class talent.  Definitely a place to take your artistic out of town friends to take in the details.  That alone will keep them busy for days.  Some parts of the park is super-bustling while others are quiet for lone introspection.  If you have a specific location in the park you want to go, just know that parking is a pain unless you're willing to pay.
author: Jeff C.

description:
Great place to take the kids for the day . We went to the kids area. There's a merry-go-round and a long bumpy slide. My kids ran up the stairs to go down that slide about a hundred times. 
Clean place, no graffiti.
author: Danielle A.

description: The Windmill, the Bison, The Casting Pools, The entire DeYoung and Cal Academy area, the Aids Memorial, The park, The Carsouel, hippy hill, stowe lake, the japanese gardens, the botanical gardens.... I could go on.  This is one of the most magical places on earth.
author: Uncle Fishbits Aeneas X.

description: This place is beautiful, sunny, has tons of things to do, eat, and see. There's plenty of parking, loads of running trails, and it's absolutely gorgeous.   I came here to visit the de Young Museum-- and I can't wait to come back!
author: Allison M.

description:
The best park in the country, IMHO. You can do everything here from playing a game of pick up soccer, tennis, running, watching bison graze, practice fly fish casting, biking, swing dance, eat a hot dog, go see the amazing botanical garden and sip Japanese tea. Plenty of museums as well. Sundays are great because they close off a few of the busier streets.

A San Francisco classic.
author: Spoon G.

description: I love Golden Gate Park.  It's perfect for exploring, running or just sunbathing.  There are so many sights!
author: Philip C.

description: Lots of gardens, museums, lakes, and other stuff to check out right in the middle of SF. Check the map when you walk in to see what parts you're most interested in seeing.
author: David H.

description:
Nice park but the dr young museum's art was not very impressive.  Much of the art had no business being in a museum.  It would have been nice to have signs posted around the park, as we had a hard time finding Japanese Tea garden, etc.  

I was very turned off by the name "Nancy Pelosi Drive".  What an eye sore to see her name by an otherwise beautiful park!
author: Serena V.

description: Japanese Tea Garden, Botanical gardens, Flower Conservatory, Dutch Windmill, DeYoung museum and the Science Center are just some of the wonderful, exciting icons located inside the park.
author: P. C.

description:
What's not to love about Golden Gate Park?

There is so much to do and see; I would recommend renting a bike for the whole day (which I believe is $25). 

It is a perfect place for museum goers, nature lovers, picnic havers, and people who love to lay in the grass and relax. 

My friend and I rented a tandem bike and rode all the way down to Ocean Beach and back! It was tough at first, but once we got the hang of the bike it was extremely fun!!

If you're a San Franciscan or a tourist visiting San Francisco, Golden Gate Park is place you MUST visit!
author: Juliette R.

description:
The second most quintessentially San Franciscan moment I had was soaking up the warm sunshine while laying down on hippie hill and watching dog owners play Frisbee with their dogs, listening to the drum circle and sipping on a Tecate out of a brown paper bag.
 
Have I died and gone to heaven? Is this really my life right now? Not to mention I lucked out with the most gorgeous weather I could ask for all 3 days I was in the city - not a cloud in sight, 75 degrees and not a drop of rain to be seen (no fog either). So we hung out on the hill for at least two hours people watching and relaxing.
 
We finally got up and headed to the gorgeous and brand-new Science and Art building (what was it called?) only to discover it had just closed! I did get to see the very top of an Albino alligator's head from the other side of the glass though, so that was pretty cool. We then headed to the fine art museum that has a tower that overlooks the city and we missed that too (de Young, I believe)!
We cruised around the rest of the park, taking pictures and just sort of taking it all in and being stoked on life. We spent four hours in the park and saw maybe a third of it. BTW, the last place I would expect to have clean public park bathrooms is in this city. Not only were they not smelly nor dirty, and did have locking doors (albeit, doors at all) they had soap AND toilet paper. Um, wow.
author: Lauren V.

description:
You can totally spend the whole weekend here and I highly recommend it... it is like Central Park in Manhattan except BETTER!!! This park is GINORMOUS!! We spent a good 4hours at the park just sitting and relaxing and we only saw a miniscule part of the park. 

I really didn't know what to expect when we came here, I just wanted to lay out and people watch on a beautiful Saturday afternoon. We settled at the fountains by the Science Academy to eat our picnic for a few hours...

When we were walking we came across a pack of squirrels.  They were a bit snooty, they didn't eat any of the bread or strawberries we gave them. Then a local came by with her dog and was telling how the squirrels will taunt her dog. We got to see what she meant, a squirrel would slowly approach her dog and right when the dog would try to catch it, the squirrel would run up a tree.

As we were leaving we saw a festival for Holland, so we stopped and checked that out (it was located next to the archery field, which was also awesome. I definitely know what I'm doing next time I'm in San Fran.
author: Karen C.

description:
This park kicks any park in Atlanta's face!

Just beautiful!  I loved sitting on the hills and just people watching.  The diversity of people here was ridiculous.  There are gardens, the beach, a random cave, just plenty of things to do and a great place to spend Saturday or Sunday, hell everyday.

My only regret was that I wasn't able to see everything Golden Gate Park had to offer =(  Maybe next time!
author: Kate T.

description:
I'm pretty positive I ran across the Golden Gate park in some other Yelp reviews. 

What a treat this was.

I read what others suggested and rented bicycles.  The location was " kiss me mother nature ", what a treat!  Hard riding up the hill, as expected.

I will be back.  The waterfalls, windmill, bison patty all make this a pretty unique spot and I am so glad I picked it to spend with my uncle.

If you are so inclined, this is a SF GEM!
author: Michael B.

description:
I want to give this park a big bear hug.  It's funny that I've been to the Fisherman's Wharf, Golden Gate Bridge, and Alcatraz, but I didn't get a really solid San Fran vibe until I stepped into this park.

Keep in mind that you have to spend a few extra bucks to get into the museums or the Japanese Tea Garden.  Don't fret though; the park itself provides enough free sights and sounds for you to enjoy.  

If you go into the De Young museum, go into the elevator on the far right side and go up to the top floor.  There you'll find a tiny gift shop and a 360 panoramic view of the park.  I highly recommend this for photos and just to get a feel for everything.

Nearby the California Academy of Sciences, you'll see a bunch of artists outside with their work trying to sell their wares.  It was pretty neat checking out the different artwork and having conversations with the artists themselves.

I would also recommend walking around Stow Lake.  The long leisurely stroll leads you a beautiful waterfall, a small dock where you can rent rowboats/paddle boats, and benches where you can sit and chill for a while.  Plus, you'll be in close proximity to some of the wildlife such as ducks, geese, turtles, and squirrels.

I only had enough time to wander around the East end of the park.  Next time, I will conquer the West.
author: Xuan T.

description: Golden Gate Park is a massive green area in the heart of this hectic city.  Its many acres offer everything from sports facilities to cultural centers to gardens.  A massive windmill, views of the beach, and a quaint restaurant and bar are added highlights.  Golden Gate Park is a true calming escape from the bustling urban lifestyle.
author: Alison C.

description:
Traffic sucks here... Most of the time.  
They have done a lot to clean up the park but they still have a long way to go, particularly when it's not daytime.  I bike though here sometimes on the way to and from work and even at sunrise and sunset I try to avoid it.  I may be a bit timid about it compared to some people because one of my mother's friends had a sister who was found murdered here not too many years ago.  
The good part?  I love when I am around here to see all the runners, walkers and cyclists!  Particularly in the morning when there aren't as many bums around, there is a certain energy about this place that is a great way to start the day!
They have several different areas that are great for different sports, events, picnic etc.  During the day I would give this place 4 stars (not 5 because it's not amazing or anything but it's a sold "really good park"). 
Keep up the good work marking the park safer (it's come a looong way already) and I will be upgrading my review in no time.
author: Christina H.

description:
G reat place with something here for everyone
O ne could come here several times, yet find something new to see
L akes, gardens, museums, bike paths, open meadows...
D ancing lessons, rollerskating, playgrounds, random parades...
E lders and young folk, joggers and jugglers, hippies and hipsters...
N ot to mention the random buffalo you'll see along the way

G otta like how the GGP experience is analogous of San Francisco itself
A round every corner there's a little pocket of wonder 
T oday, we encountered a random Indian Festival of the Chariots parade
E arlier near the de Young, we watched the Lindy swing dancers   

P arking is easy to find throughout the park or at the garages
A t certain areas on Sunday (on the Fulton side), roads are closed off
R eally great to explore the entire park on foot or on a bike
K eep on the main paths/roads if think you're lost
author: Anthony N.

description: Is good to walked your dog there but at night I would lock my doors because there are lots of homeless living in the park who might try to open your doors, when I'm driving into the park I always lock my doors just in case
author: John L.

description:
The park could be very beautiful if there weren't bums everywhere. Being from Las Vegas we have homeless on the strip but they seem to keep to themselves at home. I was a little overwhelmed at how often I was approached at Golden Gate Park for money or drugs - just a heads up.

There was a pretty cool culdisac of food trucks near the entrance with yummy and various types of lunch options to snack on while walking through!
author: Verronika D.

description:
AMAZING. I walked through the whole length of the park (app. 5 miles) and finished at the beach. This was an amazing experience. 

My feet hurt a bit today though
author: Tamara V.

description:
Best Park in the world!  I used to live close to Central park, but Golden Gate Park is better.

All sorts of activities, golf, tennis, baseball, hand ball, and bowling green, concerts and events almost once every other week.  Great place to run and walk your dog.  Good museums. The most important is close to the beach. What a deal.
author: Jacqueline X.

description: Gerat park to hang out and enjoy the nature. Also great concerts on the weekends.
author: Freddy E.

description: Every major city needs to have a beautiful park.  NYC has Central Park, Denver has Washington Park, San Diego has Balboa Park, and San Francisco has Golden Gate Park.  Just a stunning place to go.  There are plenty of free things to do around there, and the park is so well maintained.  For the size I was expecting it to have run down spots or trash here and there.  Nope, I was pleasantly surprised that it seems all the local residents respect and love this park.  Tucked in the heart of the park are multiple museums and a Japanese tea garden.  This is an absolute must on your visit to San Francisco.  Parking is on the street so be prepared for a small walk, but the surrounding area of the park is also beautiful so trust me you won't mind.
author: Elizabeth C.

description: I moved to San Francisco six months ago and have discovered many great places to rekindle the love for the small things in life. This park is by far, the best place to unwind, meet friends for an afternoon picnic, attend an event, or just get lost in its windy paths. This is a place where the saying "All for one, one for all" was born. :)
author: Brian N.

description:
What's not to love?

*Museums
*Bike paths
*Weekend concerts
*BBQing
*Disc golf
*Tennis courts
*Sunning with a magazine
*The cute windmill 
*Public bathrooms (gross, but they're there)
*Academy of Sciences Nightlife
*Japanese Tea Garden
*I live 2 blocks away!

I recently moved to the Inner Richmond, used to live in Laurel Heights, and used to *try* and go to Ocean Beach as much as the temperature permitted when I first moved here from snowy Michigan in 2008. GGP is also a go-to spot when I have family and friends in town. One day I took a visitor all the way from Alamo Square to the ocean- I highly recommend this walk! Takes you from the Painted Ladies, through the Haight and Panhandle, and on to the park! Love.
author: Kristin F.

description:
I been here many times, and it has been consistently good to me.  The park is HUMONGOUS!! (you can actually park in there--if there's no special events going on that day) 

The very first time is probably running thru this park for the Bay to Breaker about 3 years ago.

In between the three years, I came here just for the park, Academy of Sciences, and De Young Museum. 

I still want to come back and visit the Japanese Tea Garden!
author: Jen H.

description: A really pretty park.  Well maintained that has a lot to offer.  A really nice place to wander when visiting SF.
author: Alice E.

description:
The park is very expansive so you don't need to worry about overcrowding- there is almost always some spot where there are hardly people there.

Took my dog here to run around and explore, and it was a nice visit, especially for a picnic. Admired the flora while my dog admired the fauna, and it was a great time shared by all.
author: Jean L.

description: A huge park to relax and have fun to get away from the busy life of San Francisco. Went on the paddleboat with my sister and cousins and even though the bay offers some pretty mucky water, it's a great way to bond. There is also the option to ride rowboats. The park is very green and lively and it's great for tourists as well as San Fran residents
author: Michelle K.

description:
I can still remember coming to Golden Gate Park when I was younger and walking around the lakes, sometimes even renting a paddle boat! It's like an oasis in the city - a place to appreciate nature, away from the busy city life. The paths are nice for biking and jogging and on sunny days, there are people having picnics and tossing frisbees. 

Note, JFK drive is closed partially on Saturday and Sundays. Street parking for the museums is difficult to find on weekends, so consider parking in the underground lot if there's space!
author: Kevin L.

description:
I have to give 5 stars for closing parts of John F Kennedy Drive between 19th Ave and Kezar Dr to traffic on 4th July. (Also on Sat/Sun). We wished GGP can close the entire JFK Drive. We had great time cycling at GGP with kids but there are some scary moment when you have to share with other motorist.

1. We arrived early at 11.00 am so we can get a spot Kezar drive. It was challenging to bike to JFK drive with my 8-yrs old daughter since traffic is heavy on holiday.
2. Once we reached JFK dr, it was so fun sharing the road with other cyclist, runner, family on 4-wheeler bike and road bladder.
3. You can get to de Young on the bike from JFK and explore the museum and Cal Academy of Science. Please remember to bring a bike lock so you can secure your bike. We stop to enjoy the Musical band this time but will come again for CAS.
4. Along the route, we stop at Rose Garden, the skate park, Water fall and even Stow Lake.
5. We have to continue on JFK to see the Bison and traffic is very heavy plus there are many drivers who double park to drop passengers and goods which make the road not safe for kids. Google maps indicated that it is Bicycle safe road but not with cars rushing to get parking spots and opening doors without checking for other road users.  Not a good experience here.
6. No bicycle allowed on pavement because there are pedestrians and family with strollers. We decided to use the "bike" trail to return back to JFK drive and have to avoid dogs which is safe than cars.
7. We stop at the Conservatory of Flowers on the way back and it was educational and interesting.

Overall, it is great park for family and we highly recommend JFK drive on Sunday when it is closed to traffic. It is partially closed on Saturday. Plenty of restroom for nature break, ice-cream and hotdogs carts. It does get cold when the fog roll in so make sure you have layers.
author: Sam M.

description: Gorgeous park. Loved every minute of my visit. The park has a European feel to the architecture and it's just delightful. Great for couples, kids, pets, and even a solo getaway.
author: Nancy A.

description: In a town I otherwise lament for its litterers, loiterers, citywide traffic jams, and stupid Clear Channel bus shelter takeovers, Golden Gate Park is literally a breath of fresh air. A sprawling expanse of lush green Cypress & Eucalyptus, playgrounds and flower gardens, there's much more to be seen than the neighboring dirty city streets would impress upon you--and it's free of charge.
author: Julianna O.

description:
I took the girls to the Golden Gate Park to go bike riding. It was a BLAST there are so many different paths to take and there are hills, flat areas and ponds to ride by. Perfect place for a hike, walk or picnic.

We went through the paddle boat area and watched the swans. I must warn you though be careful riding off the beaten paths we came upon a "nest" of homeless people in the trees as we were cutting through a path to get away from the freeway. That was a bit scary.

Respectfully Reviewed
author: Pam S.

description:
I love this place I could see myself hiking, running, biking or just plain ol'strolling up and down this park. Everytime I've gone up to SF I've just driven on the edges of the park to get to where I needed to be but this time my trip up was a lil'californian food adventure and I decided a little stroll to combat all the munching I've been doing. This park is much longer than it is wider, and awe-striking with a blend of nature and contemporary buildings, ie De Young Museum. 
I'll definitely be back up to SF and next time I'll take my bike w/ me, I have a park to ride in
author: James S.

description: Mr. McLaren and his associates really designed a great park here:  A great place to walk and recreate (jogging, field sports, ... ,) and I especially enjoyed a walk around the Sharon Art Building, near Lincoln (Drive?), Kezar Stadium, and some of the other places more toward the beach.  Also saw lots of people walking their dogs.  Depending upon whether or not you like animals, this can make or ding a good walk in the park here.  Good.
author: Thomas H S.

description:
There's no way I could give Golden Gate Park anything fewer than five stars--despite the frustration I have experienced here. For example, every time I meticulously map out a run in the park, I get lost. It's partly because crossroads are almost never labeled (although the online maps on sites like myfavoriterun give names for the smallest dirt paths). It's also because, as I'm convinced, Golden Gate Park is magic. Whatever I do, I can't predict or replicate runs here. One moment I'm running along, convinced I know where I'm going, and suddenly I find myself surrounded by bison, or in the middle of the polo fields, or in the midst of tunic-clad yeomen clanging swords or shooting arrows. See? Magic.

Beyond running, there's something for everyone at Golden Gate Park: the DeYoung, Academy of Sciences, Japanese Tea Garden (one of my favorite places), Prayer brook Cross (?), the conservatory of flowers. 

So despite my regular frustration here, this place is great. I couldn't get lost in a better place. (Confidential note to the soccer mom who tried to run me over at the pedestrian crossing: I hope you get mauled by bison).
author: Susan S.

description: Beautiful park, nice peaceful feeling. I had lunch here with the family by the lake. Highly recommended.
author: Samuel M.

description: There are so many things you can do in this park... I love it! It's my go-to place for a jog in the morning, it's my go-to place to walk my dog, it's my go-to place to escape the busy city life... Every sundays, they close the street on the east side of the park and pedestrians, rollerbladers, skateboarders, bicyclers take over. On a sunny day, there's nothing better than a sunday walk through the park !
author: David L.

description:
I would never survive city life without the wildness of golden gate park.  It's my refuge from the hustle & bustle.  Having my big, active doggie wouldn't be possible without it either, for which I am oh so grateful.  I love the solitude of early mornings among the trees, and the hidden treasures to be found down every pathway.  If you haven't found the secret lake, start following every little footpath you find until you do.  It's spooky and wonderful.

I am really bummed out to hear about the development projects planned for the western end of the park.  A soccer stadium with synthetic turf and 60 foot lights has no place here, and will be extremely disruptive to the wildlife that abound here, not to mention that it will completely destroy the aesthetic value of this side of the park.  You can find more info at the links below if you're interested in preserving the park.

http://home.earthlink.net/~sfoceanedge/index.html

http://www.goldengateparkpreservation.org/
author: sara b.

description: Waterfalls, hippy hill, ponds and lakes, bike paths, and meadows. What more could you ask for?
author: Naimah M.

description:
Pretentious?   It can be. 1.5 extended pinkies
Worth the money?  Totally
Overall - its a yeah



Its a giant park in the middle of the city - whats not to like?

Also there are Wind Mills and Polo fields (they actually play polo there, yes on horses).

and ahhm - watch out for the urban outdoorsmen.
author: Oleg H.

description: A great place to do a long walk, jog, or simply ride a bike. The sheer size of it can help you get lost and enjoy some time within the woods, or quiet walk to the Ocean Beach. Love it.
author: Victor G.

description: I love Golden Gate Park! Walked there with my friend today and thought it was going to be freezing but it wasn't! The nature blocks most of the wind. I've walked some of GG Park before but my friend showed me Stow Lake and it was gorgeous. Two different trails: one dirt path around a little island in the middle of the lake or a cement path that's on the outer rim of the lake. Bonus, they have paddle boat rentals! You can also see the look out tower of the De Young museum. It could also be a great place for a picnic!
author: Jessica D.

description:
There are some people/places/things in the world that consistently deliver, that always make you happier than you were before, that give you reason to care.

Golden Gate Park is one of those places for me.  I think that when you find something that adds a little more magic or calm or *insert anything positive* into your life, you have to go with it and get as much out of it as you can.  

So, Golden Gate Park.  Here's my story, written as part-advice, part-autobiography of a San Francisco native.  

+ Botanical Gardens.  On Saturdays when we were little, my sister and I used to go with my grandma to feed the ducks and the squirrels here.  From the Inner Richmond, you walk through the Rose Garden, cross John F. Kennedy drive, go up the hill, past some Cherry Blossoms, and you're there.  We brought the ends of bread loaves and packs of peanuts for the animals.  The ducks, pigeons, and seagulls would swarm around us, and then a few minutes in, would all fly away together, in a frantic rush, only to return a minute later, ready to eat more.  The squirrels, they come right up to you and take the peanuts out of your hands.  If you're a little girl, stuff like that is thrilling, enough to make you squeal.  My suggestion: Go with your family or friends, bring some food, and sit on a bench feeding the animals.  Life moves slower for a while, and it feels right.

+ CA Academy of Sciences: On Friday afternoons, my dad and I used to rush from my Kumon classes over to the California Academy of Sciences to catch the last half hour of the museum, which was open for free during those 30 minutes.  I had a mortifying moment once, when we were at the tide pool area, and my dad was pointing out to the white woman next to us all the different animals sitting in there that we Chinese people like to eat.  "That's a sea cucumber.  It tastes really good in black bean sauce."  The Academy is much different now, but here's my advice: Bring your kid to it often.  Curiosity is something that people lose as they get older, so make sure that you stimulate your child's curious heart with as much life and science and animals and wonderful things as you possibly can, and maybe when they're 23 years old, they'll also write about their childhood memories at the museum.

+ Sunday in the Park: On Sundays, a lot of John F. Kennedy Drive is closed to traffic so that families can bike, walk, roller-blade in the park, without worrying about traffic.  We used to roller-blade and bike in the park, getting our exercise and catching the folks doing Lindy Hop on the bridge or roller-skating and dancing by that area near 6th and Fulton.  It's good for people watching, taking in some sun (at least 15 minutes of sun a day is required to produce enough Vitamin D!), and getting some fresh air.  Here's my advice:  If you're near, make it a habit to come out to GG Park on Sundays to either get your exercise (it's a good place to run), or to just relax and walk around people-watching.  The people in this city are interesting, you'll never get bored watching. 

+ Conservatory of Flowers:  The building is beautiful, and it's a greenhouse in a city.  How awesome is that?  But even more awesome than the building and its contents is the area outside of it.  My advice:  This is a good place to walk around with older people.  Take a Sunday and bring your grandparents here, let them walk around all the flowers.  You'll enjoy each other's company while walking around leisurely.  Life moves too fast, take it slow, walk with grandma.  Also, if you have kid sisters or brothers, or one of your own, the grassy hills across from the conservatory are perfect for rolling and tumbling down.  It's good, simple fun.

+ The Bison: Because where else in the city or anywhere in the state, really, can you find random bison roaming around.  I generally jog or bike around here every now and then.  Advice: If you're biking past, just take a minute to look at it, laugh, and then move on.  It's nice to have that brief  "hehehe" moment in any day.  Then continue on your journey towards that little windmill and the ocean.  

+ Other worthwhile things to see: Polo Fields, Stow Lake, paddle-boating, the DeYoung Museum.

Final word: You can't really complain about a place that's free, fun, friendly, family-oriented.  

I think it's fantastic.  Golden Gate Park, thank you.
author: Vivian C.

description:
We drove through the park on our way to the Academy of Sciences and it was gorgeous. The museums are nestled in the middle of the park so if the weather suits you, enjoy the walk to it too. 

Bikers, walkers, strollers galore. The park is huge so bring a picnic basket and get ready to relax in the sun for a couple hours.

I'll be back to enjoy the summer when it gets warmer.
author: Debby L.

description:
Thank you for keeping your bathrooms open during B2B.

Also, thank you, guy who works the newspaper stand, for instead of taking the 40 dollars I had in my purse offering to use your bathroom, you just showed me where the free one is.
author: Jaime L.

description:
Huge park! Huuuuuuuuuuge. Its like Central Park except not as scary.

And it has museums in the middle. As a SoCal native, I say ... what the what?

Parking is confusing. What else do you expect from SF....
author: Andrew M.

description:
There's nothing quite like Golden Gate Park. A huge breath of fresh air in the middle of the city that extends farther than the eye can see...

It's the only park I've been to where I can enjoy the grass for a picnic, check out some museums, and people watch. There's a lot going on, and it's a great place to relax on a beautiful day. 

I miss the weekends when I'd visit my late grandfather and we'd walk around in Golden Gate Park and end the visit with a Filet O' Fish at the McDonald's in the Haight. 

Those were the days...
author: Grace Y.

description: Place is huge! Took my dogs for a morning walk, wasn't the easiest thing to find. All I can say is, thank goodness for smartphones & the Yelp app. I used it to guide me through San Fran to this location. Place is well maintained, with cute little water falls and multiple trails. I've been to San Fran many times, but never made it here for some reason. My hubby went here years ago, during his first visit to San Fran and said that this is a must. He was right, it's a must
author: Jackie D.

description: It's the best because it's what I grew up loving and use as a benchmark.  It's got it all and it's bigger than Central Park!
author: Keith W.

description:
One of the best parks ever. With concerts going on during the summer each year and with stow lake available for people to paddle boat and rent out bicycles, this park is a must-go-to spot for people in the city. Also, its a great place to walk your dog on sundays since cars are not allowed in most of the park on Sundays.

Also, walking distance to the museums they have there as well. Also the japanese tea garden, the botanical garden, damn i can only go on!
author: Kenny L.

description: This park is so big, you need a few days just to explore the whole thing. Every time we go to San Francisco, we explore a new area and we're always amazed by it.
author: Josefina M.

description:
What's not to like about Golden Gate Park. Love the museums, love the small trails throughout and LOVE the fact that the park is closed to cars on Sundays. Walk, bike roller blade or rent a boat. There are free concerts in the park and the various museums have free days: The first Tuesday of every month is free at the de Young Museum and Every third Wednesday is free at the California Academy of Sciences.

You can never go wrong when you visit the Golden Gate Park! Love it!
author: Lydia P.

description:
I absolutely love GGP. It's such a wonderful place to run, relax, have a picnic, talk with friends, explore-- anything! I particularly like Stow Lake where you can paddleboat, or Spreckles lake, which is an awesome view of a beautiful lake and there are usually people playing with miniature remote control ships, which is nice.
Also, in other parts of the park, there are the 2 museums: the California Academy of Sciences as well as the DeYoung Museum. Both have great exhibits and can appeal to anybody, really. Also, in that same vicinity is the Japanese Tea Garden, which is one of my favorite places. The garden architectural landscape is amazing, and there are many paths to wander and enjoy. Also, they have a Japanese tea house where you can buy snacks and tea while looking out over the beautiful view.
You really can't go wrong here. Definitely worth it for a tourist, but really appeals to the non-tourist as well. Highly recommended.
author: Azinda M.

description: I don't think I'll ever be able to fully explore what this park has to offer
author: Adrian A.

description:
I'm not going to review the parts of the park that I visited today because altogether GGP is just beyond awesome!

Today's pick for me and my boyfriend was a walk through the Botanical Gardens, then a (10-minute drive with traffic) to the Dutch windmill, then a quick drive to see the bison, which I totally forgot are there. I loved every moment especially when discovering new spots.
author: Jamie L.

description:
Beautiful park! I haven't been here since I was little and I just realized that I was here for the Bay2Breakers.. a little intoxicated lol. 

Anyways, I was in the area for the science academy and brought my dog and we came here after the academy. Super beautiful day and peaceful! This park is huge so look at their maps to find your way, they are located everywhere. 

There are tons of stuff here to check out and visit so definitely plan a weekend trip and visit the museums and the botanical garden!!
author: Crystal V.

description: Really cool place to see San Fran!
author: Shelly S.

description:
In the 1890's Golden Gate park was the site of California's first world's fair, "The Midwinter Exposition of 1894". The purpose was to showcase San Francisco's mild winters and state's abundance.

After 110 years later, Golden Gate Park is nowhere what it once was. The City-owned park is still the most beautiful park in the planet. The city needs to eliminate the homeless hiding and sleeping in the bushes.

Matt and wifey took advantage of the Sunday road-closure and ride our bikes in the park, on our way toward Ocean Beach. The closure of the park is an excellent idea for those who come and ride your bike, jog, roller-blade, or sashay your metrosexual self in the park; but can be a nightmare for nearby residents, who faces traffic along Lincoln Blvd. Matt loves the idea of the closure of GGP on Sundays and hoping to take more advantage of it.
author: Matt G.

description: A great park and a required stop when showing out-of-towners a good time. Watch out for the weather its seems to be colder and more cloudy in that part of the city.
author: Jeremy S.

description: Beautiful park with so much to see! One day was not enough to even begin to explore. Parking is limited. My favorite part of my trip.
author: Kay Y.

description: I love the weather, the atmosphere here. I even bring my coworkers to walk and pic nic weekends.
author: Jennifer P.

description:
Between Golden Gate park and a beautiful rooftop in Sausalito, I managed to finally fall for San Francisco's splendor. 

I was fortunate enough to come to an event here and was struck by the size, it seemed large and varied. It reminded me a little of Central Park. 

After spending time laying out on a blanket with some of my favorite people from around the country and the world all basking in the sunlight. I walked up a small hillside, turned around and at that moment with the sun setting, and the park bathed in a noir, dusky light, I saw the fog rolling in to the park. Simply beautiful. 

Deep breath and add water, instant love.
author: Maria A.

description: I love this park! It's a great place to have a barbecue and hang out with friends. I came here once with friends...we played a little game of whiffle ball as we grilled some hambugers and hot dogs. After, we made crowns from dandelions. It was so relaxing after we fought for a parking spot and found a nice spot.
author: Margaret R.

description: I love going to the Golden Gate park. It definitely is a part of San Francisco everyone should visit. There are so many things going on here it's amazing. My favorite part is the Japanese tea gardens, botanical garden, and the Shakespeare park. I'd recommend to come early and just walk around and take in everything. Have a picnic as well. Or you can drive from place to place. Either way check it out!
author: Katalina R.

description: Spectacular.  Nothing better than spending a sunny weekend afternoon in Golden Gate Park.  So many trails to meander down, and gardens, and museums.  It's especially been a treat since this year's summer has been so lengthy.  Can't wait to get down here on my next opportunity -- it's amazing.
author: Mel G.

description: Tax money well spent! Beautiful park, plenty to check out, and great place for a relaxing stroll.
author: Irene L.

description: Visiting from the NW so many times, I still have not figure out this park with main traffic in the middle of the park.  From the outside, the park looked so grey and confusing.  It looked scary.  I don't know if I want to explore more besides the seaside part.
author: Flora C.

description: Decided to visit this massive park on a rare, clear, sunny, January day.....Friday at that.  PERFECT! This place has loads of different activities to do and plenty of space. lol. It wasn't too crowded with people and clear walk paths with manicured landscape for visitors to enjoy & go Instagram crazy on. Near the De Young museum is a courtyard with a fountain. Very peaceful with friendly patrons frolicking with their four-legged family. Even a slight yet soothing melody from a guitar playing set the scenic place as a eutopic oasis amid the dry personality exterior the city often possesses. This jewel (the park) is a staple of SF & should be enjoyed often as life permits.
author: S W.

description: I really enjoy the park! I was a little big for us to walk the whole thing so we did not get to explore it all but we came here so my kids could enjoy the playground and boy they sure did!. They had a rock slide which was just super fun. The only reason why I will not give it 5 is on our way to bus the neighbor was fill with drug dealers and homeless. They were other tourist around but just watch yourself around this part of town.
author: Carlos M.

description:
This park is amazing. It definitely reminds me of Central Park in NYC... in fact, I like it better than CP-- (fun fact): and 20% larger than CP. That's what Wiki said. The park is absolutely gorgeous, there are beautiful sights everywhere you look. 

There are so many things to see and do... I know if I were a San Franciscan I'd be there A LOT. It's a great place to walk/jog/run and take lunch for a picnic. The possibilities are endless.

My husband and I visited the Botanical Gardens here but weren't impressed with the actual gardens. Most of the areas looked like they needed pruning and better maintenance over all. A lot of the plants were dying or at least needed trimming. [I'm rambling, this belongs in another Yelp]. All I'm trying to say is... if you don't live in SF, don't spend the $7 to visit the Botanical Gardens. You can enjoy the park and won't miss out on much. 

If you're visiting and like the outdoors, Golden Gate Park is the place to be.
author: Patty G.

description:
Went here for my friend's birthday picnic. It was a bit chilly, but still an awesome place to throw some footballs or frisbee, sit and talk, drink beer and wine, snack on some chips and pita. 

You can't go wrong with Golden Gate Park, just be careful when you come out around sunset, the mosquitoes start to come out and eat you.
author: Erica T.

description: One of the most beautiful places in San Francisco. Home of Cal Academy of Sciences, Japanese Garden, Conservatory of Flowers, de Young, and more! Every major race runs through here (well, Bay to Breakers and Nike Women's Marathon).
author: Esther Y.

description:
I like the multicultural musician jam bands that congregate in the park.  One could definitely spend the day chilling out and listening to them.

Being openly asked, "Would you like to buy drugs?" upon entering the park, has its own special charm.  I met a gutter-punk kid here who was traveling the country with a wolf/husky mix on a leash.
author: Alf O.

description: With 745 reviews it doesn't need mine but I feel the need to urge people to enjoy this park. You see,  I never took the time to do so on my many trips to SF. There were cable cars to ride, food to try, a tower to climb, a crooked street to drive and I said how great could a city park be? Superb. Instead of one of many sights to see in a day, spend an entire day here. This place is super humongous. It is an oasis in the city.  So much to see and explore. It is beautiful, the air is cool and clean and the place reeks recreation and relaxation. Just do it!
author: H D.

description:
Amazing urban park makes you feel as if you were in the suburbs. Every city needs a park like this.
* Huge area
* Great biking and running trails
* Beautiful gardens
* Wild animals 
* Convenient location
author: Calvius W.

description:
I so under-appreciate this wonderful city that it's damn shameful.  For instance, I did not know til a few days ago that there was a bison refuge in the park.  I know, I suck.  My friend Emily and I ventured out on a late Sunday for a walk that turned into 6+ miles in search of the refuge.  Let's make it clear - I am not one of those runner/walker/baby stroller pushin' girls.  I prefer to park my ass on a picnic blanket and relax.  So, the fact that I walked so much inadvertently and really enjoyed myself is a testament to this place.

I should say that I've done something that very few people have done -camped out here overnight for the Dave Matthews Band Golden Gate show.  The park is crazy cold & scary at night, but I felt like we bonded that night.

Also, apparently, Gavin wants to do good things for the park.  A woman just randomly started talking to us about the sex trade & drugs that goes in the park (this I knew) and how Gavin wants to allocate $$ for park patrol.  So as concerned citizens, we should write letters supporting this move.  If it makes the park safer, I'm all for it.  Although during my overnight "sleepover", I didn't encounter anything shady...
author: Helen F.

description: Cool park. Huge amount of land. Plenty of green surroundings. Fresh air and lots of exercise here to be had. A Dutch windmill built in 1902. Ducks in a pond. Odd looking people feeding those ducks. Free parking. What else do you want?
author: Warren C.

description:
Where else can I see bison in the Bay Area????? I think I'll go visit them this weekend.

The new Academy of Sciences, Japanese Tea Garden, DeYoung, archery, row boats at Stow Lake, other lakes, many parks, concerts, flying fish? or fish flying & so forth are located right in between the Richmond & Sunset District...also in between the Haight (Stanyan-ish area) & Ocean Beach. There are probably much more things to do in the park, I just don't know.

When I was younger & occasionally still do, I would bike inside GGP. As I am getting older, the trails are much harder and steeper, not as fit as I use to be.

I believe reading somewhere that this park is bigger than Central Park...I haven't been there YET, so I wouldn't know.

Remember not to feed the birds (fyi, it's ILLEGAL), they'll keep making babies & those babies will poo on your head.
author: Kylie L.

description:
Golden Gate Park, by far, is one of me and the boyfriends favorite ways to spend a day in San Francisco. We normally start at the De Young, then head over to the Japanese Tea Garden for a snack and some tea... and of course some gummy candies. Then, we'll either head to the Botanical Garden for a stroll and with a nap and picnic included or the same at  Armstrong Grove. Sometimes both if we're feeling up to it or we haven't finished our blaze yet! The squirrels at the Garden are VERY aggressive. But bring a little treat for them anyway because it's kind of fun to see how crazy they can be. I'm sure this is probably not allowed by the parks so of course  I want to mention I haven't experienced this myself, firsthand or anything =)

I'm excited about the opening of the Science Center here and can't wait to see it! I'll update this as soon as  I do. 

Golden Gate Park is an excellent opportunity to experience something beside the go-go-go ways of San Francisco. If I lived in the city, I would probably be here every weekend!
author: Laila P.

description:
The best park I've ever been to! It's ridiculously LARGE! There is plenty to do here and multiple things occurring day in and day out. From concerts to rollerblading to playing playing a game of baseball to taking a trio to the flower garden and watching the wild buffalo roaming their designated area. This place is pure magic. 
Big enough to take a wrong turn and get lost. So many good things to say about this place. Take a day and Go check it out for yourself, you won't be disappointed.
author: Joshua P.

description: :)  I love the idea of Golden Gate Park, but at the end of the day-- it's a big city park.
author: Kendall R.

description: This place is HUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUGE! We spent a couple hours here and we still didn't get to look at everything the park has to offer. It's really an all day adventure here. We enjoyed the CA Academy of Sciences here. By the time we parked, walked to the Academy of Sciences and explored it and left, we were pooped. My friend didn't want to hike/walk anymore so we ended up giving up early... but next time I want to come back and definitely explore the park much more in detail!
author: Nari L.

description:
GIGANTOR!!!

When planning our trip to GGP I downloaded a map and made not of all the things we wanted to see: www.sfgate.com/traveler/acrobat/maps/1999/ggparkmap.pdf 
I thought we could park somewhere on the perimeter, wander in and walk our way through to our chosen destinations.  With a 2 y.o.  In a stroller.

HAHAHAHAHAHAHA!!!!

Oh, silly me.  We'd have to live in this city to have the sort of time it would take to see everything we wanted to in one visit, never mind the rest of the park's awesome amenities.

Come to think of it, that wouldn't suck.
author: Christmas D.

description:
Seeing that I was the quintessential San Francisco tourist while visiting I had to visit Golden Gate Park.  I saw the Dutch Windmill but missed the Bison and Hippie Hill, I'm sad about the Bison but not so much about the hippies.  

Besides windmills, bison and hippies Gold Gate Park is also home to the de Young Museum, Academy of Sciences (currently closed), Strawberry Hill and it's artificially made waterfall, the Aids Memorial Grove, San Francisco Botanical Garden, Japanese Tea Garden and Garden of Shakespeare's Flowers along with a few other things, so many things are here for you to enjoy.  

It truly is a beautiful park and on a warm sunny day it is a great place to spend the afternoon roaming around and checking out all the gardens and sites.
author: Me H.

description:
Ever heard the saying "if you're bored than you're boring?"

I can't vouch that it works for everything, but it certainly should ring true for Golden Gate Park. I have been to this park as both a tourist and a resident now. If I could only give one reason to keep going back, it's that as many times as I've been to GG Park, there's always something I have yet to discover about the place. Where else can you find both a buffalo pen and an open space for hippies to smoke and hold drum circles, Love Fest and an AIDS memorial walk, dog parks and windmills, walking trails and an art building, playgrounds and thousands of plant species?

Yes, there really is something for just about everybody here.  If you're bored in Golden Gate park, then yes, you may very well be boring.
author: Kat E.

description: On my 3rd trip to San Francisco, I finally visited this park. It is clean, beautiful & historic. We walked the first day & biked the next day. This park is very huge. Wear nice pair of walking shoes & clothes depending on weather. Lots of attractions. They have food trucks, stands. Average restroom all around. Most of them were out of toilet paper. The east side of the park have lots of homeless. Once you pass the first 300 yards, you will see what 'm talking about. I suggest to rent a bike, pack snacks, booze, water, football or freezbie, baseball, kite, depending on your interest.
author: Vlren P.

description:
Golden Gate Park is a gem.  To me, its the best park in the world which makes SF one of the best Cities to live in.  Golden Gate Park is public so we can spend all the your time exploring and taking advantage of what it has to offer, http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Golden_Gate_Park  

I consider it my big backyard :)
author: S F.

description: Love this place! So peaceful, beautiful and HUGE. I've lived in the bay area all my life and never have I ever been to this place until last week. There's lots of things you can do like play tennis, ride a carousel, stroll though the japanese tea or botanical garden, go to a museum, or even mini hike through the place. You can even rent a bike, which I plan on doing next time b/c the place is so big!
author: Krissy L.

description:
I love Golden Gate Park! Wonderful sanctuary in the city.

If I lived in San Francisco I'd be here all the time. Huge, beautiful trees, tons of green grass & plants, lots of neat gardens to see (Japanese Tea Garden, Shakespeare Garden, etc.) Plus of course the Botanical Pavilion, Conservatory of Flowers... etc. etc.

I plan on spending more time in GGP the next time I get to visit San Francisco. :)
author: Carrie O.

description: A true jewel in the City.  I have wanted to explore this park for many years and finally had the opportunity to get a start on it.  The Conservatory is spectacular, the Japanese Tea Garden is so serene and beautiful and the view from the Hamon Tower at the deYoung Museum was breathtaking.   I know we only touched on one small part of it, but what we did see and experience was incredible.
author: Elise G.

description:
It is obvious why this is San Franciscans' back yard. There is so much to do: conservatory of flowers, deyoung museum, academy of science, Dutch windmill, beach chalet.  The list goes on. I am just happy riding the bike. If only I could add a stop along the way and have a good sun-worshiping moment. He he. Gotta have dreams. 
Sfmta better not mess this up and add parking meters!
author: Rupert W.

description:
Golden Gate Park is the Central Park of the West. They are equally wonderful, magnificent, and gorgeous.

Golden Gate Park is incredible. It is one of the treasures of San Francisco.It contains just about everything a person could be looking for. It contains multiple museums, (nightlife at the museums), meadows for picnics, tea garden, frisbee golf, free Summer concerts beaches on the west side, lakes, creeks, and waterfalls. Golden Gate Park is versatile.

Its versatility makes it a great date spot and awesome place to visit and spend the afternoon.
author: Richard K.

description:
I'm a sucker for large city parks, especially one like this that has everything from tennis courts to a carousel and Japanese Tea Gardens located inside.  One could spend days in the park and still not uncover everything there is to explore.

The only major negative I have here is that I was offered drugs 3 times in the first 15 minutes I was there.  Literally.  Here I was on a lovely Thursday morning stroll, taking in the sights, looking with anticipation at the areas of the park I would visit in my limited amount of time, and it becomes apparent that the people in the park see me as a wandering addict looking for a fix. 

Not cool.

And yet, I can't fault the pretty park for the issues of the masses.
author: Miss L.

description:
This park is soooo huge!! Seriously...

I purposely planned a long layover in SF, so that I could go out in the city -- check out the park, meander around, get some good food, and just explore. 

Visiting GGP was first on my to-do list (after checking my email at a coffee shop) - ha! I've never explored before on all my other visits to the city, so I definitely wanted to atleast see it on this visit. 

First of all -- it is huge people! Huge....  And so beautiful! I took the Muni bus #5 from market, after getting off the BART. So it's a convenient bus ride. And then I think I stopped around 8th avenue... and just walked through the park a little. 

It was so beautiful - -all the gorgeous green trees, flowers, plants. I just loved even the smell of the park... so refreshing. 

It was so peaceful and a nice escape... to just wander through the park. 

There was much left unseen, so next time I'm in town I'll be able to explore more.
author: Jessica A.

description:
My favorite park in the world! This review will mainly focus on running but whether you're alone, on a date, with your family, kids, the milkman, or a bunch of friends, GGP has something for everyone:

BBQ and play ultimate frisbee at Speedway Meadow. 

Take your kids on a carousel ride.

Visit the California Academy of Sciences and the De Young Museum.

Rent tandem bikes and head west towards Ocean Beach.

Catch a free concert at the concourse.

Learn how to swing dance on Sundays.

Take a painting, sculpture, or drawing class at Sharon Art Studio.

Go for a boat ride around Stow Lake.

Explore the many trails and roads that wind through the park.

Dance, skate, and people watch at Skatin' Place Sundays in the Park (see my other review for details).

*I could go on and on*

But I'll stop here and focus on my favorite activity in the park - RUNNING!  There are a myriad of running trails and having lived in San Francisco for 20+ years and thinking I've covered them all, I always find another waiting to be explored. 

My usual (~10 mile) route covers all the basics:

From Fell Street, enter John F. Kennedy (JFK) Drive and run past the Conservatory of Flowers, and either continue straight or turn left and enter the road that loops around the museums and the Japanese Tea Garden. 

Exit back onto JFK Drive and continue past the beautiful rose garden and Stow Lake where you can do a loop, stop for a drink of water, or use the restrooms. Continuing on, you'll approach Spreckels Lake where you can either turn left into the stadium area or go straight. Here's where the bison hang out. Yes, you read correctly. There's bison in Golden Gate Park! They are fenced in so don't worry, you won't be running for your life, just past them while staying on JFK.

If you've made it this far, there's no reason to stop now. Just a little further is the golf course on your right and then a few paces past that is Ocean Beach, where I often end up taking a breather and stretching. 

Insider tip: If you get tired or lost inside the park, just head north or south and you'll end up on Fulton Street or Lincoln Way, respectively where you can catch a bus. 

There are many other options and the possibilities are endless, but this is definitely a great place to start. Happy running!
author: Patty L.

description:
I am a die-hard, enthused lover of trees, nature, and green. But like many people I also hold a deep appreciation of culture, convenience, and urban life. So naturally Golden Gate Park provides me a perfect and treasured slice of metropolitan heaven. If you enjoy the outdoors, love exploring, and treasure gems in a big city, you will fall in love with the endless surprises you'll see and experience at GGP. There is something for everyone here.

Just some suggestions: If you enjoy physical activities, you can find hiking trails at Stow Lake, turn a shrubby corner and play a few sets of tennis, bring a soccer ball or frisbee and get some running into your afternoon. If you enjoy artistic and architectural sights, there is the metallic DeYoung Museum, the Asian Art Museum, and the Strybing Arboretum. Or perhaps you enjoy the finer charms and details of life, you would love the Shakespeare Garden with its romantic air and the AIDS Memorial Grove with the peaceful breeze and friendly crowd. 

GGP is one of the best investments and best use of public space San Francisco could have created for its residents and daily tourists. Even better, GGP is going green with rain-collecting roofs to help lower the use and waste of water along with moss-insulated panels to help decrease the use of electricity. This place is great! I love San Francisco!!!
author: Ellen C.

description: Love the live music they have had,especially when they had Reggae in the park. That was good times ;)
author: Dani D.

description:
Hands down, one of my most favorite parks in the WORLD! 

I love how I can still get lost here, after years of visiting. I can just walk forever. It's like a forest. 
I love the weather of San Francisco. It goes well with the park's tree atmosphere. It's fairly clean. 

OutsideLands is held here! Currently living in Los Angeles, making a trip up north is a must for me at least once a year!
author: Dave A.

description: this is a great place to take kids. I climb the giant rope pyramid with my 10 year old son. It's the absolute greatest junglegym feature I've ever seen. Pretty eclectic place overall, and i really enjoy the walks too
author: Daniel M.

description:
You could spend weeks roaming around this place.
It's amazing.
The Japanese Tea Garden is a must !
author: J S.

description: Okay this place is massive and wonderful. we walked a lot of it and went in the gardens I had so much fun here and you have to sit and have tea it is so nice.
author: Shane A.

description: It's nice up there. We toured the Japanese tea gardens which was beautiful. We parked on the street and saw people exercising and walking back to their cars from touring the Japanese tea gardens or botanical gardens. Lots of cars parked on the street. We checked out early and left our luggage in our tinted rental car and when we got back to our car, it got broken into. Plz don't leave any valuables in your car.
author: Roseanne S.

description:
Shame on me for dismissing Golden Gate Park like it didn't have anything to offer!

Now that I've had the chance to explore more of Golden Gate Park while on my runs, I couldn't be more grateful to have this sprawling park so close-by. 

Stow Lake is definitely a favorite w/ its mini island for you to conquer on foot or by bike, and a few picnic tables to lunch on around the perimeter. And if you're looking to have a bit of fun on the water, there's paddleboats for you to rent as well. 

Other GG Park treats... the Conservatory of Flowers (w/ a dahlia garden to the right of it), the Botanical Gardens (you get free admission if you're an sf resident! w/ such small crowds, it's like your own private park), the small bison paddock, the charming windmill, Spreckels Lake (where people race their remote control mini boats), the frisbee golf course, the De Young & Academy of Science museums (my favorite sf museums), and Kezar Stadium (perfect for doing stair workouts). 

I really feel like I've fallen in love w/ this park over the last few months and have found a new appreciation for it. I'm sorry I ever doubted you, GG park!
author: Tiffany M.

description: I could seriously spend all day here. It's so gorgeous and there's so many things to do around the park!
author: Licia L.

description:
I got married right under the windmill at Queen Wilhemina Garden...in August, a month notorious for fog-drenched days.  But on our wedding day, the sun was out, it was a balmy 72 degrees.  I can still remember the tour buses out in full force with the guide and his megaphone doing a play by play...I suspect our wedding is probably captured on some midwesterner's home video collection.  

How can I give this park less than 5 stars?
author: Joc V.

description:
Golden Gate Park, one the largest urban parks (174 acres larger than Central Park!) in the world, holds so many wonderful memories.  Some of my favorites include singing opera with my friends during the annual Opera in the Park celebration, running through during Bay to Breakers, assembling at the Windmill with other runners during marathon training, and every single visit I've made to the deYoung museum.

Safely tucked away inside this inner-city oasis you'll find the Shakespeare Garden, bison grazing and plenty of space for picnics and BBQ's. On Sundays, a big stretch of the park is closed to cars and that's when you'll find parents teaching their kids to ride bikes, folks dancing on roller skates, runners, cyclists, skate boarders - there are even swing dancing lessons at 12:30!

We San Franciscans are truly lucky to have Golden Gate Park in our fair city.
author: Miriam W.

description:
What a HUGE park!!  If I lived up in the SF area I would come and go for a jog here every now and then.  There are so many little hidden parks within this park (like the Japanese Tea Garden)... there are art galleries and an outdoor amphitheater too.. I can't imagine getting sick of this place.  I would totally come here for a photo shoot or something, so many things to see and do.

Really really greaat place.
author: Angela C.

description:
I'm not sure that I wouldn't rank Golden Gate Park ahead of Central Park as the #1 urban park in America.  In any case, they are very close, and put to shame anything that Chicago has to offer (I'm looking at you, Grant Park, Millennium Park, and Lincoln Park).  

The immense variety of things to do in the park is terrific.  Really, you can walk around for hours and be entertained, edified, and put at peace all in the same morning or afternoon.  The grounds are extensive, so it's possible to take several little bites of the park and never see the same thing, or to spend a day exploring its entirety.  Favorites of mine are the Shakespeare Garden, the Dutch windmill, the De Young Museum and Music Concourse vicinity, and the buffalo paddock.
author: David R.

description: We spent a whole day in Golden Gate Park, part of that time in the Japanese Tea Garden.  Awesome place.  Beautiful arrangements of landscaping elements to form a unique environment to explore and enjoy.   We spent about 90 minutes there.  Well worth it.  There is so much to do and see in GGP that you can't squeeze it all into one day...  next stop was the Conservatory...... Don't miss the  Starwberry Hill and the American Bison and the old Windmills by the beach .... Then there are the two museums which we did not get to but will in the future.  Can't rate those at this point but we have heard good things about them.... those will be for a rainy day..... hopefully we get some of the wet stuff soon, we need it !!
author: Patrick C.

description: How can you not love a big park? It's different from other urban parks like Central Park because it gives the feeling that you are really truly separated. One of my favorite weekend activities is to take a long stroll and there are few better places. I live so close and I try to take advantage of this part as much as possible.
author: Brittany N.

description: Such a beautiful oasis, John McLaren developed in the early 1900's, he was brought in from NY Central Park.  Mosiacs, murals, wood carvings and statues.  A 9 hole golf course, archery filed, museums and Stow lake.
author: DJ J.

description: This place is amazing, it's like 15 parks rolled into one. I've been here a ton, and I still find new nooks and crannies. Great place to go biking or jogging, and I love the fact that they shut down JFK on Sundays. We always bring company here when they're in town, but it's hard to convey the immensity of the park to someone in a single visit/day.
author: Pat M.

description:
There are many, many reasons I love living in this magical city...but running in GGP is first on my list.  

The park is huge and well maintained, is dog friendly, and has all kinds of natural wild life such as turtles, bisons, fish, birds, cat colonies, and horses... And it is always open!  I love the variety of plants and flowers too.  There are lots of museums and cultural events for when I want to be around people, and lots of trails to run for when I want to away from everybody.

It is SF's best kept secret.  Oh wait, it is not a secret since there are thousands there each day...but the park is so huge and well organized you would never know it!
author: Quality T.

description: How?! HOW?!!! How can anyone review this park as a whole? It's impossible! There's so much to do and so much to see and each site, each meadow, they're all so different. Nature galore! Beauty galore! Activities galore! Festivals galore! All so accessible! I don't know what else to say. I don't know if I even have the time to Yelp all that there is to Yelp about this awesome park. Oh, but I will try!
author: Helen L.

description: 420 Fest here was AWESOME! no fights. no negative energy. hippies EVERYWHERE! Cops only on four wheelers and on the streets. They bugged NO ONE, only directed traffic. And made sure everyone was getting along. Edibles EVERYWHERE! insense, music, rap battles, beer, food, edibles.. a stoners dream! The park was beautiful and made me want to go back for moore on a day there isn't trash everywhere and a million people crowding it. GOOD TIMES!
author: Jacinda F.

description:
If you're visiting San Francisco on vacation like I was, know that you could easily spend an entire day exploring this park. We were exploring on foot and started the day late, so my friend and I weren't able to cover every square inch like we had hoped, but what we did see was fantastic. 

The bulk of our time was spent meandering on the paths through the botanical gardens. In early March, it was refreshing to see flowers and trees blooming and blossoming and the smell was divine! The gardens would be the perfect place to plop down for some quiet time. 

From the botanical gardens we headed to Stow Lake and Strawberry Hill where serene photo ops abounded and then peered in to the Japanese Tea Gardens from the outside- pretty! Had we had more time, I would have liked to visit the de Young and Asian Art museums. 

The park is easily accessible and near several bus routes. You will be missing out if you don't add this to your agenda!
author: Emily T.

description: This is like my 3rd or 4th time here. I love coming here cuz of all the people and atmosphere, but I hate the parking situation.  I wish there were more free parking spots.
author: Thyda S.

description: Popular Tourist attraction but so large that you are not crowded with people.  Dogs are welcome on leash. I have walked here many times and I see new parts every time I go. Many of the attractions has free days to attend.  Many different fields to do different activities such as Frisbee and soccer. Recently just found Stow Lake which was a hidden treasure. Fun place just to walk around and take photos.
author: Maverick W.

description:
I remember the different style of trees and the various colours of the leafs and the enormity of this glorious green space.

I remember the beautiful little lakes, with the mini waterfalls.

I remember the Japanese tea room on the way, what a beautiful sight.

I remember the paths we cycled through, with the glorious height of the trees above us, lending us it shade in the warm sun.

I remember the windmills that we passed and the distance of the Golden Gate Bridge not far, and saying "Ah we are nearly dear"

I remember leaving with sheer delight on my face and thanking my Creator for this beautiful place.   :))
author: Omoraka O.

description: One of the coolest places I saw in SF. Lots of people there, the flora & fauna are incredible, wish I'd had more time to spend there walking around!
author: Tom T.

description: I've lived by GGP my entire life and had taken it for granted long enough. I'm usually driving through on my way home, but the recent beautiful weather got me running and I'm not a runner. Hell, I'm not even a walker. There are so many great things to see in the park, even if you're not there to run. Every time I go for a run I see something new. It's kind of hard to not get distracted by all the great things happening here.
author: Adelina W.

description: My family spends time at this park every time we visit San Francisco. The Buffalo Paddock, Pétanque Courts, the museums and the natural beauty are all favorites. Last weekend my daughter and I decided to go to the Japanese Tea Garden and have a cup of tea before I put her on her flight and I was to go to Sonoma for a beekeeper's party in Sonoma County. The tea and the garden were amazing; as we walked to our car parked along MLK Jr Dr toward Crossover car after car had broken windows all to have their plans changed. It happens everyday I learned. Two tall thin African males dressed in black systematically, with electronic detecting devices go down the street and ruin unsuspecting visitors plans. If your visiting the park and find back packs laying about please give them to Richmond Station Police Station 415.666.8000. If yours is stolen call 415,553.1377 this is where all items are logged and turned in.
author: Denise D.

description: No other park can compare. I'm blessed to live 2 blocks from this beauty.
author: Trisha D.

description: This park is amazing! There is no other that can compare. The many options I have to go for a jog, have a picnic, throw a frisbee or act like a kid and swing on a swing set are endless. I have enjoyed many outings to Stow Lake to feed the birds, row a boat and get great views at the highest point of the Golden gate bridge and the rest of the city. The panhandle is completely included as well - such a great diverse group of people, both strange and the not-so-strange, runners, cyclists, skateboarders. It's all just beautiful. I will always consider this my favorite park in the entire city and will continue to make it my #1 spot for a jog, just as it has been for the past 2 years.
author: Amber Y.

description:
I likesssssssss! 

Co Planned a 4th of July BBQ here. We reserved 2 tables at the Speedway Meadow. This place had a restroom and a volleyball net. VERY NICE!! 

So you need to get a yearly permit which is $25 in order to reserve the tables. I like it.. because you can get there whenever. They also have grills for bbqing. 

The only trouble is that it's really hard to find, and people get frustrated trying to find it. hahaha Sadly !!! the GPS sometimes loses signal and the road signs are hard to find. Parking can be an issue especially during the holidays.
author: Jenna L.

description: This place is the bomb.  Nature in the city.  They have different plants everywhere, art to see, and the tea garden was great too.  I would highly recommend exploring.
author: Jason H.

description:
Whooo! what a huge park!

Finally had a chance to come back to check out the windmills and the bisons.  Very cool free attractions!

Too many attractions and not enough time!!
author: sherry t.

description: Must see! Check out the amazing views from the free observatory. Gray place to bike and enjoy. Beautiful gardens and surroundings. Lots of museums packed into a smaller area. Lots to see, enjoy and do.
author: Rosie P.

description:
Chicago spent $750 million on Millenium Park! We got taken. 

Good going San Francisco. This park is beautiful!

You can spend a couple of days in GGP. My family loved it.
author: Ennos P.

description: I've lived in New York, I've been to Central Park countless times... It has a certain charm to it. However, Golden Gate Park is truly triple the charm, quadruple the hiking paths and trails. The atmosphere is just so carefree and breathtaking. The bike paths allow safe access for both bicyclists and cars, just be careful at the intersections... Bicyclists (for the most part) just ride straight through without stopping at the stop signs. The lakes are endless in the park, along with two waterfalls (the big one on the main road in the park) and also the one by stow lake. Not only that, but of you are up for the hike you can walk, jog, or run the length of the park straight to ocean beach(and the pacific ocean!). I love this park, who wouldn't!?
author: Ashley D.

description: Golden Gate Park is definitely a park to rival all other parks. Its winding paths and vast hills are ideal for any type of setting you're looking for. There are tons of different types of trees and flowers to admire as well as courts and fields to play a pick up game. It is too bad that the homeless take over certain parts of the grass, but I recommend going farther west for the less crowded, less adulterated part of the park.
author: Jess L.

description:
I spent most of last Saturday in the park drinking 99-cent wine and playing croquet and bocce ball on the lawn with some friends.

I have no idea what the alcohol laws are in the park, but our consumption was flagrant and other than a lone hobo who asked for a cup of wine we weren't bothered by anyone.

My only complaint about the park is that I wish people there were a little bit friendlier and more outgoing.
author: James C.

description:
Gorgeous park with tall canopy trees, trails and lots of fun things to do. This is a park for biking, running, and sight-seeing. It is similar to Balboa in San Diego and I'm told bigger than Central Park.

Alice 97.3 puts on a great Summerthing with free concerts!
author: Stephanie H.

description:
REASONS WHY I LOVE GG PARK:


1. I live only 100 ft from the park
2. Great run, jog, walk and bike ride
3. Frisbee Golf
4. Academy of Sciences 
5. de Young Museum
6. Conservatory of Flowers
7. Japanese Tea Garden
8. Botanical Garden at Strybing Arboretum
9. Koret Children's Quarter
10. Children's Playground
11. Beach Chalet Brewery and Restaurant
 
Here is a map of the park and things to visit and do:

http://www.sfgate.com/traveler/acrobat/maps/1999/ggparkmap.pdf



ENJOY!
author: Oliver D.

description:
This is one of my most favorite places for a stroll.  The sights, sounds and sometimes smells are amazeballs.  I feel so "one" with nature here.  Walks here always take longer than they should because there is always a detour like the de young or the food trucks over there to stop you from walking briskly.  I feel most accomplished once I walk through the joint because it's so beautiful and so long of a walk, because we start from the windmills or the lake by the flying disc place.  

I have been here many times to enjoy the park for its wonderous places.
author: Daphne A.

description: This is a review of the park as a running trail. For that it is excellent, with long stretches of unbroken flat asphalt and multiple pathways. Total loop if you wanted to cover the entire park once would be around 6 miles depending on the pathway. The views are gorgeous with lots of people and activity. Weather is San Francisco chilly. It's the majority of the path for the Kaiser half-marathon, voted most scenic half marathon in the country so that should give you a hint All in all, a great place to exercise.
author: John N.

description: What's not to love. Beautiful park, on a spectacular day. Bring it on!
author: Ric P.

description:
Beautiful, awesome! 

If you don't like to walk around and just enjoy the beautiful sights it's not for you. You are better off just looking at pictures that people take. 

My husband and I wanted to move and were excited to see and be around lots of runners, walkers, bikers, rollerbladers out and about getting their fitness on in such a beautiful area!

We walked half the park to Stow Lake then rented a tandem bike to bike the rest of the park out to the ocean.  We didn't feel comfortable biking on the roads so we chose to bike on the paths. I wish the paths were a little wider when there is so much traffic on them as we often found ourselves in "pedestrian traffic jams".  

After we viewed the ocean we biked back to Stow lake where we rented the bike to return them. ($15 for one tandem bike for one hour).
author: Jenny D.

description:
I lived in the city for years so anytime I get to hang out with mother earth golden gate park is the place to be.

Well maintained park.

Parking can be a hassle depending what event is going in the weekends.
author: Michael m.
