description: My mommy & daddy used to take me to go play in the playground whenever I was a little kiddie. I love the rose garden because of all the different beautiful roses! The japanese tea garden is nice too & they charge an admission. If you want to check out a pretty nice (free) japanese garden, go to the one in Hayward or San Jose. Also, the paddle/row boats are fun. It's a very big park with lots of trails & things to do.
author: Amy C.

description:
Limited through-traffic on Sundays
Parking in the park
Miles upon miles of running trails
Lindy on Sundays
Dancing rollerbladers
De Young/Cal Academy
Sunshine (sometimes)
Outsidelands
The occasional vintage car show

Smiles.
author: Amanda F.

description:
Tried to go to the Conservatory of Flowers two days in a row.  Sunday, couldn't find parking; Monday, it was closed;(

But we managed to find a lovely walk that we hadn't discovered before during our numerous visits to GG Park.  Found a algae covered pond that looked like it was completely covered in lime green felt.  The greenery surrounding it looked like something out of Jurassic Park.   Such an oasis in the middle of the city!
author: Janet S.

description:
I came to this park with my friend for a holiday/end of the semester BBQ.

I had a most fun time here at this park. I thought this park was just beautiful and amazing!! My friend and I walked around this huge pond and I just thought it was beautiful!!

This place is lovely and a great and wonderful place to take the family on a nice sunny day. This place is just hands down beautiful!!!
author: Andy C.

description:
Can I just say how lucky I am to live in San Francisco?

I'm a runner, a cyclist, and nature loving S.O.B. I cannot live without this park now that I moved 2 blocks away from it.

This park is huge! I once had to use my GPS to get me back on the road to my house. On the weekends, they close down JFK Drive for pedestrians and cyclist to roam freely on the roads without the fear of getting hit by a car. There's concerts and events almost every weekend, a skateboarding area, several types of gardens, lakes, pedal/row boat rentals, museums, hiking trails, wildlife, and the beach! There's dance lessons on sidewalks, people randomly playing music, a fenced in dog park, hippies, recreational/track field, etc. The list goes on and on. 

This park is great for dates, old people, kids... you name it, buddy. This parks got you covered.
author: Mary Anne R.

description: This was a lovely park for a Sunday morning; we especially loved the Japanese tea garden. I'd recommend renting bikes because the distances can be rather far. Also, wear layers. We were there in August and it was freezing.
author: Emily S.

description: Super foggy and chilly, so the cold air was wet. Gorgeous grounds and parks. Be sure to dress in layers.
author: Mariena F.

description: LOVE THIS PLACE!!!!  I can spend the whole day here.  I went to almost all of the highlights at the park.  The best areas are the Japanese Garden, Stowe Lake to row a boat, and bisons.  I wished the windmills had tulips like the pictures in the website.  Cant wait to come back
author: JAN I.

description:
this park is awesome. there is a chance i might be mistaking golden gate with a different park in SF, but i saw buffalo here one time in a huge enclosed area. how cool is that? it was even more amazing that i was wearing a modest mouse shirt with a buffalo on it. 

buffalo aside and back to the awesome, this place is a great place to go for a walk. watch out for some turns have some pretty strange characters sitting around but where doesn't.
author: Walt D.

description: Gorgeous. What strikes me above all else are the smells of the florae and faunae. So much to do and see. Bison! People grilling the crap outta some hot dogs on the weekends. Lovers entwined. Peeps jogging and biking. One of the best public parks in a large metropolitan area in the country.
author: Mike O.

description: AWESOMENESS! My favorite place to just walk about and kill time...
author: Jesse G.

description: My oasis in the city. If I want quiet I have quiet and if I want music, people watching and fun I get it there as well.   Great place for a picnic as well.
author: Margaret C.

description: This is one masive park. To bad you have to pay for everything you enter. Great for walks, jogging and children.
author: Shakei D.

description:
This is a great place to ride your bikes.  If you live in SF, you could come here every weekend for a year and not see the same thing twice.  If you are from out of town, you might want to just drive through and look at everything, check out the museums (must see the academy of sciences).  You could spend your whole trip here.  It is larger than central park in NYC and a lot more exciting too.  

Go here with various weather conditions as well; it can be a totally different experience.  When it is sunny it is nice to ride your bike from haight straight to the coast.  On a foggy day, take a stroll through the botanical gardens and japanese tea garden.  Both are great.
author: Jonathan U.

description:
Be careful of the gutter punks selling weed near the McDonald's-side entrance to the park. I've been ripped off many times and once almost robbed. 

I think it's great and all that they maintain this park, and blah blah blah it's beautiful but I think Dolores Park is far superior. 

Of course D.P. seems to be the hip choice for locals as a park lately so by the time you get there it'll probably be run over with said gutter punks slinging their crummy "weed." 

But anyway, Golden Gate Park is O.K. and it's definitely a must-see if you've, you know, never seen it. But don't buy weed there.
author: Chris S.

description: I love the Golden Gate Park, the thing I love the most about this place is when you walk down the paths people stop and look at you. They look at you straight in the eye and keep looking at you until you pass them by. Great place to find inner peace and to go people watching. Very Serene and comforting!
author: Sam N.

description:
I dig this park; I run here every week , I run all the way down to the Ocean. As you come down the road and around the bend, you see  Ocean beach, and that in itself is worth it.   Whether the weather is cool, foggy , misty or sunny,  running to the beach and seeing the crashing waves and smelling the salty air is wonderful. 

  As the seasons change so does this park, seems there is always some thing changin' at GG park. Its huge - bigger than New Yorks Central Park. yep. Lush and land scape architecture is not rigid but free !   :)

  The half dozen man made lakes are soothing too.   Across from the planetarium, look for the area full of Ferns, and check it out on foot, it's like being in a prehistoric time period. If no one is around, laydown on your back under a giant fern and day dream, it's great!
author: Bert K.

description: Golden Gate Park: surrounded by the Cal Academy of Sciences, Japanese Tea Gardens, food trucks, botanical gardens, and a huge green park in the middle of it all. It's a tourist attraction, but I'm sure it attracts a lot of locals too. If I lived in this area, I would definitely be more motivated to jog ;)
author: Amy Q.

description:
I absolutely love this beautiful park! I love it even more because it's my garden/backyard (basicially). I've always lived within walking distance to it. What's not to like? There's buffalo (seriously), lakes, ponds, woods, trees, great expanses of green meadows for picnics, a lovely botanical garden, windmills, a major art museum...there's so much to do!

I like going to the San Francisco Botanical Garden here (there are redwoods!), as well as the Conservatory of Flowers (historic and pretty Victorian greenhouse), De Young Museum, the Shakespeare Garden, the Rose Garden, rowing boats on picturesque Stow Lake, hiking up Strawberry Hill for amazing views of San Francisco and the bay, having tea at the Japanese Tea Garden, watching musical performances at the Music Concourse, watching the model boats on Spreckels Lake...the list goes on. I still have yet to see the Academy of Sciences which I hope to do so soon.
author: Helena H.

description:
It's a huge park in my eyes and there are all walks of life.. museum goers, cyclists, walkers, kids at the playgrounds, people picnic'ing, and random people like me standing by the lake to feed turtles, Koi fishes, and turtles!  

The park is clean and very crowded almost always.  The garage is normally full and parking is scarce near the kids' play area.. but it's oh so worth of it if you have the patience.. such a scenic and calming experience..
author: Tram N.

description: Had a wonderful day at Golden Gate park.  Bison, remote controlled boats, fantastic paths, and a beautiful polo field!
author: Mitchell L.

description:
hello awesome park. Great weather, great walking, and lots of museums, flowers, trails, and plenty of people watching. 

This is a cool place to hang out during the day. You can walk into the De Young, tour the exhibits, go up to the 9th floor of the tower (free) and see an awesome image of the entire city and greater bay area. Very cool place to visit. The Academy of Sciences looked like a fun way to spend some time as well.
author: Amit K.

description: This park is beautiful and vast...a great green space. It has a terrific botanical garden you must see. The Academy of Sciences is here too. The one big drawback for me though is feeling unsafe when walking from the outer edges of the park toward the populated areas. Last spring I walked to GGPark from Union Square. I saw a trail at the beginning of the park and figured I would take it instead of walking down the road to the garden areas. 5 mins into the walk this mentally unstable man walked up and starting gibbering about something or other. He was the size of a twig so I wasn't really that worried - I was basically ready to pounce if needed - but he was so out of it I was wondering what craziness he was pondering. After that I kept walking and saw a lot of packs of homeless people hanging out on the trail. That's when I decided to go back and walk on the street to the main entrances.
author: Isabella L.

description: This is truly one of the great parks, great museums, botanical gardens, hiking trail, I have been here several times and still find new things like yesterday I found the lake where you can rent a boat...... great place to come and unwind
author: Mark B.

description: Wow.  We left this park, jealous and defeated that Seattle has nothing like it to compare it to.  It has BUFFALO??!?!  It is by far one of the most beautiful parks I've ever seen, and if I lived there I would want to live in walking distance of the park.  It was loaded with people, but nothing felt cramped or over-populated with people.  There was a wedding going on, soccer games, tourist groups, frisbee golf, picnics, tulip fields, you name it, if its park-friendly, we saw it.  I wish we had spent a whole weekend at the park.
author: Shannon H.

description:
If you have a chance, take a stroll around GG Park... its is very big and its great to have bbqs as well.

Dont forget the paddle boats, the water fowls and turtles, Japanese tea gardens...

alot to check out.
author: Roger A.

description:
A classic SF spot. You can chill on a blanket, walk your dog, learn how to hoola-hoop. Whatever you want to do, you can do it in Golden Gate Park. It's beautiful & big. The park leads to a bunch of other attraction in the city as well.
I'm not sure why exactly I dropped a star, I just felt like it was more a four star than a five star place. Still radical though.
author: Jessica G.

description:
Golden Gate Park is an amusement park of parks. It's super huge and there is the Japanese Tea Garden, Botanical Garden, CA Academy of Sciences, lawn bowling, horse-back riding and many more within this beautiful park. There are many nooks where you can hang out and relax. It's great to just hang out with nature and feel like you are in a forest and completely away from the city. 

I was there recently for 2 events, Power to the Peaceful concert and Om for Kids Yogathon. Both were at different parts of the park and dramatically different. The concert was in a big field surrounding by trees. It was very cool. The Yogathon was at Sharon Meadow and it was near a main path where you'll see drum circles. It was amazing practicing yoga at Golden Gate. I highly recommend it. 

Though the Golden Gate bridge isn't located near the park, it's absolutely worth checking out. You'll see lots of little kids soccer leagues in the weekend and tourists. It's a great place for anyone to enjoy. 

**check out the cool tree where you can sit on top of it (see pic)**
author: Gladys C.

description:
I love this park and am sad I no longer live close by to it.

There are so many wonderful parts to get lost in and experience solitude in spite of being in a city. Great biking, jogging and people watching. 

Loved taking a bike ride from The Haight down to Ocean Beach while passing the buffalo and the windmills to watch the sunset at the beach. 

The AIDS Memorial Grove is beautiful and tranquil (thank you to the volunteers who keep it that way!). 

The deYoung Museum is wonderful and access to the tower is free giving you panoramic views of San Francisco (if it's not fogged in!)

Try and enter from Frederick or Hayes-to-Fulton instead of Stanyan. "Hippie Hill" is more like smelly and gross street kid hill that you have to go through to get into the park confines.
author: Steven H.

description:
*Swooning* 
No visit or trip to the park is ever the same. I've strolled through with tourists, friends, friends-of-friends, and significant others and this place always leaves me feeling romantic and a little more in love with the world. There are tons of things to fall in love with here: gardens, groves, places to picnic, carousel, windmill, fields, and buffalo. It makes for a wonderful addition to your day. Anyone who doesn't enjoy their time here can only blame themselves- or the weather. 
Parking is a little more hard to come by on Sundays, but the road closures make for a more peaceful visit.
author: Loli L.

description: How can you not love this park?  It's in the middle of a very heavily congested city. It is HUGE.  It had gardens, museums, concerts, places to walk, places to run, places to eat, places to sleep and whatever else you may be looking for.   What else do you want?
author: Denis S.

description:
Golden Gate Park, how great are thee,
How your majestical land galvanizes me:
From your breath that hath brought life here,
For you call yourself the almighty one,
As anyone gazes on your fields, they shall surly weep,
Though within the depths of the metropolis, we roam like sheep.
Generations have stood at the steps of this wonder of one,
And they ask to themselves, "Blessings to the lord that has brought me here."
Golden Gate Park, who hath not sung thy lips to thee?
Over and over again I ask, why not worship such epic majesty?

Golden Gate Park, I roam through thee,
Golden Gate Park, I bathe in the sun before me,
From the trees to the buffalo, I know you tend to feed,
The sheep in your flock, I am blessed from my soul that you've freed.
Amongst wolves I walk with fright on my feet,
Drop by drop, the rain plays a rhythmic beat.
This is where I am free, protected by the destructive gale,
Inch by inch, I pay close attention as a snail.
Golden Gate Park, I sing to thee!
Through the depths of nature, I shall praise infinitely!
author: Jon-o G.

description: A wonderful gift as a San Francisco resident. I just love the park and all it has to offer. I just need a bike now so I can enjoy all the bike trails.
author: Mario A.

description: Love the park...so lucky that we have a park this size and with so many unique features in our city. I love running in the park, so many different trails one can take. I especially enjoy running on days that cars are not allowed on JFK drive.  Then on those sunny days, it's always nice to find a grassy area and chill out and soak up the sun.
author: Dilly M.

description:
Nearly every trip I make to the city seems to include SOMETHING that takes place in Golden Gate park.  It's not that I plan it this way, it just sort of happens, because it's such an awesome place to host things.

I have run participated in several run/walks) (nike, avon, skirt chaser, bay to breakers kaiser to name a few) that have all had either a starting, ending or both come through the park.  Why? because it's beautiufl and again, an awesome place to host things.


Museums?  check.  Art lessons?  check.  Lawn Bowling, golf, archery, check check check.  A big windmill? check.  places to sit, relax and play?  yup got them too.  It's even got Bison! 

such an amazing place, we are so lucky to have a park this awesome in SF.
author: Samanta V.

description: I never been to a park this big I ended up walking the whole thing,  It was about 6 miles. It was a work out but it was worth seeing everything this besutiful park had to offer. I saw the botanical garden, Japanese tea garden, the lake, & the museum. I recommend visiting all those places if you visit.
author: Alexandra A.

description: Where else can you see people roller skating, grilling meats, drinking 40's out of paper bags, and an old fashioned baseball game with people dressed up like they are in the 1930's?  Where else can you find statues of Goethe?  And Cervantes, complete with Pancho Villa and Don Quixote kneeling before his face in genuflection?  Where else can you find the wonderfully weird and modern de Young museum?  And the California Academy of Sciences, that tries to be wonderful.  AND where else can you walk down the middle of the road on Saturday and Sunday, because there are no cars allowed?  Nowhere else!
author: Rebecca H.

description:
An impromptu drive to San Francisco on an idyllic and perfect Easter Sunday ending up with lunch and a glass of wine on the grass in Golden Gate Park - what an awesome way to spend a weekend!

I spent a good part of last Saturday in Central Park back in New York but had no idea that my Sunday morning drive to the Costco in Fremont (near 880/Auto Mall) would end up in quite such a remarkable way.  The glorious weather made me want to really take Little Red out for a long drive - she's endured many patient hours waiting for me in cold lonely airport parking lots and I knew she'd love the chance to show me her German heritage on the wide open 880 freeway (it's true, there was hardly any traffic!!!)

So, off we went - thinking - hmmm, let's go up to the San Mateo bridge and cross over to the Peninsula and go to Costco in Mountain View!  Little Red would have none of it and soon, we were breezing past the Colisseum (Boo! Raiders!!) and approaching what appeared to be a hearty lunch in Berkeley.  Again, Little Red said no and on 580 we stayed, past the Richmond-San Rafael Bridge and into Marin county, past San Quentin and onto the 101 where I had been only yesterday on my way to Santa Rosa with the guys!

Little Red now led me southbound on the 101 and I knew she wanted to see the Golden Gate Bridge - ah, ha, tricky little thing...  I've always been a sucker for these flashy German types in flashy red garb - today was no exception!

Exit Sausalito and a nice little drive to the foot of the GG Bridge and an exhilarating view of the city across the Bay!  Little Red was purring with excitement - and curses!  I did not have my customary camera so had to make do with the weak-a$$ iPhone camera to capture the moment!

Then drove across the GG Bridge into the city and decided to go to GG Park.  I've never been here before and after Central Park last week, I was eager to see what San Francisco had to offer.

Golden Gate Park is a real gem!  I need to spend more time here but I drove through the park, past the Japanese Tea Garden (how beautiful...  can't wait to go back and see it up close), the baseball and soccer fields teeming with kids of all ages and all the way up to the Dutch windmill.  Then, I drove back to the picnic area and spent about 2 hours on the grass, making myself a sandwich out of some good crusty bread and interesting cheeses I had picked up earlier in Mill Valley before crossing over.  And, shhhh, a nice, not-so-chilled Pinot Grigio...  ahhh, a perfect spring afternoon.  I was kind of impressed that I actually had a blanket in the trunk of my car (no doubt a result of some drunken evening with the SBC) so I was able to make quite a decent picnic out of it.

I can't wait to get back!  Fantastic afternoon - great weather - I'm happy that we have something here to compete against Central Park (which is still very near and dear to my heart :)

Impromptu outings like this rock - it makes for that much more fun since things just unfold as they happen - and you go with the flow.  A simple lunch, good wine, fabulous weather, a short nap and I was off, back home to the South Bay.

5 stars to the park for making this day perfect - it was the almost perfect finish to an already awesome day.  Almost because there's still room on the blanket :)

~ 5 stars overall!

# 79
author: Badri N.

description:
A little more than 3 miles from east around 9th Ave west to the Pacific Coast Highway.  This park has everything a runner could want. Trails, hills, pavement, multiple trails that run East West so that you can still get lost after years of running.  Look up every now and then for the palm trees, to see the lovely houses along the South side of the park and see if you can find the exercise areas to do chin ups and sit ups. 
A pool would be a nice addition, but aside from that, a perfect Sunday afternoon- with closed streets and tennis courts and rollerbladers.
author: Kat T.

description: This place is like rapist central after sundown. I took a piss in the bushes and even I felt unsafe..... Oh.... It's really pretty.
author: Savier M.

description:
There is so much to do and see. 

Things that I've done, and will do again and again...

De Young Museum
Academy of Sciences
Get lost in Botanical Gardens... free!
Japanese Tea Garden
Cops and Robbers on Strawberry Hill... also free!
Rent boats at Stow Lake
Conservatory of Flowers
Merry-Go-Round at Children's playground
Watch bfnlf ride at the Polo Fields, wishing I wasn't so chicken to do the same (4th grade)
BBQ's at Marx Meadows
Run track at Kezar
AIDS Walk
Pass out at Spreckles Lake after B2B

I could run around and hang out here for days! Days only though, nighttime is scary.
author: Deanna T.

description: Too cold.  Pretty large though.   Good for bicycling.
author: Michael E.

description:
First let me say that this is one of the most beautiful parks in the world. But this review is in regard to the management by Parks and Recs dept. More specifically this is from the perspective of a concessions standpoint. 

The food there is and has been hard to find for some time now. When you do find it there is often a line. Most areas in the park have nothing unless there is an event that day.

I now know why. After speaking with many street vendors in the area I've learned that they charge ridiculous fees for them to get in...if they get in. It seems that the city is looking to make up for a massive deficit by overcharging the vendors and in turn...hurting the public. I'm guessing that this is why most of the park has very little to offer. It's too bad because it really is a special place.
author: Edward N.

description: Great Park with really nice walking and biking paths. The grassy areas are beautiful for a romantic picnic. Stow lake is a fun walk, but the boats and concessions are way too expensive. All in all an awesome place to spend a sunny San Francisco day.
author: Sheva B.

description:
Big. So big I got lost while driving through. Or was that the mj that did that? Whatever was the cause for me being lost, it was worth it. We visited the park on a wet March afternoon and it was beautiful. I don't know.. something about being from the NW make trees and bushes and flowers better when it rains. And we fed some ducks and that was fun.

Bring a map.
author: Erin H.

description:
if you think it reminds you of central park but in horizontal format...it's because the two were created by the same landscape architect

with merry-go-rounds, frisbee parks, science academies, and bison reserve this park has got something for everyone...whether you want to stroll . run . drive through it
author: Donna S.

description:
Golden Gate Park is something for SFers to be proud of.  I just moved within walking distance of the park and a constantly amazing how beautiful it is.  This urban park is full of hidden gems, from green algae filled swamps to waterfall laden island mountains.  You can spend a whole day in this park if you are visiting the city and have little sign that you are in one America's finest. 

Full of museums and gardens, GG park is a great place to go on a walk or run. 

As far as parks go, I'd give it 5 more stars if yelped allowed.
author: Andrew Christian C.

description: It's hard to write a review for this park because it's like a million in one things here. Just go there are check it out. The park is best on those hot summer days when you don't need a sweater and things are in bloom and the park is buzzing with people.
author: Will D.

description:
Golden Gate Park has so much to offer for everyone....

1. Want to exercise? Perfect place for a jog, a bike ride, golf, archery, frisbee golf, rowing! Sundays are great for a bike ride FYI. They close off certain roads just so bikers and other pedestrians can use the whole road.

2. Art lover? De Young museum is in the heart of the park.

3. Science geek? The new Academy of Science is right across the street. For you environmentalists, the building is also a LEED green building. =D

4. Hungry? Beach Chalet is right along the coast. Great view and good food. 

5. Have kids? Children's Playground is awesome. Plus, there's a merry-go-round that's been there since I was a kid. 

If you've never been, check out GG Park. You're sure to find something that appeals to your senses.
author: Jonathan L.

description:
I love the variety that this park has to offer.  Truly, there's something for everyone of every age.  My family and I enjoyed a day in the park for my birthday.  It included a visit to the Academy of Science and the Japanese Tea Gardens.  Both are absolutley fabulous locations.  

Next time I go, I'm going to hitch my bikes to the car and enjoy the scenery.   There's so much I haven't had the chance to see here, so I look forward to my next visit.
author: Maryrose S.

description: If you find yourself in San Francisco, and you want to get away from all the touristy spots, but still do a bunch of fun stuff, then the Golden Gate Park is what you're looking for.  A friend brought the wife and I here on our recent trip to SF. The park offers a lot of different things to see and do, including the California Science Academy, flower gardens, museums, a lake, fields and plenty of walking and running trails.  Far too much stuff to cover all in one day, let alone an afternoon. We will definitely return on future trips.
author: Andre B.

description:
What can I say about this park that hasn't been said before? 

As I occasionally drive or bike through the park, there's one aspect that never changes. In the mornings, it is clustered with people walking, running, and biking in GGP. Just a wonderful sight. 

It just has some of the best things about SF. The blooming Conservatory of Flowers, the contemporary De Young Museum, the unique and amazing Academy of Science, and of course, the calming scene of Stow Lake. 

Great place to walk around or to get some exercise. There's also fields of grass and playgrounds you can bring your kid to along with recreation places to rent out those 4-6 person bikes. 

Nothing better than to wake up early in the morning, take a stroll around GGP, and then stop by a local coffee to grab a hot cup of joe with a delicious pastry to finish it off.
author: robin w.

description:
The Verdict: "So many things to do in a park...you'll never want to leave."

Location: Had a picnic on the lawn near the Conservancy of Flowers during Bike Day Sunday and the Aids Walk, then biked over to the beach.

Pros: Beautiful scenery of flowers, trees, grass; friendly people laying out with their dogs (very dog friendly); so many things to do (people watch and chat with friends or meet new ones), listen to music nearby (provided for the walkers), perfect for biking or rollerblading since the road is closed off to automobiles during bike day, diverse crowd; kind and happy people (no joke); sunny weather with a breeze; well maintained restrooms nearby.

Cons: Can get crowded, but there is plenty of room for lots of people and the more the merrier; be careful of the sun (make sure to protect yourself with sunscreen).

Would I Recommend It?: Absolutely! We rented bikes from a nearby bike and skate rental ($5/hr/pay for what you use) and went riding all the way to Ocean Beach (it was fantastic!!!)
author: Judy P.

description: This review comes prior to the LOVE 'EM OR LEAVE 'EM Valentine's Day Dash 5K that we will produce in Golden Gate Park on Sunday, February 12th, 2012 but to date, based on the interaction we have had with the park's staff and the beautiful scenery we have seen along our course route that goes around Stow Lake, we are more than impressed with the park. We're excited to have the honor of producing this first-year 5K run/walk event and we look forward to many more years in Golden Gate Park!
author: Garett S.

description:
I didnt realize that this park is gigantic. 

Its very beautiful here. Everyone is on their bikes, hugging trees, being hippies. Its pretty cool. 

I wish there was a fat bus for someone like myself that gets lost and has to find her way out.... walking. FML. 

Either way, i lost a few pounds walking here. It was sooo peaceful.
author: Aidan V.

description: Always have loved this park. Its the Central Park of the West. Just recently for the first time reserved a table and BBQ in Marx Meadow for my fiancees 30th birthday. For only $27 you get the two all day. Just an awesome deal. We had the best time and could not have asked for a better location. Definitely suggest doing this as it secures your spot so there wont be any issues. Had to unfortunately kick out a family who did not have a reservation.
author: Bri R.

description: Busy! We drove through Golden Gate Park on our way to the Academy of the Sciences. Nice park, huge! Parking was pretty sparse and cost about $15 for 3 hours in the parking garage. Locals may have a better idea of hidden parking, but as a tourist I stuck to the garages.
author: Amanda S.

description: I love this park.  There are so many journeys through Golden Gate Park en route to Ocean Beach.  I recommend taking the journey.  At moments you'll forget you're in the City.
author: Melanie W.

description:
What can I say that hasn't already been said? Golden Gate Park is one of the most beautiful, scenic parks I've been to. There's so much to do here from the museums that you can head over to within an easy walking distance, you can run and bike around the place where you can get a great workout and not get bored from the scenery, and people watching is fun when it's nice outside and people take every opportunity they can get to soak up the sun. Certain days they have free swing dance lessons near the de Young museum and vendors along the pathways. You can pretty much just spend your day here and come back again for more. Also, you can bring your dog for a walk around. GGP is definitely puppies galore.

Every time I've been here this place has not disappointed me. They hold great concerts (Outside Lands, Hardly Strictly Bluegrass, etc) and the annual AIDS Walk is held here where you get to walk around, getting your own tour of GGP and raise money for a good cause. If you're bored, there's a lot to do over here.

If you want to get over here and save some money, park elsewhere or take the MUNI because it costs you can arm and a leg to park in the garage if you choose to do so. Especially on weekends when they raise the prices.
author: Leslie K.

description: Great place to go to for a nice outdoor jog/run or a bike ride. There are lots of tourists here so it can get crowded, but the place is definitely worth seeing. The bf and I came for a bike ride around the park and honestly I was amazed at how nice the park was. I love the Japanese Tea Gardens and the Botanical Gardens. Great for sight-seeing especially on a nice warm day. Definitely a good place for a date, workout, and spending time with your furry loveable companion :)
author: Hannah L.

description:
My 200th review is on the Golden Gate Park!

I shall detail you about my 2.6 mile walk (in 49 mins!? says Googlemaps. i think not!) inside the park in about 1.5 hours and my finding of a four-leaf clover! :)

9:50am: It was a beautiful day in SF last Saturday. After breakfast at Park Chow, I walked up 9th Ave towards Golden Gate Park on Martin Luther King Dr. My destination was the southwest part of the park near Lincoln and Great Hwy for a volunteer event. I alloted myself 2 hours for detours and getting lost. I really tried my hardest to not detour and go into the botanical gardens because I knew that once I'm inside, it'd probably take all day just to find my way out (it happened once already)! As I was walking north on MLK Jr Dr. I made a slight left onto South Dr. Lots of greenery to stare at and some plants and trees had tags on them with their names. I won't lie. I picked some flowers and lavenders along the way and pressed them in my hardcover book, The Last Lecture by Randy Pausch. haha :P I saw bits of the de Young Museum and the Japanese Tea Garden, lakes, giant trees, people jogging, and lots of cars driving on the roads too! 

10:10am: 20 minutes later I got to 19th Ave (Crossover Dr.) and crossed the street to continue on my journey towards the volunteer area that was southwest part of the park. I would stop every now and then to stare at the green grass and clovers! I was in search for a 4-leaf clover! I was determined! I think the walkers/joggers must have thought I lost something in the grass because I was scanning the ground and concentrating so hard to find the unique clover. "Oh, is that a 4-leaf? Aw, nope. Only 3..." =\ I continued to look at nature as I passed by Elk Glen Lake. Walking westward on South Dr/MLK Jr Dr, I just happened to find a 4-leaf clover!! I couldn't believe it! haha That made my day! Patience is definitely a virtue! 

11:30am: I passed by Sunset Blvd and Chain of Lakes Dr. By the time I got close to my volunteer meeting spot I still had half an hour to kill. The road forked. So I decided to go towards Kennedy Dr. It was kinda creepy walking by myself cause on the left there were these abandoned buildings with graffiti. I totally thought someone was going to jump out of the bushes and strangle me. But the area was woodsy. Just before you get to the paved parking lot and sports field, you will see this nice bed of clovers! You could hear the faint sound of the ocean in the background as you stare out! I felt really relaxed and quiet. I almost felt at peace. Forgetting about the chaotic world outside and not thinking about the problems.

11:50am: I headed back to MLK Jr Dr and right when I walked out onto the road a volunteer coordinator saw me and asked me if I was one of the volunteers. haha Dang, that was quick! They found me too soon!

Golden Gate Park is a lovely park to have some "Me Time" or get some exercise. In the spring time go to the windmill and see the tulips in bloom! Visit the de Young Museum and Cal Academy of Sciences! Lots of nature to see! Take a deep breath and inhale the nice SF air! sigh... :)

P.S. Don't wear jeans if you do plan to walk more than a mile in the park. Your legs will feel itchy after. =\ Layer your clothes. It gets chilly in the shady areas of the park and some parts it's really sunny and hot! No flip-flops. Only good walking shoes. Bring some snacks and water along too!! No need for a map if you have the time to get lost! :D Have a little adventure and some fun exploring the park! And find a 4-leaf clover, too!
author: CeCe C.

description:
Quality: 4

We went to the Golden Gate Park on December 29 after grabbing dimsum in the city for lunch. We were lucky enough to find parking inside the park, and we decided to visit the Conservatory of flowers and the de Young. 

The conservatory wasn't as interesting as I was hoping; we saw a lot of interesting plants, but it was kind of a letdown. Admission fee was somewhat high as well, since we were only in there for about half an hour.

The de Young Museum was much more interesting, and we were there for almost two hours. The King Tut exhibit looked really cool, but we decided to just get tickets for general admission instead.

The stroll around the park itself was quite nice, and it was refreshing walking around in the afternoon. Will definitely drop by again for another visit, and perhaps visit the Japanese Tea Garden and some of the other places in the park.
author: David L.

description: This is what wonderful  San Francisco is all about- a little something for everyone. Sports, culture, fresh air. Hiking, biking, boating, botany, art.  There is nothing not to love about Golden Gate Park.
author: Lempi M.

description:
Yeah yeah, I am a total loser who's trapped in the nineties; I own an expensive pair of Rollerblades. I cannot even be somewhat cool and say that "I got them when I was a teenager which was (sigh) back in the nineties and I still have them." Oh no. They are all of two years old. (I bought them when my endurance running FUBARed my knees). However, I feel like less of a loser after finding another rollerblading Yelper who is also trapped in the nineties. I'll keep him anonymous because he may not be as openly uncool as I am.

But on Sundays at GGP, you can rollerblade freely with other losers who are also trapped in the nineties. The traffic is blocked off for skating. Be sure to stop and catch the roller dancers. GGP provides great scenery and people watching. It is an easy MUNI transfer from Powell (because we all know I hate driving the stick shift through SF). And if you still think I am a loser for blading in GGP, then I pity you for being ignorant of the free and exhilirating feeling that can you get when you coast through the cool city breeze in this beautiful park. (Yes, I am aware that cycling does the same thing. You can do that here too.)

Hey man, sometimes you gotta look like a loser to look this good.
author: Zulu Q.

description: Parts of Golden Gate Park feel like a sanctuary from the bustling city. I walked through to Stow Lake, which took about 30 minutes starting from Haight Street and then enjoyed a serene hike up Strawberry Hill, which features a beautiful lookout point with striking views of the city, mountains, Golden Gate Bridge, and glimpses of the Pacific Ocean. My trek up to the top of Strawberry Hill was so meditative and enjoyable, it was only fitting to come across one other person up at the top, deep in meditation. It felt as if I was in a sacred and secluded place that was my little secret. I highly recommend Golden Gate Park for any nature-loving folk, seeking a retreat from the untiring energy of the city.
author: Caroline M.

description:
.

                                .................................................. ...................
                               /                                      *soccer fields       \
                              /    *windmills                                                 \
                             /                                                                          \
                            /                    *golf course                                  \
                           /                                                 *bison                 \
                          /                                                                                \
                         /           *stadium                                                      \
                        /                                                                                    \
                       /                          *paddle boats                                  \ 
                      /                                                                                        \
                     /                                                         *rose garden         \
                    /           *academy of                                                          \
                   /              science                   *tea garden                         \
                  /                                                                                                \

                /                                                                                                    \

              /                                                             *conservatory                  \
             /                                                                  of flowers                      \
            /             *children 's                                                                           \
           /               playground                                                                           \
          /________________________________________________\


i wish i could have drawn all the trees, bike lanes, lakes, people and everything else the Golden Gate Park contains.  

But you get the picture (literally..!).  One could easily install a tent and spend a loooooong time there. 

Actually, maybe they should check into that, a camping ground??
author: Margie B.

description: I love Golden Gate Park!  This is a wonderful place!  I would come and retreat here often-- to climb Strawberry Hill and see the buffalo.  The eucalyptus trees are gorgeous and there are flowers blooming most of the time.  There are many museums to see like the Academy of Sciences and the De Young Art museum.  It is lovely to just sit and have an iced green tea in the Japanese Tea Garden. Lots of natural beauty including  the Conservatory of Flowers nearby and the botanical gardens.  Get a map of the park and plan your visit-there is so much to see and do!
author: Kat S.

description:
I come home to an empty apartment that smells like cat piss and a pile of mail I can't bring myself to open.

I love my life.  I love my life.  I love my life.

My options for any given evening include pirating Internet from my neighbors, cleaning the litter box, having some soft carrots or some stale granola, watching one of the two movies I own for the 30th time, plucking my eyebrows again or exploring Golden Gate Park via Nike Shox.

I choose GG Park.  

I love my life.  I love my life.  I love my life.

I took a new route today that led me to the Buffalo.  I had no idea there were Buffalo in the park.  Did you know that there were Buffalo in the park?  I mean, Buffalo in the park!  That's kookie.

So I turn left at the Buffalo and suddenly I get turned around.  This may be due to the fact that I had been running away from my life and dirty apartment for the past hour with no water, or that I'm pre-menstrual, or general female hysteria.

But for one shining moment I thought I might be lost in the park forever, and I would have to go live with the Buffalo, and they would call me She Who Walks Like Buffalo and I would dread my hair and get all Mary McDonnell in Dances With Wolves on y'all.  

Then I looked to my right and realized my house was two blocks away.

I got home and there was a hairball on my pillow and a half eaten Splendid tanktop on the floor.  I just ate half a bag of jelly beans and am writing a Yelp review.

I love my life.  I love my life.  I love my life.

If you need me, I'll be with the Buffalo.

Can someone feed my cats?
author: Rachel G.

description:
Having finished my first of many weeks of unemployment, I've clearly identified the high and low points:

The lowpoint: Taking the non-express 38 bus to job interviews.  Holy fuck.  40 minutes from 20th to the FiDi?   I could race that bus on foot and win.

The highpoint:  Golden Gate Park, Golden Gate Park, and more Golden Gate Park.  I've been starting each morning with a run through here and have been eagerly exploring every acre.  Some of my favorite gems that a lot of people don't know about:

1) The peak in the middle of Stow Lake, with a giant waterfall running down it.  2nd best view in the city, after Twin Peaks of course.

2) The windmill at the northwest corner, across the street from Ocean Beach.  Looks like something about of a book.

3) The George Washington Elm Tree, on JFK just west of the Conservatory.  Its daddy was witness to Washington taking command of the Continental Army.  Much cooler than the statue of President Garfield, if you ask me.

4) The frolf course in the North central side, right along Fulton.  I haven't played in years, but it looks challenging.

5)  The Bison range, just west of Spreckels Lake.  

As for going through it at night, I've been warned not to, but nothing too bad has happened thus far.  My scariest encounter thus far was at about 7 PM on a Wednesday when I turned a corner and found myself staring face to face with a gigantic skunk.  But you deal with them the same as the homeless - step to the side, avoid eye contact, cover your nose, then run like hell.
author: John H.

description:
Favorite place to spend a warm, sunny day in San Francisco:
On a blanket, in shorts and a bikini top, in Golden Gate Park 

Favorite place to spend a cold, foggy day in San Francisco:
The hot and humid Conservatory of Flowers in Golden Gate Park 

Favorite place to workout in San Francisco:
Running on trails through the Aids Memorial Grove in Golden Gate Park

Favorite place to be alone for some self-reflection in San Francisco:
The Redwood trail in the Strybing Arboretum in Golden Gate Park

Favorite place to send out-of-towners in San Francisco:
The De Young Museum's observation tower in Golden Gate Park

Favorite place to watch some hot, sweaty men in San Francisco:
The soccer fields in Golden Gate Park

Favorite place to get a contact high in San Francisco:
Near a drum circle on Hippie Hill in Golden Gate Park
author: Kathryn T.

description:
So, this really isn't a review of the park, which everyone knows is fantastic and green and lush and full of buffalo and a coyote or two, but a review of the Handball Courts near the baseball diamond and the intrepid park rangers of car #124 or 241 or something like that.

It was a perfect spring Sunday afternoon. My 11 year-old son and I were playing our version of handball in one of the enclosed courts, the ones with wire mesh over the top to let in air and light.  All of the other courts except the one next to us were vacant.

Our version of handball employs not the regulation small hard ball used by professionals, but the large light plastic ball you can purchase for $1.49 at the 99 Cents and Up Store. (What's with this concept anyway? Aren't all stores 99 cents and up?) Anyway, we take turns hitting the ball with our hand and then running out of the way.  It is great fun and auditorially very satisfying as the ball smacks off one's hand and resounds into the wall. If it is very low against the wall, near the floor, and impossible to return, it is called a "baby." If the ball is high and slow, and sort of dribbles straight down the wall, is is called a "waterfall."

A half hour into our game, two park rangers began rattling the door to get into our court.  We let them in and they told us we had to leave. I asked if someone was waiting to play, or had a reservation, and was informed by the young man ranger that we were violating park regulations by using the court in this way. I explained that we were using our hand and playing with a ball, handball, and that no one else was probably even considering using the courts as it was 89 degrees outside. He said that we weren't playing handball the proper way and had to leave. His ranger companion, an elderly woman who is well-known to dog walkers in that part of the park, stood by the door and said, "Get out." I told her that she didn't need to guard us and that we would leave as soon as my son retrieved his shoes that were in a corner in the far end of the court. She said again, "Get out."

Maybe it was the heat that made her cranky. I don't know. Just make sure you bring a handball handbook with you if you ever decide to visit these crumbling WWII era courts.
author: jeff s.

description: Some of seems too contrived. The natural weather patterns do not suit some of the features of the park. It's a pretty great park in a popular famous city. It's accessible to San Francisco inhabitants and visitors. It's clean, but some of the upkeep leaves it stinky. This happens in California where it barely rains, so the watering systems leave forestation smelly. I come from DC, so I am used to the "Mall" and other suburban parks and trails. I do recommend this park for leisure time activities, except when it tends to get bummy and potty. It's classy and whimsical at the same time. It promotes diversity and learning. It's different. I've spent a lot of time there and don't think twice. It's definitely in the class of New York's Central Park and LA's Griffith Park. Fun memories.
author: Denise C.

description:
What to bring:

1. A friend
2. A GPS unit
3. Plenty of water
4. Some food
5. Signal flares
6. A first aid kit
7. A Sherpa

Your friend's going to help you spot open parking spots. The GPS unit is going to help you navigate it so you don't get lost... and turn back INTO the maze of roads. The water and food are, well, because you'll be stuck driving here for awhile. The signal flares are in case you can't get out, and hopefully a low-flying plane will find you. And the Sherpa is just insurance.

Because, you know, you'll have a hostage.

Advice: Don't let those douche people who stand in parking spots w/ no car stave you off from parking there. You tell them to move the f--- out, because in car vs. human, your car will win.

Request: Please learn to park people; it is absolutely ridiculous that people leave 3-5 feet in between cars.

Thailand would be appalled.
author: Jeffrey C.

description:
you're here.  i'm pleased.  i really dig your company.  your style. your smile. your peace mentality.  lord, have mercy on me.  i was blind, now i can see... what a king's supposed to be.  baby, i feel free... come on and go with me.

let's take a long walk around the park.. after dark. find a spot for us to spark conversation. verbal elation. stimulation. share our situations. temptations.  education. relaxation. elevations...maybe we can talk about Revelation 3:17...

or maybe we can see buffalo. or maybe we can see the hippies play on Saturday. or maybe we can sit under a tree and feel the breeze and listen to a symphony. or maybe chill and just be, or maybe... maybe go on paddleboats and listen to the Roots...or maybe people watch... seein' parents with their babes, pot smokers, drum circles, can collectors, naked guys sunbathing, joggers, children playing soccer...or maybe cry to the blues. or maybe we could just be silent....common, common...

let's take a long walk at Golden Gate Park...
author: Grace M.

description: I've been coming here for years and I always find something new. Last time I saw a fox! There almost too much to do, so I usually throw some disc, have a few drinks, and lounge around with good company. A great place to spend the day and it doesn't cost a dime.
author: Jordan P.

description: I wish there were more parks like the Golden Gate Park! There really isn't anything that I do not love about it. Even on a cloudy day, there are a plethora of things to do here. You can simply take a jog and admire the trees, plants, and flowers, or you can take a trip to the Academy of Sciences, De Young Museum, SF Botanical Gardens, and/or the Japanese Tea Garden! I came here on Saturday, when the weather was overcast, but I still enjoyed myself. The scenery was absolutely beautiful! I enjoyed walking along the paths and simply taking in nature. It's a great place for both locals and tourists.
author: Lien T.

description:
I love this huge park as there are soooo many places to go, but it does of course get crowded on the weekend. If there were more parking options without making the park ugly that would be cool... the parking under the DeYoung and AoS helps a lot.

Couple of nitpicks... signage inside the park needs improved dramatically. Once inside you're more or less on your own. 
Also, is there a more efficent way to water (i.e. not in the middle of the day when a lot evaporates) without paying a lot more to those city workers that move those huge hoses around?
author: Scott L.

description:
Central Park has nothing on the Golden Gate. You can see amazing concerts here, the Flower Conservatory, the Academy of Science and De Young Museum. Plus, the rose garden and the Fly Fishing Club and the gondolas. You can just go on and on and on.

Personally, I just like to park by the Amoeba record store and then walk the paths along the beautiful trees and bushes. The deeper you get in, the less homeless people that you see which is nice. We have the city to thank for all of their bum cleanup over the past two years. It is soooo much nicer.

Or, instead of walking, you can plop yourself down in the sun with a blanket and a book and a radio and some food and some drink and relax. That is nice too (The ground can be kind of wet though so try and find as dry a spot as possible). It is possible to get a tan at the park if you are a tanner.

Or, instead of walking and relaxing, you can put on some music and exercise, do some yoga, tai chi or stretching. Or play tennis or bike up and down or barbeque or walk your dog. Or sit by the many lakes and people watch.

Or if you have kids, you can bring them to the park and let then go nuts until they get really sleepy and tired so when they get home, they go right to sleep. Yea park, the great babysitter and free fun maker.

It's all possible at the Golden Gate. The great jewel of San Francisco is open and available to everyone so take advantage of it.
author: Terry H.

description: From the fly fishing to the guy fishing..haha I crack myself up sometimes..but really folks great place. Love to lay out in the sun and catch some rays as well. Amazing that we have this green space in an urban setting. I've seen foxes here and no I wasn't looking at a mirror!
author: melissa r.

description:
Amazing place for a date because there's SO much to do here. Japanese Tea Garden, Conservatory of Flowers, Botanical Gardens, De Young Museum... all amazing. Even just going on a walk and finding yourself somewhere unexpected.

I loved going to the observation deck at De Young because you get a fantastic view of the city and there's this really cool map that shows an image of the entire city (think google earth) where you can find your apartment! Another cool map- I bought one of the fold-able maps at the gift shop that highlights all the things to do in the park and absolutely love it.

Still haven't made it to the Academy of Sciences... definitely need to make this happen soon because I've been wanting to go since the opening in October- and apparently it turns into a bar on certain Thursday nights?! Also on my GG Park to-do... see the BISON! I'm still not quite sure I believe they actually exist.
author: Brianna H.

description: this is a fun park to take the family, there is a lot of room for every one, great place if you're in the city but want to get away from all the noise also it is close to a nice beach, Ocean beach is right down the street.
author: Jay J.

description:
Update: July 2007
    The disc golf course is awesome.  I'm there every Sunday.  I'm addicted.


I wanted my 100th review to be special so I wrote an acrostic poem about my favorite park in San Francisco. There are so many things to do in Golden Gate Park that requires little or no money. Exploring the DeYoung museum and Japanese Tea Garden are fun and educational. Though the pedal boats at Stow Lake can get tiring for some people, it can also be very relaxing to make your way around the lake. For those who love flowers and plants, make sure to check out the Conservatory of Flowers, Strybing Arboretum and  Botanical Garden.  Enjoy :-)!


Golden Gate Park
by Celeste L.

G igantic trees and green
O pen spaces, with
L ovely flowers, birds and
D ucks, in ponds and lakes.
E ven the bisons are
N ice to see, though should be set free.

G ather your friends

T ogether playing baseball or frisbee, and
E veryone will sure be happy

P eople have plenty to do
A t this wonderful place, but
R elaxing is the best or flying a
K ite with the rest.
author: Celeste M.

description:
1. Bison
2. Stookies
3. Horses
4. Fly fishing
5. Golf
6. Windmills
7. De Young
8. Stowe Lake
9. Disc Golf
10. Stuff from 1939 
11. A guy who ran the park for half a century and created its beauty by taming mother nature (he literally stablized sand dunes)
12. You can run a more than 1/2 a marathon without taking the same road twice
How much more awesome can it get?
author: Jason C.

description:
What can you say about this place?

It's the best backyard I've ever had!

Great for BBQ's, napping, sports, and whatever you wanna do at the park. Just don't trash it.

Don't make it your home either.

(Hey Gavin, please make the homeless go away )
author: Stanley K.

description: Wow, didn't know a review for Golden Gate Park exists!  Since I'm a SoCal girl, having a HUGE park is something I don't usually see in my natural habitat.  You can walk around and easily get lost appreciating nature or just people/bird watching.  Besides exercise, this is a great photo opportunity too!  We came here on an early weekday afternoon and the weather was cool and brisk, great for a morning jog.  Unfortunately, since I was in vacation mode, exercising is against the rules for any vacation!  Though Irvine's Great Park really wants to be as appealing as this park/NY's Central Park, I still commend the real OGs of parks.
author: Janey Y.

description: Such a beautiful place to spend time with family and to have a party. Also the bison were really cool to watch, and I had such a wonder time playing with my remote controlled boat.
author: Juan F.

description:
Golden Gate park is kind of like it's own little city. It has quite parts, louder parts, cracked out ghetto parts, beautiful scenic parts, etc. 

If I were to judge the place by the entrance and first part at Haight and Stanyan then I'd probably be giving this place two stars. Seeing washed up ass runaway kids trying to nickel and dime weed sacks and scrounging change together for 40's of 211 got old when I was 15. It's just plain sad now.

On a much brighter and positive note I've had some awesome times in Golden Gate. Finding a nice open space to kick around a soccer ball with out of town friends, stumbling across a random Malaysian day festival and even spinning drum n bass records on top of hippy hill to lots of stoned folks dancing, these are just some of the many unforgettable experiences I've had at this big beautiful park and I haven't even begun to cover all of the ground in this bad boy!! 

Thank you Golden Gate Park for being one of the reasons I thank my lucky stars that I get to live in SF.
author: Tommy P.

description:
I have two dogs. They control my life to a certain extent: when to be home, how to live, etc - but they're worth it. (Sorta. KInda.) 

Anywho...when I move the first consideration is usually: what can I do with the dogs near here? It's one of the top reasons I moved to the Outer Richmond, and *the* reason I moved across from this park. It's amazing, everything about it - and not just for the dogs. The shear size of it, concerts in the late summer are stunning, walking the park down to Ocean Beach is an experience of pure joy (not just the dog's joy either), the museums are right there... everything. They even have fraking buffalo there. (Seriously.)

It's a wonderful place, any time of year. Nothing bad to say about it. (Oh, maybe one thing: the "disc golf" players think they own the park, and take their "sport" a little too seriously, but that's the beauty of a big park like this...room for everyone.)
author: Rob D.

description:
I don't know why it's taken me so long to write a review about the single place in the city that I frequent the most: Golden Gate Park.

I am steadfast in my love for the park.  I am constant in my love for the park.  I am devoted, I am loyal; it can trust me with all of its secrets.  The park has seen me sans make-up, in thrashed up gym clothes, hair slicked back in a messy ponytail.  The park accepts me for all of my faults, lets me expel all of my frustrations and welcomes me with open arms to traverse its' trails with my toe' up running shoes.

If Golden Gate Park was a man, I'd marry him in a heartbeat.  He lets me be myself, and no one else, and encourages me to be the best woman, the best athlete I can be.  

I have run many-a-10Ks, several half marathons and my first FULL marathon along your thoroughfares.  I have played many-an-Ultimate Frisbee games on your polo fields, I have had many-a-picnics and have heard many-a-free concerts camped out on your luscious lawns.  Oh GGP, you complete me in so many more ways that you will ever know.  


And, there's no denying it -- I'm in love with you.
author: Katie C.

description: One of the many attractions that San Francisco has to offer.  As you get your sexy on, you'll walk/jog/run past the Conservatory of Flowers, the Japanese Tea Garden, De Young Museum, Stow Lake , and the Academy of Sciences . Be sure to exercise here in the morning to afternoon. The SF fog rolls in around 5pm. You can make your own trail, covering 10 miles! Don't forget to take a deep breath of the nice, crisp SF air!
author: The Fuzzies S.

description:
Golden Gate Park is one of my favorite places ever. Whenever I have out of town friends or family come visit, I always take them to Golden Gate Park because I simply cannot stomach another trip to Pier 39

Our day usually goes like this:

Take bus/cab all the way to ocean beach and have Sunday brunch at the Beach Challet (try to arrive by 10am otherwise it gets very crowded). We will have hopefully brought some cookies, fruits and afternoon munchies with us before we set out on the quest through the epic park to exercise off our breakfast.

This includes stops at the Windmill, the Bison, a polo or soccer game, the botanical gardens, stow lake, the conservatory of flowers, the japanese tea gardens, etc.

There are a few things I don't like about golden gate park. I don't like that you cant' find bathrooms, that there is no food aside from beach chalet and the golf course, that boat rentals only go until 4pm, and that the de young museum houses contemporary art (rant to be posted under De Young Museum).

But despite all these things, it's the perfect place to go with a group of friends and the perfect place to go on a date. You can see the view of everything from the top of strawberry hill, participate in a drum circle, lay in the sunshine, have a japanese tea ceremony and get lost for hours in a park that's in the middle of a city. You can forget you're in SF for a while (though it's very easy to get lost... I have intended to emerge on Fulton many a time and ended up coming out at the SE corner of the park instead)

There are places to do everything! You can fish, play a game, read a book, go boating, picnic, play with dogs, watch free concerts, see sporting events, buy drugs from homeless people, kiss your sweetheart... do other things with them too...

I would give this place 6 stars if, like a former yelper said, they had a free wifi tree somewhere in the middle...
author: Stephanie H.

description:
Need some magical mushrooms?  Don't care where/who you're getting them from?  -  Come here.  Use here.
Hippy central!  -  Beware of laced products.

But yeah, this park is freakin huge!  In between the golf course and Kezar Stadium.  And next to like Kezar stadium, there's a bunch of trees and area to walk around if you feel like going on a nature walk in the middle of SF without going to the beach or the zoo.

They got the new Academy of Sciences Museum and Aquarium over here too.  Hopefully check that out sometime this year.

And besides the plethora of hippies and homeless people you might find wandering around this park on any given day, there's also the "haunted" stow lake.  I went here once a couple months ago after we went to Poleng for a homegirl's birthday and I've never heard the story of the old school ass police officer who drives around giving tickets, but when you try to pay for them, none of the tickets really exist.  And no joke!  We saw that like 70s old school police car pulled over behind another car, but we saw no one in either car when we drove by.  Then he we hurried up and took our drunk pisses into Stow Lake and cut the hell out of there.

SF/The Bay Area's version of NYC's Central Park, but not on par at all on any level.
author: Chris T.

description:
People laughed when the landscape architect proposed building a world-class park in the middle of the city's west side among wind-swept sand dunes.

Who's got the last laugh now?

Golden Gate Park has been a regular attraction for my family as long as I can remember.

Whether it has been the Bison exhibit, the Steinhart Aquarium and the Japanese Tea Garden, or the Botanical Gardens, Strybing Arboretum and Stow Lake, GGP has a lot to offer.

You can chill out in a more secluded part of the park, or you can check out world class museums and collections of cacti.

My dad used to take us out to Stow Lake to row the boats.  My sister and I loved it, and I think my Mom did too.

Golden Gate Park is a great place for families, lovers, dog lovers, joggers, swing dancers, and museum goers.  The list goes on.

I remember when the DeYoung Museum hosted the Asian Art collection, and when I took first dates to the fish roundabout in the Steinhart Aquarium because it was voted one of the "best places to kiss in San Francisco" in a number of guide books.

I think I even used that line before, just before leaning in:

"You know, this is known as one of the best places to kiss in San Francisco."

Well that date turned out great, as I'm sure many of yours have after visiting the inspiring and romantic areas of Golden Gate Park.
author: Justin C.

description:
Hello denizens of the park!

Please enjoy:
Tai chi in the early am in Music Concourse (or under the Academy eaves when it's raining)
Public restrooms behind the band shell
Bus parking behind the band shell
A concession stand behind the band shell

Music Concourse is a great place for kids to run around, blow off some steam, and then sleep in the car on the way home!

Amenities galore behind the band shell!
author: Erin G.

description:
June 2007 Shakespeare Garden
This part of the review is about Shakespeare Garden. Since I can't post twice about the same place, I'm splitting the review into 2. Shakespeare Garden is our wedding ceremony and standing reception venue. After visitng several garden like places, we liked Shakespeare Garden the best. There are plenty of grass.  The space can hold up to 200 people according to Park Services.  There is electricity that you call Park Services a week in advance to turn on.  You can reserve 4 parking spaces in front of the garden for a fee. I think it's $50.  You can have finger foods at this venue just not a full sit down dinner. The rental rate is quite reasonable. It's $500 for 2 hrs and $50 for each additional hours.  Of course, you have to rent your own chairs.  A 10 watt microphone is allowed.  There is public bathroom behind the band shell. The public bathroom is actually quite nice for park bathroom, spacious. It's about a 5min walk from the garden. When you walk into the garden, there is some construction going on in the left, so there is a fence with green tarp.  Not a pretty sight, but there are plenty of space in the garden to take beautiful pictures. There can be more flower planted in the brick area, but overall the garden is well-kept. It has a walk path, so it's set apart for main thourghfare , so pretty private. I'll update my review after our wedding.


April 2007 Fuchsia Dell
This review pertains to Fuchsia Dell gardens. It's located a northeast of the Conservatory of Flowers.  I was checking it out as a possible wedding ceremony site.  This is one of the spots that can be rented out in Golden Gate Park for private events/weddings.  It has lots of grass and it's semi-private.  It's definitely more private than the Rose Gardens, which can be rented out as well.  There is a paved path that cuts through Fuchsia Dell from Conservatory East Drive to the Conservatory of Flowers. If you have your wedding on Sundays when JFK drive is closed, this spot might be difficult for your vendors to get to, especially if they are trying to unload chairs.  Overall a wonderful garden wedding ceremony venue for a great price.
author: traveler Y.

description: Golden Gate Park makes me happy. Free Bluegrass festival. House parties. Drunk rollerbladers. Homeless off rythym drumming circles. There's everything here and on a beautiful day, there's nowhere I'd rather be. It's a must for any tourist and San Francisco does a great job of holding really quality events here on a regular basis. Golden Gate Park does SF proud.
author: Jessica T.

description:
Golden Gate Park is definitely one of San Francisco's best features.  The Golden Gate Bridge is beautiful, but how often do you actually use it?  Sadly, I don't come to Golden Gate Park as often as I should, especially since I live so close.  But when I do, I'm never disappointed.  It's literally impossible to get bored of because it's so large and there are so many parts of it to explore.  I've found interesting parts when I was looking for other parts.

My favorite part is definitely the Buffalo Paddock for all its strangeness and sadness.  Close seconds are Spreckels Lake, the turtles in Stow Lake, the dog area near the buffalos, and the area outside of the Conservatory of Flowers.
author: John S.

description:
I cannot add to those who have already enumerated the many amenities of the park, but I can tell you why I love it:

Two years ago, December 26th - I am wandering in the Park with my brother and father, both of whom are visiting from out of town.  My first truly, truly grown up Christmas (I was the hostess).  As we wander from one end down towards the Beach Chalet , with no deadlines or plans, we happen upon a road heading up a hill.  Deciding to take the trail, we amble up the road and find Stowe Lake - which I did not know was there.  Now everything was closed, but you could see paddle boats and a refreshment stand that would obviously be open come summertime.  We three stood at the edge of this tiny ornamental find in the middle of the city, in the rain, in the cold of December near the sea, and my brother turns to me and says "Now I know why you love this place so much."

Yep.
author: Suzanne B.

description: My favorite city park ever.  I walk/bike through here several times a week and still haven't discovered all the lil hidden coves or explored all the museums.  The perfect urban escape, without having to actually leave the city.
author: Stephanie S.

description:
A great date:

Get a cup of coffee at the Blue Danube on Clement Street.  Walk up through the Richmond to Stanyan and stroll into the park.

Enjoy the sunshine, the view and the company.  Get hoodwinked into thinking that the "drum circle never dies".  Watch oldish men lawn bowling and comment on how it is so very Great Gatsby.

Appreciate San Francisco on a sunny January day.

Talk about how cool you think the fog is when it rolls across the park.

Watch little kids ride the carousel and get some popcorn.
Laugh a lot... That is crucial.
Find paths and plants and birds and dogs and benches to sit on.

Golden Gate Park is... well... it's San Francisco, isn't it?
author: Kate R.

description:
I love this time of the year at my beloved GGP! 

The cherry blossom is in full bloom. The peach blossom is in full bloom. 

Weather is nice as usual. Sunny warm but never too hot. 

The birds are singing. I have actually been seeing more exotic birds hanging around our little lakes lately. Large snow white cranes and tiny little singing blue birds.

And I love staring at the elegant Chinese mountain pine trees in and around the Golden Gate Park. You don't see this kind of pine trees anywhere else in North America.
author: Float C.

description:
When I first came to the city, a little over a year ago, I had this little map I got from the public library (where I spent most of my time due to free internet and unemployment). On the map, the west side of the city was compressed, so the park looked almost like a square near the beach. 

My friends said this was not the case, so I decided to have a look at this "largest city park in the world." I read that it was 4 miles long, and since I was a good boy scout, I decided to take a hike and see the entire thing.

This was one of the better decisions I have ever made. 

I went by my self (essential) and I brought my ipod. I started at the eastern most point, and ventured into this amazing world. I hate to admit coming from LA, but it is important for you all to understand that I had never seen anything like th sights I saw that day. All the different types of people, from the hippy-bongo playing-frizby throwing-dog having loungers to the yuppie picnickers to the runners and walkers and bikers and boarders. I saw people who looked like they spent their entire lives there to people who were on vacation, walking in wonder as I was. 

I walked and walked. I hiked up hills and down into wet meadows. I crept through bushes, crossed fences, and ran from bison. I played with dogs and I helped photograph a swan. I daydreamed as I walked, down, down down the road toward the setting sun.

Lakes and trees and feelings of prehistoric times. People out like I was enjoying the day. There was real peace that day. I was by myself, in a meditative walk. Exploring inner and outer worlds (I am so cheesy-zen).

When I got to the beach, the sun was about to set. I crossed the same PCH as we have in LA, San Diego, and everywhere between here and there. I stood with a bunch of people at the wall, looking out over the water as the sun went down. I was just in time to see a beautiful sunset.

Did you know it turns a shade of light green right before it winks out of sight? It is because the atmosphere blocks certain wavelengths at that angle and we see green.

It got cold, and I went to get a sandwich at the store. The people were somehow different than in the east side of the city. More small town, more beach town type people. I got on the bus and took a long ride home. arriving in the dark, contented that I had spent my day in heaven.
author: Michael L.

description:
I've lived across the street from this park for over 20 years now and I still can't get over how much I love it.  When I used to run, I loved that everyone else was running in it as well.  When I used to bike on Sundays, I remember how fun it was and how great nature was.

Now the De Young and The Academy of Sciences have reopened their doors and I love this park even more.  I am only a few feet away from these tourist attractions yet they feel like my neighbors homes.

Hippie hill is always a nice place to sun bathe when the sun is hot enough and the hills in front of the Conservatory of Flowers is still the best ones to roll down.

I am lucky.
author: Susan C.

description:
How could I not love this park?!! I've had tons of great times in this park growing up in SF.  A few choice memories:

     * Rollerskating with my dad here most Sunday's when I was little, and being amazed at the disco jam moves of some of the adults.

     * ALMOST learning how to blow FIRE around age 9 before my dad ran up to stop me.

     * Running my first Bay-to-Breakers at age 11. And watching all the shenanigans. And doing it again ten years later.

    * Tai Chi near the lake with my older Chinese lady former-roommate.

    * Drunk viewing of De Young Museum at 3:30 AM.

    * Bringing all my out-of-town friends to see the BUFFALO!

Did you know there are buffaloes in the Park? NO?! Really there are. Did you know they used to be named after Shakespeare characters but now are more appropriately have Native American names? Aren't I full of fun semi-useless facts?
author: JC R.

description:
Despite having grown up in the Bay Area and living in San Francisco for four years, I've only been to Golden Gate Park a handful of times.  After recently using its many paths as a training ground for the upcoming marathon, I was shocked as to why I haven't come here more often.  

It always warms my heart to glance over to see an elderly couple holding hands, friends having a picnic in the grass, or a father and son playing catch.  Everyone here seems content.  

And on Sundays, I would bike on the road closed to vehicular traffic, sharing it with the many kids and adults on rollerblades, skateboards, bikes or on foot, and leisurely cut through the park, down Arguello, through the Presidio, and out to the bridge.  

It's so peaceful, so tranquil, such a beautiful urban park in one of the greatest cities in the world.
author: Marsha Z.

description:
The park takes you a million miles away from the pace of the city.  I love hanging out on the lawn.  This place is convenient and lives up to the billing.  Perfect place for you to go crazy with the pooch or ankle biters.  Nice spot for a run or rollerblade also.  I prefer to thrown out a blanket and crash.

If you want to get your pan handled this is the spot for you.  On the fringes people literally come out of the bushes and offer you all kinds of goodies.  Gavin is putting the crack down on the self employed pharmaceutical sales reps, but they're still prevalent.  This almost makes me feel 4 stars is appropriate, but it's just too great of a spot for that.
author: Nicholas H.

description: My favorite place in SF. Go to Say Cheese cheese ship in Cole Valley and then have a picnic at the park! Every time I have visitors I take them here!
author: C C.

description:
Alright Mr. Park, why do you have to go around being all hot and stuff.  I mean, you're naturally gorgeous, massive, and simply irresistible. Everyone wants to be on you - gender, age, and sexual orientation aside.   You make me green with grass stains, er, envy.

You're the Brawny man of parks.

I will say that you're a lot smarter than the Brawny man lets off in that flannel shirt.  You're this cultural mecca with the Japanese Tea Gardens, Conservatory of Flowers, Botanical Gardens, and the de Young Museum.

You know what else I like about you?  You know how to throw a good party.  For the last six years you've welcomed thousands of residents during the Bay to Breakers.  You're such a good host and can only hope that we'll be able to come to our seventh annual party.

Hey, and next time it's sunny out maybe we should, um, you know, meet up or something?  You know, if you're not busy and all.
author: Jenn T.

description:
