Dear Golden Gate Park,
    Every morning I wake up and am thankful to be able to run through the beauty that you offer. I am in awe by the endless amounts of trees, flowers, and natural beauty that surround me when i am within your boundaries. i cherish you for the fond memories of concerts you have held. I am blessed with the museums, botanical gardens, and buffalos you posses. 
     Thank you for being here. Thank you for being apart of my life. Thank you for allowing me to take part in your beauty and giving me a safe place to run. 
     With Love,
           Wes P
author: Wes P.

description: Been here a couple times with my GF and once with her and a friend. It is really nice to just walk around, have a picnic and take pictures. The playground was fun to play at also, even though I don't think we we're supposed to. But sometimes you just can't resist being a kid. It is super easy to get lost though, as I did every time we were here. I really want to come back with my bike and just spend the whole day here to see all it has to offer. It is just so huge that I don't even know if one day is enough to see everything. Just the drive through it (while I was lost) is beautiful.
author: Jonah S.

description:
It took me a while to get used to the American concept of a park with car lanes through it. Getting accustomed, maybe. That said the park is lovely lovely lovely. 
Some of the best museums, the botanical garden, waterfalls, creeks, roses, cherry trees, meadows...the only thing I really do miss is a longer, continuous, looping sand path for joggers. No dodging cars, easy on the knees. Please, pretty please?
author: Mien S.

description: This park is very serene and nice in many areas and contains specialty places such as conservatories and museums with a huge selection of specialty gardens such as the Japanese Tea garden. I always have a great time when I come here but the weather is BRUTAL. During the day it can absolutely be a beautiful balmy 77 degrees but once its past 4:00 PM and the clouds roll in, be prepared for 50 degree weather!
author: Lorrie M.

description:
I was born & raised in SF and Golden Gate Park = SERENITY

Taking walks, watching a concert, going for a run, enjoying the different aspects and sites, having tea at the Japanese Garden, admiring the De Young Museum, vegging out on a blanket under the blue sky, or watching the rollerskaters (which i just found out about recently....wtf?), whether the sun is shining or the clouds are covering the sky........its a great place to be.  

I love it here.
author: Juv C.

description: Very nice park and a good place to bring family or guests out of town. Also, I would get there early so you can get a chance to take a paddle boat out on the lake. Thoroughly enjoyed my experience here.
author: Robert D.

description: Really don't go here enough.  But today, riding my bike through on a sunny November day and observing all the nice spots one could hang out, it really made me appreciate the place.  Upkeep and maintenance is pretty good and didn't see too many bums, though they most likely are in the dense jungles I didn't go too deep into.  Variety is amazing.  Good signage.  Not even taking into account any of the museums, it's just a great natural wonder of the city.
author: Marc S.

description:
Large, beautiful, fun, interesting and puts central park to shame. 
Watch out for non-car areas. They've just banned cars in key areas 6 months out of the year.
http://sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2007/04/14/BAGT9P8QAV1.DTL
author: Kat C.

description:
Here is nature right outside my front door.  That's essential for my sanity.  

I've given to Friends of the Urban Forest, and to the SF Parks Trust.  It's tax deductible, and I'm supporting my local trees.  

It was fun one day watching a dog dig in the panhandle.  He was fanatic, although I don't think he came up with anything.  He got shoulder-deep into the sand.  It's also fun watching people play with their dogs in the sunshine.  

I could go on, but each feature of Golden Gate Park deserves a review of its own.  Things I like include: Stow Lake, Strawberry Hill, the deYoung Museum, the bandshell, the Japanese Tea Garden, the bike trails, people sunbathing in the meadows, the Rose Garden, Shakespeare Garden, live jazz at the Dutch Windmill, the Chain of Lakes, the Beach Chalet, the classic carousel, walks down the little footpaths among the (mostly eucalyptus) trees, surprising turns that give us views of the corporate yard, looking across the street at Kezar Stadium.  I could go on forever.
author: David D.

description:
There is so much to do in Golden Gate Park!  De Young Museum, Conservatory of Flowers, Japanese Tea Garden, the Botanical Gardens, Lindyhop in the Park - just to name a few.  

While it is HUGE for San Francisco, I wouldn't mind a little more park space in the city.  

The only times I do not get lost trying to get through the park is when I take:  19th Avenue, 25th Avenue, or Sunset Blvd.
author: Tinna H.

description: good place to bring your touristy friends and relatives.  also good place to get some exercise.  parking can be challenging though.  you can spend the whole day at a botanical garden or go boating at the lake
author: Elc C.

description:
I like coming to this park to smoke my Marley. Really. Then I watch the Tatanka free graze like the silly mammals they are. Sometimes, if Im grumpy, I'll knock an old lady into the green pond where the RC boats race. Then I laugh and laugh like a hyena on nitrous oxide.

The last time I was there I met a Ukrainian woman in the Japanese tea garden and we shared an Italian ice cream. Then we made out; sloppy like. I've just about finished the dose of antibiotics for the herpes sore - but thats no matter. Ohhh - spitting on the tourists in the Garden is appropriate. They hate Americans anyway. 

The Steinhart Aquarium is the best- I once hopped the railing and wrestled an alligator. A baby one. The sh*t bit my balls and I had to skin it. Made a nice belt. The gator steaks sucked and so hustled over to Korea town and sold them to this old man with man boobs.Who cares.

My pal - Mark - and I used to bring our flasks of thunder bird here and watch the birds crap on the runners. One day I fell asleep and messed myself; but just a little. 

Really tho- this park enhances life.
author: Dan S.

description: What's not to like.  Buffalo, plenty of space, trails, and SF weather.  Love the Golden Gate Park!
author: John F.

description: One of the better big-city parks I've visited... and in our own backyard!   In addition to the oft-mentioned Stowe Lake boating, carousel, bisons, museums and free concerts, I'd add that the large playground adjacent to the carousel is a great find for little kids.  Among other things, it sports a couple of those long, liability-prone cement slides that kids of all ages ride down on cardboard squares.
author: Geoff D.

description: I LOVE the Rose Garden. Seems the best time to go is March -September-ish. If you go to the middle (where the circular flower bed is) and face West, you will see another flower bed that is quite long and in the shape of an arc. There are some pink roses all the way to the left of that bed and they smell AMAZING.
author: Jennifer P.

description:
I never realized the size of this park until it thought i could avoid the parking congestion and walk...never doing that again! Luckily the walk was beautiful and i got the appreciate the scenery more than one ever could in a car. Oh, and bring a coat. 

The conservatory of flowers is definitely a must see. The Academy of Sciences is also a must. Drop by the gardens in between and you're in for a great day. I agree with everyone on getting to the academy of sciences early. We got there right after it opened and it was packed! When I'm not going into the buildings I ALWAYS bring my dog. Ocean beach is at the end of the park. A lot of dogs run off leash there (not sure if it's allowed) but i join in and let my little guy run around too. Try it out, its the highlight of his life, other than eating.
author: Marinelle H.

description:
Bison (or buffalo) corral + 17 lakes = automatic 5 stars



I grew up here and never knew of their existences until today.
i. am. an. asian. tourist.
sue me
author: Mona N.

description:
It's kind of hard NOT to love a seriously massive, festive park containing awesome museums and frequent events of all kind!

There's not  much more to say other than:

IF YOU HAVEN'T BEEN HERE YET, GO ASAP!!!!!

You'll thank me later.
:)
author: Kai S.

description: Beautiful park, so many things you can do. Let's see, light trail walking, people watching, row boat racing, watching my dog trying to scare off ducks, stow lake ghost hunting, having sex in the car at night.. wait, what??
author: Ari C.

description:
Like El Retiro is to Madrid, Golden Gate Park is the lungs of San Francisco.  

I love this place...there's so much to do there, such a wide variety.  I've been there multiple times for many different reasons...Conservatory of Flowers, Steinhart Aquarium (field trips as a kid), De Young Museum, Japanese Tea Garden, AIDS Walk, Women & Cancer Walk, various music festivals, rollerblading, botanical gardens, rose garden, Shakespeare garden, just random walking around...and there still so much of the park that I haven't seen (except for walking past as part of some of the walks I've done).  They have swing dancing on Sundays (or is it Saturdays?) too...I know I've walked past them before.  There's even a bison paddock!  There's 10 lakes in the park, did you know that?  I didn't until I read it.  Then, there's all the stuff that's there that I haven't used...golf course, soccer field, & various other sports fields, paddle boats at Stow Lake, & much much more.

OK, I admit it, I use this park a lot, & I don't even live in the city!
author: Linda T.

description:
Golden Gate Park is as much a gift to our city as Central Park is to Manhattan.  It is an oasis from the concrete jungle, and full of magical little secrets (as well as some magical people who have an altered view of the universe, but hey, this is a city after all...)

Here are some of my favorite ways to enjoy GGP:

1/ Stow Lake 
By some feat of physics, the path around Stow Lake is the EXACT distance that my dog will tolerate on a walk.  See?  Magic.  You can take the outer (safe) path or the inner (view from a desert island) path.  Paddle boats and canoes available for rent.  Crowded on weekends.  If you love birds, there are plenty of ducks etc in close proximity.  If you hate birds, my dog will chase them away for you (that was for you, Kirsten F)

2/ Toy Boat Boathouse.  
I think that this is the cutest thing I've ever seen.  The lake for sailing toy boats is across the road, and early in the morning there are people who like to practice Tai Chi there.  

3/ Japanese Tea Garden
I *thought* I gave this a separate review, but apparently I just imagined it!  I love this tranquil spot of manicured trees and exotic plants, with the little tea garden in the middle.  Sure, the gift shop is a bit touristy, but go for the ambiance.  The bridge near the front entrance is a climbing challenge and makes a great photo.  My favorite image is the deer in the bushes, at the very back behind the tea garden.

4/ Bison Range
I think some people might be mad about bison caged up in the middle of the park?  All I know is that when I used to drive to work this way, I would stop and say hello to the bison every day, and it made me feel good.  I usually take out-of-towners here for the shock value.  They (the bison) always look pretty pissed off, but I think they're just bluffing.  We saw a fox in there once.

5/ Botanical Garden
Sooooooo pretty.  Makes you want to write poetry.  

6/ Sharon Meadow 
The site of Opera in the Park.  I KNOW I reviewed this separately!
http://www.yelp.com/biz/hYaaFPl19yti-sAFmFAbkA?hrid=MfkwPgjXCm9iDqYXKz-7bA

7/ Unnamed open areas
There are so many places to set up your picnic, bbq, soccer game, etc.  You can just find a spot and not feel crowded.  I had a particularly great time one Sunday with my brother and his radio-controlled airplane.  You can just do your thing, be it roller disco, croquet or playing the bongos.  

I also enjoy the DeYoung grounds and just generally driving around the park.  In the wee hours of the morning when the sprinklers are just turned on, it feels like the world is being covered with fairy-dew.

When you want to feel happy, go to the park and play.  Explore.  Enjoy.
author: Liz S.

description:
Golden Gate Park is the quintessential San Francisco experience that one could ever have.  Everything that makes this city great is all right here.  I only strolled through part of the park the only time I was here, but I really want to go back and see the other parts of the park.

I came here with an old friend on a weekend afternoon and walked from Haight-Ashbury through part of the park.  A Rastafarian greeted me as I walked onto the park grounds and wondered if I needed anything.  Walking a little further, a hippie from Humboldt was showing his wares as well.

We walked towards the percussion music and sat and listened for about 20 minutes to the congregation of drums.  People from all walks of life were here either listening or playing music.  

We walked further and towards the Carosel, which was already sadly closed for the day.  We watched the kids play on the playground as well.

I have to come back here.
author: Kathleen B.

description:
Thank you Joan S. for inspiring me to do a review on the big park in the city~ Golden Gate Park....

When i was a wee child I remember being scared of the squirrels (heh i got a photo of me crying holding on to mom in front of a squirrel) , playing in the japanese tea garden, running around polo field. Ive also had numerous field trips here when I was younger back when they had the museums. Oh yea i also remember that annoying hive of bees near that big windmill...god i hated those bees...

Anyhow, there are lots and lots of things to see and do in Golden Gate Park, may it be joggin through the fields, walking around the lakes, taking your younger siblings or kids or nieces and nephews to the playgrounds or pedaling on those funny boats over the lakes..hmm even riding horseback over some of the park...sometimes when your in the middle of the park with all the trees around you, you kind of forget your still in this city and it makes you feel pretty good...just look up and admire the skies on a nice sunny day~

hmmm I'm not sure about the horseback riding anymore and I'm not too sure if those buffalo are still in the back there...those were buffalo right? ermm I gotta go back and take a look sometime =_=

But there is so much, hahaha you can even come by at night and go ghost hunting or so, I havent had much luck with that but back in high school my 3 friends and I ran to our cars after hearing the snap of branch or something during the middle of the night while walking around stow lake lol.....*beware* there are a bunch of homeless or nutty people staking out there at night so try to be safe and walk in groups if any of you do decide to explore there during the wee hours.

ooo my friends and I also made a short film in Golden Gate Park and SF State..its a funny film..its still on you tube i believe..hahaha my horrible acting and lousy "fighting" might bore you but if any of you plan on taking a look go on Youtube and look up Assasin by Stuntpeople.
author: phillip w.

description:
I love golden gate park, and am lucky enought to live a couple blocks away.  I spent yesterday afternoon getting some sun with a friend....walking around, checking out the de young, the tea gardens, etc.  the only thing I hate about GGP..hippies, or rather, punks. and i am not sorry about it.  i DO NOT find your little signs at all cute nor are they remotely funny.  I mean come on...  "give me a fix and i'll give you a kiss?"  or "sharing is caring."  that's original.  this was my favorite one...some guy actually said to me as I passed him and his girlfriend, "bet you can't bounce a quarter off her head."  Are you serious?  Did he really expect me to go, "oooh yeah? bet I CAN!!!"

how about this?....stop taking up the entire sidewalk on haight street, stop playing those drum circles, stop pretending you can play the guitar and expecting me to pay tribute to you for it, stop expecting something for nothing, and get rid of the patchouli. that is the worst smell on earth. then I might consider giving you a buck in the future.
author: k. w.

description:
Okay, so I'm not some kind of eastern elitist bullshit artist when it comes to parks (i.e., oh this city doesn't have a decent bagel, so it's gotta suck.,...the same kinda of bs I hear a lot from the regular media).  But at the same time, while New York's Central Park has the Frederick Law Olmstead kinda of vibe, Golden Gate Park has kinda of a "hey dude, good vibe" kinda vibe.  To each his/her own.

All I know is that I like having a wide open space in the midst of urban chaos.

Word to the wise, if you have kids and plan on spending a day at the Children's Playground, right next to the Carousel, read Lord of the Flies first or listen to "Games Without Frontiers" from Peter Gabriel.  You'll know what I mean.
author: James K.

description:
Long time lurker, 1st time reviewer...

Hanging on the grass in front of the Conservatory, jogging, the Acad of Science (drinks & cheap admission during Thursday's Nightlife), the De Young, free music, disc golf (!), and the Park Chalet ($3 micro brew pints for happy hr)...not much to complain about.  The best part of the location where I live, the Inner Richmond, is prob the park.
author: Kevin K.

description:
I love Golden Gate Park for the most part BUT
Why does the city of San Francisco allow the Stanyan end of Golden Gate Park to be a lawless open air drug market? How is it acceptable that a few yards from where young children play soccer colonies of vagrants solicit any and all passer bys with "kind bud"?
author: Marcus R.

description:
I dont even know where to start with this park. Let's start with a random trivia--this park is LARGER than Central Park. Whaatt?

So being as big as it is, of course it is going to feature a lot, and i mean A LOT, of activities and sights. I've been here for an outdoor concert in amazing weather, been on bike rides through the park (and was able to avoid going up hill more than down hills), the modern play ground, tea garden, museums, etc etc.

This is such an amazing place. The music concourse may be one of my favorite spots in the park. Its flanked with amazing architectural structures--the CAS (Piano) and de Young (HdM) and a stage, where I've seen live fire spinning shows. Right by the deYoung on the street, on sat/sun, roller skaters perform and practice. On a nice clear saturday, there were artists posted out around the fountain in the middle of the concourse, selling art. Got to talk to one metal artist who made great shadow pieces.

Another favorite location of mine is their play ground. Its not your everday swings and monkey bars jungle gym that we all loved from our elementary school days, but there were modern day installations, such as this thing that looked like cat-tail and you just swing around on it.

I love that there is a buffalo running ground, a casting pond, a lake for row boats, an asian pavilion, horse stables, a botanical garden that is semi-reminiscent of the crystal palace, and just fields everywhere. I'd be in the park everyday if I lived remotely close to it. Definitely a great hang out place and cant wait to spend more time there over the summer!
author: Rena Y.

description:
Really? You're Yelping Golden Gate Park? The fuck's the matter with you? It's a *park*. It's got buffalo, or buffaloes if you will, and windmills. The AIDS Memorial Grove borders on the sublime, when the fog wafts at ground level Stowe Lake *is* sublime, and for the more randy of you it's got several meadows' worth of rentable swaths of grass on which you and your 25-year-old friends can play drunken kickball all summer (sorry, "summer"). And then there are the Botanical Gardens, which the careful reader notes I've set aside in their own sentence. 

If you actually live in San Francisco, why on earth wouldn't you go there. (I left the question mark off because it's not really a question, or if a question then a merely rhetorical one.) If you live in the Easy* Bay, ibid., unless by "Easy [sic] Bay" you mean like, I don't know, Moraga or something. But even then. 

But that reviewer who noted that there sure are a lot of roads in this here Park...wasn't wrong. I could do with a few fewer cars, ibid. as to hippies on, ah, Hippie Hill, but fuck it, nothing's perfect. 



* Ed. Note: After roughly 4 years spent correcting this typo your reviewer in 2009 threw in the towel, noting as he did so that it creates an arguably more accurate image of the region.
author: T U.

description:
I bitch a lot about living in the Inner Sunset.  I'm a big city girl, and living out here feels almost like a suburb.
But, then a warm, sunny weekend day rolls around and I'm so happy to walk a few blocks into a whole other world of beautiful flora, lakes, and (relatively) safe space to bike ride.  I love that I'm still finding new spaces to explore and feel blessed to have this in my backyard.
author: Jessica L.

description:
Running through here last Sunday kind of reminded me of a Tim Burton movie...no cars in sight, people jogging, walking, laughing, talking....70s roller-skating dance party on my right, intense swing dancing and music blaring down the road on my left. I saw a woman on roller skis, a waterfall, a three-piece hippie band on the corner, people picnicking and grilling, Frisbees flying about, children with balloons, buffaloes, and at least 12 different dog breeds. (Where was I? I had just left my house moments ago...) 

I must admit that this area of flowers, gardens, museums, people, classic San Francisco architecture, lakes, trees, paths, trails, pick-up soccer games in the mud, and grassy knolls that stretches to the beach can seem like a hidden fantasy-land within the city limit. Or seem like one of those strange, dark and scary Tim Burton movies at night.
author: Kelly R.

description: Pleasant! you can do pretty much anything here. you can come here anytime of day just to get away from the city. theres a lot of quiet spots for you to chill and ponder. they offer bike rentals and boat rentals for you to enjoy whatever nature adventure you're craving! theres just so much to see that you can't just read a review on it.. jut go out there and experience what it has to offer. you will not be disappointed i promise! its a getaway for your mind, body and soul! so why are you still reading this... GO!!
author: Carl T.

description:
This could be my favorite park in the world.

I lived next to the panhandle for 3 years and have run through the park hundreds of times.   I've done like 6 bay to breakers thru the park, more than a dozen DJ-style renegade parties,  weddings, birthdays, concerts, picnics, and many more dozen walks and bike rides thru it, stopping at flowers, lakes, museums, and grassy knolls.   I'd say about half of my top 50 events in SF were in this park.  What's not to love?

That said, my favs include 
- all the paved and non-paved bike/running paths 
- rose garden (stop and smell the roses, yo)
- live buffalo (free the tatanka!!)
- the new deYoung museum tower (not museum, just the free view from on high)
- Strybing Arboretum (plants from all over the world)
- hippy hill (spent many weekends here when i first moved to SF)
- dough boy field (capture the flag anyone?)
- windmills by the ocean
- streams and lots of lakes

-
author: chad n.

description:
This is by far my favorite park ever! It's so frickin huge. It has everything in it. Sunday is particularly very nice cause they closed the street for cars so you can walk and ride your bikes. Rollerblading is out btw. 

My favorite spot is Stow Lake. I love to just sit on the bench and feed the ducks with bread though most of the times I forgot to bring the bread, so just sitting on the bench watching ducks. 

I also love the fact they have shooting range, for archery it is. I used to take archery class and we went to 47th Avenue. Good times. I was pretty damn good so watch out! Give me a bow, arrows, and a horse, I will whoop Legolas' ass. 

The Botanical garden was my other fave place just to walk around. It's very serene and peaceful though sometimes I can hear kids screamin. 

Oh, my first kiss was also in Golden Gate Park, somewhere deep in the woods =) Just kissing though, what a shame.
author: Perry S.

description:
By far the most magical place in the city. There is so much to do in this park, and so much nature to see. 

I learned to ride my bike here!

I used to play in the playground and ride the carousel (it was only $0.25 back then!). 

I've been meaning to go back to Stow Lake for some boating action. 

When the Academy opens again, this place will be five times as cool. Man, I loved that place...

Is it emasculating to admit I like the Conservatory of Flowers?

They apparently have a parking structure on the northern center. You can also park at UCSF and ride the free shuttle that runs on weekends and holidays. You can also (eventually) find parking in Richmond or Sunset for free.
author: Keane L.

description:
This one time, I was tripping, and I fell, and broke my foot.

Sounds like some silly line about falling while tripping, but its real folks, and have you ever broken anything while on copious amounts of mushroom tea in addition to the thre caps your friend continues to feed you - its not very cool.  
Your whole understanding of pain gets Morphed and all of a sudden you see your life spiraling down until there you are, living in a cardboard box having recently been disowned by everyone you know.

Ok seriously - the park is nice but stay away from the rose garden on hallucinogens - its manicured, and scary, and nice wholesome families from ohio are taking close-ups. 
 So you run.  Far far away.  down a hill .and break your foot.

Other than that - great park.
author: amy b.

description:
After managing to roll out of bed, get hiking chic, grab our sandwiches and get out of Richmond by 3:00 my buddy and I set out in search of the dome.  We saw this giant dome when we were driving accross the Golden Gate Bridge ($5 toll is total bullshit BTW) and it was off to the right.  Anywho's somehow we surmised that the giant dome was at Golden Gate Park, so we headed out 580-80-101-where the hell am I? and finally found our way to 9th & Lincoln.  Parking was snappy and free on Martin Luther King, Jr. drive and we just headed over through the botanical garden, grabbed a seat and had a snack.  It was quite peaceful.  We continued to explore the park and managed to sit in on some monks playing recorders at the Golden Gate Plaza (Chinese Gazebo), hike to a peak and find a waterfall, Catch some awesome ocean front views, sneak into the De Young Museum just before closing time and take copious photographs in compromising positions with the art pieces, hang out at an outdoor art show, take pictures of people having their wedding photos taken, go down the slide at the children's playground, walk through some funky tunnel, meander through the lawn bowling green and carousel areas, get lost in a mini redwood forrest, befriend some squirrels, and have a very hilarious bathroom encouter that's damn near inexplicable and most assuredly noone else will find remotely as amusing as we did.   To that end, we only covered about a third of the park - if that. I never knew such a wonderful place existed in San Francisco and if anyone had ever told me I wouldn't have believed them.  I would have looked at it similarly to my view of central park - kind of a waste.  Historically relevant, some very lovely spots, but overcrowded and not so nice/clean. The similarities between these two end with the word "park." 

If this park were a wrestler it would be Hulk Hogan and central park would be Macho Man Randy Savage getting bitch slapped with a slim jim.

PS - we later figured out that the giant dome was the friggin Palace of Fine Art! lol.  Maybe next weekend.
author: Traci G.

description:
You must visit  this park, it's SF equvalent to Central Park  in NYC. 

So much to see and do. Gardens, lakes, museums, and alot of scenic views.
author: emmy a.

description:
Absolutely breath-taking and beautiful....
When you've had enough of life go to this park and unwind... its hard to find places like this in metropolitan cities in California.  

Make sure to go to Stowe (sp?) lake and rent those little boats and enjoy floating around the lake.  Enjoy the wildlife like the ducks and squirrels.  Go to the gardens and admire the different flowers there.  

It just all feels very nature-y. =) I make a point to go there everytime I go to SF, or at least try.
author: Cristina M.

description:
Beats Central Park hands down. Parking under the museum is expensive but convenient.

and umm.... you can get "tobacco products" there so EZ. Word-up.
Next best thing to delivery. :-)
author: Ed V.

description: I love this landmark! I can just go here and relax and bring friends and family.  Its one of the things I love about San Francisco! I love taking my friends' kids to the playgrounds and the arboretum for a nice walk.
author: Nadia N.

description:
It's quite possible to spend an entire day here and not get bored. the de Young museum, the Botanical gardens, going for a run, the Beach Chalet, going for a run or a walk, the scent gardens, lounging in the grass, playing soccer/baseball/football, hanging on the playground, or watching a dance group perform for anyone walking by. 

It's truly a San Francisco gem that many people neglect or don't appreciate, but that everyone should experience for themselves when they live here. :)
author: Nicolas H.

description:
Every time I ride my bike, I go through Golden Gate Park. I usually enter around Fulton and 6th, ride up to the entrance of the Haight, then back down to the De Young Museum. I always make sure to take a break in front of the museum and soak in the view. 

Even at night, it's one of my favorite spots in the park. I have an affinity for the trapezoid-like tower engulfed in brown metal netting, the Roman arch and pillars that are constantly being renovated, the new museum across the way, and the field of palm trees in the central paved area. Plus, the Japanese Tea Garden is only a few feet away and there are statutes of philosophers, poets and artists scattered throughout the circle. 

And this is only the tip of the iceburg. You get the Conservatory of Flowers, the water bison, the wooden windmill, the hundreds of secluded pockets (perfect for picnics and volleyball), hippie hill and Kezar Stadium... all in a park that spans almost half the length of our city. 

I often bitch about living in the Outer Richmond, but one of the things I'm thankful for is how close Golden Gate Park is to my apartment and that I actually take advantage of that proximity as much as I can.
author: Jared S.

description: This park is gorgeous. It's perfect for a picnic, bike riding, running, and rollerblading. The architecture in the midst of it is a lovely view, and there are always enough people around to give it a vibrant, community feel. Plus, you can take your bike to the beach right after.
author: Cher H.

description:
For a long time I thought NY had us beat on parks.  But after moving to San Francisco and spending some significant time in the park, I've decided I was sorely mistaken.  I've been visiting Golden Gate park since I was tiny (tiny enough to fit in the baby swings at the children's playground), and I still discover things I didn't know were there.  

The park is magical.  There are so many gardens to explore, hidden paths to follow, events to attend, museums to visit, people to watch.  I'll never grow tired of it.
author: Katie S.

description:
I wanted to make a careful decision about my first review on Yelp! and finally decided on the much-loved Golden Gate Park! This is my jewel in the city and is one of the greatest places to spend a lazy or adventurous afternoon. 

As I child, I enjoyed catching a glimpse of the roaming buffalo, riding the carousel with friends, rolling down the grassy knoll before Mother's Playground, and frequently visiting the California Academy of Sciences. Now, as a young adult, I have rediscovered the beauty of the park and all the more it has to offer - gardens, museums, music festivals, art shows, and car-free Sundays.

I love taking a jog through the park on a sunny morning when it's not too crowded, and I am able to discover the random nooks and crannies of this treasured playground for all ages :)
author: Jaclyn T.

description:
Lions and Tigers and Bears, oh my!

Well, they don't have these but they have Bisons. Or is it Buffalo? I love this park because of all the activities that are available. They have a windmill here, too. Don't forget that they close down a section of the street so that pedestrians and bicyclist can enjoy roaming around without the dangers of cars hitting them. 

I once had a secret rendezvous at Stow Lake. And no, there's no stupid ghost there, silly.
author: Genevieve S.

description:
So much space to walk, run, explore, remember what it is like to be surrounded by trees...

I've been having trouble fitting outdoor time and exercise into my daily routine. So I've made it a habit to do a long Golden Gate Park walk on Saturday mornings. I take off from either the Mission or Hayes Valley, head to the Upper Haight, into the park, randomly walk all over the park until I'm tired, then walk out and down Haight Street in the direction of where I came. I'm all plugged into my ipod so I really disappear into my own world.

The cool thing about it is that every week is a little different. There are so many different environments within the park. I always notice something new and never take the same route. Especially on the nice weather days, it's a great opportunity to disengage from the hectic reality that normally surrounds me and soak up some sunshine while breathing in the freshness of vegetation. It's also a proven hangover cure for me.

The only part that sucks is the grungy guys bumming around the park looking wasted and acting offended that I don't respond to the random things they say to me that I can't hear anyway since I'm listening to my freaking music. I'm here to get away from that, not get bombarded by it.

Overall, Golden Gate Park is a true treasure within the city.
author: Amy K.

description:
I got married here, I run or walk here every day. I love this place.

On Saturdays and Sundays, when cars are prohibited on JFK drive, it's like paradise. It is difficult to find even one unhappy person. I wish San Francisco could limit traffic, or set a maximum speed in the park, so people could feel like that more often. 

This is one of the best reasons to pay rent in SF. Especially mountain-dew hued Stow Lake!
author: H G.

description: If you like your urban parks, you should make your way over to Golden Gate Park.  Highlights include the DeYoung (Art) Museum (and its free observation tower) and the Japanese Tea Garden.  It's also just nice to chill out for an afternoon on hippie hill.  And then you can make your way to the Haight Ashbury district.  I'm fond of the Alembic on Haight Street for a high-quality whiskey-based cocktail (and of course, check out Haight Ashbury).  Also just off of the park is Amoeba Music, which features one of the largest used music collections in the world.  Amoeba staffers are quite knowledgeable, but they're not quite on the same level as those who work at Aquarius.
author: Matthew L.

description: I have been in the city for ~2 months total so far and never ventured into the park, until the bluegrass festival a couple of weeks ago. I have to say that the park really blew me away. I couldn't believe how much there was in there, and how you can sometimes feel like your going through a forest only to come out to a center with art, fountains, etc. I can't wait for the day when I have the opportunity to really journey through it and enjoy everything that is has to offer. Of course I am very excited to make it to the science museum for the 'adult' night! I am a little angry that it took me that long to actually walk through the park because I feel like I have been missing out on a crucial part of the city for so long. It is definitely worth a trip to it, just to enjoy a stroll, go to the museum, watch the bison, or have a picnic. Good job SF, this park is awesome.
author: Brandon R.

description: I love this park!  There is so much to explore, and it's really great for everyone from kids to adults and dogs!  If you are just visiting there is always something to do at the park!
author: Jennifer L.

description: Golden Gate Park, on the Day of Bay to Breakers, was so... f---ing... beautiful. Sunday's A++++++ weather made the park just breathtaking, and I was sad that I don't live in SF anymore! Walking to Lincoln Street from the Polo fields, I was going along a bunch of really romantic little hidden trails with wildflowers (my favorite sight is those little white daisies on a grassy lawn). When I lived in the city, I remember feeling like, Golden Gate park was the thing that made it worth putting up with the traffic, the parking, and the higher rent. Now that I'm not in my 20's, I can do without the night life in the city, but GG Park is like the biggest thing that could pull me back. Too many great things to say in one review. I know I might be a little biased but, seriously... this has got to be the most beautiful park in the country.
author: Laura S.

description:
I hesitate to write a review of The Park because it's so mindblowingly great that I know I can't do it justice.  Man, GG Park inspired me to start running 10 miles.  That's how enticing it is (I run to the beach and back).  Here are a few of my favorite things:

- Japanese Tea Garden
- Conservatory of Flowers
- De Young Museum (and the area in front of the bandstand/outdoor stage)
- The huge cross at the top of the waterfall on JFK
- Free concerts
- That little pond on the northwest end
- The botanical gardens
- The rose garden
- The giant purple head
- The windmill
- The mountain bike trails

Perhaps my favorite part is Stow Lake/Strawberry Hill.  There's a rustic cabin marking the entrance on the JFK side.  You can rent paddle boats.  There's a waterfall next to an Asian gazebo (can't remember if it's Chinese or Japanese).  If you climb Strawberry Hill, you get views of the city, the bay, Golden Gate Bridge, and Marin.  There are so many places where you can forget that you are in the city.  Truly sublime.

Okay, so there are needles and homeless hippies.  I've never seen a needle and the homeless hippies add a little spice to the mix.
author: Chad W.

description: (This review is for doin it in the park) Ok so I appreciate free, but Three port o potty's???? Really? Come on guys!!! There's girls here!!! Other than that..food was good, music at times could have been better...(sorry pirates) and people were awesome!!! I'll probly be back next year...but please!! More port o potties!!!!
author: Marina R.

description:
It's a miracle of modern society that a city as vibrant and full as San Francisco can still manage to have so many square miles allocated to look like the set of Jurassic Park. If this were any other city, the park would have been filled-in decades ago by condo highrises and hourly parking garages. But because San Francisco is such a special city, we've been blessed by pretty much preserving the park as it has been for the past 100 years. It's simply one of the many reasons why I love San Francisco so much.

Top five greatest things about Golden Gate Park:
5. Walking through the arboreteum with a cup of coffee from 9th street...
4. Paddle-boating around Stow Lake on a brisk spring morning.
3. Crazy nekkid runners during Bay to Breakers (okay, not my favorite...)
2. Not one, but TWO windmills at both sides of the west end of the park... Looking like something out of Sleepy Hollow...
1. I love buffalos!

I hope that my kids 30 years from now can enjoy it nearly as much as I do now...
author: Stephen W.

description:
I watched a mole push up dirt from his little hole the other day. "Aww", I chirped at him while he sent me haughty glances, "go away, lady. I'm busy. Stop chirping at me." 

Then I finally realized he was pushing all that dirt out to cover the hole and before long, he was gone. 

Just one of the many reasons why I adore Golden Gate Park.
author: Nathalie L.

description:
So beautiful, but soooooooooo overcrowded. 

If only I could filter out the homeless man picking his butt on my memory, his friend coughing up mucus onto the flower bed, and the swarms of people packed into this park, this place would be perfect.
author: B B.

description:
Obviously I'm not telling you anything that the 290 reviews preceding me didn't, but for my personal hundredth review, I thought Golden Gate Park was deserving. 
Some of my oldest memories are of this park, my parents are San Francisco alumnus's and even after moving north, we would come here very often; the family was still here and who could stay out of the city??
There's so much to see and explore. It's always lush, beautifully cared for and serene. Even if there's droves of people here, you manage to feel like you and whoever you're with are the only ones. 
I love the city for all it's character, life and artful ways, this park is one of those places that makes it so.
author: Katie W.

description: Golden gate park better start doing something about being overrun by wildlife and the worst is the raccoons.  You can't even walk your dog.  They stand in groups of eight or nine on the walkways just waiting for you to try and pass so they can attack you.  Most people are carrying big sticks with them.  Three days ago a beautiful yellow kitty was killed and eaten. She was so pretty. I loved her. This was in my backyard.  They have taken over our neighborhoods. They are everywhere. I can't stand it anymore.  When they start eating our children maybe they will do something about it. They carry disease and eat our pets. They break into our homes and make a mess of everything.  I think the papers should do a story on this.  I feel like I need a gun or big bat to protectmmyself and family.  Get those smelly big rodents out of our residents and parks and streets and yards and every where! ! Do your job. Get rid of raccoons so we can live a safe clean life again.
author: Lina S.

description: I was lucky enough to come here today and see Lila'angelique and Thoth perfom by the conservatory of flowers. They even gave me a free cd. Golden Gate park is awesome. It's awesome to stay in a city and still experience nature.
author: Kayla G.

description:
Ah GGP.  This park is my sanctuary for life.  As a small child I would ride my bike through its syringe ridden trails, dodging homeless people as they camped in plain site.  As a high school kid I would drink 40 oz. Malt beverages on cold nights, while my buddies egged cars on Lincoln Way.  As a college student I would smoke fat blunts in front of middle aged women as they walked their dogs.  Today, I live in the dumpster behind Stow Lake lodge.

Haha. Just Kidding.

GGP rules.
author: Justin O.

description:
I'm just going to go  ahead and say it: GOLDEN GATE PARK IS WAY BETTER THAN CENTRAL PARK. 
The people, the nature, the different ecosystems, the animals, the museums, tea garden, hidden pathways, rivers, sports fields, lakes, wide open spaces for miles...what's not to love?
author: Julie F.

description:
how can you NOT like ggpark?!!

it practically covers the whole city! :)

but i wouldn't walk or drive through the ggpark at night. and DONT ever stop when a cop tries to pull you over in ggpark.
author: Carol Y.

description:
The Outdoors.

Hmm, sounds kinda familiar, but it's not an area I am all too familiar with. You see, as a glow in the dark, pale girl, I try to avoid the outdoors as much as possible, but thanks to a little coaxing from my company and its team outing last week, I, actually spent an afternoon....outdoors.

.....And liked it, because this is a pretty awesome park. Granted we only enjoyed a small part of it, but it's really beautiful and the fact that I could actually notice that in the midst of Sudafed popping, runny nose blowing and shivering in a blanket due to a nasty case of the sickyness, I think that is sayin something.

I'll be back GGP, just you wait and see, you may have made an outdoors person of me yet.

maybe :)
author: Stephy S.

description:
This is one of those reviews you write for a place that leaves you speechless over time as a result of how amazing it is! GGP ROCKS! zeriouzly.

I feel like this park deserves its' recognition as a micro-ecosystem of its' own accord. The eucalyptus groves, the fields, lakes, minor attractions, and big destinations makes it a wonderful hub for urban active life. 

I enjoy this park for its' serenity when I'm about to go stark raving mad, and for its' energetic spice when I'm ready to kick a few beers back with the gurls. 

So get out there and go versatile.
author: Andrew C.

description:
If you don't love Golden Gate Park you have no soul.  Or you've never been there.

I used to live in London; one of the things the Brits do much better than we Yanks is park life.  Pic-nics, well manicured gardens, relaxing afternoons, families, sporting and play time are trademarks of the glories that come along with buoyant park-life.  Golden Gate satisfies all of these criteria (well I cant say the gardens are well manicured) and offers a sanctuary the hustle and bustle of city life.  Without having to drive miles for redwood groves you can escape.  

I would be lying if I didn't mention my favorite part about the park is the fact that you can have kegs in certain areas.  Mind you, you have to apply for a permit, but I am a fan of any place you can drink publicly during daylight without judgment.  There is little I love more in life than slosh ball...so you can image my elation when I first discovered this wondrous gospel.

Viva Golden Gate Park.
author: Kayti S.

description:
Hippie hill is my favorite part, i don't do halucinogens but i do like to be offered them.

it's a nice park, lots to do inside.  even has a museum in the middle.

the man-made fake ass waterfall pisses me off, why bother?? lame

i love grass, i love picnics, i love being outside. i love that it ends with the beach.  right on SF
author: kiki b.

description:
I love that I can sit and drink out in the open.
Picnics with the girls and mimosas...tits.

word.
author: desiree n.

description: Too large of an area, which still gets me lost. Don't drive here at night because you will get lost. Skunks and bums will scare the crap outta you. In the day time, probably the only park in SF worthwhile because it's sooooo huge, diverse with many offerings that you will not have enough time to finish in a day or two. The Academy of Science is my favorite attraction at this park. I absolutely love marine life (always been a hobby of mine from owning goldfishes to salt water tanks with coral reefs).
author: Jeff C.

description:
Talk about a multi-functional park!  Everything happens here at one time or another during the course of the year.  Festivals, running races, dance exhibitions, soccer games, museums, botanical gardens, concerts ... everything!  This is a great place to get lost in and yet have the City still easily within reach.  The Panhandle portion (stretching from Stanyan to Baker is only about a block or so wide and offers two very nice curving paved trails, one for runners only.  Expect to see plenty of people walking or running every morning in the light fog.  In the heart of the park there is so much in terms of entertainment, culture, and scenery it's really hard to take it all in.  Even if you live here for years you probably can't get to it all---every time I walk through it I find something new.

Your best bet is not to park anywhere close to the park and just take the bus in---it's only like $1.50/person!  Have a leisurely morning and go to one of the many cafes or restaurants (mostly on the Lincon side).  Or cap the day off on Ocean Beach.  Or take the family out to Chinese food.

Times visited: who's counting?
author: Amy L.

description:
Any day I can drag my ass to the park instead of laying in bed is well worth it.

I live two blocks from the 8th Ave entrance and could not be happier.  Whenever I go, there are always other people enjoying life as much as I am.  

It's a hop, skip and a jump from de Young, Conservatory of Flowers, Haight Street, little pathways, the skate rink and tons of space to just lay out and soak up the sun.  

You can ride your bike, walk, run, roller skate, start softball games, have picnics, do yoga, meditate, walk your dog, run your dog, pretty much anything!

I usually use my time to lay out and relax on the grass with my dog catching up on cell phone calls or reading.  I always make a stop at the skating area on Sunday.  Cool skaters, great music, a real fun watch.

On Sunday JFK Drive is closed to vehicles and there are people everywhere, all over the street.  Sometimes I zig zag, just because I can.

Get outside and enjoy!
author: B C.

description:
Good Park ~ houses four areas for the doggies; my only two gripes are: 
1) the people are 'clicky' which I believe is B.S.  You don't own the park, its public and others are also allowed to bring their dogs for play! 

2) throughout the entirety of the park there are just not enough doggy watering bowls.  Hello, dogs need to rehydrate themselves.  I find it difficult to enjoy the entirety of the park due to lack of watering facilities for the pooch.  My doggie needs WATER
author: Cris B.

description:
Great cities, by definition, include a versatile public space freely available to all denizens. A park that offers something for everyone, and is conveniently located to the majority of the population.

San Francisco is a great city, made so in no small part by Golden Gate Park. Venture into the park on any sunny weekend or holiday and you'll find the whole spectrum of San Franciscans enjoying our incredible park. From the families picnicking in Speedway Meadow, to the drum circle keeping time for Hippy Hill, to the soccer fields, to the dog runs, to the fly-fishing pond, to the archery range, to the lawn bowling, to the golf course, the disc golf course and the myriad children's playgrounds; Golden Gate Park has something for everyone.

That doesn't even begin to cover the cultural resources in the park: the De Young Museum, the Conservatory of Flowers, the Botanical Gardens, the lilacs surrounding the windmill, or the soon to re-open Academy of Sciences. You could live in San Francisco for a decade and not explore the whole park. 

Plus, a big chunk of the park is closed to motor vehicles on Sundays and holidays, so that pedestrians, roller skaters, bladers, bikers, trikers, dog walkers, and strollers can all enjoy some outdoor time without having to share the road with big cars or trucks. That rules. 

Only drawback: spend enough time walking the trails of GGP and you will eventually find a homeless encampment. Or three. 

But the sheer size and location of this park make it an integral part of the city, and help make life in such a densely urban environment fun for all walks and ages.
author: Greg Q.

description: Breathtaking.  Golden Gate Park is better than advertised.  It's so unique to come across such a large, wooded area in the middle of a vibrant city.  The park is very active and family friendly.  The trails are easy to follow and the grounds are pristine.  Lots of open ground to play or watch games of frisbee golf.  I'd really like to get back here with a bike and cover some serious ground.
author: Joseph Z.

description:
Woohoo! As good as it gets is right! This park, along with Golden Gate Bridge and Pliny the Elder are what convinced me to move to San Francisco. You could seriously spend your whole day, well, two or three days at GGP and see something new every day. Bicycle rentals, playgrounds, Japanese tea garden, BUFFALO!, waterfalls, rose gardens (roses bigger than my head!). remote control boats at Stow Lake (along with the famous baby owls living there right now!), adorable groundhogs, skate park, giant windmill leading to Ocean Beach, tons of trails always filled with runners and cyclists...I could go on. If you come to SF and leave without seeing GGP you have done yourself a serious disservice. Guaranteed to be lush, green, well taken care of, and filled with life. Basically, prepare to take photos, ride a bike, smell a flower, walk to Ocean Beach, engage in a festival or two, maybe fight off a park kid*, and have an all around good time. 

*As for the park kids, I recommend walking further into the park if you are coming from Haight/Stanyan/the Panhandle. Use common sense, stay aware of your surroundings, and with most public places/parks, don't stick around after dark. Not a big deal.

Central Park...what's that?
author: Leigh W.

description:
I've lived in the Bay Area my whole life and can't get enough of Golden Gate Park. There are just so many elements to this park, and there are always things to discover.

A fun day walk is to start in the Haight, cruise through the Inner Sunset and walk the length of the park down to the beach. The beauty is that after you make the trek back there are tons of restaurants to satisfy the hunger for food and booze that you've just worked up!

Cool spots that I like are the little island on in the middle of Stow Lake, the Botanical Garden (you can lose youself in here if you want, what with all the little side roads) and the windmills down by the beach.

If you live in San Francisco and haven't checked out the park, you're missin' out!
author: Art D.

description:
I love this place. There's nothing (well almost nothing) that makes feel better than a run through Golden Gate Park. Sometimes I'll start ocean side by the Dutch windmill and run east past the American Bison. Other days, I'll run from the panhandle by Stowe Lake. On the weekends, it makes for great people watching as the guys with their toy speedboats gather at Sprinkles Lake, and the roller skaters groove to tunes from their boomboxes, and the AIDS Marathoners and Team in Training folk make their way on another training run. 

There's always activity all of which reflects what's so wonderful about this city - the people. There are tons of tourists on the panhandle side if you're looking for that sort of thing, while it's always nice and quiet on the MLK side closer to the ocean if you're looking for some solitude. 

I used to live a couple of blocks away. And while I love my new neighborhood, the one thing I miss is being so close to the park. But I make a point of getting over there a couple of times a week. It's my sanity.
author: Marie M.

description:
Tennis court review only.

These courts could use a little work, but they are generally pretty good. One of the private club team captains (aka. The Witch) complained about the courts being "dangerous" because one of her team members injured her knee during a match at these courts. But that is just plain bullshit. With any sport, you risk injury. I was just playing at Darling Tennis courts in Las Vegas where the courts are pristine and my opponent tore her ACL trying to chase down a ball. So, you know what? Maybe The Witch should just stick to playing at country clubs or next time, ride her broom over to sweep up the courts. 

Anyways, the best part about these courts isn't the courts itself. It is the community and all the great people I have met through the teams. Not to say there aren't some bad seeds, but there are a lot of good ones too. 

The one confusing thing here is the court booking situation. I've never really understood it. You have to dial in one weekday at a particular time and constantly dial until you reach someone. I wish to god they could just move to the 21st century and let people do it online. PLEASE???!?!?
author: Karen C.

description:
The old stables behind the polo field are so historical.  A great place for running - a hidden staircase in the polo fields is also the perfect place for running up and down the stairs.

Note to self: When a helicopter flies by and news vans are in the park, don't try to get on TV during that time.  It means they probably found a body.
author: Stacey C.

description:
I loved the playground in Golden Gate Park as a kid You know when Kids actually played outside.. instead of playing video games all damn
day

My cousins and I would stay in tha park on those giant slides some times pushing our luck because we had to be home b4 the streetlights
came on

Back then all you were waiting for was daylight savings time
author: Kim R.

description: The best man made park in the world! I come here on sunny days to ride bicycle and people watch.  A great place to have a picnic and a nap.  While there, you should check out the museums.  There are big patches of open space in random parts of the park to throw football and play sloshball.  Go here for a nice walk / run and to get away from the bustling city
author: Alex G.

description:
This park has EVERYTHING one might need....museums...grass lawns...tennis courts....running trails..........concerts.........
It's BIG..it's green...it's AWESOME!
I always find an excuse to come here..whether it's a picnic, or a work-out!
author: Lerka J.

description:
I LOVE PARKS!

There is a ton to see here...De Young Museum, Academy of Science, Flower Conservatory, parks and more parks...you can bbq here, there are concerts here, you can walk your dog, bike, skateboard, hike, play tennis, play volleyball...kiosks are available if you get too thirsty or hungry...you can lie out your blanket and sun bathe on a warm day...an unlimited amount of activities...
author: Oanh N.

description: GORGEOUS park.  HUGE!  lots to do.  LOVE the lawn bowling.  there is also a super cool play area for kids.  walking through there, i wished i had a kid just so i could take them to play in there.  ;)  if i were going again, i would ride a bike through the park with a picnic.  enjoy!
author: Debra R.

description:
Ok, the first thing that really got me are the buffalo.  That's just crazy, buffalo, in the middle of a city.  How funny!?!?

Anyway, the park is awesome.  I could easily spend many hours there walking around, looking at things and visiting the many little places inside the park.  I've been to the Japanese Tea Garden, worth the $3 admission.  The conservatory is expensive, but absolutely beautiful inside.  And they have an area where the butterflies buzz by and sometimes land on you - love that!
author: nicole h.

description:
I have friends who live in the city, and we have driven by the park, went to specific places in the park on a  mission to see it and go, and walked by the park, but never have I ever just taken time to explore the park until this last visit to San Francisco.  Boy, oh boy, did I discover what I was missing, and I can't wait to come back and have more time to go adventuring in the park.

I didn't have a plan at all when I went.  I simply set aside 2.5 hours to wander the park by myself.  I took a book, my camera, and a sweatshirt because it can get a little cold.  There were random trails to walk through feeling like you were on a hike.  There were quiet spots in the park where different people claimed a spot of grass as theirs.  The botanical garden was fun to roam around.  Then I found myself at the Rose Garden, and I took the time to smell all the different types of roses and read my book.  The roses were beautiful and most smelled good.  Sadly I'm a person who hardly has time to stop and smell the roses, but this trip I took the time and it will hopefully encourage me to slow down.  What else?

Stow Lake was a part of the park I had never been before and I thoroughly enjoyed this discovery.  It may not be a secret to you, but for me, it was a whole different part of the park that I thoroughly enjoyed.  I walked around the island part finding myself climbing dirt stairs higher and higher, and before I knew it I was face to face with a waterfall that I didn't know was there.  Then I saw people taking little row boat rides through the lake.  I definitely wanted to come back here with some friends.  How fun?!  

I know, I know.  I must sound like such a dork.  You're probably thinking, "What's the big deal?  It's just a park."  But I truly appreciate these big outdoor parks more than I used to when I was younger.  Maybe I'm getting old?  I don't know, but bottom line is that I would like to return to Golden Gate Park because I know there is far more to explore, it's relaxing and fun to walk around getting lost along or with friends, and it's great way to get exercise without feeling like a caged animal on a little treadmill.  Try it some time.  You won't regret it.  Don't be like me and wait until your 50th visit to San Francisco.
author: Nicky C.

description:
If aliens decide to land on Earth, I really hope they choose to do it at Golden Gate Park on a Sunday. That way maybe they'll actually think there's hope for our species.

Golden Gate Park is wonderful, Sundays are the best. Everyone seems to be really happy, either with their family or friends. There's always something to do: skating, biking, walking, frisbee, dancing, and a lot of geo-caching!

I get nothing but a good feeling every time I go. That sort of feeling like everything is going to be OK.
author: Franz V.

description:
Probably my number one hang out spot and I bring visitors here. It's unfortunate that our Frisco weather sucks two enormous balls and that I have a huge load of school and work, otherwise I'd probably stop shaving my legs and showering all together and live in a tent with my dog forever at Golden Gate Park. 



The Botanical Garden is definitely my favorite. I love getting lost in the Redwood "forest". I've also befriended the obese squirrels while sketching with my friend Andy one day. I started making kissy noises at a squirrel from a mile away and it ended up sitting in my lap. I'm surprised I didn't end up with rabies. YAY GOLDEN GATE PARK!
author: Shereen R.

description:
Pretty amazing to have this in the city, and for me, to live 1 block away. 

You can do just about anything in here--picnic, exercise, play soccer with strangers, go to little league, go to adult baseball leagues, sunbathe, rollerblade, bicycle, hang out, and some even engage in "unsavory" activities. 

And, it's peaceful, and easily accessible.
author: Caroline C.

description:
Concerts in the park
Buffalo (okay, bison) in the park
Joggers and cyclists in the park
Cancer-walk walkers in the park
de Young in the park
Smiley people in the park
[sometimes] Sun in the park
Botanical gardens in the park
Ponds and birds in the park
Happy in the park!

[Little] parking in the park
Silly tea garden in the park

But I'm still
Happy in the park!
author: Catherine H.

description:
Beautiful area. Public transportation (I don't think there is much parking). You can walk across the Golden gate bridge (don't forget to wear a hat or sunblock;I got burned). Right along the water. 

Of note, crossing the Golden Gate bridge is expensive.
author: David A.

description:
Oh, here is the home
Where the buffalo roam,
And the skies are quite foggy all day. 

Not counting the museums, on a scale of things to see and do, it falls below Central Park in New York City but outshines Hyde Park in London. From its start at the end of the Panhandle to the ocean and back, it measures roughly eight miles, for joggers and walkers interested in knowing how much ground they've covered. Midweek, JFK Drive is busy with traffic, and on weekends it gets lots of pedestrians, so detour to Middle Drive and enjoy relative peace and quiet. Make sure you spend some time in the Arboretum.
author: Gourmet G.

description:
"So, how many people do you think will offer us drugs this time?"
"Two."
"I got three."

Ah, yes, the infamous walk from Haight into the park. Probably the most reliable place to buy weed if you don't have a hook-up. And if guessing how many times you'll be offered gets boring, try to guess HOW they'll offer... Will it be the uncreative, "Bud," or will some ingenius hippie show you a bag so you can preview the goods on your pass by. hmmm.

On a side note, this is one of the best places to run, entertain a kid, or see bison in the city.
author: Jessica W.

description:
WARNING Bicycle Riders - bike thefts are increasing in GGP, especially around the concourse/DeYoung and Science Museum areas - mine was stolen while cable locked at the bike rack.  I recommend if you must lock your bike anywhere in the concourse area, to use a NYC chain or Gorilla lock - a simple cable lock will get snipped.

Prior to the theft, I enjoyed a bike ride encompassing the entire park to get my orientation - there is so much to see and enjoy, it is a great park to bicycle in, despite the theft.  Also, the park shuttle is a very fine offering get off/get on for one daily price...

BTW if you get there early enough, parking is not a problem and you can find parking along the roads outside the concourse within an easy quarter- to half-mile walk to the concourse.
author: G W.

description:
Great place to be when the weather is good! Take your dog, and make sure to bring your own doggie bags, and be prepared to hold the filled bag for awhile as there are not enough trash cans around! (this should be fixed imo!-not exactly dog friendly now is it?)

However there are water spots that have doggie water bowls, so that is a big plus!
author: Deirdre P.

description: Big, great park where we bring the kiddies.  With museums, gardens, play areas and just plain lots of stuff to do in a clean and safe environment.  Always a good place to visit.  We mostly visit the area with the Japanese Tea Garden and California Museum of Sciences.
author: Al C.

description:
Golden Gate Park, I've been here at least once a month since I moved to California.  I've ridden every bike I ever owned here and this place is beautiful.  When I went through a stoner-phase, I went here to get my fix (too soon?)

You can just walk around aimlessly and it's never too crowded here.  You can also get lost! which is awesome, but not at night.

Oh, but bring a map cause it is really easy to get lost.
author: Bobby Y.

description:
So many memories: bike riding, running, Aids Walk, museum trips, picnics, and such.  Golden Gate park offers a diverse variety of activities.  Anyone and everyone can have a good time here.  Sure, once you've been to New York's Central Park, Golden Gate Park pales in comparison.  But if you're a visiting tourist this is a no-brainer that will surely make you mellow.

Oh, and what's with the festival of weed smokers I encountered?  The mary jane clouds reminded me of the pollution in Beijing.  I also saw a shifty guy running around with a HUGE bag of pot.  I guess this might be a good thing depending on your "hobbies".
author: Michael H.

description:
The highlight of the week is my 6 mile run through Golden Gate Park every Sunday afternoon. It's sanctuary, really. I enjoy the greenery of the extensive garden landscapes and well-maintained foliage, as well as features such as the Conservatory of Flowers, the Swedish windmills, the rollerskating area (shout-outs to the boombox guy) and the bison pins. Considering the relatively high tourist traffic, people are friendly  and the park is extremely clean. It's an excellent place to come and absorb the cultural diversity San Francisco is renown for.

Summers are exceptionally extraordinary in the park. Everything from bluegrass festivals and renaissance faires to marathons and weddings.

Lovely all around.
author: Matthew H.

description: very nice and cared ... many activities to do, visit the Japanese gardens, the academy of sciences, the reserve with the Rams, lakes, mills Antilles, wonderful
author: Andrea M.

description: This park is awesome.  It's so so so so so so so so so BIG!  Came here in August, and just... blew me away!
author: Susan A.

description: Drove around over 30 minutes and could not find parking. The only place there is parking is on the street. I don't know where people parked otherwise. It was worse than being at a mall the day before Christmas. I would try to take a bus or rent a bike next time. Basically saw nothing and ended up leaving
author: Chris T.

description: This is one of my favorite spots in the city. They have concerts here such as the Dave Matthews Band concert in the park which is amazing every year. They also are home to various walks for causes which make participating in things like those so much easier when you walk through a park as beautiful as this one. There is so much space here picnics and group events are perfect and it is located near Muni stops to make getting there easy. There are tons of gardens and trails creating tons of photo ops. I am living in LA now but I still miss this park!
author: Sarah G.

description:
I spend a lot of time at GG Park. I will admit it is just four blocks from my house, but everyone should venture here because it has so much to offer in local flavor. The following are all reasons this place is not to be missed: 

I love lounging on the lawn outside of the conservatory reading a book
Hanging on hippy hill people watching on sunny Saturdays
Going to the tea garden on relaxing afternoons
Taking advantage of the trails for running and walking
Watching the roller skating community on Sundays when no cars are allowed
Playing disc golf at the far end - newly renovated and lovely
Finding a hidden spot to call your own for a bit of peace
Free concerts in the summertime
Drinking beer and watching outrageous recreation sports leagues
Picnicking on its open spaces

Go here...and keep going here. You won't regret it.
author: Alicia J.

description:
It's the equivalent to Balboa Park in SD, minus the row of museums, and add a few acres of grass.

Wear comfortable shoes. Ride a bike or rollerblade.

Excellent people watching.
People on their rollerblades dancing, a guy with furry ugg-like skates doing squats. 

I like the fact that the road was closed to vehicles and people could walk, skate, or bike on the street without getting run over.

Walk to the de Young museum and go to the observation tower. 
The museum was cool too but I'll save that for another review.
author: Melissa S.

description: I've been back here to visit the gardens and attempt to go to the Academy of Sciences.  I greatly enjoyed my visit to the De Young with my family here and we came back the next day to scope out the rest of the park.  Over winter break my boyfriend and I just did a photo day taking pictures of the place.  It's one of my favorite places in SF.
author: Anne N.

description:
This place is simply enthralling in so many ways. 

For my wife and I, we love just seeing and watching all the different kinds of people and the different things they do. From playing musical instruments, to roller-skating, to painting, to flying kites, to playing frisbee, to just lazing in the sun or reading a book - you name it, there are all kinds of folks at Golden Gate Park having a great time.  

There are bikers, joggers and strollers galore, and people walking dogs of every shape and size.  Its a great atmosphere that will leave a smile on your face.

For our kids there is plenty to do - explore the botanical gardens, visit the Academy of Sciences, hop on the Carousel or play on the awesome "Spider" play structure. 

This is a great day out for the family. I recommend you take a picnic hamper and drinks to keep you going, as eateries are pretty scarce and busy. 

Enjoy this great green slice of San Francisco.
author: Kevin C.

description: A super lush and green public space in the middle of an urban city.  There is plenty to do and see, including lakes, streams, picnic areas, and buffalo.  As other people have posted, not alot of trash cans, so please hold on to your litter and don't leave it on the ground.  We took a cab from the downtown area, given the fact we were in the city for the weekend.  About $25 each way.  A great place to take a walk, or run, or just hang out for the day.  IF you come to the park, you won't be disappointed.
author: Matt M.

description:
great park.  especially if you are frying on acid.  i love this park!

yes!!!
author: Cynthia B.

description:
This place smells good - there is a different but equally rich and good smell everywhere you go.  Probably especially rich near the bison, but we don't need to talk about that.

A nice place to run and think and pretend to be on vacation.
author: Catherine F.

description:
This park is extremely lovely, and a San Fransisco attraction you must NOT miss.  It is not a park-park in the most strictest of conventions because it does boast a multitude of activities to partake in--the variety of gardens, museums, etc.--so much so that it would take more than a day or two to truly enjoy everything.
 I went recently on a beautiful blue-sky spring day and let me tell you, the environment really is breathtaking.  The admission prices for some of the venues within the park can get a little pricey, but those are for more detailed reviews.  The park, as a whole, is fantastic.
author: Ivana Y.

description:
Who's idea was it to put such a great park  in the most overcast part of the city? Well at least they added one of the world's most stunning pieces of architecture in the middle of it.  

There is so much to do in this park, play soccer, ride horses, train for a marathon, look at buffalo, hold a yogathon, row a boat, get a blow job from a 60 year old man in the woods, really the list is endless.  

Get yourself here today.
author: Sean S.

description:
Perfect distance run if you run starting at the tip of the panhandle through the length to the water and back to start.  It is gorgeous, green, peaceful.  When its foggy it is eerily quiet and deliciously creepy, when its sunny it is crawling with people and buzzing with life. 
I love running this park!
author: Nilu r.

description:
I've lived  a block and a half from the Polo Fields entrance for almost 6 years now.  I have two or three different preffered jogging routes through the park, a bunch of different biking routes.

The western end of the park is quiet and forested.  The eastern end is bright, colorful and overflowing with statues, museums and playgrounds.  Sort of a microcosm of the city itself, you might say.

My favorite lake is the one by the 36th and Fulton entrance, where people sail their model yachts and oldsters practice tai chi.  

If you ride your bike down JFK drive starting at the Park Presidio overpass, you can get going really fast by the time you make it to the lake.  I'm talking hair flying, time warping, tearing a hole in the fabric of space-time fast.  Along the way you'll pass the big speedway meadow where there will probably be people picnicking, kickballing or just goofing around on the lawn.  

Try it sometime.  Just be careful not to get doored by the cars parked along the side of the road.  And watch out for potholes too.
author: Gopal R.

description:
There is so much the park offers that it should be a crime not to take advantage of it.

Enjoy it because it is special.
author: Patrick B.

description:
Our family with two elementary-school-aged kids had a great day at Golden Gate Park. We entered near the playground, which was the best playground we've ever visited. Our kids really liked the rope-pyramid climby thingy and the cement slide where you use a piece of cardboard to slide down.

Right next to it is an amazing carousel--$1 per ride. We skirted the edge of the Japanese Tea Garden and the Botanical garden and had lunch at the cafe at the de Young museum.

We spent most of the day in the park and only made our way to about the middle of it, walking around Stow Lake and then taking a paddle boat ride. It was a great way to spend a day.
author: M K.

description: Let me be up front about the fact that I haven't spent much time here. The most significat exposure I've had were the shows I've seen there at the Polo Fields, with the last being Dave Matthews.  It was a beautiful day and it was amzaing to be surrounded by thousands of other people enjoying a failry extensive setlist bolstered by the guest appearance of Santana.
author: Kim N.

description: Even though I've only lived in San Francisco for a year's time, some of my favorite memories have been spent on Golden Gates abounding grassy knolls. From volleyball to kickball, frolf to tennis, and even an epic outdoor concert or two, this park yields limitless opportunities for the kinds of experiences that turn a normal day into an incredible one.
author: William H.

description: I love this park, but most recently I noticed the new painted bike lanes.  How selfish is it to force cars to park 4 ft from the curb, so bikers could bike.  It's equally hazardous drivers to exit their cars, and oncoming hitting opened doors.   Frankly, it's an eyesore to have such a pristine landscape spoiled by all the road paint.  Thank your bicyclist for this act of selflessness.
author: David M.

description:
Until last weekend, I hadn't been here in years - not since an out-of-town relative popped into the fair city. It's always there, but it was always just a peripheral thing in my mind.

This time around, I really enjoyed it. Visiting Queen Wilhelmina Tulip Garden and watching the slow-moving bison in their grove. You completely forget you're in the middle of a big city - and not even the sexiest part of said city at that - an experience rivaled only by Central Park in NYC.

If animals and plantlife aren't your bag, there are plenty other activities, including fly-fishing, intramural sports, biking and good, old-fashioned walking around.
author: Tara R.

description:
Sometimes, I see turtles here and there. Other times, I see homeless people wrestling for whatevers left of a 40oz Mickeys. Golden Gate Park has a little bit of something for everyone.

What? You said you were into freaky shit? Why don't you check out Stow Lake around midnight, and walk around with a friend or 5. The light mist that floats on that lake looks quite eerie when present. 

If not, you can catch a few bands here and there on Sundays in the park. Or better yet, get there early on a sunny weekend, and start up a BBQ with some buddies, and be sure to refill that keg!

The best times I had in Golden Gate Park were when they had those free F8/Skills parties back then. Man, those were the good old days in Golden Gate Park...
author: Andrew W.

description:
I look forward to strolling through here whenever I visit SF.

I am particularly in love with their Japanese tea garden but there is so much more to the miles and miles of green spanning this park that make it so special - botanical gardens, paddleboating, scenic trails, the De Young museum...it is much more than a place you take your dog to pee or bring your picnic lunch. It's a destination. And yet another reason for making LA jealous.
author: Cat L.

description:
