The Park is by far the best thing about SF. It is absolutely beautiful and everywhere you look people are together either exercising, lounging, or planting flowers.  

Patrick is right on...the Park is special.
author: Meredith M.

description:
""Once I knew the City very well, spent my attic days there, while others were being a lost generation in Paris, I fledged in San Francisco, climbed its hills. slept in its parks, worked on its docks, marched and shouted in its revolts~ It had been to me in the days of my poverty and it did not resent my temporary solvency." --John Steinbeck

Like Steinbeck, I "fledged" in the Bay Area in many ways, and no place captures my love for the city quite like Golden Gate Park. I've come here as a little kid on vacation with my family, as a broke and unemployed "artsy" type hanging out in the nearby Haight, and as a rat-racing "young professional" attending a museum event, and every time I've fallen in love.

From Hippie Hill to the elegant Conservatory of Flowers, to the somber AIDS memorial grove, to the impressive DeYoung Museum and Academy of Sciences, this park has it all.  You can ride the carousel, play sports, watch the buffalo, rent a boat, and more...I've spent entire days just wandering around the park, discovering new things--what's great is that there could be a free concert going on in front of the museums, but there will be a wilderness area worthy of Thoreau not far away with nobody as far as the eye can see and nothing in earshot other than the birds.  I've visited other great urban park spaces in this country (Central Park, Lincoln Park, Griffith Park, the Boston Common, the National Mall), but, in my humble, tiny, little opinion, none is so all-encompassing and none embodies the spirit of its respective city quite like Golden Gate Park.

Tip: There are "free days" (such as free Friday nights at the DeYoung) for many of the attractions...check their website. 

This is the place to come--if you want to leave your heart in San Francisco.
author: Bear S.

description: Golden Gate Park is amazing. I don't think I will ever have enough time to explore all of it. Definitely a sweet place to go for a jog or to walk the dog.
author: Darius A.

description:
I LOVE golden gate park!  when i have time, i try to go to GGP to walk, hang out on hippie hill, or chill out with the rollerskaters and their rockin' music.

I saw somebody get punched in the face once on hippie hill. But otherwise else its superfun just hanging out, and people bring there instruments and so its cool to just sit, watch and listen.

Sundays the best time to go because they block off the parks streets so people could bike, skateboard, rollerskate, without worrying about getting ran over! FUN!
author: Jackie S.

description:
Love the De Young Museum, and the free observatory at the top with the view of the whole city. Plus, on Sundays, there's Lindy in the Park - lindy hop dancing right in front of the museum, for anyone to join in or just watch.

Also like the Japanese tea gardens very much, though they are a bit overpriced, IMHO.

It's a great place for a stroll, a bike ride, or a jog, especially on the weekend when the streets are closed off from traffic. Also great for frisbee and/or a picnic, and there are some great free open air concerts from time to time.
author: Jacqueline D.

description: This is a REAL park. Seriously, it's so huge and has so many things to do/see. Every time I come here, I always discover a new trail or attraction. Great place to enjoy a sunny day. And the fact that SF has this enormous nature place in the city is totally super sweet.
author: Patrick P.

description: I'm a fan, it can get boring if you expect the world or go too often but it's a lovely place with many things to do and see. Parking is really bad though, especially in the summer. It is bigger than you might think, so if you go, plan some time if you intend to see everything or go from one end to the other.
author: Jon P.

description: This is a large park full of nature and museums to explore.
author: Jen S.

description: This place is great! There is a ton of things to do here. We were here for 5 hours and didn't even really scratch the surface of the park. A cheap way to stay entertained for the whole day. Next time we're gonna bring lunch for a picnic. My wife says to wear your sneakers!
author: Mario C.

description:
So I've only strolled through here in the middle of the day, but i was impressed with how big it was. 
It had an awesome playground that made me feel jipped for never being there when i was i kid. 
It has more wilderness feeling parts with trails as well as HUGE open areas of healthy green grass. There were people playing in a drum circle too : ) They also have a recreational building and a flower conservatory (but it costs money).
All in all, i don't know what more one could ask for in a park.....
author: Kathryn G.

description: When my dad and I used to live by here, we spent many days on this park. Riding our bicycles up and down, all over San Francisco, using the Golden Gate Park as our beginning. The park has a lot to offer to users, more than I have seen any park in Florida have so I really appreciate it.
author: Carlos H.

description: My favorite park ever. It is SO HUGE. I've been toy sailboat racing in a lake, watched people sit in trees that were like clubhouses, I've played soccer, drank beer in a cluster of trees, gone crazy in the park on mushrooms, watched someone get stood up on a blind date, gone for sunday strolls. This place is amazing. It spans across half the city! I'm sure I could go there everyday and find a new exciting place, but I don't live here anymore :-(.
author: AL S.

description: It is so beautiful here!  On a sunny day in San Francisco who could ask for more?  Well that is if you don't get lost for an hour looking for your destination.  haha  I went here the other day to volunteer for a program and could not find the part of park I needed to go, since there are no street signs once in the park.  But its worth going.  Love it here.
author: Kimmy G.

description: This HUGE park is so expansive and offers so much for everyone that you can always find something to do here. Go to a live show, browse the botanical gardens, the Japanese Tea Gardens (pay admission), the museum, the rolling lawns for leisurely spending an afternoon or day. I just think it is a wonderful patch of green packed into an amazing city that should be a highlight on any visitors list. It is the Central Park of San Francisco.
author: Mandy L.

description: The park is very peaceful and beautiful. It's very big so be sure to wear comfy shoes and take a good camera. The best thing to do is see the Japanese Tea Garden, closing at 6pm,  Flower Conservatory, though it closes early at 4pm, and the benches and auditorium of the National Aids Memorial. It's a quiet and relaxing world inside of the big city. Well worth it.
author: Jason M.

description: Living right next to Golden Gate Park is awsome! Biking, Hiking, Frisbee Golf, Picnics and BBQ's doesnt get better than that! My favorite thing is the multiple outdoor concerts held in the park every year, and once you think youve seen everything in this park. you take a turn and end up seeing something new!
author: Sean C.

description: Golden Gate Park is huge. To truly get a feel of this place, you'll have plan an entire day there. There's so much to do! There's the California Academy of Science and the De Young Museum. Bot renovated and quite new. There's Stow Lake, where you can rent a paddle boat and ride along the water. It is expensive, though. There are plenty of gardens and even an arboretum. It's a fantastic place.
author: Holt D.

description:
Golden Gate Park is the ONLY place my rookie ass can take my road bike and not fear getting hit by a Taxi or clueless driver!!!

Talk about feeling safe and secure. I love it.
author: kate r.

description: I LOVE GGP but that wasn't always the story, I use to hate it when my mom would drive through it to get me to chinese school on saturdays, i didn't do well in chinese school =( Great for hiking, dates, picnics, bdays etc
author: Tiff W.

description: I want a national park in my city!!! Rent some bikes and explore this park!
author: Lindsey J.

description: Every time (except once) I have made the trip here, iv found my shrooms. Reliable, friendly people. Love it.
author: San F.

description:
GG, although I love your sister in the East, Central Park, you, darling, have a beach in your favor. And museums. The gardens, the gardens, the gardens. 

If we could only have the fine-ass cops like NYC, I'd live there.
author: Rene D.

description:
This is a great park...I have yet to find out and discover everything it is hiding. I am rather curious about all the ghost stories I hear but I'm scared. :) Otherwise it's a great place to just drive through and get lost. 
I like getting lost....it's an adventure that way.
author: John-Michael C.

description:
As a native how can you not love GGP. Then again even if you're not a native how can you not love it. There are lakes, bison, windmills, parks, trails...the list goes on....

It's a little piece of heaven in the middle of the city.
author: Maria M.

description: GG park is a well-maintained and lovely place filled with miles and miles of trails, museums, flower gardens and playgrounds. It's really large so if you're looking to get away and relax alone you will find the space here.
author: Mister Chub S.

description:
The excellentnessicity of this place is off the scale. 

So much to do here, and its so damn nice. Stowe Lake is great, I liked the waterfall area. Plus there's the Conservatory of Flower, the Botannical Gardens, the Japanese Tea Garden, etc etc etc. So much to do here; although I go to SF quite often, this was my first time hanging out here and I really relished the experience.
author: Kenny H.

description:
Try this walk for size on a Sunday. 

Start early, about 9 am at the edge of the park at Stanyan and just walk through the park all the way to the water's edge. The only requirement, you can take any trail, just do not walk around the park along the edge on Fulton or Lincoln. You'll see sights of local homeless beings to tai chi enthusiasts, families on bikes, tourists on their way to the de Young, soccer players, tango dancers, swing dancers, roller skaters (although this bit is temporarily closed), gardens, lakes, buffalo and many other wonderful things! Once you get to the water's edge, celebrate with a hot chocolate or beer at the Beach Chalet. 

Also check out some haunted stories about the park to spook you or catch up on the park's history.
author: Judy L.

description:
I adore GG Park. There is something wonderful about having such a huge stretch of green in the city. And there is so much here to explore! Every time I visit the park I seem to find something new. You can't really learn this park unless you walk/run/bike the paths off the main roads. A few favorites:

The lake with the miniature yacht club. Watching these guys on a Sunday is fun - I'm impressed with the level of detail on these boats!
The Botanical Gardens.
The Japanese Tea Garden is awesome - just try to go during the "off-peak" hours or it is a bit crazy with tourists.
De Young Museum.
Chain of Lakes.
The Windmills.
The Buffalo. 
The weird path I got lost on one day by the Fell Street entrance to the park. 

So - why only four stars? Because the horse stables are CLOSED and have been for years. There is suppose to be a plan to rebuild these and it has gone no where. BOO!! HISS!!
author: Sarcastic T.

description:
This is one of the best urban parks in the country!

Every time I find myself in San Francisco I make a point to visit this park. It's a Great way to spend the day or more, walking around looking at all the amazingly diversity of flora and taking in all the amazing scenery.
author: James F.

description:
Fun place to explore or just hang out with friends. One of the first times I visited my boyfriend and I got lost and wandered for hours around the park, which I found to be amazing since the park is in the middle of San Francisco. I haven't yet visited the museums in the park but I plan to someday, so I can spend all day in the park. There are so many possible things to do! 

The only negative aspect is the overly assertive homeless people or hippies (although that is to be expected in any park, and this park is huge). Just know not to go down the dark paths that lead into bushes or into less well-traveled areas, and the park is otherwise beautiful and quite safe.
author: Jamie M.

description:
Man I love parks. I went to San Francisco this weekend for my boyfriend's birthday and we actually spent more time in the park than anywhere else. It is just a great place to hang out and clear your head and there always seems to be something going on. We happened to be there during the Tour de Fat a bike festival which was fab-u-lous. Man you people love to dress up! 
I love parks more and more these days. Every city needs a great green space.
author: Sami S.

description:
Oh Golden Gate Park... How do I love thee...

On the rare occasions we have a sunny day, this is the first place I want to go. Lucky for me, I'm a short bike ride away from grabbing my usual slab of grass in front of the Conservatory.

I've tried everything from the deYoung, to the Bison, to Stow Lake, to the Tea Gardens. I even enjoy a random afternoon on Hippie Hill, dirty as it may be. We are so lucky to live in such a beautiful city, and even more lucky that beautiful city has this amazing park!

I can't WAIT to try out the CA Academy of Science!
author: Kate Y.

description:
Jocelyne V, somehow I remember those tour buses and the balmy 72 degree weather.  Wait a minute, I was invited to that wedding!  

Older sis is right about this place as one of the most gorgeous places in the city.  Whether it's walking around the Japanese Tea Garden, shooting the breeze near Queen Wilhemmina, or running along JFK you'll be astonished at the beauty that this area of the city possesses.  

I highly recommend checking out the De Young Museum if you haven't gone already.  The building returned after a couple of years of renovation.  In addition, I am awaiting the return of the Asian Art Museum and the California Academy of Sciences from their temporary homes downtown...
author: Joe V.

description:
I love Google maps and when I look at the hybrid view of San Francisco, it is nice to see such a large green space in such a dense city.  By the way, SF is the second densest US city (after NYC).

Being in the park is better than the beautiful view from above.  There is so much to see.  Like the drum circle, the conservatory, Stow Lake, the new de Young Museam, and all the different people.  Being in the place on a sunny weekend makes me glad to be living in SF.
author: Julie R.

description:
The epitomy of urban city parks!!!  I LOVE LOVE LOVE THIS PLACE!
Pick you activities and you will most likely be able to do it here.....
author: Mich Q.

description:
This is a huge park.  

I remembered when they closed off the park for people to Rollerblade or roller skate in here.  

For those that are much more skilled in their roller abilities: I remembered seeing a game of roller hockey.   The paths were hilly so it added  a bit of a an obstacle for a beginner rollerblader like myself.  And i was so glad i  was wearing my knee pads when i was rollerblading. 

I still had a lot of fun here.
author: Evelyn K.

description: Nice little meadows to have a picnic.  The best time to visit is on a Sunday, when the main road, JFK Drive, is closed to cars.  A great time to bring the family out to ride bikes or rollerblade.  Not many places to get a bite, best to buy something and bring it with you.  Parking is always a challenge, especially near the museums.  You can spend all day here exploring and just looking around.  Safe in the day time but I would not venture out towards dusk.
author: Larry G.

description:
There is so much to do in GG park. Whether you're a tourist walking through it for a day or a local looking for something to do, this park is worth the trip. Botanical gardens, De Young museum, CA Academy of Sciences (with numerous free days for locals, check their website), lawn bowling, archery ranges, bison ranch, tennis courts, waterfalls, gardens, a place to practice your casting skills (like fishing in really long pools without any fish), lakes (with paddle boats), tons of trails for running/biking/walking, baseball and soccer fields, places for picnics and barbeques, kids' playgrounds, and even lots of random lessons and classes if you're looking to start a new hobby. What else can you ask for?
The only bummer is that the far end of the park, by Ocean Beach, used to have a whole little theme park (very similar to the Boardwalk in Santa Cruz) way back in the day, it also had an ice skating rink years back, and now it has a giant soccer field (it is actually several soccer fields, I think)-- which is basically the same as saying that it just has a giant patch of empty lawn. Don't get me wrong, I like to go there and read a book once in awhile or let my dog run around or play catch with a friend.... but I still think that space could be put to way better use. As someone who lives in the Outer Sunset, I can attest that there are people out here and even plenty of tourists going to the beach, the Cliffhouse, and Beach/Park Chalet, that I'm sure would all love to have some neat little attraction/something to do. However, those soccer fields... well, they're virtually deserted almost all the time.
author: Christina M.

description:
When I'm feeling blue, all I have to do, is take a look at you, then I'm not so blue!

... we got a groovy kind of love!

Groovy kind of love because the Park has something for everybody:
1. For those inclined towards museums, science projects in faboo buildings and cool architecture:
a. Academy of Sciences 
- recently opened and packed on weekends but worth the lines for the awesome exhibits and cafe
b. De Young Museum 
- OK art in great building and check out their cafe
c. Legion of Honor 
- great art in OK building and check out their cafe
d. Japanese Tea Garden 
- great everything and free after 5PM
e. Carousel 
- if its running, go let your inner child out for he/she will thank you for that
f. The Musical Concourse 
- perfect for lounging with a book and listening to an outdoor concert along with art shows on weekends
g. The Windmills 
- nice to see and get a taste of Netherlands
h. AIDS Memorial Grove 
- great place to get some peace and quiet, center yourself and pay homage to those no longer with us

2. For those inclined towards flora and fauna and water bodies:
a. Conservatory of Flowers 
- no better place to take a mat, the newspaper, a picnic and enjoy the greenery
b. Arboretum 
- great place to find out about plants from all over the world especially the stinker carnivorous ones... hold yer noses!
c. Sharon Meadows 
- perfect for concerts and big picnics (if your picnic is more than 25, you need a permit from McLaren Lodge by Stow Lake) otherwise its first come-first serve
d. Stow Lake 
- nice for walks and boating
e. Strawberry Hill 
- nice for uphill walks and watching people who do not know how to boat
f. Bison Paddock 
- nice to see bisons graze... please don't honk or yell to get them to move... want me to do that when you're snoozing or eating?!
g. Shakespeare Garden 
- nice to take a snooze in
h. Chain of Lakes 
- if you like calm lakes, head here
i. Spreckles Lake 
- see (h) above
j. Ocean Beach 
- good for everything and bon fires are first come-first serve and a permit is needed for 25 attendees and above
k. 3 other lakes / ponds (what's the difference?!) 
- see (h) above

3. For those inclined towards being health nuts:
a. KOI Fitness (shameless marketing, I know!) 
- Session 5 begins shortly!
b. Lawn Bowling
- Lazy form of exercise but great fun to watch
c. Tennis courts
- its tennis! no explanation needed here
d. Innumerable paths and trails for running
- Panhandle to Ocean Beach and back is 9 miles
e. Innumerable paths and trails for biking
- See (d) above and check out the trails for your mountain bike... road bikes, stick to the road
f. Innumerable paths and trails for walking
- Grab a map at McLaren Lodge or buy one
g. Every possible marathon going on all year around

4. For those inclined towards eating:
a. Beach Chalet and Park Chalet
- Great brunch and dinner and on many weekdays, Park Chalet has BBQ and beer out back... awesome!
b. Japanese Tea Garden
- See 1(d) above

5. For those inclined towards things I don't know how to categorize:
a. San Francisco County Fair Building
- Hosts many fairs including cacti fair, psychic fair, flower fair, paper fair, etc.
b. Hippie Hill 
- Nuff said

... and the Park's my front porch so lucky me! :)

And if you're going "how the F@#K do I find all these place?". Say no more:
http://www.sfgov.org/site/recpark_page.asp?id=17796

Love, Peace, Amit!
author: Amit S.

description: The park is beautiful & there were a lot of jogger & runner on Sunday.  Need $7 per person for Botanical Garden entry & $3 for Japanese Garden (free for SF resident).  Not so great when San Diego Botanical Garden is free for everyone.
author: Vincent C.

description:
"The place has buffalo, for Christ's sake!!!

You can spend a ton of time wandering this place.  On mountain bike you can really rip around the area, it kindof reminded me of being a kid in the woods.

One down side would be the obnoxious ammount of people trying to sell you weed.  That's not really a complaint, but it does get old real fast.

"If I wanted a bag I would have bought that shit five blocks back, sucka!"

If you're not scared of perma-trip homeless people, walk in from Haight and head West...  It gets more and more amazing as you travel.

But yeah, also check out the Academy of Sciences-- I hear its free admission once and a while.  Otherwise you gotta throw down to get your mind blown."
author: L J.

description:
All that and more! Golden Gate park is a classic hangout place. With more nooks and crannies than the skeleton closets of Saddam Hussein, you could play a giant game of paintball in a place this huge. (But you can't for obvious reasons). Parking spaces, lakes and watercraft, your occasional bison, animals, Plant Conservatory, the new Museum that's huge, and just general fun. 

What else can you expect from a bushy forest oasis in what is naturally a desert environment?
author: Michael C.

description:
It is to Golden Gate Park's interminable trails that I owe my current state of superb cardiovascular fitness.  Before moving to S.F., I had never run more than six miles consecutively (Hey, I only ran the half mile race during track in those days; give me a break!).  One day, however, while on what was supposed to be an easy recovery run, I became hopelessly lost on one of Golden Gate Park's many dirt paths.  I backtracked, chased down runners who looked like they might be familiar with the park's shortcuts, and, by the time I had finally located my car, I had run an unprecedented ten miles.

I still return here as often as possible and have found that the park accomodates any type of workout I might have planned for myself.  Long runs are easy; GGP's trails are so numerous that you can explore a new one upon each visit.  If you're looking for a hill workout, jog over to Strawberry Hill in the middle of Stow Lake and put those quads to use.  The park also hosts a panoply of cross country races, most of which occur between August and December; to find out about upcoming race opportunities, visit active.com.

Mornings are usually quite chilly in the park, but regardless of what time you visit, come prepared for any type of weather.  This area is given to frequent unpredictable climate changes.
author: Karin H.

description:
Love love it here. Not only is it a great place to throw around a frisbee on a warm day but its awesome to go see a concert or even just drive through. I drive through it quite often on 19th/Highway 1 and you forget that you are in a busy city and feel like youre in the Northwest for a brief minute. The museums, tea gardens, everything...5 big stars.

Also, they have free dance lessons sometimes, or, if the mood should strike, interpretive roller blading...even just watching these people are worth it.
author: Erin F.

description:
Quite possibly one of the best things about this city!  And free!  And beeeeautiful!

Whether it's summer in the rose garden, spring with tulips and windmills, a sunny winter afternoon people watching in the arboretum, or a long walk straight through, man-o-man is it a sight to see.  

You'll always discover something new and usually will manage to get lost finding the buffalo (or is it bison... or are they the same thing?).  GGP reminds me that there is life and green stuff outside -and inside- this concrete (lovely as it may be) metropolis.  
Mmmm... breathe in that fresh air!
author: Rashmi N.

description:
This place is sooo beautiful and HUGE! You probably couldn't get through all parts of it within a day.

I was only here for a couple of hours, due to my long list of places to go in SF. It was a fun, but very short trip, and I HAD to squeeze in a visit at the park.

Or did I...

While quickly deciding to stop by at the Conservatory of Flowers, because it seemed like a great place for taking pictures, my cousin's car, which we had left a couple of purses in, got broken into.  And by the time we got to it, our purses were long gone. We were literally gone only for about 4 minutes, so it must've been done by some pro's.

After reporting to the police on site, we learned that this happens very frequently here since lots of people know that this is one of the most popular places for visitors from all over the world. Visitors = lots of cash, generally. We were devastated, because we had lots of valuable things in there like cash, credit cards, iPods, etc.

Despite the horrible incident, I still remember the park as one of the most beautiful places I've ever been to. And I'd like to visit again soon. I just have to make sure to never leave anything behind, or carry valuable things with me!
author: Rina K.

description:
As far as city planning goes, William Hammond Hall and his carriage of merry gardeners, knew what they were doing.  The built in the last 25 years of the 1900's a park in what was then "The Outside Lands" of Gold Rush SF.  Made up then of barren sand dunes and wind swept nothingness, they used two large windmills that powered pumps to irrigate a park 20% larger than Central Park in NYC.  Once the Western Portal was opened so was an entire new side of the City By The Bay, and preserved for those then and us now, splitting the Sunset and Richmond Districts like a rectangular knife, is one of the most famous parks in the work.  With sports, museums, science academies, ponds, gazebos, rows and rows upon rows of eucalyptus trees...Tight grass carpeted meadows, a stadium (Kezar), a Polo Field, hiking and biking trails....There are Buffalo, offspring of those gifted  from William Randolph Hearst...yes there is a paddock for them.  It is the nicest sanctuary one can find just minutes from the metropolis, our cultural epicenter, San Francisco.
With at least 5 large concerts each year, The Outside Lands Festival at the end of August bringing over 150,000 fans to it's meadows, The Free Politically Charged "Power to the Peaceful Festival", put on with friends of and by Michael Franti for 50,000 or more fans and yogis each year in September and the largest non-bluegrass, bluegrass festival in the USA, October's Free Hardly Strictly Bluegrass Festival, where you might find, comedian Steve Martin playing banjo on stage after M.C. Hammer raps in his parachute pants.  Yes it is an icon.  On weekends the roads close to traffic except for the main route through the park, 19th Ave - or Park Presidio as it winds it's way to the Golden Gate Bridge.  With multiple lakes, a Japanese Tea Garden and Windmills it is a sight to see.  As you walk amongst the overgrown bushes and trees and breathtaking  Botanical Garden at Strybing Arboretum.  It has a little for everyone.  Frisbee.  Soccer.  Football.  BBQ's.  Peaceful Morning Tai-Chi.  Peaceful Sunset Yoga.  The Park is favorite place of many who live here...and with so much history and almost too much to see and do, it can be visited for free every month of the year in San Francisco's moderate climate.
author: Samuel M.

description: I love running in here.  Makes me feel really lucky to live in a beautiful city and have legs that can run.
author: Wakako U.

description: As a whole it's nice but not all of it is. Some of the lawns and areas are dated and need attention. Also, there are cops on horses that give people tickets without putting the tickets on the car, you just get a notice in the mail a couple months later. Beware of the parking rules in Golden gate park and also that these cops are strict on the "no front license plate" rule.
author: Eva B.

description: I should write this park a thank you letter for all the memories it's given me!  I have been here so many times through my life - for concerts, school field trips, walks with friends, meeting interesting people...There always seems to be something to do in the park...Not to mention the amazing festivals that are put on in the park! Certainly worth seeing! Parking for this place can be a little frustrating...otherwise this park is just perfect!
author: Ryan L.

description: Golden Gate Park is one of those massive great American city parks. It contains a bison preserve, a lake, running trails, the old Keisar Stadium, and museums. There are tons of separated nooks and crannies that one can relax in and just picnic. It does get crowded, but there are places where you can really feel like you are getting away from the compact nature of The City. Did I mention that it is HUGE! The city keeps this park in great condition seeing as how difficult it would be to up-keep a park this large. If you are looking for a break, I suggest you pack a lunch and hike it to Golden Gate Park. You won't be disappointed.
author: Brian A.

description: How lucky are we to live here and have access to this?  what I think is the greatest aspect of the park, is that it has so many things  to do incluiding museums, parks, horses, gardens, children's areas, etc.  In short, it's not just a park.
author: june b.

description:
Our friend took us here on our first trip to San Francisco to see the roller skaters on Sunday. It was totally awesome - it is so wonderful to see people in a big city getting together to share an experience or passion. I could people watch all day. 

We also walked by the Flower Conservatory, but it was closed. I will have to go next time because I have heard it is great.
author: Brandy S.

description:
I love this park.  It's great to just spend an entire Saturday or Sunday walking around and checking out all the sights.

I spent a few hours there today.  Where else will a random stranger ask for a few photos to take of you, a homeless person will be nice & say hello & not ask for $$, you will be offered free pot in the park in exchange for a cigarette (note, I did not take up the offer, and I didn't have any cigs since I don't smoke), and a huge woman & her thin boyfriend will offer you a ham sandwich out of the blue & strike up a conversation about random things while there are drums playing in the background, all in one afternoon....right there in Golden Gate Park, that is where!!  ;-)

I like the Botanical Garden.  I recommend taking the free shuttle around the park & down across from Ocean Beach when it is in season.
author: Rox M.

description:
Yeah! Go Golden Gate Park! Go Sundays when the road is closed and I can rollerblade up and down the street without being hit by a car! YAYAAYAYAYAYAYAYAYAYAY!!!!!

I like to go in the mornings. That's when the families and dogs are out with their kids, running, biking, and spending quality, ABC-family approved time together. You can tell that all the non-family people (twentysomethings, urbanite thirtysomethings) spent Saturday night going out, because none of them are there at 9 in the morning (except for me, but deep down inside, I'm really just an old, cantankerous lady at heart). 

And then noontime strikes, people have recovered from their temporary hangovers, and the non-family people come out to the road; and then I get hit on. Which isn't very smart. Seriously, if someone is rollerblading *away* from you, do you really think yelling at that person, no matter what you're saying is going to work? 

Seriously, just stick with the mornings.
author: Patty W.

description:
The GG P is going down hill, little by little.  It's past its prime and at this point, I'd rather see it made into Condo's, with little parks here and there.
Play grounds and tennis courts and maybe some public fountains.  That would keep the homeless out anyway.
author: Sarah H.

description:
We live so close to Golden Gate Park yet we don't visit  here enough. Our dog loves GGPark.... every time we go on a walk he will almost always pull his leash in the direction of the park - and if we follow him he WILL take us inside :-) 

So far we have really enjoyed: De Young Museum of Art, California Academy of Science, Stow Lake, Rose Garden, Arboretum, Japanese Tea Garden & the Conservatory of Flowers.... but there is SO much more to explore in there! 

Also, vehicles are prohibited from the park on Sundays from 5am - 5pm.. allowing you to ride your bike without worry :-) 

My husband and I look forward to our walks with our dog through the park and picnics near the Conservatory of Flowers. We consider ourselves lucky to live so close to this little piece of heaven :-)

Just remember to never leave your car inside the park over night.
author: gibronandsahar K.

description:
I'm so glad I live near Golden Gate Park. I love walking around the DeYoung and Academy of Sciences, saying hello to the buffalo, and running around the great expanse of the park. In fact, when I was training for my marathon, I did almost all of my training runs in the park because of the inclines and the beautiful scenery. 

The best part about GG Park is that they close off a section of JFK Dr. to vehicular traffic on Sundays (and sometimes Saturdays). Here, you'll not only find runners, but also cyclists (and little kids who are learning how to ride their bikes...cute), walkers, skateboarders, and lindy hoppers (there's free swing dancing lessons every Sunday in the park). It's a great way to get people outdoors.

Golden Gate Park is definitely one of my favorite things about San Francisco!
author: Christine T.

description:
So many great memories here. And so many more accumulating.
Who would've thought there'd be Buffalo?

Go have some fun in the sun, yall.
author: E.Mo. ..

description:
I used to come here several times a week to chill out & get lost  trying to hike the whole thing. I always ended up not covering much ground though. There are many reasons why people come here, =B
of them being.... horseshoestennishikingflowersplantssleepbbq(youreno longersupposedtousethepits)musiccardboardslideplacetosmoketreesgrassflowerslakescrittershippiehillmushroomsbaseandsoftballpassinthe pigskingettinglostinthe japaneseteagardenthingiewhilepeakingandrunningacrossopenlanesoftrafficwhilesfpdhightailsitafteryourbuttagainsttrafficoverpricedfoodcarousel....

and a lot more..
author: Eugene G.

description:
Golden Gate Park is one of those places that make me happy to live in San Francisco. Which I say each and every time I'm there, regardless of whether or not anyone's with me. 

Minus one star for the dog run on Fulton and 36th. I so wanted this to be the place I could bring Maggie when I was feeling especially lazy or had a cold, and she could still enjoy cavorting around with any number of canine friends. But finally I realized that...Maggie hates this place. Once we're inside the gate, she looks around, then sits right by the very same gate, and proceeds to stare out into the parking lot longingly, occasionally glancing at me with that imploring "Can we go now?" look. If she does manage to trot around a bit, it's always right back to the gate after a few minute, where the whole routine starts again. I don't get it - the dog owners/walkers are all friendly, and there's every kind of dog there. I've got no beef with it, but Maggie insists that it's just not her kind of place.
author: Michelle C.

description:
What's not to love about this park? Soooooooo many fields for you and your friends to hang out, bbq, throw the bee around....a little disc golf, if that's your thing....plus all sorts of other things I never go to, but I should someday soon, like the DeYoung, or those Tea Garden thingys....

Fun Fact: Those smelly hippies in the 60's planted so many psychedelic mushrooms that they now grow wild in parts of the park....but make you sure you pick the right ones!
author: Matthew S.

description:
Ahhhhh!  Golden Gate Park!  What a jewel!

I have been an avocational runner for years and, over those years, have been in every nook and cranny of this marvelous urban park.  I have seen red tailed hawks, meadowlarks and other avian friends too numerous to mention.  Running there in the cool of the morning is the best thing about San Francisco.

I grew up in NYC and, by comparison, Central Park is inferior.  In NYC, any installation that is not under constant supervision is vadalized or stolen.  Central Park is largely unusable because of the constant danger of  criminal assault.  Not so GGP.  When I returned to SF after a long sojourn in NYC and began running in GGP, the only graffito that I saw was, "Die, Yuppie Scum!", spray painted on the outside of a disused restroom.  It gave me a laugh, and was quickly obliterated by the Park maintenance crew.

There are lots of things to complain about in San Francisco, (e.g. the MUNI, the DPT,), and there are things about GGP that one could do without, (e.g. the homeless), but, considering how intensely this park it used,  it is remarkably well maintained.

It is truly a refuge for the anxious.
author: Paul Q.

description:
Fabulous park.  Provides the haven that I seek.  Has enough room on the side, to run on the grass and salvage my damaged knees and ankles.

I run here three times a week and GGP always welcomes my out-of-breath, red-in-the-face, sorry excuse for an athlete shell of a body.
author: E L.

description:
Golden Gate Park of San Francisco is a treasure for sure. Yet, for all the reviews on Yelp I have read so far, no one seems to notice how much the park needs proper care. 

There is so much of the park that has been neglected. People see the park as the wonderful green space but they need to look a little closer to realize the park is old it needs maintaining and some serious upkeep in certain parts. 

For example, the byway or crossover from 19th Avenue to Park Presidio Blvd. Yes, there is constant traffic, but that area needs tending to. Brush and foliage that needs to be pruned and swept away. So many trees need trimming. And in some cases, need to be taken down and replanted. 

See the article that was published in the Sunset Beacon Newspaper a few years ago about the park and its needs. See web link:

http://www.sfrichmondreview.com/archives/SunsetBeacon/2004editions/Jun04/ggparkhelp.html
author: Jonathan F.

description: So lucky I get to bike through this place on my daily commutes. It's a treat. Central Park is nothing compared to Golden Gate!
author: Bootylicious J.

description: A must see! I love coming here but make sure to check the website for hours as the attractions here all have different hours of operation. If you're on a budget you can still stop by the Botanical Gardens, they're free and there's so much to see! If you have a few dollars to spend you can go to the Japanese Gardens or the Conservatory of flowers, both beautiful! For $25 you can get in to the Academy of Sciences--expensive but worth it!!
author: Mrs. B.

description:
Beautiful and expansive.
Don't forget to check out the museum and art gallery located inside!
author: Metallic O.

description: 1000 acres in the heart of the city.  where else, but in san francisco? I could spend months here and constantly discover new things.
author: Sasha R.

description: If not for the freezing weather in this park, they'd get my full approval! This place is almost pristine, and is filled with events year round in SF. Sometimes you'll see packs of friends bbqing in this area. Overall a radically cool place to hang around or go for a stroll to clear your mind and heart.
author: Carl Z.

description:
Avoid the east entrance at all costs.  It's not safe, and it's full of bums.

The rest of the park is a delight!

Shakespeare's Garden is tiny, peaceful, and beautiful.  Probably one of my favorite locations in the park.  The playground is great for children.  We spent two days in the park and still didn't see everything.

The Academy of Science is great for children - with caveats (see my review), the museum is wonderful, the Japanese Tea Garden is expensive and over rated, but there are plenty of free places to go and visit.
author: Noah B.

description: I love Golden Gate Park. A lot of tourist touring the place around. I even seen joggers jog as early before the sun rises. It doesn't get any better with De Young Museum and California Academy of Science. People are flocking there everyday. Heck i even seen nude modeling and wedding photos taken at the park.
author: Ronald N.

description: Very relaxing. Extra points for having a place to lawn bowl. More extra points for having the botanical gardens and ponds with cute ducks and geese. I'm smitten.
author: Ramon E.

description:
I spent all the Saturday afternoons in my first year of US experience in the Gloden Gate Park! Nothing is better than playing a little of volleyball with your net set up on the huge Lindley Meadow while girlfriends of your buddies BBQing juicy chicken wings on the side. While beer and snacks are always within reach, sometimes you just want to lay back and watch the clouds and occasionally the Blue Angels fly by.
I am giving a 4-star because the Soccer Fields in the Park never seem to be ever maintained. There are pits in the fields and sometimes it's slushy.
author: Jin H.

description:
Iconic San Francisco landmark. Kids, dogs, stoners, musicians, MILFS, joggers, tourists, athletes are all welcomed with open arms. This review can can either be a painful combination of 15 reviews or  1 concise overview of my favorite places here, and since I'm like the 500th person to review this gem, no one except my fans and friends will actually read this. On to the review.....
Tennis courts-check
Frisbee Golf-check
Hippie Hill for 4:20 observance-check
Bison paddock-check
Best SF view from DeYoung observation deck-check
9 holes-check
Leaving your car unattended for 9 holes and getting you stereo stolen-check
Flat-ish running-check
Polo Fields-check
I could go on and on, but I'll finish with this: If you live here, do not go more than a month without a trip there. You will always discover something new or rediscover something old. For the people who are visitors to SF, this place is right up there with the Golden Gate Bridge as a must see. I love this place.
author: Matt H.

description: Awesome place to visit. I always watched all these movies seeing them through a screen. When I saw it up close it was an awesome experience. I'll go back someday.
author: Diego O.

description:
I love this huge park.  I know it is not your "Central Park in New York City", but it is the city of San Francisco's park and I like it.

It has a lot to offer just check out the website:

http://www.nps.gov/goga/

Thanks for reading this.
author: Michael L.

description:
I went to the AIDS Memorial Grove on my dead friend's birthday to reflect on our time together and on the fun we had together before AIDS took him away from me... Super sad to see how dilapidated the grounds seemed. The meadow was more weed than grass. I did see a gardener's cart and they had some sprinklers going so maybe they're working on it...

The grounds in front of the Conservatory seem better maintained but they are so over run with unleashed dogs of all shapes and sizes that I've never been able to sit there for more than a minute before finding a cold, wet nose pressed into me... (That is if I can actually find a spot that's big enough to sit on that is free from dog doo)

I'm also not very impressed with the new DeYoung - sure it's improved compared to its previous incarnation but still not good enough to justify the hassle of trekking all the way out there - MUNI still sucks and driving/parking is still an expensive proposition that makes an already expensive trip to the museum a very costly outing.

Maybe the new Academy of Sciences and the renovated band shell area can turn that section of the park around...
author: Quartknee K.

description: By far the best park I have ever seen. the unique thing about this park is that it offers substantual recreational facilities as well as many wooded nature trails. Great place!
author: Joshua L.

description:
One of the greatest urban parks anywhere in the US, maybe even the world.  

When I was training for a marathon I worked out routes of varying lengths from around 3 miles to just over 7 miles for a complete loop.  That way I was able to get all my marathon training done in the park and the great highway.  Amazing!
author: Fs A.

description:
I love golden gate park!!!!! 
It's huge and most places is FREE! I love the botanical garden... the squires there is evil!! They are not afraid of people, maybe because people are always feeding them, so they literally follow you thinking you will give them food. 
I also love the Japanese tea garden... such a small place, but every corner is breathtaking... perfect perfect place to take pictures!!! it's not free most of time... couple dollars to get in.. cheap enough. Go look into it online, I think it's free in the early morning on tue or something. I forgot! 
One time on nov I went to windmills because I saw this picture with ton of tulips surrounding the windmill and it was sooooo pretty. Gosh~ i went there in the wrong season. I was told that tulip was seasonal... ahh.. stupid me~ so apparently, its only during spring time like march, that is when they plant tulips around the windmills. 
If you continued driving past the windmills, you will arrive to the beach... so it's good to get down and take a walk on the beach. 
Golden gate park to me is somewhere every romantic... perfect for dates and stuff. It's one of highlight in SF in my opionion.....!!!!
btw... did I mention De Young Museum and Academy of Sciences is free first weekend of the everyone month for boa customer!!!??? yep! check this out...
http://museums.bankofamerica.com/
author: Stephanie J.

description: Great things happen here. I could right a book of all the cool concerts, smoke sessions, walks, and barbecues I've had here. Not to mention 4:20. Check this place out.You'd have to be a fool not to love it.
author: Alexander W.

description: I love all that this park offers!  Great park, people watching, and an array of activities to please all,  It was a beautiful day and a great way to enjoy the weekend with friends and family!
author: Grace C.

description:
Huge Lawns
Conservatory of Flowers
Botanical Gardens
Japanese Tea House
De Young
California Academy of Sciences
Buffalo
Carousel
Playground
Tree Ferns
Closed to Cars Sundays
Fastest Routes
Ocean
Windmill
Slides
Paddle Boats
Bowling Green
Casting Pond
Cypress
Statues
Places to Kiss
Places to Picnic
Places to hear music
Places to Bicycle
Places to Skateboard
Places to throw a Frisbee
Places to play baseball
Places to lie down and sunbathe
Places to Explore
and so much more..
When my father was a little boy and it was all sand dunes, he and his family would walk to the beach after church on Sundays and pick the wild watercress and mushrooms along the creeks.
When I was a little girl I would ride the carousel, go to the museum, play on the playground, watched the big pendulum knock over the pegs, and could almost hear the lions roar in the African exhibit...
When I got older, I kissed my first beau in the darkness of the aquarium, tripped in nooks and crannies, and fell in a lake.
When my son was little, he played on the Bufano statues, rode the carousel, played in the playground, watched the big pendulum knock over the pegs, and cowered at the lifelike dinosaur dioramas...
God I love this place
author: Kimberly V.

description:
I left my heart in San Francisco

I grew up near Golden Gate Park - it is one of my favorite places on earth.
Make sure to get a Coke from one of the park stands - it has a very specific taste...not too sweet, a bit more fizz than you're used to - it's the ancient water pipes I suppose, or the well water or... who cares, it is just about the only thing about SF that has never changed, so I don't care if it's asbestos. (Central Park-schmark. You do not have the awesome Pacific Ocean, so shut up).
Right before I moved, I took my beautiful collie dog for a farewell walk. After our ocean beach run, we wandered up to the conservatory of flowers. It was a beautiful sunny day with a breeze. Just perfect for park sitting.
There was a jazz dude wailin' on the sax in front of the tunnel that goes to the other side, and I just sat on the grass and watched the lovers cooing at each other, and the babies playing and listened to the great music in the place my dad had taken me on picnics from the time I can remember. A wee tear escaped down my cheek, and dude started playing "I left my heart in San Francisco".
That was it - I was toast - soggy toast.
boo hoo.
One of my most cherished memories
author: MissMaryAnn D.

description: I try to stop in here whenever I'm in town, or at least drive thru it.  The museums are for sure worth a visit, esp the science one.  Lots of nature to enjoy.  Last time I was there, I got to see free opera.  There were some drunk homeless guys next to me who all the while were giving their reviews of the performances, which of course meant they knew a lot more about opera than me.  Only in SF.
author: W K.

description:
I'm a Golden Gate Park Hater.  I mean, it's like totally artificial, 100% non-native irrigated greenspace.  Like, what the hell?  In it's natural state, a little over 100 years ago, the area that is Golden Gate Park was all sand dunes, all the way from the beach to like freaking Stanyan.  Man, could you imagine if they would have just left it that way?  San Francisco would have this like huge swath of sand dunes going through the city for like 50 blocks.  I mean, I know it's kind of pomo, but like for real, that would just be so epic; every weekend, I'd have this awesome Paul Bowles/Arabian Nights/Taliban Hunting fantasy jam with me and all my friends.  Hell, maybe I'd even buy some kind of yurt and invite leaders from Middle Eastern states over for tea, and hang out hard like they do from Khartoum to Casablanca.  But instead, we've got a run of the mill Frederick Law Olmstead sculptured greenspace just like every other Gilded Age American city.  And the last time I checked, you certianly can't have no Paul Bowles/Arabian nights/Taliban Hunting fantasy in one of those.  But sand dunes!?!  IF ONLY!!!
Oh, and the buffalo should totally be freed to roam the city as they please.  I bet they'd prefer sunny Bernal Heights and Mclaren Park, anyway.
author: Ben V.

description: this is the real deal urban park.  their japanese house gave birth to the philadelphia japanese house.  their horticulture center can kick my city's horticulture center's johnny appleseeds.  I got lost in this park.  twice.  on the same day.  jogging, hiking, biking, paddling, walking, fishing, you name it, this place has got it.
author: Jen H.

description:
Thanks for hosting an absolutely amazingly gorgeous Saturday, Golden Gate Park.  It was really nice of you.  Thanks too for the very touching tribute to the late James Kim.
And thank you thank you thank you for the new parking structure where the old De Young used to be so we don't have to drive around for hours looking for a spot to leave the car.
I also really like your windmills and tulips, and secret little areas.  Oh, and your wide open spaces.  You're pretty amazing really.  Thank you for never giving me poison oak when I've cut through your leafy green-ness on a path that is of my own making because I'm too lazy to go and find an actual trail.  I'm still only marginally upset about the blackberry thorn scratches, but as I was looking for a spot to pee during a drunken Bay to Breakers stumble, I figure it's only fair.  
I'm coming to find the swing dancers sometime soon.
I'm only taking off one star because your weather sucks more often than not, preventing me from wanting to take advantage of you as much as I may otherwise.  But even in the fog you're gorgeous, just not so good for lounging.
author: Jennifer D.

description: Incredible...a BIG patch of paradise in the city! Like Central Park, you could spend a lot of time here and see only a fraction of it. Explore Stow Lake in a row boat, rent a surrey/trike/quad/bike and cover some ground, or relax and sip tea in the Japanese Garden. We have literally only seen a fraction and can't wait to go back and explore some more...
author: Janet D.

description: There is an endless list of things to do at this park! You'll love it whether you are a tourist or a local. The first time I came for Alice's Summer Concert in the Park, it was a blast. The second time I came to have a picnic, there are so many places to choose to lay your mat down and just chill/enjoy the nice scenery. De Young, Academy of Science, Japanese Tea Garden, Botanical Gardens, Rose Garden, Bikers, paddle boating, hiking up strawberry fields (No strawberries btw, I know, I hiked all the way up and searched! Sad to say, but the name IS deceiving.) just to name a few things to do here and the list goes on. This is truly a great place for a workout even if you did not intend to due to this park's enormous size and things to explore!
author: Tracy T.

description: LOVES IT!  This is one of the things that separates SF from so many other cities.  When you're walking or jogging in the park it's really easy to forget the hustle bustle of the surrounding city.  Every now and then you need to dodge someone who's blazing up a doobie [or worse], but hey, you're not in Kansas anymore.
author: Nikki c.

description: Central Park holds too many embarassing teenage memories (or maybe, just one in particular) & Hyde Park in London was better (becaause of the abundance of beautiful birds & very beautiful pagodas) but I have to admit that  one of the best perks about living at the Gateway to Street Punk Hell is close proximity to Golden Gate Park. It makes getting to the Inner Richmond that much easier (and you avoid that nasty hill by St Mary's and that ugly stretch of Fulton before you hit Arguello) and for those days when the ridiculousness of Haight St bullshit just gets to be too much, it's excellent for a stroll with some coffee.  Avoid hippie hill at all costs and walk by the conservatory of flowers, unless you require green buds or shrooms. Or unless you're the kind of person who enjoys drum circles. In which case, please de-friend me immediately.
author: Maria D.

description:
It's the best park ever. It's just fabulous. Once you think you've seen everything in it, you'll realize that you've seen less than half. I also consider Ocean Beach to be an extension of the park since they're adjacent.
The one exception actually is the mass of indigents, some homeless and dirty by choice and some not by choice, who inhabit the main entrance by Haight Street. On the other hand, if you want to buy drugs, then head over to Haight at Stanyan.
author: Ted H.

description: The bf and I brought Mila (our dog) here after her being upset at us for weeks after we shaved her beautiful hair. We walked around everywhere, and I haven't seen her this happy in such a long time. She and we just loved the park, hopping on the grass,around the plants and flowers. It would have been so nice to have a picnic there if we planned it out. The butterfly exhibit at the Conservatory of Flowers was amazing as well...some places there were signs that said 'No Dogs Allowed" but then again, there were people that were smoking when theres clearly a 'No Smoking' sign in front of them. Hmm...so in some places in the park, there are no dogs allowed, but crack addicts and homeless people are??
author: Valerie P.

description: Definitely, a place you have to visit when you stay in San Francisco
author: David C.

description:
If an artist wanted to find inspiration for his/her art- I AM SURE that they will find it here.

I could just imagine Seurat's "La Grande Jatte" being painted on one fine afternoon by Stow Lake or find Rainer Maria Rilke contemplating the roses' contradictions in his poems as he walked through the Rose Promenade or inspire Jacques Herzog whose pictures of Golden Gate park gave him the idea of the copper textured skin for the new De Young museum-  mimicking the light filtering through the leaves of the trees.  And if one could spend the afternoon here- meandering through the paths and discovering each flower after flower and plant after plant- its a journey that will enrich your life forever.  
There were many times I came here- and shed a few tears  to find hope coupled with calmness.  And then there were times I entered the gates trying to find answers to my dilemmas-- and found solemn peace with my decisions. This is a place where I have been comforted as well as comforted a  friend in need.  
I wouldn't be surprised if people get married or engaged here, find their loved one here and well even find themselves here- its truly a place rooted  deeply in unifying, and if you listen carefully,  the very breeze that echos through the rustling leaves were the prayers that met their answers ~ here.
author: Arissa C.

description:
by far the best place in san francisco to dispose of a body

ok, seriously, even though it's not a natural park, ie: everything is man-made, i have had some of the best times growing up in that park. ok, i don't mean i actually "lived in the park" growing up... unless passing out drunk at a kegger counts as living in the park

whether you want a great place to go mountain biking locally, have a picnic, lay out on the grass (on one of the 12 days a year where it's warm enough to) or just go on a walk with a friend, this is the place

...oh yeah, the roller disco on sundays is kinda entertaining in small doses as well
author: Thömas F.

description: Being near Golden Gate Park is one of the true pleasures of living in Haight-Ashbury.  It seems like there is always something interesting and fun going on there, and I take the kids to the main playground or the one in the panhandle most weekends.
author: Bob H.

description: It's all been said...GG Park is everything a park could be. Be sure to check out the buffalo and the wind mills, look for the little Buddha statue hidden in the Japanese Tea Garden, try pick out the fake rocks fromt he real ones, or head down there one beautiful Sunday to bike or skate through the park. That's the day they close off the streets. Overall, a great place hang with friends, see some sights, or people watch.
author: N B.

description: What did they do with Golden Gate park??  I'm talking about the area by the Concourse, where the California Academy of Sciences used to be and where the new (ugly) De Young Museum is.  Don't get me wrong, I'm a big fan of change.  Out with the old and in with the new!  But man, not only is this area an eyesore, they don't even allow through traffic anymore.  I don't know anybody that's got a ticket yet coming through here, but I don't see the point in rerouting traffic around this area.  Maybe it's just to steer people away from  how ugly it's become.
author: Tony L.

description: Best place to run in all of SF. I know, I've been running everywhere in this city for the past few months getting in prime shape for the SF half marathon. Thank you GG Park for making my runs enjoyable.
author: Defne A.

description: I LOVE GOLDEN GATE PARK!!!! It's is the perfect getaway for those times when the city life gets a little too intense. With the lush gardens, lakes, landmarks, and museums, the park is the best "mini" vacation" for San Franciscans. Thank god for Golden Gate park..... we all need a place that can remind us that life's too short not to "stop and smell the flowers".
author: Caroline J.

description: There's nothing like a walk in the Park, whether you're a local or a visitor.  Check out Lindy in the Park Sundays 11-2 (or so), with a free beginner's lesson at 2, in back of the De Young.
author: Hank G.

description: Big! So, so big! Our initial plan was to bike the park, then my boyfriend said we should try walking and see if we like it. It was COLD that first day, unbearably cold so I hated the park's guts. The times after were great though. Had fun walking around and enjoyed the scenery, but the parks in Handforth, Great Britain, where I grew up are way cooler!
author: Bekkah R.

description: When the cherry blossoms are in bloom, there's no better or beautiful place on earth to spend a day with your one true love.
author: Barb B.

description: Great place! It hard to imagine you are in the middle of the city when you explore this park. It takes me back in time... It feels like what San Francisco would be like if we didn't build a city of cement.
author: Dee C.

description: It is an amazing park and is the best park in SF. Though, traffic and parking are huge problems which is why I don't rank it 5 stars. They also have a large playground for kids.
author: S. K.

description: I think so many people in the US and those who hear about SF in the general media as just being some "gay" town or just a place that has alot of crime and deaths in the recent few years just doesn't see it through the eyes of many good natured people who've grown up here. Golden Gate Park to me is one of the most unique and beautiful FULL parks I've ever seen or been to. It reflects the true nature and beauty of the city. I've grown up in this city and since I've been forced to move to the DC area I've only heard about how much they hate the place and how they think it's nothing special and I gotta tell them each time, don't speak another word until you've actually been here and lived here and seen all there is to see. It's more than just a place for gay rights but SF would like to represent a place of where EVERYONE is entitled to their own beliefs and life as well as to be respected for their uniqueness and beauty as well as diverse history. I know there has alot been alot of negativity surrounding the city, such as bad school system, violence, kids jumping other kids, and the extremely high living costs thus resulting in such a huge homeless population not to mention cops who just aren't doing the city proud I would still like to believe theres still something about SF that you won't find anywhere else. Overall it's not "San Francisco's" fault. After all SF is just the city itself and the scenery and the historic beauty that is has is only being buried by all the bad media attention and portrayal and it's making me very sad, because though I currently don't live in it anymore, my heart has never left the city by the bay and it never will. I love the CITY and all it's beauty even though I've come to resent and be angry with many of the negative people who've been trying to turn it into something it never deserved to be known for. I can assure you all that when it comes to the food especially the Asian cuisine NO other city or state in the US compares, and I've personally tried many places in my current area and neither have done it for me. We truly have the BEST selection of food anywhere besides maybe NY but we're both unique in that with so much diversity comes all this GREAT food. Golden Gate park is a sacred place to me because it's where my family used to be a family, where both my mom and dad used to take me for strolls in the park, and seeing all the beautiful flowers and plants and waterfalls was like an adventure to me. It's so big that you just feel like your in a forest. I even enjoyed walking my dog here and just laying on the grass on a "rare" but warm and sunny day with my doggy laying his chest on me and just feeling a sense of warmth inside my heart, knowing that to me this place always and forever will be simple known as home even if the only place i could afford to live in were the park itself. (as sad and real as it may sound) it's the only reason why me and my hubby were forced to leave. =(
author: Petra S.

description:
I can't even believe a park this size and quality exists in a large city. Growing up in the rural woods instilled in me a fear of large stretches without trees, and visiting NY once I was completely depressed by Central Park (there's nowhere you can go and not be reminded that you are just in a patch of trees surrounded by larger city life). But in GG Park, you can roam for hours and never see another soul. And dogs are allowed in most of it. Perfect!!

And yes, there are the gorgeous cultivated paths, museums, and gardens, including the Botanical Gardens (aka prettiest spot in the entire city), for when you're not in a ramblin' mood. Oh, and did I mention the park dead-ends into Ocean Beach for a sunset bonfire?
author: Geae D.

description: Concerts, Arboretums, Bison, Tea Garden's....ahhh, so many memories and hopefully more good times to come.....
author: Yelper A.

description: i used to regret driving thru gg park as a shortcut between the 2 parts of frisco. upon driving thru the park, i felt an inner  calm seldom felt. i now look forward to accessing the park again.
author: Victor G.

description: I've been slowing down on my reviews lately, partly because I'm busy with school and haven't had time to go anywhere, but also because I realized that I was approaching the 100-review milestone, and needed time to contemplate what to review. Golden Gate Bridge? The Streetcar? Homeless people? The Muni? City Hall? Union Square? None of these quite epitomize my San Francisco experience. Then today, I realized the Golden Gate Park is perfect for my 100th review. Like the city of San Francisco, it's full of fun, quirky, culturally-stimulating (and just entertaining) activities, and yet I've barely scratched the surface. And come on, it's got buffalo, crazy rollerskaters, museums, and a windmill, all in the same park!
author: Rachel J.

description: So many great reviews about GG Park, I'm sure another one doesn't hurt! I feel fortunate to live two blocks from the park; it's like my own "backyard". I ran in the park and through the park countless time en route to Ocean Beach; I know it like the back of my hand. This morning I tried something new. I woke up early, went for coffee, and since the coffee shop was too crowd, I decided to go to the park. The Botanical Garden (one of my favorite park locations to enjoy leisure strolls) was not open yet. So I ventured to the field where I often see people play soccer, baseball or simply walk their dogs. Well, this morning, I sat down at the bleachers, pull out my book, and read. Coincidentally I was reading about meditation from the book Eat, Pray, and Love, and it was quite a meditative experience sitting there, engaged in my reading as the sun rays beamed down on me.  I was at peace with myself, and felt fortunate to be living in a city much appreciated for it beautiful landscape and culturally-enriched people.
author: Nadine D.

description: If you are looking for a great place to bicycle, read a book, people watch, check out a museum, look at Bison, enjoy a windmill, watch hippies play their drums, paddle boat across a lake, roll down a hill, drink tea while observing the Japanese gardens, wonder down numerous pathways to gardens galore, play at a playground, ride a carousel, play tennis, watch Rollerblades and skaters groove to music, see live and sometimes free concerts, meet new people from around the world, check out an conservatory in the butterfly season, and feed crazy hungry little squirrels. Then you must check out Golden Gate Park because you will defiantly not leave unsatisfied. Maybe a little lost, but surly happy.
author: Kelli H.

description: At the time I write this, there are 61 reviews, 50 of which are five stars, so you don't really need me to reiterate that this is a great park.  Instead, let me tell you a story.  Once upon a time, Rachel went to see the Free Tibet concert in Golden Gate Park.  She had a great time.  She loved being amongst tens of thousands of people listening to music in a park.  She loved the oddity of the Bison.  On the way out, Rachel and a friend were walking between the trees on the way to where they had parked when Rachel noticed something strange.  There was a man in just his underwear tied to one of the trees.  Rachel really wanted to know what this was all about, but her friend was too disturbed and shooed Rachel along, preventing her inquiry.  Rachel is still curious about that scene to this day.
author: Rachel R.

description: I really miss living just a few blocks from this place. So nice to wander through on a beautiful day. The botanical gardens, the DeYoung, Conservatory of Flowers (and jazz playing in the tunnel below), the roller skate party, the lindy hop party, the rose garden, the lake. What's not to love?
author: Leigh M.

description: Working hard to remind everyone that not ALL of San Francisco smells like urine.
author: Matthew R.

description: I had my wedding ceremony here. And no, it wasn't a stoned-out event centered around a drum circle... We had it in Shakespeare Garden, which is absolutely lovely and green in the summertime. The low-slung misty clouds of July sauntered by above. It was peaceful and beautiful, and made for awesome pictures.
author: Sahra H.

description: How many long jogs through the park? How many football games? Biking and rambling in this oasis. From the Panhandle to the windmills this park made it possible for this kid from the mountains to live in the City.
author: Seamus M.

description: I love you Golden Gate Park, I love you more today than yesterday!! I used to get lost in you all the time, but now that I'm a runner I know you inside and out.  I don't even mind the tourists that get in my way, unlike other parts of the city.  In fact I find myself smiling at the tourists, a smile that says "Isn't this just a beautiful wonderful place!".  Granted that could be the pot that I'm inhaling second hand from Hippy Hill, but whatever...this place is wonderful :) Whether you live in the city or are just visiting go here!!
author: Amanda P.

description: We started on our bikes from the Ocean Beach and went up the road past the Windmill, Beach Challet, soccer field, homeless people, buffalos, deYoung museum, homeless people, Aids walk, homeless people.. is that guy wrapping a dead body in a blanket?.. better not look.. waterfall with some white film floating on top, rose garden, tennis courts, a congregation of homeless people, Conservatory of Flowers, homeless people, Japanese garden, Shakespear garden, old 49ers stadium, and back to the beach to catch the sunset. Among more homeless. What's happening to this city?
author: Anya B.

description:
I was just thinking about Golden Gate Park this morning and how much I miss it.  You see, we don't have anything like Golden Gate Park in L.A.  Sure, Griffith Park is nice, and there are plenty of other parks and museums throughout L.A.; however, none of it compares to Golden Gate Park.  Also, as nice as L.A. weather is, it doesn't compare to the warm, but not too hot, San Francisco weather.

There's simply so much to do in Golden Gate Park.  Want to go for a bike ride, go running, or go rollerblading?  A pedal boat trip around a man-made lake and past a waterfall?  Horseback riding?  Check, check, and check!  Do you want to see a vintage Japanese tea garden?  How about a herd of buffalo, scratching their backs against tree stumps?  Check and check.  You see, Golden Gate Park is so huge, and yet, each of the individual attractions so intimate, that you'll find something totally relaxing and worthwhile no matter what you're in the mood for.

My favorite spots in Golden Gate Park are the windmills on the far West side near Ocean Beach, Stow Lake (hey, I used to come here as a kid), and the Bison Paddock, where it is always nice to spend a few minutes watching the buffalo.
author: Andrew D.

description: Golden Gate Park is so beautiful.  A must see in San Francisco.  As long as you don't wander along some of the outlying areas, it's a perfect place for the family, or a date, or a relaxing stroll/drive.  I love just driving through here with the sunroof open, and taking different turns.  Beautiful.
author: Darian H.

description: One random day in the height of summer, me and my then bf decided to spend the better part of the afternoon picnic lounging in front of the conservatory of flowers where all the butterflies hung out.  I'll just say, from personal experience, it's a great place to practice that move in dirty dancing where she runs to Patrick Swayze and he lifts her up in the air.  The grass was nice and fluffy.  People were also doing other random things like having a group flute lesson.  Lots of couples.  Kids making daisy chains.  There was also a jazz ensemble releasing lazy mood music into the ether.  I can't guarantee you'll have the same enchanted experience, but it is one of my favorite corners of the greater GG Park.
author: Marjorie B.

description: Golden Gate Park makes my evening run something more like fun and less like a torturous hour I endure before my evening cocktail. This great green stretch of land fill is also so pretty, it makes me proud to be a San Franciscan.
author: Kirsten B.

description: I just moved to SF from the East Coast, and being close to GG Park was a requirement for my apartment.  Thankfully, I am just 4 blocks from it.  I often walk, jog, or simply ejoy the surroundings of the park at least 4 times a week.  The city and the people would not be the same without this green space.  No matter what other neighborhoods I live in, I must be close to this park.
author: Victoria K.

description: The mother of all parks in San Francisco, Golden Gate Park is home to countless activities. Our Church used to have our Memorial Day picnics here and we never ran out of things to do. If you have a free Saturday you should definitely roam around Golden Gate Park and get lost in all its wonders.
author: Rommel N.

description: Super Duper! 5 blocks from my house! Big enough to get lost in! Freaks! Animals! Cruising! Flowers! Music (sometimes)! Pick up soccer games! Rollerblading! Scantily-clad runners! It's the best. Love it.
author: T O.

description: This place is great. Absolutely golden. You can truely get lost in this park. The worst thing you could run into is a dirty hippie with a jar of patchouli oil. There are plenty of other animals to see besides hippies. You can see, squirrels, ducks, swans, and even bison! Sans Kevin Costner dancing with wolves. I recommend a quick game of frisbee golf in the park. The course starts around 25th ave. What can be more fun than throwing a frisbee and walking around the woods? Oh wait, I sound like a hippie. Damnit!
author: Sal B.

description: I lived in New York and was more of a fan of Riverside Park but, I have to say Golden Gate Park is difficult to navigate.  It just isn't as accessible as Central Park.  It feels more car friendly than ped friendly.  And what is up with the street signage?  If you're going to have a park this large at least sign it!  There were way too many street closures when I was visited on a Sunday.......
author: Wendy B.

description: I can't believe I haven't reviewed this yet! We've been here many times, each time exploring a different area of the park - it's so huge! There's the Japanese Tea Garden (a slice of Japan in San Francisco), Botanical Garden (interesting plants from different parts of the world), Dutch Windmill, De Young Museum (great museum with great view from the tower), California Academy of Sciences, Bison enclosure (with a few sad bison that you can't get close enough to to see clearly), Conservatory of Flowers and more. We still haven't completely explored the whole place. And, if you go all the way to the end, you reach the ocean! Walking on the beach, you feel like you're not in the city any more. A great respite from city life.
author: pj n.

description: Not really a review, rather, just noticing... how could one not give gg park five stars!?
author: Lisa K.

description:
came with a couple of friends to golden gate park for a nice, relaxing sunday.  it was a gorgeous day and this park is beautiful.  we rode our bikes around and had a grand ol' time.

it's days like that which makes me soooooooo happy to be living near SF.  parking not all that bad around here either :)
author: Peggy W.

description:
Paul and I had just a few hours to spend in San Fran so we decided to head to Golden Gate Park.  I am so glad we decided to do that, we had so much fun.  The park is stunningly beautiful!  When we first stepped out of the parking structure we were greeted with an awesome blues band up on a big stage with tons of vendors selling food, people dancing, families having picnics, and the entire place had such a fun vibe.  It was hard to tear ourselves away to continue our explorations of the park!   We did so many fun things during our time here....had a bit of tea and a few treats in the Japanese Tea Garden.  That was a lot of fun, poor Paul I don't think he was excited as I was for that one.  The Botanical Gardens were stunning...well maintained, wide range of flowers, lots of places to sit and picnic.  Really beautiful.  The Shakespeare garden was also interesting to see.  A bit of graffiti there though, that was disappointing!  

There were so many other parts of the park that we saw that day but those were just the highlights.  It is so massive though we only saw a small portion of it that day.  OK by me, gives me a reason to go back to San Fran.  So beautiful and fun!  San Francisco is AWESOME!
author: Z Z.

description: A little overrated in my opinion, but they do have tennis courts, paddle boats, the tea garden, and live bison. Wait, this place rocks, except for the hippies.
author: Nish N.

description: So beautiful. The Panhandle, the hills, the walkers, joggers, tea garden, flowers, people watching, roller skates, sunshine and great way to walk to the beach.
author: Jessica P.

description: What is cooler than a park that is home to Bison just randomly wandering around? It's gorgeous and huge and I love that it makes Central Park look like someone's backyard because this park is so rustic and overgrown and charming. I didn't get to check out the Japanese tea room or the windmills on the edge but the Conservatory of Flowers was awesome.
author: Ayelet I.

description: As imperfect as it may be Golden Gate Park is quite incredible.
