Run, bike or walk by the Conservatory of Flowers, rent a boat on Stow Lake, tour the Japanese Tea Gardens, take a free Lindy Hop class on Sunday afternoons, find the Bison roaming, have a picnic, play soccer, tennis, frisbee, see a concert, people watch, train for your next event, run a race here, get married in the Tulip Garden or Shakespeare Garden, make it all the way out to Ocean Beach, go to the De Young for happy hour or an exhibit, check out the new Academy of Sciences, have a zen moment, have a celebration....Avoid the homeless smelly people, sketchy bathrooms and even sketchier stretches of area (including tunnels) as you get closer to Haight Street. Otherwise a fairly family friendly, people friendly, dog friendly park.
author: Abby W.

description: I am always amazed at how beautiful and big the park is.  And what a treasure it has in terms of museums.  I have many good memories here.  Since it was on the list of tourist attractions I showed off this weekend to a friend from France, I was reminded again of what a local gem we have - that I don't take advantage of.
author: Anne K.

description: I love this park so much that I moved there, well not inside the park but across the street on Stanyan street. I love being able to walk across the street and be inside a huge park where you can get lost, meet interesting people or check out some cool events like the newly opened California Academy of Sciences. It is also a great motivator for me when I want to go for a run or a bike ride. The only reason I am not giving it a 5 star is because the weather doesn't cooperate enough.
author: Bobby B.

description: Love it for its carousel ... dislike parts of it  because Food not Bombs brought the methadowners towards Stanyan and then let them stay in the bushes to rape and pillage unsuspecting, scrumptious young things to be turned and tricked out to burn and scar others.
author: miriam b.

description: There are many wonderful things about good old GGP, but my favorite is the Shakespeare Garden. Very few places inspire in me such a feeling of peace and quiet beauty. As a writer I feel a close connection to the poetry of the garden and as a San Franciscan I am very glad to have such a lovely place within walking distance from my home. A runner-up is the AIDS Memorial Grove, which is almost equally beautiful and of course quite emotional.
author: Janine M.

description: I have rollerbladed to the beach on this torn up pavement in that park so many times that............I had to take off two stars. Fix the road please City of San Francisco. You can do it. The ocean is an integral part of the design of this park yet you will not see half the rollerbladers to number of assholes on bikes.
author: fuck you p.

description: Waterfalls, buffalo, ultimate frisbee, Radiohead in less than 10 days - GGP is the largest park in the United States (they added the panhandle to the park so it would surpass Central Park in NY). From hippie hill, where you can find nature's unique trees, to the Dutch Windmill and Ocean Beach- it's always sunny to be in the park.
author: Jessica M.

description: How can one not appreciate the beauty we have right in our own city! This weekend the park hosted a run to benefit the new museum sans Gary Larson. Unlike past years, the turnout was a bit smaller - but the runners were just as excited. A family bay to breakers, this run has a 5 and10k with lots of kids being pushed in strollers. While the run was great, the beauty and calm of GG park on a early Sunday morning is priceless. Sun out or fog or rain, this place is magical.
author: Mark U.

description: I love this place, but I hate it all at the same time. It's clean, but yet, it's not that clean ( you only really understand it if you're from the city). Sunday's are the best time to head out as they close off most of the park for pedestrians and the park is flooded with people on their bikes, rollerskating, walking their pets or just lallygagging around.  It's fun, relaxing, and you meet a lot of people and even develop new friendships.
author: M T.

description: How could you not give this park 5 stars?  There is something to do for everyone here, including sports, museums, botanical gardens, lounging, listening to live music and even checking out the buffalo!  On a sunny day, this is one of the best places to be in SF!
author: Dana D.

description:
In the span of a few hours my friend and I went to Japan, the Wild West, and Holland.  We started out at the Japanese Gardens which were really nice.  The one steep bridge was a great photo op, and the tea house was a great experience at 4 dollars.  A "geisha" brought us each a pot of tea and a bowl of cracker and cookies in a lovely hut atmosphere.  We also had a third member join out party--a fearless squirrel who went from table to table trying to get scraps.  
After the tea gardens we headed to the Bison Paddock.  What is a paddock you ask?  As large open space.  And this one had 5 bison on it.  Unexpected sight in San Fran for sure.
We drove a bit farther down JFK Drive until we came upon the Windmill.  Unfortunately the tulips were not out, but the flowers that were around were lovely.
The last thing we wanted to do in the park was the lawn bowling---but we couldn't find the lawn bowling area or the free lessons!  Disappointment.
There is much more this park offers, if I was a city dweller I would frequent this place often.
author: Katie F.

description: Awesome park!  So much to see and everything was absolutely gorgeous!  We had purchased a map of the park because it is sooo huge  and I would highly recommend doing the same if you are unfamiliar with the park.  Golden Gate Park is on my list of reasons why I should move to SF.
author: Stephanie K.

description: Most of the tennis courts here are reservation-only and they cost money which means that they are well-maintained.  Another plus of these tennis courts is the number.  If you decide to forgo the reservation, be prepared to wait for the courts farthest away from the clubhouse.  The practice wall is great if you can find a time when no one else is there to use it.  Some of the people who play here are really good so if you stick around and watch you might learn a thing or two.
author: T-Bone L.

description:
It was a random last moment gathering, a few phone calls to friends around 1'oclock on Sunday: 
'wouldn't it be a fine day to play in the park? Come meet up with us and bring all toys, beers and food to share.' 
By 2 we were all in the park, at Spreckles Lake meadow. We had bocce ball, smashball, frisbee, racer 5's, wine and loaves of bread, cheese, salami, tomatoes, chips. We had a picnic table, blankets, additional chairs - everything we needed (besides a nearby bathroom which after some racer 5's and jumping around became an issue). 
The afternoon sun was abundant as we all know who experienced SF this weekend. We were playing like little kids for hours. Our neighbors were playing volleyball, dodge ball and the like. 
In the 6 years I have lived in SF, I still continue to unveil new offerings from this park, things I have not yet seen. I think the park is a bit underutilized and I'd like to see more people coming out and enjoying and exploring.
author: Amy E.

description: I live across the street from the park and its kinda boring but not.  I found a cool dirt path that allows me to run to ocean beach.  Ok I lie.  I roll my fat ass or drive my car on the path and pretend I am running in my car.  Its better than finding a treadmill that will fit my geo metro.  On sunny days this place is pretty awesome to roam around.  I am scared a bum is going to jump me at night so I am usually out of the park by 500pm.
author: Fatty A.

description: on a gorgeous sunny day--such as today--i give it five stars!  considering that GG park was once a sand dune, you have to appreciate the beautiful variety of trees, flowers, and plants.  One fresh morning, many many years ago, we took the 38 Geary all the way out to Ocean Beach...while on the bus we ate a hit of acid and then walked back through GG park.  by the time we reached the conservatory of flowers and went inside, I saw a man there who looked just like Elivs--when he turned around, I swear it was the King himself...we ran out crying...trying to contain ourselves we finally made it home several hours later....Ah Golden Gate Park--what a place--Long live the KING!
author: Sue U.

description:
duh II.

note:  Perhaps not the best place to trip on psychedelics late at night.  You will get lost and you will go in circles.
author: herbert r.

description: You can always find something to do in the Park and there's always some type of special event going on. Outside Lands, free radio concerts, fundraisers, BBQ, you name it, it's there! Seriously, how many parks have wild bison?!?
author: Lisa H.

description: My fave. Damn we're lucky to live in the Bay Area.
author: Helen K.

description: Wow this place is great.  So many times my boyfriend and I parked and made footprints on the ceiling of my truck there.  We also get sandwiches and eat while people watching and when any of my friends is blue, there seems to be an understanding that we meet here and walk and talk it out.  I like running around the Panhandle when I'm feeling athletic.  I dream of one day shoving my recalcitrant steed into his easy-bake oven trailer and showing him at one of the horse shows in the park with him behaving beautifully and placing well in every class.  I remember my foreign-exchange student friend's school party here where I was converged upon and treated as an exotic amongst all the foreign born.  I remember Mike, Jason, James and I strolling along just before Mike and James moved away and Mike stopped talking to me.
author: Jill D.

description: i am OBSESSED with the Bison.  I mean honestly, bison, in the city?  What other major US city has bison just hanging out?  I have never seen more than 10.  Has anyone else?
author: Marla L.

description: Do I even need to write anything? It's Golden Gate Park! This place is huge with a ton of different things to see, just watch out for the squirrels. All the damn tourists feed them so the squirrels think that we are all going to feed them. Seriously, walk away from one then turn around and see if it is following you lol. worked for me!
author: Pancho P.

description: This place is magical.  Forget the GG Bridge, forget Fishermans Wharf, forget Alcatraz, spend your time in America's most amazing park when you visit the bay area cause you won't regret it.
author: Derek J.

description: By far my favorite place in the city.  The GGP is THE place to run/walk/bike/read/explore/eat/drink/people watch and just simply enjoy life!  The park is very big and is filled with little hidden secluded forests and paths.  I've been through this park hundreds of times and  truly could write an entire book about Golden Gate Park, but I won't.  This short paragraph will do.  One of the greatest places on earth? Perhaps...
author: Scott G.

description: Free Thai Chi by Spreckles lake every Saturday (or was it Sunday? maybe both) at 8am? Oh yes! The park is absolutely beautiful, very active, and I love it! Make sure to check out the Japanese Tea Garden. =)
author: Narina A.

description: GG Park is an amazing park and are ulitmate frisbee games played throughout SF http://www.ultimatefieldlocator.info/san-francisco-ca-ultimate-frisbee-pickup/. There are weekly games in Sharon Meadow and a Saturday beach pickup game played at Ocean Beach, on the opposite end of the park (though technically not in the park).
author: Lawrence M.

description: I saw a real honest to goodness gang fight here! They had clubs, they had chains and leather, it was crazy! It was broken up by a bunch of guys playing flag football; a cop on horseback, three firetrucks, and my group of drunken-croquet-playing-mallet-wielding friends. Half an hour later I was offered pot by three different homeless people and then got to go see the field of buffalo! I love this place!
author: Elissa D.

description: look at other reviews.. it's a great place to host anything: bbq, baby shower, party...etc.
author: James L.

description: My backyard and playground.  I take it for granted sometimes but I love you GGP.
author: Pelle Y.

description: Wow I never realized how big golden Gate park is. And heavily wooded as well. I went mainly for the Outside Lands festival this past weekend but I will return for a run next time I'm up there. Sincerely beautiful... I can't wait to explore it further.
author: Lynn C.

description: Come on Sunday when they close off the park to cars and you can rollerskate, rollerblade, dance with like-minded folks.  Don't forget to visit the museum, the Strybing Arboreum, the ducks, the waterfall and all the other animals that make the park their home.  A nice place to just walk and take in some much needed air.  Also a place of origin of many an urban legend.  You hear about the ghost who, you know the story.
author: brenda b.

description: I have attended many parties in the park, played tennis and even watched the Buffalo roam.  Everytime, I have had fun, so it must be a great place.
author: Pele N.

description: AKA   Oasis in the city.  I think I would go bonkers without my rides thru this place.  If you don't spend time here, well you're basically blowing it.
author: Eagan I.

description: My ideal day is one filled with sun, standing thigh deep in the casting pool with my fly rod. My mind is clear, calm, relaxed. The rod swings back and forth and I hear my line whizz back and forth by my ears. I let go. Another perfect cast.
author: Andrew B.

description: Have people visiting? Bring them to Hippie Hill and watch the culture shock. Oh, be careful what you buy here.
author: Tom A.

description: You are my  neighbor and have been infused in my life since time immemorial, but I still find new meadows and glades.  Thank you.
author: Nate B.

description: I love GG Park because when you walk, drive, or ride in you feel like you've left the city and entered a historic, majestic paradise.  The foliage is so old and entrenched you'd barely know the park once stood on sand dunes.  All the little pathways, groomed gardens, wild forests, grassy dells (I just like to use that word when NOT referring to a crappy laptop), lakes and streams make for an endless array of recreational possibilities.  Get shitfaced and listen to bluegrass in Speedway Meadow.  Watch lawn bowling at, well, the Lawn Bowling Green.  Hop on the carousel.  Check out the bison (fo reals!).  Play handball, basketball, polo, golf (this course is amazing), disc golf, bocce, or any other outdoor activity you can imagine.  Use your park, people, it's there for you!!
author: Eric S.

description: I really like this park. It's a happy place. There's really so much to do. Things I enjoy include feeding the ducks at Stow Lake, laying in the sun, playing frisbee golf, going to the Academy of Sciences, and the view from the top of the de Young. Haven't tried out the paddle boats yet but the people who have always seem to be enjoying themselves. I have not yet lived in San Francisco for a full year but I can already tell that it's going to take a long time to fully explore all that this park has to offer. Keep it clean people!
author: Jordan G.

description: My friends and I came here yesterday after not wanting to hang out at the mall or restaurant (which is the usual). I haven't come here in agessss, but I don't think I've ever realized how beautiful and huge this park is. We ended driving through the entire thing because we got lost looking for Stow Lake (which we never went to, btw). We admired the cherry blossoms, bison (who knew!!), ponds of ducks, the AIDS memorial, and the children's playground. I noticed a whole hillfull of homeless near the playground and wished that I'd brought food or something ): but my friends and I had fun flying kites and inappropriately playing in the playground. I definitely want to come back to spend more time in the other parts of the park next time! (:
author: Jen T.

description: You can definitely get lost here. The park is freakin humongous! Really nice during the day time for bbqs (on nice days of course) and just a stroll down the lake. At night though.. this place is CREEPY! Don't go driving up no one-way lanes.. for you might have trouble returning! MUAHAHAHAHA! No.. seriously.
author: Elaine H.

description: Nice place to sun bath and volunteer for events like the aid walk or the park ranger stuff.  I guess you can take care f the bison too.  Volunteer for the museums.  Take a run through the park.  Smell the air Take kids to the playground.
author: John F.

description: this park is amazing - especially when considering how much land in SF is worth these days and how much land is in golden gate park preserved for recreation. Yes - you will get lost. This park is massive. But getting lost in it is part of the fun. This is a great place to play tennis, or lay out on a nice day and be entertained by people playing music (usually the drums), or if you're into it  - play a game of ultimate frisbee. Anyhow if the weather is nice you must bring out of town guests here.
author: Stacy H.

description: beautiful park with a lot of fun things to see and do--museums, gardens, trails, carousel, and play areas for children. it's a great place in the middle of the city where you can be surrounded by nature and enjoy running or walking through the pretty scenery. go on a sunny day and have a picnic!
author: Betty W.

description: Wants to be:  Central Park, NYC.  Settles for:  Golden Gate Park, SF.  Not bad, but not quite as good as the big guy on the urban park block.  While I never miss Central Park when I go to NYC, at least for a stroll, I tend to come to GGP more for specific purposes.  But it's still a great park.
author: Kevin S.

description: Is there any better place to be than GGP on a sunny day with books, friends or food? ALL THREE AT THE SAME TIME?!?! Heaven. Even on those cloudy days ggp is the best place to walk around, bike and people watch. The park itself is amazing with the trails and little places you can find. Since those sunny days are rare (enjoy them!!), always bring a jacket!
author: rukshan b.

description: Huge, truly huge, with every manner of attraction - golf, bison(!), museums, lakes, summer plays & concerts, picnicing, grass, trees, jogging/walking/rollerblading, you name it.  Just prepare for the usually cold windy weather.
author: Don H.

description: This is a legendary place that happens to be right in our backyard.  I love that I have lived here for 10 years and I still get a thrill when I walk down JFK on a warm Sunday and observe the Pepperland (as my father would say) atmosphere where the cars are blocked off.  As a runner, I am blessed to live a few blocks away from it.  There's nothing better than a Saturday run to the beach.  One note of warning for dog owners: the dog park which is adjacent to the buffalo fields usually has some scary, out-of-control dogs.  All the dog walker people let their crazy canines loose there.  Watch out!
author: Emma K.

description: This place is amazing. It's a shame it's only rated 4.5 stars. I would give Golden Gate Park a higher Yelp rating than any other place I've yelped: 10 stars.
author: Anonymous P.

description: Have you gone there lately?  Have you seen the fresh blossoms and the tulip garden out by the windmill?  Have you seen the bison?  Have you seen the hippies drumming in circles? How about the De Young, the tea garden?  Have you seen the non native eucalyptus and smelled them?  Have you seen the turtles ironically setting on the stone turtle in the pond?  Check it out!  It's toe-up.
author: Lauren S.

description: Sitting on hippie hill on Sunday afternoons, completely hungover, watching the people dance is one of the most surreal experiences ever. And you come up with brilliant phrases like "I don't even need an ipod, I just hear the music"
author: Srinivas R.

description:
any big park in a metropolitan city that houses coolbean american bison (buffalos) in the park deserves 5 whole stars! yeay!
buffalos are so cute :)
i like going and looking at them...
author: charlotte s.

description: I cannot take all of Golden Gate Park at 5-stars.  For me, it is not a 5-star park by any stretch.  The park especially towards the western half has mangy grounds and seems has a low maintenance plan.  I think the park is okay and doesn't seem alive like Central Park.  The dirt trails and the plants look so poor.  I am not sure what is so great about this park; 5 stars for the Arboretum, Stow Lake and the DeYoung.
author: Jaime Patricio M.

description: This park isn't really a park as you'd think of a park. it's more like a giant wilderness.  my friends and i walked through some of it and i would have gotten totally lost. it's acres and acres and there's so much room you could have a whole party with blasting music and no one would notice or be bothered.  there are different fields for if you want to play sports, there are bathrooms, wilderness areas, picnic areas, anything you'd want in a park.
author: Merredith L.

description: Definitely one of my favorite parts of San Francisco!  You do NOT feel like you are in the middle of a major city when youre in Golden Gate Park. Its absolutly beautiful.  Some of my favorite parts: Rose Gardens, De Young Museum, Observatory, botanical gardens, Polo Fields, Hippie Hill, the many amazing free concerts, the variety of trees and flowers, the herd of bison!, Stow lake, access to ocean beach.... EVERYTHING!  I love this park!
author: Lauren M.

description: An oasis in the middle of our urban dwelling, I'm so appreciative to live so close. Yay!
author: Claire S.

description: I was in here for two hours and I barely made a dent in the place.  This park is amazing!  The kids playground is especially rad and made me wish I was five again.  We also walked through the Conservatory which has a rotating plant exhibit and butterflies.  Great way to spend an afternoon.
author: Lauren L.

description: Although some parts carry the usual slack jawed idiots all in all its a nice park to visit.  The De Young is there, Japanese Gardens/botanical etc etc.  Good for families to visit with kids who are a little bit older, or if you enjoy sports its great for that, or just a walk/jog.  I long for the days that I will be able to visit the park on a somewhat daily basis.
author: Winter Lee S.

description: I love the enchanting Golden Gate Park, it's so pretty and green.   There were plenty of pink cherry blosssom trees blooming. Went here over the weekend with friends and had a blast.  Walked around, saw squirrels, dogs, bikers, roller bladers, and came upon secret bamboo forest, went up to the cool waterfall, and walked through the rose garden and through the music concourse? between de young museum and the academy of life sciences.  Chilled at the chidlren's playground near 9th-11th fulton?
author: John L.

description: I grew up in and around Golden Gate Park... It's beautiful and has lots to offer... With that said, it has it's dark sides too... But to me, the good far outweighs the bad... If I could give it 10 stars I probably would.
author: Lindsey S.

description: There is so much to do here! I try to go as often as I can. It's a wonderful retreat from all the craziness of life and such a beautiful place. I love the Arboretum, the Japanese Tea Garden and Stowe Lake especially. The AIDS Memorial is beautiful and evocative; peaceful and wistful. The Shakespeare Garden is also lovely, as is the Conservatory. And the bison paddock, well it's random, but kind of fun. I like the windmills too; it's so sad that the South one is in such terrible shape though. I love coming here to read in the sun or take very long walks, even when it's foggy and chilly.
author: Barbs J.

description: So much to see, so much to do, so much free time on my hands. We spend a lot of time in the 'summer' at Marx and Speedway Meadows, great for bbqs, seeing great live (and often free) music. Good place for some fundraising run, greatest place ever for biking. I love that I can pretty much bike through the panhandle 'park' all the way through GG to the beach. That makes me forget I live in The City sometimes. Then there's the Conservatory, the Band Shell, the buffalo, pinner golf course, Japanese Tea Garden, museums, rose gardens, ponds with tadpoles and turtles, waterfalls...or you can just lie in the grass. But don't do it anywhere near hippy hill.
author: Colleen B.

description: What park showcases concerts such as Reggae in the Park, Power to the Peaceful , Opera in the Park and also  De Young Museum, Japanese tea garden, botanical garden in the midst of  lush greenery- it's Golden Gate Park of course.  One of my favorite place in this picturesque city  I love.  I also love seeing the diverse group of people jogging, having a picnic, playing soccer/volleyball just enjoying the day regardless if it is sunny or cold and foggy.  This is what makes San Francisco such as a special city.
author: Belle M.

description: The park is huge.  It's great to take kids, friends, out of town friends, etc...  May be a bit too touristy in some areas, but if you know where to go, it can also be nice and quiet.  Really good place to show off the great city of San Francisco to your out of town friends! :)
author: Neil K.

description: Great park with a great many places yet to be explored by San Francisco locals, such as the golf course, the archery range, concerts, and riding trails. These places are located at the far end of the park near the Ocean Beach.
author: Tony N.

description: If I moved here, I would probably look for an apartment nearby.  In the Spring, we visited the Botanical Garden, Japanese Garden, and de Young.  My boyfriend hates the walking to he likes to use the bus to speed our hike across the park.  This is our favorite place in the city, so we always go here and do something different on our first or second day of visiting.  We have a handheld map because we've gotten lost before.
author: Ai M.

description: Ohhhh Golden Gate Park. What a perfect place to hang out and de-stress. Perfect if you enjoy constant background beats, delicious smoke, drinking beer on the hill, dogs, and the occasional nude dancer-swordfighter-acrobats (true story). And I do. Five stars, would enjoy again.
author: Drea M.

description: Place in a city to get away from the city, although not too far though heheee.  Nice place to walk or bike, just to get away from it all.  I go like once a year but I enjoy it everytime.
author: Xiu L.

description: One of the natural wonders of the Bay Area.. Where else could you find a museum, rollerskaters, a concert venue, windmill and bison?
author: Trish P.

description: Take your guests, your family, your dog, or your crush. Golden Gate Park has something for everyone: museums, lakes, fields, hills, tennis courts, flowers, rose garden, tea garden, bisons, and *gasps* Parking!! Yes, parking. Take that, Central Park!
author: Zell C.

description: What a place to just walk around, relax, and take in all the scenery! When the sun is out, break out the sunblock and find a spot where you can just hangout or if you like exploring bring some comfy shoes and have a good time!
author: Mel P.

description: The Central Park of the West. The botanical gardens are beautiful and the Japanese tea garden is lovely. There's something for everyone with it's many hobby-centric areas. My personal favorite place is the fly casting ponds, right across from the buffalo. That's right, there's buffalo in the park!
author: Chris S.

description: Clearly the best park in the city. It's massive and offers tons of sweet treasures. Every time I go there, I find something new and wonderful. Great place for picnics, although due to the location, sun can be scarce. The only downside is hippy hill where nonstop drum circle actions seems to be had. I can hear it every day from my balcony.
author: Jade L.

description: It's by far a 5-star.  Okay, I must admit, I did not think much about it until I moved into the neighborhood.  Growing up in the other side of town, GGP was too far to trek for a cold, overcast walk in the Park.  I take that back now.  Bit-by-bit, I am discovering it.  Faves are DeYoung and Botanical Garden so far.  You can discover something new that you didn't know existed in the park, every time.
author: Uimuim B.

description: I love Golden Gate Park! It might not be perfect, but it is a great place to get away from everything. I've been going to Golden Gate Park since I was young, I used to go to the park every weekend and play tag and so forth with my sisters. Man... the memories...
author: Edgar G.

description: Saying that I love Golden Gate Park is a serious understatement.  There are so many amazing things throughout the park, I cannot even fathom running out of things to do there.  Simply lounging on one of the countless grassy knolls is often where I can be found, probably including a picnic with friends.  The flower conservatory (even just the building itself) is beautiful.  Ocean Beach is at the end of the park, just a quick bike ride away.  There is stuff for kids to do, dogs, adults.  The De Young is amazing too!  Golden Gate Park is a wonderful oasis that should be explored by all.
author: Lauren H.

description: A huge park in the middle of a city! Pretty amazing to have.. not many city has it. Even Central Park isn't this big. Anyway, love the park. Perfect to walk around for fun or exercising. Lots of open field for picnic and pretty flowers during summer time. There are so much to do!! you can spend a day in this park.  I especially like the Japanese garden and museum the park has. Pretty cool.
author: Daisy S.

description: This is a beautiful park. My cousin lives a block away. It's so romantic and peaceful here. Beautiful museums nearby and just wonderful trees and a whole lot of space. This place is a perfect date area and just full of energy.
author: Bella D.

description:
Spectacular. Enormous. And serene. I have been to the park for events like the annual AIDS walk, or for outdoor shows, but its beauty shines through even brighter on a calm weekday afternoon, if you can manage it. And it has more on offer than you can explore or digest in a single visit. 
The best part is that there is something for every age, mood and personality. Formal pruned rose garden? You got it. Arboretum? Check. Wooded trails? Uh huh. Japanese tea garden? Hell yes. (Oh, and by the way, if you do visit the tea garden, try and do it when it's raining. There are few things more beautiful than sitting under the pavilion sipping steaming jasmine tea, looking out at the leaves elegantly dripping moisture.) 
Got some energetic kids with you? We've got you covered with a kids play area and the coolest carousel ever. And if you're with a mixed group looking for some variety, take a turn at the bocce ball lanes or paddle around Stow Lake. 
And if it's just you, looking for an escape from the city, walk, walk, walk everywhere. Take a break at the De Young museum to get re-energized (or if just art doesn't do that for ya, stop by the museum cafe). 
I could go on and on, but then, you need to get out and go explore this wonder for yourself. One of my favorite places in San Francisco, and a big part of the reason I love living here.
author: Purnima M.

description:
hmm. slept here for a few nights. that was pretty sketchy but i guess you could say we had no choice at the time (such is the life of a the travelling vagabond) but other than sleeping there a few nights, we also went to a bluegrass festival here and that was alot of fun. ALOT of fun. we got really drunk and wandered aroudn the park. made fun of the tweakers. threatened to chop down the janis tree, and watched a bunch of wierdos doing this wierd interpretive dance for like 3 hours.

basically you can find anything in golden gate. and i mean that however you want to take it. there's a little bit of everything, and something for everyone if you catch my meaning. from upper class people getting married in the park to strung out junkies at the end of haight. everyone has their place.
author: annie c.

description: Me and two friends kicked it on Hippie Hill with a few homeless people and jammed with a drum circle. We got offered inexpensive pot cookies and my friend bought one. Paramedics came and broke up the drum circle momentarily to pick up a homeless man that was apparently kicked in the head? It's a beautiful park, but we have yet to see all of it.
author: Sharee R.

description: Most cities are lucky to have parks one tenth the size and coolness of Golden Gate Park.  I merely scatched the surface with a 6 hour stroll through the easternmost reaches.  Entering off of Haight you have to run the homeless stoner gauntlet and make your way through the dark creepy underpass (there were 6 hammered homeless screeching sailer songs at the top of their lungs under there as I entered).   But once through you get to appreciate the majestic beauty of this crown jewel of city parks.   There will still be the periodic attempt to sell you weed, but it is a minor annoyance or convenience depending on your tastes.   The park is sprawling and offers something for everyone.   I passed by the art center, soccer fields, miles of trails, dog parks, memorial groves, science/history/museum, aquarium, conservatory, tennis courts, raquetball courts, play grounds, nursury (they have their own), and lawn bowling facility and I only made it a short way into the park.   There is a mountain of more stuff to be had in there.  Go see for your self.
author: Brent F.

description: C'mon, how can you not give GGP 5 stars? When the sun is shining, the birds are chirping....ahhhhhhh.
author: Jewel N.

description: A great place to just go and relax where you know you won't be bothered.  Occasionally there are concerts going on, art exhibits and just generally picnicking going on.  Making the park an generally playful and enjoyable place to hang out.
author: Jonathan B.

description: Beautiful place but I can't help but avoid it cause it's always foggy out there. Go there and check out the bison, take a calm paddle on the lake,  go laugh at the Dirts on Hippie Hill and hit on unsuspecting German tourists. I will personally be at Dolores Park bbq'ing in the sun with my transgender homies.
author: Steve H.

description: It's flat and pretty.  Parking is good.  However, I tend to get slightly bored when I run here.  The 3 stars are for the flatness.  When I want a flat run without wind and don't feel like the gym, I'll head to GG Park.
author: Christina N.

description:
HOLY CRAP

A HUGE PARK IN A CITY! WHO WOULD EVER GUESS?

and buffalo

and archery

and boccie

and model boat ponds

and paddle boats


and closed for biking on weekends

and kickball


and bar b q

and amazing flora

and tea gardens

and tennis

and kickball

and i dont even know what else

this damn park is so expansive and amazing, i think it will take me another 3 years just to figure out the roads in here.

aquarium in 2008? exploratorim? museums?

people selling beers, butterflies, and sunny warm days where there is no stinky crowd on dust and dog crap like Dolores?

really, this park is one of the greatest plots of land in the world.
author: Raccoon S.

description: It is what it is. Beautiful, weird, and endlessly entertaining. Drum circles, old skool hippies, new skool hippies, suggestive salesmen roaming the park. "Mushrooms, rolls, purple buds, anyone???" Lacks the hipsters usually chillin at Delores Park. Golden Gate Park is a particularly badass place to bring visiting friends. They will trip out.
author: Nikki H.

description: An absolute gem in the middle of a city with many idiots.  I have lived within 5 blocks from Golden Gate Park and know the ins and outs of it...but every time I go for a stroll on a Sunday afternoon, I stumble upon something new - a new park or a new inlet - something!  I love it.  Absolutely enchanting.  Always something going on here - marathons, concerts, free gallery, updates etc.  Love GG PARK!
author: Nathalie C.

description:
It has bison, smelly/high bongo-playing hippies, beautiful sub-parks, butterflies, playgrounds, sunny fields, and more dogs than children.
I love it.
author: Sora O.

description: Every tree, bush, flower, buffalo, etc. that you see in this park was placed there by man.  This is a much prettier park than Central Park, yet oddly it is not more famous.  A very relaxing oasis from rat race.
author: Christopher G.

description: This park is awesome.  So much good stuff here.  My favorites, the Japanese tea garden and conservatory of flowers.
author: matthew w.

description: How could you NOT give GGP 5 stars??? There's so much to do, but I love just grabbing a blanket and a frisbee and heading out to ANYWHERE (sans tourists) and enjoying a nice day. Or take your bike out and ride to the beach. It's exhilarating! Great place to relax and enjoy the outdoors...especially on a Sunday when there's not so much traffic!
author: Nicole S.

description: A typical Sunday in GG park: ride our bikes over to the park, cruise through, watch the roller skaters practice their routines, listen to the swing music and watch the swing dancers practice, hang out on the grass with a good novel and a popsicle. End up at the Beach Chalet for a Bloody Mary. Walk through the Japanese Tea Garden, look at the De Young architecture. I love this park (especially when it's sunny.) Love that it exists, love that people use it. Love the activities going on. Makes me feel a sense of community that I don't often feel here.
author: Dana K.

description: I love this place, and it helps that I live so close to it. I can't seem to explore all of it though....apparently there are live freaking animals living in the park that I have never seen. Plan on exploring more of this place...but I can't seem to make it past Stowe Lake.
author: James J.

description: Yay golden gate park. I am bound and determined to have the spectral ghost of a cop try and pull me over in the middle of the night, since I am a ghost story whore. Stow lake and the isle in the middle is where I would probably go if zombies attacked san francisco. I know I am weird. Yay to this man made oasis that dosent look man made, with its many adventures ahead.
author: Ryan O.

description:
pros... one of the few places in s.f.ca. that you will find vast amounts of open space.  nothing but trees, grass, plants and other non-concrete structures.  you will find lots of people here just cause it is not the city.  

without fail, everytime my wife and i go to the city by the bay, we end up here.  there is a nice man-made lake in the park, with a chinese style pagoda in the middle of it, and the best park is that you can row a boat.  this is the part i love, i feel manly and i get some exercise as well.  if you aren't into rowing, then you can always rent a bike or something human powered and roam around the park.  just don't be late, then they charge you extra. 

cons...parking is scarce at times, cause all the locals and tourists are here.  oh, and just like the city, you will need to plan ahead for any unforeseen atmospheric changes, uh i mean the unpredictable s.f. weather.  so bring a jacket, or anorak and perhaps an umbrella too.  the mist can be very cold.
author: Joel G.

description:
I love Golden Gate Park. Put on a pair of rollerblades or ride your bike for a truly fantastic experience. I lived in SF for 4 years and still didn't see all that Golden Gate Park has to offer. Beautiful scenery, nice trails, ponds with turtles, open grass areas,  buffalos, etc. 

This is one of the few places that can take you "out of the city" while still being in San Francisco.
author: Michael S.

description: Awesome city park! Definitely the safest feeling city park I've been in. My wife and I were looking a little lost and this guy turned around on his bike and came back to see if we needed help. I love SF. I always go back home resolving to be kinder to tourists.
author: RJ A.

description: I have been coming here with my nephew for quite a while now. Despite some of the negative reviews this place has recieved with regards to the homeless hanging around there doing drugs, i have yet to witness that. Its a place where a kid can really be a kid. Too bad i never really grew up in sf hence never really had a chance to go through all the fun and excitement my nephew goes through everytime we go there. Coming to think of it, its not a really bad place for a first date either, but oh well we leave that upto the individual. I wll continue to return here.
author: Raj K.

description: The most perfect eight miles run in the park, down to the ocean  beach and back passing by the Young Museum!!. beautiful place, glad to have it in the city!!
author: Runner M.

description: GG park.  What comes to mind?  Greenery, de Young, tourists, runners, picnics in the sun, and a bike ride to OB.  A walk/bike around the park finished with take-out lunch from Marnee Thai...perfect weekend day!
author: John D.

description: what a great place to go and relax.  I love the fact you can meet so many people.  make sure to take your bike and go for some rides.
author: Richard J.

description: I love this park and so does my dog.  We heavy users as we live near it.  There's so much variety that it's hard to ever get bored here...we're at the grassy dog park area one day and walking along the wooded trails the next.
author: lucy ..

description:
Ben V. should consider that when GGP was originally envisioned, ALL of the western side of San Francisco was sand dunes.  Think of how cool a park running to the beach surrounded by dunes that stretched for miles to the north and south must have been.

Raze the Sunset and the Richmond before you touch my glorious park.
author: Lou V.

description:
Everyone else has already hit upon the known, idyllic qualities of this urban oasis. However, rarely mentioned is the time wrap that is the Roller Skating Rink on Sundays. It serves as an immediate transport to Sesame Street or Reading Rainbow, circa 1985. Skaters, from those rocking the short shorts and fishnets to those sporting  furry skates all dance and spin to the beats (often Ghost Busters or a little Michael Jackson) emanating from some specially constructed boombox stroller on wheels.

 Roller bladers seem to be welcome too, as are hoola hoopers, but the sights that remain transfixed in my mind are the real, true-blue roller skaters, working on their line dances involving some super impressive toe-heel moves. The perfect place to bring anyone, to observe, laugh, impress, and maybe wish that you too, were bold enough to don eight wheels and a mini skirt.
author: Emily P.

description: i've been living here for almost a year now and, i never really made  the effort to appreciate the park.  i've started to do a run out to ocean beach and there's a beautiful trail that runs through the park alongside lincoln ave all the way to the water.  it's lovely and peaceful - NO iPOD NECESSARY.  if you're into trail running, i would recommend it.
author: Tanvi A.

description: my favorite place to puff and perambulate in the sunshine.
author: Ligaya T.

description: one time i was here on acid having a "business meeting" with some friends. the problem was, people kept jogging past us, constantly interrupting our "meeting." we had to put a stop to it. so we decided to make a sign that said NO JOGGING, and block their path with it. then we hid behind a bush to watch their reactions. they didn't seem to find it funny, but we sure did!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
author: jaqui s.

description: As a tourist, I was disappointed to see the large amounts of litter (mostly empty beer cans and cigarette butts) laying all over the greens and ponds. The landscaping and flora was not impressive.
author: odaravlaa c.

description: some of my first memories of moving to san francisco as a little girl are sunny days in Golden Gate Park.  the fact that they close it off to cars on sundays is one of the reasons i love this great city -except when i'm pissed that i'm driving my car and can't get through the g$*D#mn#d park, but that's another story entirely.  this is a story of my first job- a lemonade stand catered to the thirsty bike riders and phenomenal skate dancers where i made A WHOLE DOLLAR.  a story of my first time on roller blades FLYING down a hill and slamming into the ground so hard that i blacked out.  a story of my uncle's wedding in the shakespear garden that ended in bitter divorce.  a story of a childhood in the city.  ahhhhh, memories.
author: Shanti G.

description: i like to go coyote hunting here at night.  minus one star for the homeless bums almost getting shot, for being mistaken for a coyote.
author: Pickle R.

description: The park is big, a lot of people even on weekday.  Free parking along the streets.  Tea garden admission fee $7.
author: John c.

description: I find it hard to imagine asking more from a park than GG Park offers.  It is so wonderfully expansive and jam-packed with attractions both hidden and famous that it almost seems its treasures will never be exhausted.  Every time I go, I find something I've never seen or noticed before.  It's not the point to list them all, but I can't resist enumerating a bunch of the best and/or most interesting.  Of course there is the Japanese Tea Garden, which is just beautiful and serene, and the Conservatory of Flowers and the Arboretum (a recent breath-taking discovery).  In addition, however, there are (not one but) two bocci fields, a working vintage carousel, a stable of riding horses (which I think can be rented),  a fly-fishing society, about a dozen head of live bison, an archery range, the expansive polo fields (which host the entirely free Not So Strictly Bluegrass Festival every October), the Rose Garden (with more varieties of amusingly-named roses than you ever thought to see), a 9-hole golf course, the National AIDS Memorial Grove (inevitably sad but also lovely and inspiring), baseball and soccer fields, the off-the-beaten-path and charming Shakespeare Garden, a restored windmill with a gorgeous flower garden at its base, and countless winding paths with small hidden wonders of all descriptions around every corner.  Somewhere in the middle of it all is the marvelous Stow Lake--from which you can rent various pedal-powered vehicles for exploring the park--and its towering island-hill in the center, complete with a pagoda-like structure and a lovely waterfall.  Perhaps best of all is the view from the top should you make the climb--though largely obscured by trees, on a clear day the vista will show you an awfully large portion of the city and the Marin headlands to the north.  San Francisco is incredibly blessed to have such a generous swath of green space within its boundaries, and it's one of the wonders that makes living here a real privilege.
author: Michael T.

description: i love this park.  always filled with activities and interesting folks.
author: dae m.

description: i didn't go to ggp for more than a decade after my dad had a serious accident there when i was a kid. wow was i missing out! when i finally ventured back into ggp for a photo shoot i was amazed and what i'd been missing. now i go back regularly and find something completely different every time. it's pretty amazing that this piece of land is right here.
author: lisa w.

description: wonderful venue for picnics, people-watching and simply wasting time.
author: Jamie C.

description: you can visit the conservatory of flowers, the japanese tea garden, the rose garden, the strybing arboretum & botanical gardens and the deyoung museum (free 1st tuesday of the month) - all when you visit the golden gate park.  a very peaceful and beautiful place to spend the day.
author: Immer E.

description: Golden Gate Park feels like home to me.  I really love this place, thank you San Francisco forefathers and mothers for creating my favorite sanctuary.
author: Diana B.

description: This is park is part of my marathon training runs, and am after hundreds of logged miles, I'm still discovering new trails and paths through this enourmous urban park.  I love that it's a "pedestrian only" park on Sunday and look forward to the end of all the construction and the park's museums opening up again. What's up with the bison? Random, eh?
author: Michael H.

description: good: the boats on stowe lake, the playground & carousel (they have those multi-personed swings). and was i surprised to see bison. where can i rent one of those multi-personed bicycles? and how is it in the tl/civic center neighborhood? sundays rollerblading is so awesome - i have no control of my feet but fortunately the roads are closed so i have plenty of space to manuver while passing by the hockey players, the lindy hop dancers, & the guys who do fancy moves on their skates.
author: Lijia X.

description: Golden Gate Park is a San Fran must-experience.  The wonderful trees and free parts of the park are as good as some fee gardens.  My only complaint - and for me a pet peeve - is the very, very poor wayfinding signage. The Park has some attractions like a great children's playground, conservatory and botanical garden (reviewed separately). But  finding these attractions, or anything else is a challenge to say the least. I've never needed to ask for or been asked for directions any more than at this place. The maps and directions provided by the park are nice, especially when they give you a street address... but then, the streets aren't signed so you have no idea what street you're on much less which one you've found. And once you're on the paths and trails, you'll need a compass or a guide 'cause there sure aren't any or many signs.  I'm no fan of signs, but at a place as large as this one, they are critical. Especially if you're on a limited schedule like we were and looking specifically for an attraction that's closing in an hour...  Still do visit, just leave plenty of time for going in circles and looking for 'you are here' signs.  Good luck!
author: Geoff T.

description: anyone wanna jump on the back of my tandem bike?  i'm drivin'!  i have it rented for 2 hours!
author: Monk R.

description: good place, and nice place to move around just watch where you walk, golden gate can be an adults playground as well
author: Leigh McInnis Lee G.

description: This review is for the Wilhemina Tulip Garden, which we used for a wedding ceremony two weeks ago. The space worked beautifully for a small ceremony (75 people), near enough to the street but still blocked off from the windy beach. The one trouble is keeping onlookers out. Be prepared to put up signs and station bouncers, as there's no one from the park on hand to help make things look official. Of course, be sure to rent the space from the park department proper, and definitely bring a copy of your permit with you on the day of your event. Otherwise, a really lovely venue.
author: Bonnie R.

description: hippie hill on a warm sunday afternoon
author: Pete C.

description: couldnt ask for anything more beautiful than this park. stow lake is amazing. japanese tea gardens and the museums are my favorite. always get an ice cream and walk around the less bum infested areas. great place to ponder the meaning of life in the worlds larges man made park
author: Ashley H.

description: I love Golden Gate Park !! It's the closest thing left of nature in our industrialized city . I'm not going to lie .. sometimes it's just nice to take a walk through a park full of trees , bushes , and grass . It's very soothing and relieves stress ( not to mention , easy to get lost too ! haha ) . It's just wonderful . It's a nice place for photography too . Inside Golden Gate Park , there's some parks , museums , and the Japanese Garden in Golden Gate Park . It's a great place to go biking on Sundays because I remember reading on the website that one area is cleared of traffic on that day just for that purpose . Only thing I don't like about Golden Gate Park is that last time I came to do a photoshoot , I got mosquito bites all over my leg because there were just so many mosquitoes in that one area !! You can still see traces of the bites on my leg ): Also , I remember my friend driving through Golden Gate Park late at night when we were high . I might've been high but I swear .. I saw owls behind every tree !! I got so paranoid !! I'm sorry to be a hater .. but I HATE owls . They're so ugly and creepy looking with their big heads , big eyes , 360 degree turning heads , and glowing marks on their tummies !! I know they are endangered and all .. but I just don't find them cute or cool one bit . They don't even seem like animals .. they seem more like creatures with magical powers . Haha , maybe I watched too much TV as a kid . Hey , that's what TV and movies do to you haha . So now I'm paranoid when my friends choose to drive through Golden Gate Park at night because I'm scared of seeing owls !! I think it's only in that one area though ( I forgot which one it was ) because my friends take a different route through Golden Gate Park so I never saw them again since that night . Oh , and there's a lot of stories about Golden Gate Park such as the one story about the cop who died on duty inside Golden Gate Park and that comes back occasionly to pull people over . People say that's why they made it legal for people to pull over when you get out of Golden Gate Park . I don't know .. I find it an interesting story . But of course , I won't believe it until I see it for myself .
author: Eileen L.

description: Am I a bad person for wishing Golden Gate Park had free WIFI?
author: A W.

description: stowe lake, the tea garden, the rose garden, the shakespeare garden, the botanical garden, hippie hill...there is something for everyone in this park.  the perfect place for a morning walk, an afternoon stroll, an evening jog...for picnics, bench lunches, or a morning cuppa in the fog.  in grey fog, in sunshine, or in cold windy rain....  ah, this park is truly a delight and one of the gems in this city.
author: Roshni R.

description: ...so we're taking a break from our kickball game (yes, i know--the display of athleticism is astonishing) by the children's playground and i'm sitting on the grass, talking to some friends, drinking a beer, minding my own business. suddenly i feel a slight poke on my ass cheek. thinking it's somebody behind me, i glance behind me a few times, but no one's there. then i realize that the poking is coming from the ground! i get up and see a gopher bobbing his head up & down, almost smiling at me! i think i was covering his sunlight.
author: Chris C.

description: This is a huge park, and I doubt I will ever finish walking the whole thing unless I commit a day to it, and there's always lotsa nature around to see.  When my family went, I remember seeing lots of pretty flowers, and when I was here three years ago, I remember visiting the Japanese garden (at least I think it was) and sticking my foot in the pond of some green growing on the top of it, just because I wanted to disperse some of that green stuff...gross, but the water wasn't that dirty.
author: W W.

description: Lately the weekends have been really sunny and overall great.  I'm just a short walk away from GG Park and we go out here to jog around the polo field or walk around the duck pond.  I really do need to find out where to sign up for horseback riding out here...I always see people riding through the park.  If you know, let me know.  You can also go to Stow lake and either rent a paddle or row boat or rent the 2-3-4 person bikes.  Alot of fun ways to enjoy our "mini central park" on beautiful SF days.
author: Mary H.

description: perfect place to hang out, have a picnic, jog, walk, etc. Always a nice escape, right here in SF
author: Beena A.

description: what?? this park is Amazing!! all the way from stanyan to the ocean!! i can't even list it all.. hand ball, polo, horses, lakes, strawberry hill, botanical gardens, tennis, lawn bowling, hippie hill, biking, skating, the sun, speedway meadows, waterfalls, fly casting, marx meadows, kezar stadium, the beach, surfing, chain of lakes, amazing trees/nature, dogs, tea garden, bison, dutch windmills, aids memorial garden, the arboretum, the secrets of the universe, conservatory of flowers, deyoung,  soon to be academy of science, i'm sure i missed plenty but i'll be back to the park.. don't forget the "people of the woods".. pretty creepy in there at night sometimes, overall    outstanding!
author: Pflip W.

description: There is nothing like biking through you on a Sunday afternoon. Then stopping at your soccer field, getting a steak taco from the dudes with the small cart, and then reading the entire newspaper. You also provide nice access to the Ocean. Central Park is nothing to you.
author: Hmmm W.

description: Golden Gate Park is definitely one of those places, like San Francisco itself that is so well known, that you are surprised whenever someone does not know of it.  This famous park, from childhood right on up to today at 27, is still my favorite park.  As far as kids are concerned, they have playgrounds with various types of equipment for all ages.  The speedway is also cool for getting your drive on.  I always loved and still love renting peddle boats in Stowe Lake, which I have not done since I was a kid; the lake is fvery peaceful, allowing you to take in the tranquility and sounds of birds chirping.  The carousel was another favorite of mine growing up, always going on it for multiple rides with all of horses going up and down and that classical carousel music.  The park, like all parks, has expansive lawns, picnic tables, and barbecues for picnics and functions.  I love the Hajuara Tea Garden in which it is even more serene with waterfalls, a bridge to walk over when walking around the garden, and a guy that plays the fleet outside of the garden; I love eating all of the traditional Japanese cookies, crackers, and sweets and drinking all of the traditional tea that they offer.  Being under an enclosed area shaped like a Japanese curbed roof is all the more authentic.  It is all the niblies and tea that you can eat and drink.  The park also features tennis courts and gulf courses if I am not mistaken.  Depending on the time of the year, they always outdoor concerts, as well as festivals like the annual A La Carte A La Park festival in which you can try different foods from all of the different restaurants in San Francisco and around the rest of the bay area; there is everything from American to Vietnamese to please every ones' pallet.  Needless to say, I love walking through the park, just watching and listening to the sites and sounds of the busy, bustling park.  There so many trees throughout the park, that it is almost like you in a secluded area, taking a break from the hustle and bustle of the city.  This will definitely an institution for years to come.  Keep up the good work City of San Francisco.!
author: Brian S.

description: a beautiful and large park with so much to do and so many hidden hide aways, it could take months to explore everything. the bison is my favorite part of the park. parking sucks here thought. and if you dare to come here on a weekend, you are going to have to park blocks and blocks away.
author: cesar z.
